The Imperially Commissioned *Complete Library of the Four Treasuries*
*Masters Section, Fourteenth Division: Oral Exegesis of the Zhuangzi*
*Daoist School* | *Abstract*

We, your ministers, respectfully note: *Oral Exegesis of the Zhuangzi* in ten juan was composed by Lin Xi-yi of the Song. Xi-yi’s *Explanation of the “Artificers’ Record”* is recorded separately. This work is one of his three *Oral Exegeses*. A preface by the author states in essence: Reading the *Zhuangzi* presents five difficulties. One must first be well-versed in the *Analects*, *Mengzi*, *Great Learning*, and *Doctrine of the Mean*, with a mind already settled in principle. Furthermore, one must understand the veins of literary composition and the interpretive techniques of Chan Buddhism before grasping its meaning. I once heard these matters from Le-xuan, and through Le-xuan, I learned of Ai-xuan’s teachings. Thus, I gained a rough understanding of the veins of literary composition. I also delved into Buddhist texts and thereby awakened to the mechanisms of its free and transformative changes. In this work, I have achieved some insights, which are truly what previous scholars have not fully explored.

Xi-yi’s learning originated with Chen Zao. Zao’s learning was transmitted from Lin Guang-chao—Le-xuan being Zao’s sobriquet, and Ai-xuan being Guang-chao’s sobriquet. All references to “the former teacher” in the text refer to Zao.

The preface states that Guo Xiang’s commentary fails to divide chapters and parse sentences, while the explanations of Wang Pang and Lü Hui-qing obscure the main purport, further increasing doubts about the *Zhuangzi*. Now, upon examination: Guo Xiang’s commentary marks meaning beyond the boundaries of conventional thought. Xi-yi, by contrast, seeks it through chapter and verse—his perspective is already narrow. The commentaries of Wang and Lü take the *Zhuangzi* to explain the *Zhuangzi*, without forcing it to conform to Confucian principles. This is to return Daoist words to the Daoists, avoiding the conflation of the Two Schools with the Confucian gate. Xi-yi, however, having taken refuge in the Daoist gate to annotate the *Zhuangzi*, feared reproach from Confucians and thus claimed it harmonized with the Sage. This is a strained and defensive view. Yet in truth, his approach takes the *Zhuangzi* on its own terms, allowing each to elucidate its own meaning. Moreover, his expositions are clear, lucid, and fluent, avoiding abstruse language. He offers many insights into the *Zhuangzi*, surpassing later figures like Lin Yun-ming, whose fragmented and shallow readings apply the methods of examination essays to the *Zhuangzi*. Thus, we record and preserve this work to represent one school of thought.

Respectfully submitted after collation in the eleventh month of the forty-third year of the Qianlong reign.
*Chief Compilers:*
*Minister* Ji Yun
*Minister* Lu Xi-xiong
*Minister* Sun Shi-yi

**Chief Collator:**
*Minister* Lu Fei-chi

**Original Preface to *Zhuangzi Kouyi***

Zhuangzi was a man of Song, named Zhou, styled Zixiu. Born in Suiyang County of Meng during the early Warring States period, he lived contemporaneously with Mencius, yet withdrew from the world to speak freely. The book he authored bears his name, and he himself divided it into three parts: seven Inner Chapters, fifteen Outer Chapters, and eleven Miscellaneous Chapters. Though thus arranged, the three modes of expression—*yuyan* (parables), *zhongyan* (weighted words), and *zhiyan* (goblet words)—pervade the entire work. The Outer and Miscellaneous Chapters take their titles from their opening lines, while the Inner Chapters bear names with distinct meanings. Their language is more refined than that of the Outer and Miscellaneous Chapters, yet the intent of their arguments differs not at all.

Chen Tongfu once remarked: "The world cannot do without such a man, nor without such a book, for only then can a gentleman’s discourse be complete." Though Zhuangzi’s work may be deemed unorthodox, it is indispensable to the world. Guo Xiang called it "unorthodox yet the crown of the Hundred Schools"—a fair judgment. This book cannot be left unread, yet it is most difficult to read. Su Dongpo’s lifelong writings were all awakened by it; the five thousand and forty volumes of the *Great Treasury of Scriptures* were all drawn from its depths. Even the literary prowess of Zuo Qiuming and Sima Qian cannot rival it. How, then, could one not read it? Yet why is it called difficult?

Master Yichuan said: "Buddhist scriptures are like lewd sounds and alluring colors, easily bewitching people, for their language is shocking and their appearances deceptive." How much more so with this book? Its discussions of *renyi* (benevolence and righteousness) and *xingming* (nature and destiny) differ entirely from our own—this is the first difficulty. Its intent is to rival the Master (Confucius), so its words often exceed proper bounds—this is the second difficulty. It disdains the vulgar and mediocre, like the Buddhist teachings of the "supreme vehicle," so its language is often excessively lofty—this is the third difficulty. Its brushwork dances and transforms, defying the paths of ordinary prose—this is the fourth difficulty. Moreover, its linguistic veins and thrusts resemble the Chan school’s "sudden teaching," akin to matters on the edge of a sword—something absent in our Confucian texts—this is the fifth difficulty.

Only one well-versed in the *Analects*, *Mencius*, *Zhongyong*, and *Great Learning*, with a firm grasp of principle, an understanding of textual bloodlines, and knowledge of Chan techniques, can trace its words and meanings to their proper places. Though its style may be unrestrained and playful, its great principles and fundamental tenets never diverge from the Sage. Without such discernment, one may impose arbitrary interpretations, either dismissing it as heretical or being swayed by its allure, leading to licentiousness or emptiness. Thus, Yichuan’s warning about "lewd sounds and alluring colors" is not to be taken lightly.

In my youth, I once heard of Le Xuan’s teachings, and through him, of Ai Xuan’s doctrines. I gained a rough understanding of textual bloodlines and later delved into Buddhist scriptures, awakening to its mechanisms of transformation. I flatter myself that I have gained some insight into this book, uncovering what previous scholars had not fully explored. Finally, I encountered the commentaries of Lü Jifu and Wang Yuanzhe. Though they divided chapters and parsed sentences more finely than Guo Xiang, their grasp of the great principles remained unclear. Their interpretations only deepened doubts about Zhuangzi. Yet, in my humble view, this book stands alone in the world, never having offended the Confucian gate. Were Zhuangzi to return today, he might well call me a "disciple of a thousand years hence."

This is not offered as a contribution to the author but shared with fellow seekers.

**Preface by Lin Xi-yi**

*Imperially Commissioned Complete Library of the Four Treasuries*
*Zhuangzi Kouyi*, Volume One
By Lin Xi-yi of the Song Dynasty
**Inner Chapters: "Free and Easy Wandering" (First)**

"Free and Easy Wandering" is the title established for this chapter. The Inner Chapters comprise seven, each named with three characters. *You* (游) refers to the mind’s wandering in the heavens. *Xiaoya* (逍遥) speaks of leisurely ease and unconstrained freedom. In the *Analects*, the disciples describe the Master with but a single word: *le* (乐, joy). In the *Three Hundred Poems*, when depicting figures—such as "southward, the trailing vine" or "on South Mountain, the terrace"—they say *le* (乐, joy), for even the noble person knows only this one *le*. Thus, what is called "Free and Easy Wandering" is precisely the *le* of the *Poetry* and the *Analects*. The entire work begins with this single word, *le*—consider the breadth of this old man’s heart! If one can perceive even a trace of its flavor here, then one may read *Fayi* (*芣苢*). That poem depicts the joy within the heart without ever uttering the word *le*—such is the marvel of its poetic method, like adding yet another tier to a seven-story pagoda.

In the Northern Darkness there is a fish, its name is Kun. The Kun’s size—who knows how many thousand *li* it spans? It transforms into a bird, its name is Peng. The Peng’s back—who knows how many thousand *li* it stretches? Roused to flight, its wings hang like clouds draped across the sky. This bird, when the seas surge, will journey to the Southern Darkness. The Southern Darkness is the Celestial Pond. *Qi Xie* is a record of marvels. Its words say: When the Peng migrates to the Southern Darkness, it strikes the water for three thousand *li*, spiraling upward on the whirlwind to ninety thousand *li*, departing with the six-month winds. The wild horses, the dust motes—

The living creatures are blown along by the breath—is the azure of the sky its true color? Or is it so distant that it has no limit? From its vantage below, it sees only thus. Moreover, when water accumulates, if it is not deep, it cannot bear a great vessel. Pour a cup of water into a hollow in the hall, and a mustard stalk becomes a boat; place the cup there, and it sticks fast, for the water is shallow and the vessel too large. When wind accumulates, if it is not thick, it cannot bear great wings. Thus, only with ninety thousand *li* of wind beneath does the wind suffice. Only then, borne upon the wind, its back against the blue sky, meeting no obstacle, does it at last set its course southward.

The cicada and the fledgling dove laugh at it, saying: "We dart forth and fly, striking the elm and sandalwood; sometimes we fall short and land on the ground—what need is there to rise ninety thousand *li* and journey south?" This passage merely depicts the boundless joy within the breast, yet it sets forth this metaphor. Its meaning is this: what men perceive is small, hence the clamor of worldly strife. But if one knows that beyond heaven and earth there are such vast worlds, one’s own body, though but a grain in the granary, cannot be compared. This is the same idea as Dai Jinren’s "ant-horn barbarians."

The Northern Darkness is the Northern Sea. The names Kun and Peng are but allegory. Some interpret them in terms of yin and yang—all such explanations impose divisions where none exist. When a bird takes flight, the word "roused" alone is extraordinary. "Sea surge" means the stirring of the sea. Even now, folk songs from the coast speak of "the sixth-month sea surge." When the sea stirs, great winds arise, its waters seething from the depths, their roar audible for *li*. Only with such winds can the migration southward occur.

The Southern Darkness is also a sea. Zhuangzi further glosses it as the Celestial Pond. *Qi Xie* is the name of a book, its records all strange and extraordinary matters, much like the *Classic of Mountains and Seas*. Yet this book may not have existed; Zhuangzi composed this account and then cited it as proof—another instance of his playful artistry. "Spiraling" describes flight; "whirlwind" is the force of the wind. "Three thousand" and "ninety thousand" merely convey its vast height and distance.

The bird departs with the sixth-month *qi*—this means its comings and goings must pause for half a year before it can take flight.

The lines on "wild horses" and "dust motes" are the most extraordinary passage in this text. The preceding and following sections often lack coherence. "Wild horses" are floating gossamer threads; "dust motes" are water vapor, as Du Fu wrote: *"Falling blossoms, drifting gossamer—still the white sun."* These "wild horses" and "dust motes"—whence do they arise? They are the living things of the world, their breaths mutually stirring one another, so that such phenomena appear in the empty sky. These three lines are meant to set the stage for what follows, first establishing this scene: when one gazes upward at the heavens, they appear deep blue—yet is this their true color? Or is it merely that our vision, having reached its limit, finds no end above, and thus sees only a hazy expanse? When the *peng* soars to the heavens, its view downward upon the human realm spans countless *li*; the breaths of "wild horses" and "dust motes" stirring one another must appear just as hazy, much like our view upward from below. These lines serve only to depict the vast height of the *peng*'s flight, yielding such marvelous effect. If, as some interpretations hold, the *peng* were taken as vast and "wild horses" and "dust motes" as minute, the preceding and following lines would fail to connect, and the passage’s power would be lost.

"For the waters to accumulate"—their depth is the metaphor for the wind below. A hollow in the hall—a deep recess. If the water is shallow, it can only float a mustard seed; place a cup or bowl there, and it will stick fast. *Jiao* (胶) is pronounced *jiao*, meaning "to adhere, unmoving." When the *peng* is in the heavens, nine *wan li* above the earth, winds rise from valleys and ravines, swelling mightily to fill the four seas. With the *peng* aloft, these winds lie beneath it, forming a thick foundation. Only a wind of nine *wan li* can be called "thick"; such a wind alone can bear the *peng*'s wings, allowing it to "ride the azure heavens"—this speaks to the height of its flight. "No obstruction bars its way," and it plans its journey south from the Northern Sea.

"To *tu* (图) is to plan. The *tiao* (蜩) is the cicada. The *xuejiu* (鸴鸠) is the small dove that learns to fly—*xue* may also be written as *yu* (鸒), pronounced *yu*, and is merely another small bird; both characters are interchangeable. *Jue qi* (决起) means to take off in flight. *Qiang* (抢) is to dash forward. Taking off in flight, it dashes toward the elm or sandalwood, rising no more than a *zhang* or *chi* in height, and sometimes fails to reach even that, falling back to the ground—*kong tou* (控投) means to cast itself down. This is the extent of its flight, and even then, it sometimes cannot achieve it. Yet it presumes to borrow the wind of ninety thousand *li* to migrate south to the Celestial Pond—what use is that? This is to say that those of shallow vision and narrow capacity do not comprehend the vastness of the world.

Those who travel to the *mangcang* (a distant but reachable place) depart and return in three meals, their bellies still full. Those who journey a hundred *li* must prepare provisions the night before. Those who travel a thousand *li* must gather supplies for three months. How can these two insects understand? Lesser knowledge cannot grasp greater knowledge; short years cannot fathom long years. How do we know this is so? The morning mushroom knows not the waxing and waning of the moon; the summer cicada knows not spring and autumn—these are short years. South of Chu, there is the *fangling* (a mythical tree), for which five hundred years make a spring, and five hundred years make an autumn. In high antiquity, there was the great *chun* (a legendary tree), for which eight thousand years make a spring, and eight thousand years make an autumn. Yet Pengzu alone is renowned for his longevity—how pitiful that common people compare themselves to him!

The *mangcang* is a place visible at a glance, appearing indistinct in the distance. To travel there and back requires no more than three meals, and one’s belly remains full, the food not yet fully digested—this speaks to its nearness."

To journey a hundred *li* requires grinding grain the night before departure—one cannot rely on just three meals. For a thousand-*li* journey, provisions must be gathered for three months.

These three lines illustrate how human travel varies in distance, thus requiring more or less sustenance—just as human perceptions differ in scope, so too do their aspirations vary in reach. This further serves as an analogy for the Peng and the cicada-and

When Tang questioned Ji about this, it was indeed so. Beyond the barren north lies a vast sea, the Celestial Pond. There is a fish there, spanning thousands of *li* in breadth, its length unknown—its name is Kun. There is also a bird there, named Peng, whose back resembles Mount Tai and whose wings are like clouds draped across the sky. It soars upon the whirling winds, spiraling upward ninety thousand *li*, piercing through the clouds and bearing the azure heavens on its back before setting its course southward, bound for the Southern Darkness.

The quail scoffs at it, saying: *"Where does it think it’s going? I leap and flutter upward no more than a few fathoms, then glide among the mugwort and artemisia—this is the utmost of flight! Where does it think it’s going?"*

This is the distinction between small and great. This passage merely restates the previous one with further evidence: Tang once questioned Ji about this very matter. Ji was a man’s name, and *is indeed so* refers back to the earlier account. Here, the concluding phrase of the prior section becomes the opening of this one—such is the rhythmic cadence of the composition. *Barren north* denotes the land of no vegetation. *Whirling winds* describes the force of the gale; *ram’s horns* refers to the spiraling shape of the wind. *To soar* means to take flight. *Piercing the clouds* signifies that at ninety thousand *li* above, there are no longer any clouds—just as people say that atop Mount Tai, clouds gather below and thunder rumbles like an infant’s cry, or as some claim clouds only fill the mid-heavens. *Setting its course southward* means planning the journey to the Southern Darkness, first devising the migration before heading toward the southern sea.

The *marsh sparrow* refers to the small bird of the marshes. Its utmost flight—soaring among the mugwort and wormwood—is its greatest joy. Why should it seek elsewhere? Its perspective mirrors that of the previous passage.

Thus, those whose knowledge suffices for an office, whose conduct matches a village, whose virtue pleases a lord, or whose governance commands a state—such men regard themselves no differently than the marsh sparrow. Yet Song Rongzi would still laugh at them. Though the whole world praises him, he feels no encouragement; though the whole world blames him, he feels no discouragement. He has settled the distinction between inner and outer, discerned the boundary between honor and shame—this is all. In his dealings with the world, he is not overly concerned. Even so, he has yet to establish the ultimate.

Liezi could ride the wind, moving with effortless grace, returning after fifteen days. Yet even he, in attaining such felicity, was not without constraint. Though he avoided walking, he still depended on something. But one who rides the true essence of heaven and earth, harnesses the transformations of the six qi, and roams the boundless—what does he depend on? Therefore it is said: the Perfect One has no self, the Spirit Man has no merit, the Sage has no name.

*Knowledge suffices for an office* means one’s wisdom can manage a single post. *Conduct matches a village* means one’s virtue and conduct can align with a village, drawing people to follow. *Virtue is recognized by a lord* means finding favor and thus being able to summon a state, governing its affairs. These three types of men each take pride in their abilities, viewing themselves like the marsh sparrow.

Song Rongzi, however, perceives the greater truth. Though the whole world slanders or praises him, he remains unmoved, unshaken. How does he achieve this? He knows the original heart as inner, all things as outer. Thus it is said: he settles the division between inner and outer. What lies outside is subject to honor and shame; what lies within is beyond them. Knowing this distinction, he discerns that honor and shame are but external conditions—this is all. The principle extends no further.

He, valuing the original heart and dismissing external things, how could he eagerly pursue worldly affairs with such relentless haste? Though Song Rongzi’s ability is indeed thus, he has yet to establish a great foundation or achieve a lasting legacy.

Now consider Liezi, who rides the wind and wanders between the heavens and earth, returning only after half a month. When he soars upon the wind, he is *lingran*—light and effortless—so perfectly does he embody that drifting, ethereal bearing. *Lingran* describes his floating grace; *shan* means excellence. Having mastered riding the wind, he deems those who toil to cultivate themselves for blessings—anxiously fearing they may fall short—as beneath mention. *Wei shu shu* means he does not deign to act with such frequent urgency as others.

Men walk upon the earth; Liezi travels by wind. Though he is free from walking, he still depends on something—without wind, he cannot proceed. Thus it is said: he still has something to rely upon. But one who rides the inherent principle of heaven and earth, harnessing the six qi—yin and yang, wind and rain, darkness and light—and roams the beginning of the formless, without limit or end, such a one has nothing to depend upon. This marks the distinction between having traces and leaving none.

To leave no trace is to be called a *Perfect Person*, a *Spiritual Person*, a *Sage*. *Wu ji* (without self), *wu gong* (without achievement), *wu ming* (without fame)—all describe the absence of traces. The final three phrases are added to praise again and again.

Yao offered the world to Xu You, saying: “The sun and moon have risen, yet the torch still burns—is it not difficult for its light to compare? The timely rain has fallen, yet you still irrigate—is it not laborious for your moisture to suffice? You stand, and the world is governed, yet I remain in your place. I see my own inadequacy. Please take the world.”

Xu You replied: “You govern the world, and the world is already well-governed. Yet I would replace you—should I seek a name? A name is but the guest of reality. Would I become a guest? The wren nests in the deep forest, yet needs but a single branch; the mole drinks from the river, yet takes no more than its fill. Return, my lord, and rest. What use have I for the world? Though the cook does not prepare the feast, the master of ceremonies would not step beyond the wine vessels to take his place.”

The torch is but a flame; with the sun and moon already bright, why hold a fire? With the timely rain already fallen, why carry a jar? Yao said to Xu You: “Stand, and the world governs itself—yet you insist I remain in this role. I see my own insufficiency,” likening himself to the torch and irrigation. *Shi* means “to preside”; *zhi tianxia* means to offer the world to you. If fame does not arise from oneself but from others, then it is external. When name is set against reality, reality is the master and name the guest. “I do not become a guest” means I do not lose myself to external things. The wren and the mole are Xu You’s self-comparisons, expressing his contentment. *Yan* means to lie low; the *yan shu* is a burrowing rat. “Return and rest, my lord” means “go back and do not trouble yourself to visit me.” The cook and the master of ceremonies have different duties—just as I cannot abandon my joys to replace you, each must guard his own role, much as the master of ceremonies would not overstep the wine vessels to take the cook’s knife.

Shoulder Wu asked Lian Shu: “I heard Jie Yu’s words—they were vast yet without substance, sweeping yet never returning. I was alarmed and terrified by them, as boundless as the Milky Way. They were grand yet absurd, far removed from human sentiment.”

Lian Shu said, “What did his words speak of?”
Shoulder Wu replied, “On the distant Mount Gushe there dwells a spirit-person. Their skin is like ice and snow, their bearing as graceful as a maiden’s. They eat no grain, but drink the wind and sip the dew. They ride the clouds and qi, harness flying dragons, and wander beyond the Four Seas. Their spirit congeals, making things free from blight so that the harvest ripens. Yet I deem this madness and do not believe it.”

Lian Shu said, “Indeed, the blind have no part in the sight of patterns, nor the deaf in the sound of bells and drums. But is it only the body that may be deaf and blind? The mind, too, may suffer such afflictions. His words are like a timely admonition to you. That person, that power—it pervades all things, uniting them as one. Who in the world, seeking order, would weary themselves with petty cares? Such a one takes the world as their concern, yet nothing harms them. Though great floods rise to the heavens, they do not drown; though great droughts melt metal and stone, scorch earth and mountains, they do not burn. From their dust and chaff, they could mold even Yao and Shun. Who would trouble themselves with worldly affairs?

Shoulder Wu and Lian Shu may not have truly met such a person—these are but parables. Nor should one seek meaning solely in names. Though some passages may be explained, not all hold literal truth.

‘Vast yet without substance’ means lacking reality. ‘Sweeping yet never returning’ means their grand words press ever onward without looking back. ‘The Milky Way’ is the celestial river, its boundlessness referring to its endless expanse. *Jingting* means distant boundaries. ‘Grand yet absurd’ means their words are extraordinary, far removed from common human sentiment.”

The Miaogu She Mountain—such is its name—is crystalline with ice and snow. What it nurtures is the fullness of yang qi, lying dormant and unmoving, thus congealed as if in ice and snow. Even today, those who practice qi-cultivation among the Daoists may achieve this. "Graceful and supple" describes one who is tender and lovely. A "maiden" is an unmarried girl. The following four lines speak of her spiritual wondrousness: her spirit is congealed and settled, and where she dwells, the hundred things naturally suffer no blight or pestilence, while the harvest ripens of itself. This is what Jie Yu meant—his words were as mad as they were deceptive.

Shen Wu took his words for deception, unworthy of belief. "Indeed" means that it is certainly so. You remain doubtful and disbelieving. The spectacle of patterns and the sound of bells and drums—all people see and hear them, yet the blind and deaf have no part in this, for theirs is a malady of the bodily form. How could this malady afflict only the body? It resides in the heart as well, for their hearts lack perception, as if deaf and blind, and thus they fail to grasp these words, dismissing them as deception.

"At this time" refers to the present. "You" and "your" in the previous explanations were all taken to mean "maiden," but this is forced and does not convey the true meaning. Rather, it means: how could such words be within the capacity of people like you? Such people, in their virtue, roam freely above the ten thousand things, and the world governs itself. How would they trouble themselves with the exhausting task of ordering the world? This speaks of their non-action that accomplishes all.

The character 蕲 is interchangeable with 祈, and 乱 signifies governance. This speaks of the people of the world who each pray for order in themselves. Yet if I but practice non-action, they will govern themselves—why should I exhaust myself with ceaseless toil? This expresses the meaning of self-imposed weariness.

"Nothing can harm them" means that external things cannot disturb their fundamental heart-mind. The vastness of water can reach the heavens, yet such a person does not drown; the severity of drought can melt metal and stone, parch mountains and dry the earth, yet they remain unscathed—this speaks of their unobstructed self-attainment in all circumstances.

"Dust, grime, chaff, and husks" refer to remnants and excess. It is said that if such a person were to apply these remnants, they could accomplish the deeds of Yao and Shun—how would they trouble themselves with worldly affairs? Here, "things" refers to worldly matters, and "engaging in affairs" means to undertake them. "Molding and casting" conveys the sense of bringing something to completion.

This single phrase aligns with what Guo Xiang called "unconventional," though the original intent of his writing was to disparage the vulgar Confucians, hence his language sometimes exceeds proper bounds. One should not judge him by this alone. As Li Taibai said: "The deeds of Yao and Shun are not so astonishing; nothing compares to the lofty purity of Boyi and Shuqi." How is this different?

The people of Song carried ceremonial caps to Yue, but the Yue people, with shorn hair and tattooed bodies, had no use for them. The caps of Song were ceremonial headwear, yet the Yue, with their shorn hair, had no need for clothing or caps. The people of Song, bringing such goods to Yue, naturally found no market for them. Zhuangzi’s words here are vast, yet the people of this world, with their shallow views, find no use for them. What is the point of speaking thus? It means the world is unworthy of such discourse.

Yao governed the people of the world and brought order to the realm. He went to see the Four Masters on Mount Miaogu at the northern bank of the Fen River and was suddenly lost in reverie, forgetting his empire. This passage also conveys the idea that only by broadening one’s perspective can one recognize one’s own limitations. Yao, the greatest ruler of ancient and modern times, upon seeing the Four Masters on Mount Miaogu south of the Fen River, was still struck with awe and self-doubt—how much more so for others? "Forgetting his empire" means he forgot his dominion over the world. "Lost in reverie" conveys a sense of profound bewilderment.

The Four Masters are nameless; some identify them as Xu You, Nie Que, Wang Ni, and Bei Yi, while others say the *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states that Mount Miaogu lies beyond the seas, and the Fen River’s northern bank was Yao’s capital. Seeing the spirits of Miaogu in his own capital was like seeing Yao’s own heart. One version divides them into four types: those who embody the root, those who follow traces, those who are neither root nor trace, and those who are neither non-root nor non-trace. Such interpretations grow increasingly absurd, failing to grasp that this is precisely Zhuangzi’s playful wit—like what people today call "head-scratching talk." Those who engage in such convoluted exegesis fall right into his trap. How could they truly read Zhuangzi? In truth, these are all allegories.

In essence, it means that people are each confined by their own limited views and unaware of their delusions. Only those with great insight can illuminate and break free from them.

Hui Shi said to Zhuangzi: "The King of Wei gave me seeds of a great gourd. I planted them, and they grew to bear fruit of five *dan* in capacity. When I filled it with water or broth, its strength was insufficient to lift itself. When I split it to make ladles, they were too shallow and broad to hold anything. Though not insubstantial in size, it was utterly useless, so I smashed it."

Zhuangzi replied: "You are indeed inept at putting great things to use. There was a man of Song skilled in making an unchapping salve. For generations, his family earned their living by washing silk floss. A traveler heard of this and offered a hundred pieces of gold for the recipe. The family gathered and deliberated: 'For generations, we have washed silk floss and earned no more than a few pieces of gold. Now, in a single morning, we can sell this skill for a hundred. Let us give it to him.' The traveler acquired it and presented it to the King of Wu. When Yue raised arms against Wu, the king sent the traveler to lead his forces. In winter, they fought a naval battle with Yue and crushed them. The king then enfeoffed him with land. The same unchapping salve could lead to enfeoffment or remain a means of washing silk floss—the difference lies in how it is used.

Now you have a gourd of five *dan*—why not consider making it into a great float to drift upon the rivers and lakes? Instead, you worry that it is too shallow and broad to hold anything. Clearly, your heart-mind is still as obstructed as a clump of reeds."

The gourd can be made into a ladle, for it is the fruit of the bottle gourd. A single gourd of such size, bearing fruit of five *dan*, could also hold five *dan* of water. "Firm and heavy" describes its strength. A ladle is half a gourd. "Shallow and broad" describes its appearance. "Smashed" means to break it. The "unchapping salve" prevents hands from cracking in winter. "Washing silk floss" refers to the family’s generations-long occupation of washing silk floss using this salve. A *zun* is a floating gourd used to stay afloat in water—tying it to one’s waist allows one to float, hence the saying: "In midstream, losing a boat, a gourd is worth a thousand gold." Zhuangzi, having used the unchapping salve as an analogy for failing to recognize proper use, then says: "With such a large gourd, why not consider making it into a floating gourd for the river?" "Consider" means to ponder. "Why not consider?" means: why does your thinking not extend to this? "A heart-mind like reeds" means a heart-mind as obstructed as tangled reeds. The meaning of this passage is simply that seeing only the small prevents one from using the great.

Hui Shi said to Zhuangzi: "I have a great tree—people call it a *chu*. Its trunk is gnarled and swollen, unfit for the carpenter’s line; its branches are twisted and bent, unfit for the compass and square. Even if planted by the roadside, no carpenter would glance at it. Now your words are vast but useless—everyone rejects them alike."

Zhuangzi replied: "Have you never seen a wildcat or weasel? They crouch low to lie in wait, leaping east and west, heedless of height or depth, only to be caught in a trap or snare and die. Now consider the yak: as great as a cloud hanging from the sky, it is indeed large, yet it cannot catch mice. You have a great tree and worry that it is useless—why not plant it in the land of Nothingness, the vast wilderness? Wander idly by its side, roam freely and sleep beneath it. It will not be felled by axes, nor will anything harm it. If it is of no use, where is the hardship in that?"

*Chu* is the name of a worthless tree. "Great trunk" refers to the tree’s body.

The tree is gnarled and knotted, swollen and deformed—it does not meet the carpenter’s line or compass, meaning it is of no use. Planted by the roadside, it stands near the wayside. This is how Master Hui playfully likened Zhuangzi’s grand words to uselessness.

The *li* and *sheng* are types of wildcats and foxes. *Ao* refers to creatures that roam freely. They lie in wait to prey on them, leaping and bounding without regard for height or depth—nimble and swift as they are, the moment they are caught in a trap or snare, they lose their lives. *Pi* here means "law" or "method," and *ji pi* refers to mechanical devices.

The *mao* ox is an immense creature, yet it cannot catch mice like the *li* or *sheng*. This illustrates how things in the world vary in size and function—one cannot dismiss all great things as useless.

The "land of Nothingness" and the "vast wilderness" refer to the realm of natural creation and the supreme Dao, where one may find joy. In the bustling human world, fortune and misfortune are intertwined. But if one soars high and wanders far, delighting in the Dao, though of no use to the world, neither will harm befall them—just as the saying goes, "The blade and saw do not touch them; the chaos of the world does not reach them." Thus it is said: "It will not be felled by axes, nor will anything harm it. If it is of no use, where is the hardship in that?"

Master Hui’s question and Zhuangzi’s answer are like a playful exchange, from which later generations have spun countless interpretations. The original source lies here.

**Chapter Two: On the Equality of Things**
*Wu lun* refers to the debates among people and things—what we call "the many opinions." *Qi* means "to unify"; it is to harmonize all opinions into one. In the Warring States period, schools of thought differed, each refuting the other. Thus Zhuangzi believed it better to forget right and wrong and return to nature—this is the intent behind the chapter’s title.

The "Heavenly Pipe," "Earthly Pipe," and "Human Pipe" are metaphors drawn from sound. Nan Guo Ziqi leaned against his armrest, sat upright, and sighed, his gaze fixed on the sky, as if he had lost his companion. Yan Cheng Ziyou stood in attendance before him and asked, "What is this? Can the body truly be made like withered wood, and the mind like dead ashes? The one leaning here now is not the same as the one who leaned here before."

*Qi ji* means "to lean on an armrest." *Fang ran* describes a state of emptiness. "Losing one’s companion" refers to the common view of the self and things as separate—here, that distinction is forgotten. "Withered wood" signifies lifelessness; "dead ashes" mean the mind does not stir. "The one leaning here now" means that today, the Master’s demeanor is not like that of others who lean on armrests. Where there is a self, there are things; to lose the self is to have no self. Without self, there are no things. "Do you understand this?" asks whether he grasps this principle. *Wu* is the self; it does not say "I have lost myself" but "I have lost *wu*." This means that if even a trace of selfishness remains untransformed within, there will still be a division between self and other. The three words "I have lost *wu*" are profoundly apt. Dongshan said, "Now it is not I; now I am truly it"—this is the crux of the matter.

"You have heard the Human Pipe but not the Earthly Pipe; you have heard the Earthly Pipe but not the Heavenly Pipe."

Ziyou said, "May I ask the method?"
Ziqi replied: "The great clod breathes—its name is wind. It does nothing, yet when it stirs, the myriad hollows roar in fury. Have you alone not heard its howling? The towering peaks and forests, the great trees with trunks a hundred spans around—some hollows resemble noses, mouths, ears, beams, rings, mortars, pits, or puddles. They hiss, gurgle, shriek, inhale, cry out, wail, moan, and shriek again. The first calls out, and the rest follow in harmony. A gentle breeze brings a soft response; a whirlwind brings a mighty one. When the fierce gale subsides, all hollows fall silent. Have you alone not seen their trembling and swaying?"

Ziqi, seeing that Ziyou’s question revealed some insight, sought to instruct him with the Heavenly Pipe and thus posed this question. *Fang* means "method." He asks, "What is the nature of this principle?"

The Great Clump is Heaven and Earth. Why is there wind between Heaven and Earth? It is like a person’s exhalation. *Is* means "only," and *wu zuo* means "it does nothing." If it does not act, then all is still. But when it acts, the myriad hollows roar in fury—this speaks of how, with the slightest stirring, the entire world resounds. The myriad hollows are the hollows of the myriad trees. *Liaoliao* is the sound of a long wind. *Wei* is read as *wei*, and *cuì* is read as *cui*; *weijiacuì* describes the swaying of forests and trees. *A hundred spans around* speaks of the trees’ great girth—a girth measured by two hands clasped together. Above, the myriad hollows were mentioned; here, only the largest trees are described, from which the rest may be inferred. The hollows of great trees vary in shape, each resembling something: *jī* are the square beams atop pillars; *quān* are the round hoops like those of a cup; *wā* are the curved hollows; *wū* are the sunken ones. From *jī* to *yǎo*, these describe the sounds within the hollows. *Yú* is a light sound, and *yóng* is a heavy one. When the wind arrives first, its sound is like a leading chant; those that follow are like a responding chorus, light and heavy harmonizing. A *ling* wind is a gentle breeze; when the wind is small, the harmonizing sounds are also small. A *piāo* wind is a great wind; when the wind is strong, the harmonizing sounds are also great. A *lì* wind is a fierce, violent wind. *Jì* means "to cease." Once the wind ceases, the sounds that once filled the hollows vanish, and thus they are called "empty." *Tiáotiáo* and *diāodiāo* both describe the trembling and swaying of trees in the wind. Earlier, it said, "Have you alone not heard?" and later, "Have you alone not seen?"—this is the interlocking structure of the passage.

As for you—Zhuangzi’s writing excels in many ways, and this passage is among its finest, a masterpiece within a masterpiece. In the entire book, this is the foremost text; indeed, among all writers past and present, none has matched this passage. Poetry is sound, and painting is form; this describes a scene nearly impossible to depict. Yet who has ever painted sound? From *jī* to *yǎo*, eight characters describe eight sounds. *Yú* and *yóng* are harmonizing sounds. The wind between Heaven and Earth is formless and invisible, yet its sound, though unseen, is vividly captured by his brush. How could the Old Immortal of Nanhua possess such skill? Every time I read this, I cannot help but dance with joy, forgetting myself. This passage speaks of the earthly pipes, yet it naturally leads to the heavenly pipes in the following section—such is the flow of his prose. Some say this describes the earthly pipes as the natural sounds of Heaven, and thus they are also the heavenly pipes. This is true, for if the wind does not arise from the workings of creation, from where else could it come? Yet observe how he first speaks of the earthly pipes, then returns to them, revealing the sinews and framework of his thought.

Ziyou said, "The earthly pipes are the myriad hollows. The human pipes are the bamboo flutes. May I ask, what are the heavenly pipes?" The human pipes are not only bamboo flutes—metal, stone, silk, and gourd instruments all belong to this category. Here, he mentions only one example. Earlier, he spoke of the earthly pipes, then the heavenly pipes, and dismisses the human pipes in a single phrase—such is the method of his writing. To read Zhuangzi’s work, one must examine it closely to find the entry point.

Ziqi said, "When the wind blows through the myriad things, each sounds different, yet it allows them to be as they are. All take their own forms in anger—who is it that stirs them?" *Blows through the myriad* refers to all things that produce sound. It speaks of how all sounding things are blown by the Creator. *Blows* and *allows* both belong to the Creator. *Take their own forms* means they take it upon themselves. *All take their own forms* means all things believe their sounds arise from their own power, unaware that it is the stirring of a single *qi*. When *qi* arises within and becomes sound, he uses the word *anger*, akin to "angry flight," both attributed to the Creator.

"The great knowledge is leisurely, the small knowledge is petty. The great words blaze, the small words chatter." The *great knowledge* belongs to those of superior understanding; *leisurely* describes their ease and self-possession. The *small knowledge* refers to those who calculate and scheme; *petty* describes their meticulous distinctions. The *great words* belong to those with grand ambitions; *blaze* describes their radiance. Zhuangzi’s meaning includes figures like Yi, Zhou, Confucius, and Mencius in this phrase. The *small words* belong to those of limited vision; *chatter* describes their hesitation and caution. The doctrines of the Hundred Schools and the gossip of the marketplace are all contained in this phrase. These four lines summarize the two kinds of people in the world: those who understand principle and guard against affairs, and those who discuss learning, techniques, and theories.

"In sleep, their spirits intertwine; when awake, their forms open. They engage with things, forming bonds, and daily battle with their hearts." Having described the four kinds of people above, he now elucidates them through the human body. *In sleep, their spirits intertwine* means that at night, the spirit gathers in the heart. *When awake, their forms open* means that by day, the four limbs are in motion. These two lines encompass everyone from the emperor to the common people. *Form bonds* refers to external interactions; when people rest at night and rise at dawn, their encounters and engagements wear on their hearts like combat, day after day. Thus, he says, "They engage with things, forming bonds, and daily battle with their hearts." This is akin to Mencius’s "what one does by day may be fettered and lost by night," though Mencius’s phrasing is gentler. Zhuangzi’s language, however, is a hundredfold more vivid and stirring. Later Chan masters often adopted this style. *Màn*, *jiào*, and *mì* describe three kinds of people: some act slowly and hesitantly; others speak with hidden traps, hence *jiào* (pitfall); still others plan meticulously, leaving no detail unconsidered, hence *mì* (dense). These all describe how people respond to the world with their minds, yet none attain freedom—they all suffer from anxiety and fear. This is what Confucius called "the petty man is always anxious." But Zhuangzi’s meaning extends even to Yao, Shun, the Duke of Zhou, and Confucius, who were all anxious. In minor matters, they tremble with fear, hence *small fear, trembling*. In great matters, their worries run deep, their thoughts far-reaching, as if lost or doubtful, hence *great fear, mournful*.

"Their outbursts are like the release of a crossbow trigger—this is called controlling right and wrong. They cling like sworn oaths—this is called guarding victory."

Their decline is like autumn and winter—this speaks of their daily dissipation. What they drown in through their actions cannot be restored. Their weariness is like being bound—this speaks of their aged exhaustion. The heart near death cannot be revived. Joy, anger, sorrow, delight, thought, sighing, change, fear, restlessness, abandon, openness, and affectation—like mushrooms sprouting from empty steam, their discussions of right and wrong each have their own fixed target, as if archers aiming at a mark. Thus it is said, "Their outbursts are like the release of a crossbow trigger," meaning not a single word is spoken in vain. *Sī* (to govern) means to take as one’s master. The mind that clings to victory remains untransformed, lingering in the breast as if bound by a sworn oath. Their use of the mind wears them away day by day, month by month—this speaks of their inner torment.

Things are born in spring and summer, wither in autumn and winter—this is the time of emaciation. Thus it is used as a metaphor for daily dissipation. The three phrases below express this meaning, while those above serve as analogies. Yet once the mind is thus submerged, it departs and cannot return—hence "what they drown in through their actions." The first *zhī* (之) is a grammatical particle; the second *zhī* (之) means "to go." "Cannot be restored" means it cannot be retrieved. The *cǐ* (此) in "this" also means "to go," speaking of what cannot be turned back. Their being stifled by material desires is like being tightly bound—aged and beyond salvation, hence "aged exhaustion." *Xù* (洫) means to fall into a ditch. Such people, though their bodies live, have hearts already like the dead. Thus it is said, "near death," meaning their breasts hold no awareness. *Yáng* (阳) means life—this speaks of their hearts being dead, never to revive.

The above describes the worldly use of the mind. The twelve characters below—joy, anger, sorrow, delight, thought, sighing, change, fear, restlessness, abandon, openness, and affectation—further depict their outward appearance. For what lies within them is thus, so what appears without is now joyful, now angry, now sorrowful, now delighted, now anxious, now sighing.

Such shifting of intentions and postures—now desiring this, now longing for that. *Zhé* (慹) depicts the appearance of worry and hesitation, unmoving. *Yáo yāng xiáng* (姚央庠) describes the manner of indulgence and abandon. *Qǐ* (启) means openness, a lack of restraint. *Zuò* (做) refers to affectation, striking poses.

Though people appear thus, in truth they are not free—like joy arising from emptiness, like mushrooms formed by the steaming of qi. All these various types are made to be so by the Maker of Things, as if blown by the myriad winds. This speaks of the Maker of Things, yet it does not call it "naturally so." It says that when people cannot hold fast to the Dao, they produce many grotesqueries, as if ghosts and spirits made them so. Those who read the *Zhuangzi* must recognize this carefully.

Day and night succeed one another before us, yet none know where they sprout. "Enough! Enough!"—like the modern saying, "That’s it, that’s it," meaning that though the source of sprouting is unknowable, between dawn and dusk one attains only this. *This* refers to the Maker of Things. This *this* carries great weight and is not lightly placed. *Without that, there is no I*—this *that* refers back to the previous *this*, meaning that without the Maker of Things, I could not be thus. Yet the Maker of Things’ actions are only seen through the human body, hence "without me, there is nothing to take." Though this explanation seems close and visible, what it reveals of the Maker of Things is still not known by people. Thus it is said, "this is also near, yet one does not know what compels it." The *true master*—the Maker of Things—seems as if it exists, yet one dare not assert its actual presence. *Lián* (联) is the place of sprouting; not grasping its *lián* is to not know where it sprouts. *Kě xíng* (可行) refers to what is visible in the workings of Heaven. *Yǐ xìn* (已信) means "most assuredly." The actions of the Maker of Things are indeed thus, yet its form is unseen—this is "not knowing what compels it." *Yǒu qíng* (有情) means "having reality," the same as *yǐ xìn*. *Wú xíng* (无形) means "formless," the same as "not seeing its form." From "day and night succeed one another" onward, all speak of the actions of the Maker of Things, which, though before our eyes, are unseen by people. The text circles back repeatedly, weaving many phrases, its words earnest and its meaning profound, urging people to reflect deeply and examine themselves.

The hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera are all contained within. With whom do I share intimacy? Do you delight in all of them? Or is there a private favor? Are they all like servants and concubines? Are these servants and concubines insufficient to govern one another? Do they take turns being lord and subject? Is there a true ruler residing within? If one seeks to grasp its reality, whether one succeeds or not, does it harm or benefit the true?

The hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera are all that a person’s body possesses. What follows further elucidates a passage from the perspective of the human body, which is even more extraordinary. *Gāi* (赅) means "complete," and *cún* (存) means "present." It says that all these are complete and present within a person’s body. *With whom do I share intimacy?* asks: with whom do I alone share closeness? This *intimacy* is placed with great reason. For example, if one’s hand is afflicted by illness and suffers, then at that moment the hand becomes the body’s enemy. The six senses are all like this. *Do you delight in all of them?* asks whether one delights in all the six senses, or whether there is a private favor. Moreover, in the body’s functions, which is noble and which is base? When the head itches and the hand scratches, the hand serves the head. When one gazes afar and the feet walk, the feet serve the eyes. The servant is like a minister or concubine. Yet they are *insufficient to govern one another*—the hands, feet, ears, eyes, nose, and tongue all serve one another. The one that is served is the lord, and the one that serves is the subject. At times the feet are used, and at times the hands are used. Thus it is said, "they take turns being lord and subject." Since the lord and subject of the hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera cannot be definitively named, then is the heart the lord of the body? Yet the heart cannot govern itself, and what governs it is the Maker of Things—thus the Maker of Things is the true ruler. Hence it is said, "Is there a true ruler residing within?" Though I seek thus to investigate and reach the truth, whether I grasp it or not, how does it add to or diminish the so-called ruler? *Qíng* (情) means "reality." Thus it is said, "If one seeks to grasp its reality, whether one succeeds or not, does it harm or benefit the true?"

Once one receives this completed form, it does not perish but awaits its end, clashing and grinding against things. Its course is spent like a galloping horse, yet none can halt it—is this not lamentable? Throughout life, one toils and toils without seeing success, wearily laboring without knowing where to return—can this not be grieved? People call this "not dying," but what is the benefit? The body transforms, the heart follows it—can this not be called great sorrow? Is human life inherently so confused? Am I alone confused while others are not?

Generally, the human form is not self-possessed; it must be received from something. Having received this form from the Maker of Things, the Maker of Things and I remain together, not perishing until this form is exhausted. Yet people cannot wholly follow the Maker of Things; they are instead drowned by external things, now opposing, now following them. Thus they spend their lives, like a colt passing a crack, unable to rest even for a moment. Hence it is said, "its course is spent like a galloping horse, yet none can halt it." *Xiāng rèn* (相刃) means opposing, and *xiāng mǐ* (相靡) means following—both convey the sense of being drowned. *Zhōngshēn yìyì* (终身役役) means self-affliction. *Not seeing success* means no benefit. The saying "gathering a hundred flowers to make honey, yet not knowing for whom the sweetness is toiled" expresses this idea. *Túrán pírù* (荼然疲役) further depicts the laborious toil of *yìyì*, not knowing where to return, not knowing when rest may come. Human life’s self-inflicted labor is thus. Though one may live a hundred years, what is the benefit? Hence it is said, "not dying, what is the benefit?" *Its form transforms*—from decline to graying, from graying to aging. As years grow higher, virtue grows more distant. This is the body transforming while the heart does not. With no insight of my own, I merely serve the body with the heart. When the body declines, the heart also wearies.

Thus it is said: "The heart consents to this"—*mángmángrán* (芒芒然), utterly without insight. Even those foolish and deluded should turn back and ask themselves: in the lives of all people, is the heart originally so benighted, so devoid of understanding? Am I alone benighted while others possess clarity? This is to say: Heaven gives birth to the teeming masses, endowing them with things and with principles. The people’s constant nature cherishes fine virtue; the heavenly principle has never been obscure. Yet you, clouded by human desire, have come to this. How could one who knows the Dao be so dim and dull? This is what is meant by "the golden needle scraping the film"—it urges you to open your eyes.

Now, if one follows the "completed heart" as one’s teacher, who is there who does not have a teacher? Why must one know the ancients before the heart can make its own judgments? The foolish share in this as well. To have likes and dislikes before the heart is formed—this is like saying, "Today I set out for Yue, yet I arrived there yesterday." Thus, to take what does not exist as existing—even if the divine Yu were here, he could not comprehend it. How much less could I?

The "completed heart" is possessed by all. This heart is the heavenly principle, vast and undifferentiated, yet lacking in nothing. It is said: at birth, you are already endowed with a fully formed heavenly principle. If you take this as your teacher, who is without it? Not only the worthy possess it; even the foolish do. *Zhī dài* (知代) refers to the worthy of old—*dài* (代) means transformation, speaking of their understanding of the principle of change. *Xīn zì qǔ* (心自取) means the heart has its own insights. If this heart has not yet perceived the undifferentiated principle but forcibly establishes judgments of right and wrong, it is like asserting that one has already arrived in Yue when one has only just set out today. Is there such a principle in the world? This is to insist on what one does not know as if one knew it. Thus, having no true insight, one insists on having it. Even if the ancient sages were to return, they could not enlighten you—how much less could others?

Speech is not like the wind. Speakers have words, yet what they say is not fixed. Is it truly speech? Or has there never been speech at all? Does it differ from the chirping of a fledgling? Or is there no difference? This chapter, being a discourse on the equalization of things and the resolution of right and wrong, first sets forth the theory of the three winds, stating that all sounds in heaven and earth arise from the Creator. It then expands upon this, explaining that the body is likewise moved by the Creator, unfolding the idea until it reaches the "completed heart," where it pauses. From this point onward, it discusses the theory of right and wrong. The wind through hollows, the sound of bamboo—though myriad sounds differ, they are all merely sounds. Only when sound forms patterns is it called speech, and speech is not like the wind. What is called speech is each person speaking their own intent. Thus it is said, "Speakers have words"—these four characters encapsulate the discourse on right and wrong. What they say is not yet fixed. Though you may speak, is it truly your own speech, or is it the Creator speaking through you? Hence it is said to be "not yet fixed."

Is it truly your speech? Or have you never had such speech, and it is the Creator moving you to speak? A *kòu* (鷇) is a bird newly hatched from its egg. Its chirping is without understanding. Your speech is likewise without self-awareness. If you believe it differs from the chirping of a fledgling, can you truly distinguish it? Or is there no distinction? In truth, they are one and the same, beyond differentiation.

Where does the Dao reside that it has truth and falsehood? Where does speech reside that it has right and wrong? Where does the Dao go that it does not remain? Where does speech remain that it cannot be spoken of? The Dao is obscured by petty accomplishments; speech is obscured by flourishing embellishments. Thus arise the right and wrong of the Confucians and Mohists, each affirming what the other denies and denying what the other affirms. If you wish to affirm what they deny and deny what they affirm, nothing is better than illuminating that things have no "other," that things have no "this." From the perspective of the other, one does not see; through self-knowledge, one knows. Thus it is said: "The other emerges from the this; the this also follows from the other."

The Dao originally has no truth or falsehood—how could it become obscured and give rise to such distinctions? Speech originally has no right or wrong—how could it become obscured and give rise to such disputes? Where does it go that it does not remain? This refers to the great and small, the refined and coarse—is the Dao not present in these? Where does it remain that it cannot be spoken of? This refers to affirming affirmations and negating negations—all are acceptable. *Xiǎochéng* (小成) means a narrow view, a one-sided perspective. Only after people’s partial views arise does the Dao become obscured and unclear. *Rónghuá* (荣华) means self-aggrandizement in pursuit of fame and reputation. Partial views, when self-aggrandized, obscure the truest speech. Only after this do the Confucians and Mohists begin their disputes over right and wrong. What one denies, I affirm; what one affirms, I deny. How can this be settled? If one wishes to settle right and wrong, one must return to the natural heavenly principle—only then can it be made clear. The heavenly principle is clarity itself.

Thus it is said: nothing is better than illuminating that things have no "other," that things have no "this." To say "from my perspective, this is right" is to say "from the other’s perspective, this is wrong." To say "I take this as right" is to say "others take it as wrong." From the other’s perspective, I do not see; through self-knowledge, I know. Things and I do not oppose each other—thus there is no right, no wrong. Only when things and I oppose each other do right and wrong arise. Thus it is said: "The other emerges from the this; the this also follows from the other." This is the theory of "this and other arising simultaneously." Though it speaks of simultaneous arising, it introduces the term *fāngshēng* (方生, "just arising") as a metaphor. For arising must entail perishing; the two cannot be separated. To speak only of arising without speaking of perishing is to see only one side. Though you may see only one side, in principle, they cannot be separated. If there is arising, there must be perishing; if there is perishing, there must be arising. If there is "can," there must be "cannot"; if there is "cannot," there must be "can." How can they be separated? Knowing that their theories cannot be separated, it is better to affirm what they affirm and deny what they deny.

The sages of old, not relying on one-sided views but illuminating with the heavenly principle, simply followed what was right. Earlier, it spoke of following both right and wrong; here, it speaks only of following right—this is an abbreviation.

Is is that, and that is is. That too has its right and wrong, and this too has its right and wrong—can there truly be "that" and "this"? Or can there truly be no "that" and "this"? Where "that" and "this" find no counterpart, this is called the *pivot of the Dao*. Only when one attains the pivot and stands at the center of the ring can one respond to the inexhaustible. This too is inexhaustible, and that too is inexhaustible—thus it is said: "Nothing compares to clarity."

If we debate right and wrong, then their theories each have their own right and wrong, and my theories too have their own right and wrong. How then do I differ from them? Though you distinguish between self and other, in truth, they cannot be separated. Thus it is asked: Can there truly be "that" and "this"? Or can there truly be no "that" and "this"? To say that "that" and "I" are both nothing is to speak of counterparts. If "that" and "I" do not stand in opposition but merge into one, this is the pivotal essence of the Dao. The center of a ring must be empty. If I grasp the pivotal essence of the Dao, I then begin to resemble the center of a ring. Like the center of a ring, there is no end and no beginning—it is inexhaustible. That "this is inexhaustible" and "that is inexhaustible" means to follow what is natural. In this way, one accords with the heavenly principle of nature. Thus it is said: "Nothing compares to clarity." The preceding sentence is cited here to conclude this passage.

To use a finger to illustrate that a finger is not a finger is not as good as using a non-finger to illustrate that a finger is not a finger. To use a horse to illustrate that a horse is not a horse is not as good as using a non-horse to illustrate that a horse is not a horse. Heaven and earth are one finger; the myriad things are one horse.

A finger is a finger. If I take my finger to be a finger, then I take another’s finger to be not a finger. Yet that person, who is not me, takes my finger to be not a finger. If I merely take myself as right and others as wrong, it would be better to reflect on this from their perspective. If things and I stand in opposition, then right and wrong cannot be settled. The counting rods in *bo* and *sai* are like this—see the *Record of Rites*, "Touhu" chapter. The "horses" (rods) vary in number, and the players’ judgments of right and wrong vary accordingly. If we apply this principle by analogy, then heaven’s duty to cover and earth’s duty to bear can also be disputed from one-sided views. The myriad things differ—those that fly, those that walk, those that move, those that are rooted—just as the counting rods differ, and they too can be disputed from one-sided views. This illustrates that in the world, there is no fixed right and wrong. It is only because there is self and other that there is right and wrong. Can heaven and earth be divided into self and other? All these analogies show that things cannot be judged unequally.

Is it acceptable? Is it unacceptable? That which is called acceptable is what things naturally become; that which is called so is what things naturally are. How is it so? It is so in being so. How is it not so? It is not so in not being so. Things inherently have what they are; things inherently have what they accept. Nothing is not so; nothing is unacceptable. What is acceptable is accepted; what is unacceptable is not accepted. Thus it is said: Is it acceptable? Is it unacceptable? That which the Dao deems fine or coarse, when put into practice, all become natural. What is called "so" is simply what is spoken of. What do I take as so? I take as so what is inherently so. What do I take as not so? I take as not so what is inherently not so. Things inherently have what they are—this is their original nature. It is said: "Things inherently have what they are; things inherently have what they accept." Since there is what they are and what they accept, all things are like this. Thus it is said: Nothing is not so; nothing is unacceptable.

Therefore, consider the examples of the stalk and the pillar, the ugly and the beautiful, the vast and the narrow, the deceptive and the straightforward, the strange and the auspicious. The stalk is a roof beam; the pillar is a house column. The beam is horizontal, the column vertical; the ugly is vile, the beautiful is fair. The vast and the narrow, the deceptive and the constant, the cunning and the honest, the monstrous and the auspicious—all differ. Yet from the perspective of the Dao, the horizontal and vertical each serve their purpose, the beautiful and the ugly each fulfill their nature, and all can be united as one. This means all return to the Creator.

Their division is their formation; their formation is their destruction. All things, without formation or destruction, return to unity. Formation and destruction are opposed to each other in things. Yet without destruction, there is no formation; without formation, there is no destruction. For example, a tree in the mountains is felled and used—this is destruction. When used to build a house, it becomes formation. Another example: herbs are prepared by cutting and grinding—this is division. When combined and harmonized, they become medicine. The sinew and horn must be present to make a bow—when in the bow, it is formation; when in the sinew and horn, it is destruction. If the Qin did not fall, the Han would not rise. Though the Han was formed, the Qin was destroyed. Viewed thus, there was originally no formation and no destruction. Thus it is said: They return to unity.

Only those who comprehend this know that unity is the Way. For this reason, they do not employ it but lodge it in the ordinary. The ordinary is use; use is penetration; penetration is attainment. When one attains and approaches the subtlest point, following this and stopping without knowing why—this is called the Dao.

Only those who comprehend the Dao know that this principle is one. They discard their assertions of right, do not employ them, but lodge them in the ordinary, using the constant. When all uses are penetrated, one naturally attains. Thus it is said: The ordinary is use; use is penetration; penetration is attainment. When one attains and approaches the subtlest point—this too means nothing more than following this without contention over right and wrong. Only when one no longer knows why but follows nature—this is called the Dao. The word "already" in the following sentence connects to the "already" in the preceding sentence—this is a playful flourish in the author’s brushwork.

To exhaust one’s spirit in forcing unity without knowing their sameness—this is called "morning three." What is "morning three"? A monkey keeper distributed chestnuts, saying, "Three in the morning and four in the evening." All the monkeys were angry. He then said, "Then four in the morning and three in the evening." All the monkeys were pleased. The names and realities had not changed, yet joy and anger were employed—this too is following "this." Therefore, the sage harmonizes with right and wrong and rests in the equality of heaven. This is called "walking two paths."

The ancients’ knowledge reached its utmost—how far did it reach? There were those who regarded all as never yet having been things: this was the ultimate, the utmost, beyond which nothing could be added. Next were those who regarded things as existing yet never yet having boundaries. Next were those who regarded boundaries as existing yet never yet having right and wrong. The manifestation of right and wrong is the diminution of the Dao. The diminution of the Dao is the completion of attachment. Is there truly completion and diminution? Or is there truly neither completion nor diminution?

That which has never yet been a thing is the beginning of the Supreme Ultimate. The "ancients" here refer to those who understood the Dao: when viewed from the beginning of no-thing, the principles of the world reach their extremity. The next stage, regarding things as existing, is the Supreme Ultimate emerging from the Limitless. From the existence of things to the existence of boundaries is the Supreme Ultimate dividing into the Two Modes. Though the Two Modes are divided—one covering, one bearing, each following its own principle—when has there ever been right and wrong? Right and wrong arise from the private biases of the human heart, their manifestation. Once private bias is revealed, the natural Dao is diminished. When the Dao is diminished, there is liking and disliking: what is within me is love, what is in things is aversion—what the Buddhists call the "river of attachment." Diminishing the Dao and drowning in attachment is but the work of private bias in the human heart. Yet from the perspective of the Creator, when has there ever been completion or diminution? Thus it is said: Is there truly completion and diminution? Or is there truly neither completion nor diminution?

Ah! These words speak to how all disputes over right and wrong in the human world ultimately return to emptiness. Though this passage begins with the origins of Heaven and Earth, the principle it guards against is present before our very eyes. For instance, when a single thought has yet to arise, it is as if we stand at the time before things came to be. Once that thought arises, things come into existence, and with things, the self emerges—thus, boundaries are drawn. From these boundaries of self and things arise likes and dislikes, joy and anger, sorrow and delight—thus, right and wrong are born. If one cannot turn back and reflect on the moment before thought arose, then all one sees is the turmoil churning in the breast, the Dao diminished and attachment formed. Yet when this thought passes, all returns to tranquility—how then can there be completion or diminution?

Zhuangzi’s words may seem distant and impractical, but if one can truly embody this understanding, it becomes a matter of immediate, personal experience. There is completion and diminution, and so Zhaoshi plays the zither. There is neither completion nor diminution, and so Zhaoshi does not play the zither. Zhaowen’s zither-playing, Shikuang’s striking of the clappers, Huizi’s leaning on the catalpa table—these three men’s wisdom was nearly perfect in their arts, and thus their deeds were recorded in their later years. Yet it was only because they cherished their skills, setting themselves apart from others, that they sought to make them known. What they sought to illuminate was not inherently obscure, yet they insisted on clarifying it, and so they ended their lives entangled in the obscurities of "hard and white." Their sons, inheriting their fathers’ legacies, likewise spent their lives without completion. Can this truly be called completion? Even I, too, would be complete. If this cannot be called completion, then neither things nor I attain completion.

Thus, the dazzling confusion of slippery doubt is what the sage seeks to resolve. To refrain from using it and instead lodge it in the ordinary—this is called "illuminating through non-illumination."

Having expounded the principle of completion and diminution, he turns to the analogy of zither-playing, which is most intimate and apt. Consider a zither before you: if you play it, a melody unfolds with a clear beginning and end—this beginning and end arise only after the zither is played. If it is not played, how can there be beginning or end? It is the same with a single thought in a person: if it does not arise, there is no distinction between self and things.

Zhao was the surname; Wen was the given name of an ancient master of the zither. Shikuang was a music master. *Ce* refers to an object used to strike musical instruments; today, a horsewhip is also called a *ce*. In the *Zuozhuan*, Rao Chao gifts one as a *ce*, and Yang Tan strikes the West Gate with a *ce*—both are horsewhips. *Zhi* means "to hold"; to hold and strike is called *zhi*. These two characters likely existed in ancient speech. "Shikuang *zhi ce*" thus means Shikuang striking a musical instrument. *Ju wu* means leaning on a catalpa table, using it as a rest. Following the mention of zither-playing, he brings up these two figures. The three men’s skills were nearly perfected—this speaks to their wisdom being fully realized in their arts. Their techniques were refined, and they gained great renown in the world, hence "all were at their peak." *Zai* means "to engage in"; *mo nian* means "later years." This speaks to dedicating their lives to their arts.

The three men cherished their skills, believing themselves distinct from others in the world, hence "only because they cherished them, setting themselves apart." Having cherished them, they then sought to display them to others, hence "their cherishing of them." They wished to make them known, yet those who heard them already understood, and they insisted on clarifying what was not obscure—hence "what they sought to illuminate was not inherently obscure, yet they insisted on illuminating it." This is like Huizi’s stubborn arguments, which only served to obscure. The "hard and white" refers to Gongsun Long’s debate, though Zhuangzi attributes it to Huizi, merely borrowing the name of the "hard and white" distinction. *Mei* means "self-delusion." The above speaks of the three men, but here he concludes with Huizi’s arguments—this is a matter of literary structure.

Commentators on "hard and white" take it as the debate over a hard stone and a white horse: to say "hard" is to speak of stone, but one need not say "hard" to speak of stone; to say "white" is to speak of a horse, but one need not say "white" to speak of a horse—just as "yellow horse" and "black ox" are three things. Another note in the *Records of the Grand Historian* on Su Qin’s biography says: when Longquan water tempers a sword, it becomes hard and sharp, hence the debate over "hard and white." It says: yellow is for hardness, white is for sharpness. The Qi debaters countered: white is not hard, yellow is not sharp. Though the two explanations differ, both are the work of debaters.

Zhaowen spent his life playing the zither, and his son, inheriting his legacy, likewise spent his life continuing the art. *Lun* means "legacy." Above, he speaks of Huizi, and in the next sentence, he concludes with Zhaowen’s son—this is where the brush dances. "Spent their lives without completion" means they only guarded their own skills, preventing others from attaining them, hence "without completion." For all things under Heaven, if one relies on one’s abilities and deems them sufficient, then one’s present abilities can be called sufficient. But if one’s present abilities are not sufficient, then no one under Heaven, including oneself, can be called sufficient. *Cheng* means "sufficient."

Though these two sentences conclude the discussion of the three men’s skills, their meaning is vast. The three men’s skills are but metaphors for the debates over things and right and wrong—they are not solely about the three men. *Hua yi* means "indistinct and unclear"; *hua* is confusion, and *yi* is doubt, appearing clear yet not clear. *Yao* means "bright." The sage’s mind does not cling to traces, and what it perceives is as if present, as if absent. *Tu* means "to desire"—this speaks to what the sage desires. Thus, he discards the "this" and does not employ it, lodging it instead in the ordinary—this is called "illuminating through non-illumination."

From "things are not other than that" to "not one, not inexhaustible," he explains the phrase "illuminating through non-illumination." From "using the finger to illustrate the finger" to "attaining it and nearly succeeding," he explains the phrase "because of this." Then, returning directly to this point, he concludes with "this is called illuminating through non-illumination." The structure of the text rises and falls, shifting and turning, yet its guiding threads remain clear.

I have often said that the *Qiwulun* is a single, unbroken piece of writing—if one examines its words and veins closely, one can see this. Now, suppose there is a statement here: how can one know whether it aligns with "this" or not? Whether it aligns with "this" or not, if both alignment and non-alignment are taken as "this," then they are no different from "that." This passage arises from the phrase "not using this." Hence, he asks: does it align with "this"? Does it not align with "this"? This is the vein of his words. Earlier, he said, "Words are not mere blowing," and here, shifting his tone, he declares: "Now, suppose there is a statement here." This, too, is the vein running through the text. For if one swaps the positions of "this" and "not this," one sees that "this" and "not this" are both "this." His meaning is: if one takes "that" as "this" and "this" as "that," one sees that "this" and "that" are the same. This is the meaning of "using the finger to illustrate the finger, using the horse to illustrate the horse."

Though this be so, let us attempt to speak of it. There is "having a beginning"; there is "not yet having had a beginning"; there is "not yet having had that which has not yet had a beginning." There is "having"; there is "non-being"; there is "not yet having had non-being"; there is "not yet having had that which has not yet had non-being." Suddenly, there is being and non-being—but who can truly say which is being and which is non-being? Now, I have already made a statement, yet I do not know whether what I have called it is truly a statement or truly not a statement.

Though Zhuangzi’s prose here takes a turn, his words remain wondrous. His meaning is: though one may say there is no "this" and no "that," let us still try to speak of it. Thus, he says: "Let us attempt to speak of it."
