In close dealings, one acts thus; if the parties are distant, loyalty must be expressed through words, fully conveying the truth. Yet how do such words reach their destination? They must be transmitted by a messenger. But between the two—whether in mutual delight or mutual anger—lies the greatest difficulty. If one arrives in delight and the other responds in kind, their praise will exceed what is proper, hence "excessive praise." If both are angry, their censure will likewise exceed what is proper, hence "excessive slander." All such excess is falsehood, and falsehood ensures that the listener will be filled with doubt and unable to trust fully. *Mo* describes this state of suspicion. Once doubt arises, the ill will of both sides falls upon the messenger, who is inevitably blamed. Thus it is said: "Distrust brings calamity upon the conveyor of words." The *Maxims* is an ancient text, cited here as a warning for those entrusted with such missions.

To "convey the ordinary sentiments" means the messenger should transmit only plain, unadorned speech, avoiding any words that exceed what is proper. Thus: "Do not convey the excessive words." If the messenger acts thus, he may nearly preserve himself whole.

Moreover, those who contend with skill and strength begin with openness but end in concealment. When excess prevails, there is much cunning. Those who drink wine with ritual propriety begin in order but end in disorder. When excess prevails, there is much extravagant revelry. All affairs are the same: they begin in sincerity but end in pettiness. What starts simply must grow vast. Words are like wind and waves; deeds are like the loss of substance. Wind and waves are easily stirred; the loss of substance is easily imperiled. Thus anger arises without cause, and artful speech with biased words. When a beast is dying, it does not choose its cries—its breath comes in ragged gasps, and from this, hearts grow fierce, and harshness takes hold. When severity becomes extreme, unworthy thoughts inevitably arise in response, though one may not realize it. If one does not realize it, who can know where it will end?

Having spoken of the perils of conveying words, the text now turns to analogies of worldly affairs, each sentence a reflection of human nature. This is the marvel of *Zhuangzi*: those who contend with skill and strength—like today’s wrestlers—begin with outward joy, but end in hidden malice. At first, they merely grapple in play, but in the end, it often turns to real fighting. For when play becomes excessive, it oversteps bounds, and cunning grows ever more strange. *Excess prevails* means overstepping bounds. Those who gather to drink do so with ritual propriety.

At the beginning, when the feast is orderly, all is decorous; when disorder takes hold, there is shouting and clamor. For when drinking exceeds proper bounds, the joy it brings often turns strange—thus disputes may arise. All things are like this: other affairs in the world follow the same pattern. *Liang* means trust. At first, when people join together in a common endeavor, they are always sincere and trusting. But later, pettiness and deceit arise—this is another matter. At first, one acts with restraint, planning only for the moment, yet by the end, it may grow into something great. The above speaks generally of worldly affairs, but now it turns to speech and action.

For when people engage in speech, it is the source from which winds and waves arise. *Wind moving upon waves* suggests emptiness and confusion. As soon as the word *action* is spoken, there is name and trace; with name, true substance is lost. *Winds and waves are easily stirred* means they readily descend into endless chaos. *When substance is lost, danger comes easily* means that when reality does not match the name, harm may follow.

*Wu you* means without cause. Words of anger are often fabricated without any reason—thus *anger arises without cause*. *Pian ci* refers to a one-sided view; *qiao yan* are merely clever words that express only one side—thus *clever words, partial speech*. *When a beast dies, it does not choose its cries* means that when a beast is dying, what does it matter what sound it makes? This analogy describes those who, in anger or cunning speech, reach the point of contention—then their words pour forth without time for selection. As the common saying goes, *when people quarrel, no kind words are spoken*. *Qi xi furan* means rage. *Li* means fierce and cruel.

When anger arises, a cruel and vicious heart emerges alongside it. Once I am thus, those who respond to me—confronted with my harshness—will inevitably harbor unfilial or unworthy intentions. At times, this may escalate to mutual harm or destruction, all driven by anger without awareness of its cause.

Having been swept away by anger without self-awareness, how can one pause to consider its consequences? The foregoing illustrates how worldly affairs may turn from good to evil through entanglement, leading to this point.

Thus, the *Fa Yan* states: *Do not alter commands; do not urge completion*—excess leads to transgression. To alter commands or urge completion is perilous, for success in goodness requires time, while evil forms too swiftly to amend. Should one not be cautious?

Moreover, to ride the natural course of things and roam the mind freely, entrusting oneself to necessity to nurture the center—this is perfection. Why act with ulterior motives of repayment? Far better to fulfill one’s mission. Yet this is difficult. Here, the text cites ancient words to conclude the matter of serving a ruler’s command: *Do not shift the mandate*, meaning to abide by constant principles.

If, upon receiving a command, one privately schemes for its fulfillment or alters its intent, it cannot succeed. Whether the matter succeeds or not must be left to nature; one cannot force its completion. Thus, *do not urge completion*—seeking excess is to overreach. The moment an excessive thought arises from an ordinary mind, it becomes a desire for gain, which must not surpass proper measure. To exceed the usual bounds is to overreach. Altering commands and urging completion are both excessive thoughts, and such schemes are bound to endanger. Hence, *perilous affairs*.

Human relationships, especially deep bonds, are not forged in a day but require time to stabilize. Thus, *goodness takes time to mature*. A single discordant word or uncooperative act may turn affection to enmity in an instant. Hence, *evil forms before one can correct it*. This means that turning to hatred is easy, while fostering goodwill is difficult—thus, one must be especially cautious.

If I ride the natural flow of events and let my mind wander freely, entrusting my response to necessity to nurture my center, this is the highest attainment. Why then act with ulterior motives of repayment? Repayment refers to returning to fulfill one’s mission. Acting excessively to seek gain is overreaching. *Fulfilling one’s mission* means conveying the ruler’s command to Wei with sincerity.

Your duty is to deliver the ruler’s command with truth alone, without overthinking its success or failure. Even this sincere fulfillment is difficult; you must strive to achieve it. Here, the text adds another layer of difficulty, for navigating such circumstances is indeed hard.

This passage, titled *The Human World*, precisely describes the difficulty of navigating life. Its intricate portrayal of worldly affairs could only be achieved by one like Zhuangzi, whose nature harmonizes with the Dao. Some critics claim that Lao-Zhuang philosophy only grasps the subtlety of the Daoist mind (*the mind of the Dao is subtle*) while neglecting the peril of the human mind (*the human mind is perilous*). Such judgments arise from a superficial reading of their works.

Yan He was about to serve as tutor to the crown prince of Duke Ling of Wei when he sought counsel from Qu Boyu: "There is a man whose virtue is *heavenly destructive*. If I indulge him without restraint, he will endanger our state; if I guide him with principles, he will endanger me. His wisdom suffices to detect others’ faults but not to recognize his own. What should I do?"

Qu Boyu replied: "Excellent question! Be vigilant, be cautious, and first rectify yourself. In conduct, align with him; in mind, harmonize with him. Yet even these two approaches have pitfalls. Alignment should not be forced, nor harmony contrived. If you align outwardly but force entry, you risk collapse, ruin, or stumbling. If you harmonize inwardly but contrive exit, you risk becoming a voice, a reputation, an omen, or a calamity.

If he acts like a child, join him as a child. If he abandons boundaries, join him in abandoning boundaries. If he transcends limits, join him in transcending limits. Guide him to reach flawlessness."

Yan He was preparing to tutor the crown prince and sought Qu Boyu’s advice. *There is a man* refers to the prince. *His virtue is heavenly destructive* means heaven has stripped him of discernment—*destructive* here implies erosion, like frost withering grass, suggesting his nature has been corrupted by fate.

*Without restraint* means lacking principles. If one allows his transgressions to go unchecked, he will endanger the state; if one corrects him, the harm will first befall oneself. The prince’s intelligence enables him to spot others’ faults but not his own. *What should I do?* expresses helplessness.

*Rectify yourself* means to first establish discipline in one’s own conduct. *Align* means to follow, and *harmonize* means to attune. Yet both approaches have dangers: alignment should not be forced, nor harmony contrived.

To guide and lead him: outwardly display reverence and adopt the form of compliance, while inwardly exert every effort to harmonize and guide with one’s heart. Thus it is said, *"In form, nothing surpasses alignment; in heart, nothing surpasses harmony."* The phrase *"nothing surpasses"* means no method excels these two.

Yet there is a subtle shift in these two approaches—alignment and harmony. To comply and merge with him as one is to *"align and enter."* If the intent to guide becomes slightly apparent, revealing one’s edges, it is to *"harmonize and withdraw."* If alignment reaches the point of *"entering,"* one’s own harmony is entirely abandoned, leading to ruin, destruction, collapse, and downfall. If harmony extends to the point where one’s reputation spreads, he will surely incur jealousy and harm, inviting calamity. Thus it is said, *"It becomes fame, renown, omen, and affliction."* The phrasing here is most extraordinary.

*"Like an infant"* refers to one who resembles an ignorant child. *"Without boundaries"* means lacking banks or shores—his conduct is unrestrained, without rules or standards. *"Without limits"* means without edges or bounds—his actions proceed without considering their ultimate consequences. The infant, without boundaries or limits, embodies the description of one who acts in ignorance and recklessness. Since he is so ignorant and reckless, one should comply with him for the time being. Thus it is said, *"Also accompany him."* When he reaches a point of possible awakening, then apply subtle transformation to jolt him into sudden realization, so he may enter a state without blemish.

*"To awaken"* means to attain enlightenment. *"Without blemish"* means without fault. Formerly, Master Aixuan recounted an old tale from Putian: a man whose father died left him unburied and squandered his family estate to indulge his desires. When his fields were nearly exhausted, his relatives pitied him and collected money to fund his father’s burial. He feigned agreement but spent the money as before. All his kin were outraged. One clansman, however, went out and befriended him, indulging his every whim. One evening, after heavy drinking and reaching the height of merriment, the clansman patted his back and said, *"Others cannot bear such sorrow, yet Yan Hui did not alter his joy."* The man was suddenly awakened, wept bitterly, and returned home to bury his father. He ultimately became a good man. This is precisely the principle at work here.

Do you not know of the mantis? In its fury, it brandishes its arms to block the wheel’s track, unaware of its inability to bear the task—yet this is the beauty of its nature. Beware, take heed: those who accumulate boasts of their fine talents and thus provoke the world’s taboos are on the brink of peril.

Do you not know of those who raise tigers? They dare not feed them living creatures, lest the beasts’ rage at being forced to kill; nor do they dare give them whole prey, lest the beasts’ fury at tearing flesh be roused. They time their hunger and satiety, pacify their temper—though tigers and men are of different kinds, the tiger flatters and fawns upon its keeper, for this is submission. Thus, those it kills are those who oppose it.

As for those who love horses: they use baskets to collect dung and conch shells to gather urine. Yet when a mosquito or gadfly alights, and a groom absentmindedly slaps it, the horse, startled, may break its bit, smash its head, or shatter its chest. Here, devotion reaches one point, but carelessness loses another—can one not be cautious?

Below are several more analogies. The mantis, relying on the beauty of its talent, seeks to block the wheel’s track with its arms—this illustrates how those of modest talent, self-important, presume to take on great matters, and rarely avoid failure. Such is the consequence of repeated overreaching.

*伐* means boasting; *几* means peril. Those who repeatedly boast of their fine talents and offend the world’s taboos will surely endanger themselves. Hence it is said: *"Those who accumulate boasts of their fine talents and thus provoke the world’s taboos are on the brink of peril."*

The tiger’s nature is quick to anger, so its keeper must regulate and dispel its rage. Even the tiger, toward its keeper, harbors a semblance of affection—this is nothing more than submission. If one opposes it, one will surely be harmed. Thus it is said: *"Those it kills are those who oppose it."*

A *筐* is a bamboo vessel.

The *shen*-ash vessel is a utensil for holding excrement and urine—one might call this "love," yet if mosquitoes and horseflies suddenly gather upon its body, and one fails to brush them away in time, the horse will inevitably break free of its bit and bridle, smashing its head against the reins, headstall, and browband. When fury surges from its heart in an instant, all the affection of former days is forgotten.

*Clinging* here means clustering in swarms. *Perishing* is synonymous with *forgetting*. This illustrates how what is beautifully accomplished over time can be undone in an instant if one does not correct one’s faults. In human relations, there are those who follow and befriend one another for a lifetime, only to become enemies over a single word—this is the difficulty of navigating the world. Reading the passages on Lord Zigao and Yan He makes clear the intent of this chapter, *Amid the Human World*.

When Carpenter Shi arrived in Qi, he came upon a curved-shaft oak, a sacred tree so vast it could shade an ox, its girth requiring a hundred spans to encircle. Its height towered above the mountains, rising seventy cubits before branches appeared. A dozen or more of its side limbs could be made into boats. Spectators thronged like a marketplace, yet the master carpenter paid no heed and walked on without pause. His disciple, having feasted his eyes, caught up to Carpenter Shi and said, "Since I first took up the axe to follow you, Master, I have never seen timber so magnificent. Why did you refuse even to glance at it, walking on without stopping?"

"Enough," he replied. "Say no more."

A worthless tree. Make it into a boat, and it sinks; fashion it into a coffin or outer casket, and it rots swiftly; shape it into vessels, and they shatter at once; use it for doors or windows, and it oozes sap; set it as a pillar, and it is eaten by worms. This is a tree of no use—precisely why it has attained such longevity.

Carpenter Shi returned home, and in a dream the sacred oak of the altar appeared to him, saying, "What will you compare me to? Will you liken me to the so-called 'useful trees'? Those crabapples, pears, tangerines, pomelos, and other fruit-bearing trees—once their fruit ripens, they are stripped and humiliated, their great branches broken, their small branches snapped. This is how their very usefulness brings suffering upon their lives. Thus they do not fulfill their natural span but perish midway, cut down by the world’s judgments. All things are like this.

As for me, I have long sought to be of no use. Nearly dead, I have only now attained it—and this is my great usefulness. Had I been useful, would I have grown so vast? Moreover, you and I are both things—how could one thing presume to judge another? How could a nearly dead, worthless man like you understand a worthless tree?"

*Curved-Shaft* is the name of a mountain; *li* is the name of the oak. This oak stood within the sacred altar grove. The *Analects* states, "The Xia dynasty used the pine, the Zhou used the chestnut"—in ancient times, the sacred grove always required a great tree as its center. *A hundred spans* describes its girth, measured by encircling it with both hands. *Seventy cubits* describes its height. If its branches could be made into boats, its trunk’s size may be imagined. *Feasted his eyes* means he gazed until fully sated. *Worthless tree* refers to a tree discarded as useless. *Oozes sap* describes the resin flowing thickly. *Pillar* refers to setting a tree as a column. *Useful trees* are those prized for their beauty and utility. The oak in the dream says, "If you call me worthless, you compare me to useful trees." Crabapples, pears, tangerines, pomelos, and other fruit-bearing trees are all useful trees, and thus are damaged by people—this is how their usefulness harms their lives. *Usefulness* refers to usable timber. "I have long sought to be of no use, and you only now recognize it" is a rebuke to Carpenter Shi, akin to modern curses like "half-dead fool." *Great usefulness* means that its worthlessness is precisely what preserves its life. Had it been useful, people would have felled it long ago—how then could it have grown so vast? "Moreover" underscores the shared nature of all things.

"Yet the *and* in 'Moreover' adds the particle *also*—if you and I are both things, though Carpenter Shi is a man and I am an oak, we are both but one thing among Heaven and Earth. Why then do you alone mock me as a thing? Thus it is said, 'If you and I *also* are things.' How could it be otherwise? In this single phrase, four *also*s and one *how*—such are the marvels of Master Zhuang’s prose. You are a man of no use yourself; why mock me, a tree of no use? Thus it is said, 'A half-dead worthless man—how could he understand a worthless tree?'"

Carpenter Shi awoke and interpreted his dream. His disciple asked, "If it seeks to be of no use, why then does it serve as a spirit-tree?" He replied, "Hush—say nothing. It merely lodges there, as if unaware of itself, yet is reviled for it. Had it not become a spirit-tree, would it not still have faced the axe? Moreover, what it preserves differs from the common lot, and to judge it by conventional praise or blame is far indeed from the mark."

*Interpretation* refers to divining the dream. The disciple, hearing the oak’s words in the dream, said, "If this tree’s aspiration is to be of no use, why must it be employed as a spirit-tree?" *Hush* means "keep silent." *It* refers to the oak. Its role as a spirit-tree is but a temporary lodging—how could it have foreseen that today it would be reviled by one who fails to recognize its true nature? *Reviled* means to curse and shame. Even if it had not become a spirit-tree, would it not still have been felled? What it preserves is unlike what others value, and to measure it by moral judgment is far removed from its truth. *What it preserves* means what it upholds. "Would it not still have faced the axe?" Here, *would* shares the sense of *almost*.

Later, Nanbo Ziqi wandered to the hills of Shang, where he saw a great tree...

There stood a tree of such extraordinary girth that a thousand chariots could shelter beneath its canopy. Marveling at its grandeur, Nanbo Ziqi exclaimed, "What manner of tree is this? Surely it must possess rare timber!" Yet when he gazed upward at its slender branches, they were gnarled and twisted—unfit for beams or rafters. Looking down at its massive roots, they were split and fissured—unsuitable for coffins or outer caskets. Tasting its leaves, they scorched the mouth and caused sores. Inhaling its scent, it drove men to raving drunkenness for three days without cease. Ziqi declared, "This is indeed a tree of no use, and yet it has grown to such immense proportions! Alas—how the spirit-like person cherishes such uselessness!"

In the region of Jing in Song, the catalpa, cypress, and mulberry—those slender enough to encircle with one’s arms—are felled for monkey perches. Those three or four spans in girth are cut down for the lofty beams of renowned halls. Those seven or eight spans wide are hewn for the side planks sought by noble households and wealthy merchants. Thus, before completing their natural lifespan, they meet an untimely end beneath the axe—such is the peril of being useful timber.

Now, a white-browed ox, a snub-nosed pig, or a man afflicted with hemorrhoids—none of these may approach the river. The shamans and priests all know this, for these are deemed inauspicious. Yet this is precisely what the spirit-like person regards as most auspicious.

This passage parallels the preceding one, yet within it, several additional phrases further elucidate the theme. There stands a great tree, extraordinary in its magnitude—its vastness unlike that which is ordinary. Though a thousand chariots, each drawn by four horses, were to gather beneath its branches, seeking shelter from the scorching sun, it would still provide ample shade. Thus it is said: the horses shall find shelter from the heat, and this shelter comes from the tree itself, which in turn shelters all things. The heat seeks refuge from the tree, yet the tree’s essence remains hollow and insubstantial—like the stem of a taro, which, when licked or chewed, dissolves upon the tongue and rots the mouth, or when sniffed, clings to one like intoxication, so pungent is its odor. This tree, precisely because of its uselessness, has thus preserved its life and grown to such immense proportions. The spirit-like persons of antiquity preserved their lives by this same uselessness. Therefore it is said: "The spirit-like person cherishes such uselessness!"—an exclamation of admiration.

Jing is a place name. The catalpa, cypress, and mulberry are all useful timbers, well-suited to the climate and soil of that region. The former passage spoke of edible trees; this one speaks of usable timber. A *yi* is a stake, and *li* refers to the ridgepole of a house.

The great and eminent families—*gaoming* here refers to households of high status (the two characters originally shared the same meaning, though "ming" differs in pronunciation and form)—fell trees for coffin-making. Thus, the timber suited to this land, whether a mere armful or two, or three to four spans in girth, or even seven to eight spans, was felled without exception. Nothing could be spared, for their very usefulness brought such disaster upon them.

The *Guwu Zhu* is an ancient text of shamans and invokers. Within its explanations, it states: "An ox with a white forehead, a pig with a broken snout and upturned nose—none of these may be offered in sacrifice to the River." In ancient times, humans were sometimes sacrificed to the River, as in the case of Ximen Bao. Here, Zhuangzi, fond of the extraordinary, adds the phrase "suffering from piles" to the list. *Shi* means "to go"; thus, none of these may be taken to the River for sacrifice.

Though shamans and invokers deemed these three unusable and inauspicious, they did not realize that their very inauspiciousness spared them from the calamity of slaughter. From the perspective of the spirit-like person, this inauspiciousness is in fact great auspiciousness. Both these passages illustrate the perils of navigating the world: those who seek to distinguish themselves in society inevitably invite misfortune—hence the analogy.

As for *Zhili Shu*: his chin rested upon his navel, his shoulders towered above his head, his topknot pointed skyward, and the five viscera’s ducts rose upward. His thighs flanked his ribs. By mending clothes and washing laundry, he earned enough to feed himself; by winnowing grain and sifting out the finest rice, he could provide for ten. When the authorities conscripted warriors, *Zhili* rolled up his sleeves among them, though none selected him. When great labor was demanded, *Zhili*, citing his chronic ailment, was exempted from service. Yet when the state distributed grain to the infirm, he received three *zhong*, and when firewood was allotted, ten bundles. One whose body was as broken as *Zhili*’s could still sustain himself and live out his natural years—how much more so one whose virtue is thus fragmented?

*Zhili* describes a body in disarray; *Shu* is his given name. His chin sank to his navel, his torso hunched. His shoulders jutted above his head, and his topknot was bound like a mallet. The ducts of his five viscera all inclined upward due to his stooped back. His thighs, pressed close to his sides, served as ribs. This depicts a man utterly disabled. By mending clothes and laundering, he made a living; by winnowing grain and refining rice, he fed ten—so swift was his labor. When warriors were conscripted, he raised his arms among them, but none chose him. When great labor was imposed, he was excused due to his chronic illness. Yet he received three *zhong* of grain and ten bundles of firewood from the state. If one whose body was as broken as *Zhili*’s could still nourish himself and live out his years, how much more so one whose virtue is thus fragmented?

The merit was like that of the Jin people in Zuo’s account, who built the walls of Qi and levied labor from the feudal lords—yet he was exempted from all military service and conscripted labor, and further received grain and firewood on account of his illness. This too was the intent of preserving oneself through uselessness. The fragmentation of his virtue speaks of the perfected person’s virtue, which is likewise fragmented: taking non-use as the greatest use. This shares the same meaning as the "useless tree."

When Confucius traveled to Chu, Jieyu, the madman of Chu, wandered past his gate and sang:
*"O phoenix! O phoenix!*
*How your virtue has declined!*
*The age to come cannot be awaited,*
*The age past cannot be recalled.*
*When the world follows the Dao, the sage achieves completion;*
*When the world loses the Dao, the sage merely survives.*
*In this present time, one is fortunate just to escape punishment.*
*Blessings are lighter than a feather—who knows how to bear them?*
*Disasters are heavier than the earth—who knows how to avoid them?*
*Enough! Enough!*
*To approach others with virtue is perilous!*
*Perilous! Perilous!*
*To tread where lines are drawn is to follow a maze.*
*Brambles! Brambles! Do not harm my path!*
*I walk my way in retreat, winding—do not harm my feet!"*

The mountain trees fell to their own defenses,
The fat of the lamp consumes itself in flame.
Cinnamon is edible, so it is felled;
Lacquer is useful, so it is slashed.
All people know the use of what is useful,
But none know the use of what is useless.

This passage draws from the *Analects* to mock the Confucian school. Since the age to come cannot be awaited and the age past cannot be recalled, having been born into this world as this person in this time, when nothing can be done, one should simply conceal oneself. To stubbornly harbor the intent of saving the world at such a time is not the mark of one who understands the times.

Thus it is said: when virtue declines, if the world follows the Dao, the sage may complete his work; if the world loses the Dao, the sage preserves his life and no more. In this present age—a time of chaos—one is fortunate merely to escape punishment. What further aspirations dare one harbor?

Thus it is said: in this present age, one is fortunate merely to escape punishment. To live through an age of chaos and escape punishment so as to preserve one’s life—this is but the slightest sliver of fortune, yet you fail even to recognize it, though you bear and receive it. In an age of chaos, should misfortune befall you, it often leads to execution, a weight heavier than the earth itself, yet you fail to avoid it. The *Han Odes* says: “Glory and splendor fill not the eye, / While calamity looms large as a house.” This is precisely its meaning.

Enough! Enough!—meaning, cease, cease. To exalt oneself by virtue and look down upon others is the way to court disaster. How perilous! How dangerous! “Drawing lines on the ground and walking within them” describes one who restricts and torments oneself as if bound by such lines. It is like Yangming—human nature is originally luminous, yet you, deluded, lose it and thus inevitably act in the world in a way that causes harm. “Crooked and circuitous” means to twist and turn, to evade and yield. Unable to follow the true and straight Way, you act thus—twisting, evading, yielding—and so must end by injuring your own feet. “Injuring your own feet” means it cannot be walked. The mountain tree, because it is useful, invites the axe’s disaster—this is self-inflicted harm. The fat of the lamp, because it gives light and is useful, brings upon itself the torment of burning. Cinnamon, because it is edible, is felled by others; lacquer, because it is useful, is slashed by others. These are all parables for those who cannot conceal themselves, who seek fame in the world and thus invite misfortune. Thus it is said: all people know the use of what is useful, but none know the use of what is useless.

From the *Inner Chapters*, “Virtue’s Full Manifestation,” Chapter Five. *Fu* means resonance; what is within oneself can then resonate with what is without. To be full means that virtue is sufficient within oneself, and thus one responds appropriately to whatever arises. In Lu there was a crippled man, Wang Tai, whose followers were as numerous as Confucius’s. Chang Ji asked Confucius, “Wang Tai is a cripple, yet his followers are as many as yours, Master. He neither teaches when standing nor discusses when seated, yet those who go to him empty return full. Is there truly a teaching without words, a shaping of the heart without form? What sort of man is he?” Confucius said, “This master is a sage. I am merely a latecomer who has yet to visit him. I intend to take him as my teacher—how much more should those inferior to me? Why mention only Lu? I would lead the whole world to follow him.” Chang Ji said, “He is a cripple, yet he surpasses you, Master. Compared to ordinary people, the difference is even greater. If this is so, how does he employ his mind?” Chang Ji was a disciple of Confucius. “Half of Lu” means that half of the people of Lu followed Confucius, while the other half followed Tai. “Neither teaches when standing” means he stands with his disciples but teaches nothing; “nor discusses when seated” means he sits with his disciples but says nothing. Yet those who go to him empty return full—empty, having seen nothing, yet upon returning, they are replete with realization. “Without form” means nothing is seen; “heart is shaped” means the heart is moved and naturally transformed. Chang Ji, seeing this, thus questioned Confucius. Confucius said, referring to Wang Tai, “I merely intend to visit him, though I have been slow to do so. Even one such as I will take him as my teacher—how much more those beneath me? Why mention only Lu? I would lead the whole world to follow him.” “He is a cripple, yet he surpasses you, Master”—this phrase means he surpasses even the Master, and thus the difference with ordinary people is even greater. “Master” refers to Confucius; “ordinary people” means common folk. Confucius said, “Life and death are indeed great matters, yet they do not alter him.” “Life and death are indeed great matters...”

"These five characters—'Life and death are indeed great matters'—form a major thread in Zhuangzi, while the entire Buddhist canon emerges from them. What is meant by 'Life and death are matters as urgent as saving one’s head' is precisely this. 'Do not alter with them' means that though the changes of life and death are great, this heart remains unmoved and cannot be made to change with them. 'Do not' means 'cannot'; 'alter with them' means to change in accordance with them.

This saying is attributed to Confucius but is in fact Zhuangzi’s parable. Those who criticize it as heterodox claim that among all things, he fails to expound clearly, devoting his entire life to studying only this one matter—yet their critique is quite justified. However, the Buddhist teaching is precisely aimed at the ignorant and deluded, those mired in stupor and resistant to transformation; it uses fear to urge them toward goodness. Though its doctrine is flawed, its salvific intent is earnest. As Confucians, we cannot but refute its teachings, yet we must also understand its underlying purpose.

The Buddhists hold that of all things people fear, regardless of status, death is the greatest. Thus, they use it as leverage to compel entry into the Dao. Some say the Buddhists, fearing death, devised this teaching—yet they have lost sight of its true intent. Even if heaven and earth were to collapse, one would remain untouched, for one does not casually drift with external changes but guards the root amid the transformations of things. 'Heaven and earth collapsing' is a hyperbolic expression for the destruction of the cosmos. 'Untouched' means 'unfallen.' Thus, even if heaven and earth were to crumble, one would not fall with them—just as in the earlier saying, 'entering water without getting wet, entering fire without being burned.'

The language of the *Zhuangzi* differs from that of the *Analects* and *Mencius*, often employing exaggeration—this is simply its stylistic approach, not a claim that heaven and earth could truly collapse. 'Scrutinize' means to see clearly and thoroughly."

The term "无假" means "real." Such phrases exemplify the subtlety of Zhuangzi's diction and phrasing. If one were to say "clear" or "real" outright, the expression would become clumsy. "Not drifting with things" (不与物迁) is synonymous with "not changing with them" (不得与之变) and "not falling with them" (不与之遗). "Commanding the transformations of things" (命物之化) means that the transformations of the myriad things all receive their mandate from me—akin to the Chan saying, "When the mind is deluded, the *Dharma Flower* turns; when the mind awakens, the *Dharma Flower* turns."

"宗" refers to the origin of the myriad things. "Guarding the origin" (守其宗) means that what this person guards lies in the beginning of the myriad things—just as the earlier passage spoke of "having a beginning" (有始), "having not yet begun to have a beginning" (有未始有始), and so on. In Zhuangzi's text, a term like "宗" may be glossed as "beginning," but to grasp its full meaning, one must see that it signifies more than just "beginning." Only then does its profundity become apparent. "Guarding the origin" is the whole substance; "wandering in its harmony" (游其和) is its great function.

Changji asked, "What does this mean?" Confucius replied: "Viewed from their differences, liver and gall are as distant as Chu and Yue; viewed from their sameness, the myriad things are all one." Ordinary people do not understand that the myriad things share a single origin. Though liver and gall may seem as distinct as Chu and Yue, knowing that they share a single origin means that the myriad things are all one with me. Observe how these two sentences pivot in their phrasing—many skilled writers before and after have employed this device. Zhuangzi's text is not only profound in its principles but also unparalleled in its literary craft, surpassing all other masters.

If this is so, then one no longer knows what is fitting for the ears and eyes but roams the mind in the harmony of virtue. The ears are for hearing, the eyes for seeing—yet one who can do this does not merely listen with the ears or see with the eyes. This is what Chan calls "the six senses arising from a single source." How can one "observe" and yet be called "Guanyin" (Observer of Sounds)? Though this is the language of heterodoxy, it carries deep meaning. "The harmony of virtue" (德之和) is one with heaven, earth, and the four seasons. This "harmony" is not the "harmony" of the *Doctrine of the Mean*, which speaks of moderation. To read this text, one must possess a different eye.

Things are seen in their unity, not in what they have lost. To see the loss of a foot as if discarding dirt—this is to regard things in their unity without seeing what they have lost. It means observing the myriad things without deficiency or excess, which aligns with the earlier passage about the millipede. This is Zhuangzi’s reversal of Gongwen Xuan’s dialogue with Jie Yu. "Discarding dirt" means to cast it away unknowingly, as if it were mere soil.

Changji said: "He cultivates himself (为己) by using his knowledge to attain his mind, and by using his mind to attain his constant mind. Why then do people value him so highly?" "Cultivating oneself" means refining one’s person. "Using his knowledge" means that with this discernment, one can cultivate the self. "Attaining his mind" means that with this aware mind, one attains the original mind. The original mind and the aware mind are not two separate things; this phrasing is merely a way of speaking. The underlying meaning is that all people possess knowledge and all possess minds. If one can fully realize them, one can cultivate the self and attain the mind—this is an ordinary matter. Thus, it is said, "attaining the constant mind." "Most" (最) means "to honor." It does not say "honor" but "most"—this is what makes Zhuangzi’s writing so extraordinary. "Things" (物) refers to other people.

Confucius said: "People do not mirror themselves in flowing water but in still water. Only stillness can still the many." Flowing water is a metaphor for the mind that cannot be stilled; still water, for the mind that can. Stilling the mind is what makes one uniquely worthy among people. The multitude seek stillness by pursuing their desires, but only this person can truly do so. Thus, it is said, "Only stillness can still the many." These words describe those who have not yet settled their minds but seek instruction from him—he can teach them to attain stillness. Is this phrasing not extraordinary? This is akin to the Chan saying: "Bring me your mind, and I will settle it for you." The student says, "I seek my mind but cannot find it." The master replies, "I have settled your mind for you." This is the essence of that exchange.

"Receiving its mandate from the earth, only the pine and cypress remain verdant in winter and summer." "Receiving its mandate from heaven, only Shun is upright." Fortunate in his uprightness, he can rectify his life and thereby rectify the lives of others. The pine and cypress are compared to Shun, and Shun to Wang Tai. It speaks only of their unique endowment from heaven, which enables them to rectify their own lives and thereby rectify the lives of others. Here, "life" (生) is synonymous with "nature" (性). Some may ask, "How can Shun be compared to Wang Tai?" To read Zhuangzi in this way is to speak dreams before a fool.

The proof of preserving the beginning lies in the reality of fearlessness. A single brave warrior, charging alone into nine armies, seeks fame and can hold fast to himself—yet even he is like this. "Proof" (征) means evidence; "verification" (验) means confirmation. "Preserving" (保) means guarding. To guard the original word and have evidence and verification is simply a matter of trust. Without this "reality" (实), one cannot be fearless. "Nine armies" refers to a multitude of soldiers; perhaps during the Warring States period, there was a formation of nine ranks—this need not be confined to the conventional six armies of the Son of Heaven or the three armies of the feudal lords. "Holding fast to oneself" means self-trust. Jing Ke and Nie Zheng were those who sought fame and trusted themselves. If even they, who guarded this single trust, could remain unchanged in life and death, how much more so for one who embodies the Way? In Buddhist texts, one finds those who sit on python rocks or guard tiger dens—this, too, is merely the reality of fearlessness. Zhuangzi’s passages like this are not mere allegories but are based on actual observations.

"Moreover, to govern heaven and earth, to store the myriad things, to lodge in the six limbs, to model the ears and eyes, to unify knowledge in what is known—is the mind not already dead in such a case?" "Governing heaven and earth" means heaven covers and earth bears, each fulfilling its office. "Storing" (府) means gathering; the myriad things gather according to their kind. This is the same idea as "heaven and earth are born with me, and the myriad things are one with me." Mencius said, "The myriad things are all complete within me"—this, too, is the idea of storing the myriad things, though the phrasing differs. "Lodging in the six limbs" means the six limbs are where I reside. "Modeling the ears and eyes" is akin to the earlier passage about "what is fitting for the ears and eyes." The eyes model the eyes but are not limited to seeing; the ears model the ears but are not limited to hearing. Thus, it is said, "modeling the ears and eyes." "Unifying knowledge in what is known"—the first "knowledge" (知) is pronounced *zhi* (wisdom), the second as *zhi* (to know). Wisdom is what is received from nature; knowledge is the function of wisdom. Because it is received from heaven, there is nothing it does not know. Thus, it is called "unifying knowledge in what is known." The mind that perceives nothing is called "dead."

He, then, chooses a day to ascend and reach the ultimate—this is to follow the Way. "Ascend" means to rise; "reach" means to arrive. The annotations pronounce *jia* as *gu* or *xia*, both incorrect. How could he choose a day to attain the Dao? It means he does not select a day to ascend and reach the Dao, for the Dao is present at all times—this is the idea that the Dao cannot be departed from even for an instant. The reason people follow Wang Tai in their learning is simply to follow the Way.

This "is" (*shi*) is emphatic. "To take things as affairs"—"things" here refer to people. How could he be willing to take others as his concern? For people seek learning from him; he never seeks to teach others.

Shentu Jia was a man who had lost his foot, yet he studied under Bohun Wuren alongside Zichan of Zheng. Zichan said to Shentu Jia, "If I leave first, you stay; if you leave first, I stay." The next day, they again sat together in the same hall on the same mat. Zichan said to Shentu Jia, "If I leave first, you stay; if you leave first, I stay. Now, I am about to leave—can you stay? Or is it that when you see an official, you do not yield? Do you consider yourself equal to an official?"

Shentu Jia replied, "In the Master’s gate, are there officials like this? You delight in your own official status and put others after yourself. I have heard that when a mirror is bright, dust does not settle; if dust settles, it is not bright. When one dwells long with the worthy, one commits no faults. Now, what you take as greatest is the Master, yet you still speak like this—is this not a fault? Zichan, you are already as you are; do you still compete with Yao in goodness? Are your virtue and power not enough to reflect upon yourself?"

"I leave first, you stay; you leave first, I stay"—he wished for them to avoid each other. Shentu Jia did not comply with this arrangement, for the non-compliant do not avoid. "Equal" means the same; "official" refers to himself. He says, "If you and I go out together, you consider yourself equal to an official." "Putting others after" means putting oneself first. To put oneself first and others after is to value oneself and belittle others. One with learning has broad vision and understanding. "Take" means to seek. He says, "You study under the Master to seek broadened vision and understanding, yet you remain so narrow-minded?" The phrase "take as greatest" is excellent, and "compete with Yao in goodness" is most striking. He says, "You have already lost a foot—even if you could do good, could you match Yao? 'Reflect upon yourself' means you overestimate your abilities."

Shentu Jia said, "Those who describe their faults to claim they should not have lost their feet are many; those who do not describe their faults to claim they should not have kept their feet are few. Knowing there is nothing to be done and accepting it as fate—only those with virtue can do this. To wander within Yi’s drawn bow—'within' means the center of the target. Yet not being struck is a matter of fate. People with whole feet laugh at my incomplete foot in great numbers. I was enraged, but when I came to the Master’s place, my anger vanished, and I returned to myself. Did the Master not wash me with goodness? I have wandered with you for nineteen years, yet you have never known I was footless. Now, you wander with me within the form and body, yet you seek me outside the form and body—is this not a fault?"

Zichan was startled, changed his expression, and altered his demeanor, saying, "You need not speak further."

"Describe" means to recount. Those who recount their faults to claim they should not have lost their feet are many; those who do not speak of their faults to claim they should not have kept their feet are rare. Only those with virtue know that all things have their fate—how can man do anything about it? These three sentences describe three kinds of people, as if fate were to follow its course.

The passage about wandering within the drawn bow is most extraordinary—this is what the *Yi* means by "treading on a tiger’s tail." Laozi said, "My greatest trouble is that I have a body." To use a tiger’s tail as a metaphor for life’s dangers is already striking, yet Zhuangzi says, "within Yi’s drawn bow." "Within the drawn bow" is the place where the arrow’s tip is aimed—the very center of the target. No archer was better than Yi; the center of the drawn bow was where he was certain to strike. The world’s dangers are like this, and this saying is especially apt in the Warring States period. To be fortunate enough not to be struck is a matter of fate.

"Vanished" means to lose oneself entirely. His anger had reached this point, yet it all disappeared upon returning. He says, "Upon seeing the Master, I returned and lost all cause for anger." The word "wash" is excellent—it means the Master instructed him with goodness, as if cleansing him without his realizing it.

The phrases about "within the form and body" and "outside the form and body" are the best—such ideas are not found in earlier texts. "Speak further" means to praise his ability to speak, as in the *Zuozhuan*, where the people of Lu called someone "quick-witted."

There was a footless man of Lu named Shushan Wuzhi who came to see Confucius on his heels. Confucius said, "You were not careful before and have already suffered such misfortune. Though you come now, what can be done?" Wuzhi said, "I simply did not know my duty and lightly used my body, which is why I lost my foot. Now I come because there is still something worthy of respect remaining in me, and I wish to preserve it. The heavens cover all without exception; the earth bears all without exception. I took you, Master, to be like heaven and earth—how could I have known you would be like this?"

Confucius said, "Qiu is truly unworthy. Why do you not enter? Please speak of what you have heard." Wuzhi left. Confucius said, "Disciples, exert yourselves! This man Wuzhi, though footless, still strives to learn to make up for the evil of his past conduct—how much more should those with whole virtue do so?"

Wuzhi said to Lao Dan, "Is Confucius not yet a perfected person? Why does he so diligently seek to learn from you? Does he hope to gain a reputation for the strange and marvelous, not knowing that the perfected person considers such things as his own shackles?" Lao Dan said, "Why not simply let him see that life and death are one thread, that right and wrong are one strand, and thus free him from his shackles—would that not be possible?"

Wuzhi said, "This is heaven’s punishment—how can it be freed?"

"He came on his heels"—*zhi* means to visit; "not knowing one’s duty" means not understanding affairs. "Something worthy of respect" refers to his nature. The phrase "worthy of respect" is strikingly put—what is to be valued lies not outside the form and body. "Diligent" (*binbin*)—Sima Biao explains this as a respectful appearance. "Strange and marvelous" refers only to a love of fame. "His own shackles" means fame is a burden to oneself. "Heaven’s punishment" means heaven does not grant him the Dao.

Zhuangzi uses Confucius as a mouthpiece, sometimes restraining him, sometimes exalting him—all is allegory. Yet in this passage, he says, "This man Wuzhi, though footless, still strives to learn to make up for the evil of his past conduct—how much more should those with whole virtue do so?" These words are also beneficial to the world’s teachings. "Life and death as one thread, right and wrong as one strand" echoes the ideas in the "Equalizing Things" chapter—"Is it acceptable? Is it not acceptable?"

Duke Ai of Lu asked Confucius, saying: "In Wei there is an ugly man named Aitai Tuo. Men who live with him grow attached and cannot bear to leave. Women who see him say to their parents, 'Rather than be another man’s wife, I would be his concubine'—there are more than ten such cases, and the number does not cease. He has never been heard to take the lead in speech, only to harmonize. He holds no lordly position to bring order to others, nor does he amass wealth to fill men’s bellies. Moreover, his ugliness startles all under heaven. He harmonizes but does not lead; his knowledge does not extend beyond the four quarters. Yet when male and female gather before him, there must be something extraordinary in this man. I summoned and observed him: indeed, his ugliness startled all under heaven. Yet after living with me for less than a month, I began to take notice of him. Before a year had passed, I trusted him. As my state had no chief minister, I wished to entrust him with governance. He responded with reluctance, as if declining, and I felt ashamed. In the end, I handed over the state to him. Before long, he left me and departed, and I felt as though I had lost something, as though there were no one with whom to share the joy of ruling this state. What manner of man is this?"

"An ugly man" refers to one whose form is repulsive. "He does not lead, only harmonizes" means he does nothing to assert himself. "He holds no lordly position" means he lacks noble authority. "Amasses wealth" refers to riches; "fills men’s bellies" means to satiate, to fill to the full—like the moon at its fullest, called *wang*. Observe how Zhuangzi wields his brush in such passages—who could match it? "His knowledge does not extend beyond the four quarters" means his understanding does not transcend the world. "Male and female gather before him" suggests his closeness with all things, akin to the idea of gulls that are not startled. "Responded with reluctance" means he answered without intent. *Fan* implies detachment, without attachment. "I felt ashamed" means I felt humiliated. "Handed over the state" means I entrusted him with governance. "Felt as though I had lost something" echoes the Han king’s lament, "like losing one’s right and left hands."

Confucius said: "When I was once sent on a mission to Chu, I happened to see young pigs nursing from their dead mother. After a little while, they glanced about, then all abandoned her and fled, for they no longer saw their mother in her. What they loved was not her form, but what animated her form. When warriors die in battle, their burials do not include funeral fans. When a man’s feet are cut off, no one cherishes his shoes—neither has any use for the other. This is because the root is gone. The consorts of the Son of Heaven do not cut their nails or pierce their ears. When a man takes a wife, she remains outside and is no longer employed in service. Even those with whole bodies are thus valued—how much more so those with whole virtue? Now Aitai Tuo has not spoken, yet he is trusted; he has done no deeds, yet he is beloved. He makes men offer him a state, only fearing he will not accept. This must be one whose talent is whole and whose virtue is unmanifest."

The analogy of the young pigs illustrates that love and aversion do not lie in the beauty or ugliness of form. *Shun ruo* describes their startled appearance. "No longer see their mother in her" means she no longer resembles her former self. *Yi shen* refers to her body, meaning they no longer see her as she was before, hence their reaction. These are all flourishes of Zhuangzi’s brush. The idea that "what they loved was what animated her form"—if judged by the standards of conventional morality, this statement would be gravely offensive. Yet it reflects the ancient principle of "serving the dead as one serves the living," not bearing to see one’s kin dead. Such passages are exaggerated in their expression; one must not judge them by such standards, nor remain ignorant of their intent.

"Warriors who die in battle do not use funeral fans"—this is not a proper ritual observance. *Sha* refers to the objects used. "A man whose feet are cut off has no use for shoes"—external adornments have no place here. This too illustrates the idea that virtue lies within, not without. "The consorts of the Son of Heaven do not cut their nails or pierce their ears"—they do not adorn themselves, preserving their natural form. "When a man takes a wife, she remains outside and is no longer employed in service"—this refers to the *Record of Rites*, which states that newly married women are exempt from service, meaning they are not to be employed in the palace. This analogy of preserving the whole form illustrates the meaning of whole virtue.

Duke Ai said: "What do you mean by 'talent whole'?"
Confucius said: "Life and death, existence and extinction, failure and success, poverty and wealth, worthiness and unworthiness, slander and praise, hunger and thirst, cold and heat—these are the changes of affairs, the movements of fate. They follow one another day and night before us, yet knowledge cannot fathom their beginnings. Therefore, they are not sufficient to disturb harmony or enter the sacred chamber of the mind. Make it so that one is harmonious, joyful, and flowing without losing the state of delight; make it so that day and night there is no interruption, and one joins with things in springtime. This is what it means to respond and give rise to the timely within the heart. This is called 'talent whole.'"

This passage culminates in the phrase "talent whole, virtue unmanifest." Earlier, it was said that even life and death, though great, do not cause one to change; here, it enumerates life and death, existence and extinction, failure and success, poverty and wealth, slander and praise, hunger and thirst, cold and heat—all together—to prevent any elaboration from exceeding the point. *Gui* means to seek. These are the changes of affairs and the movements of fate, succeeding one another day and night before our eyes. Even the wise cannot seek their beginnings; one can only say they occur naturally. "Not sufficient to disturb harmony" means they cannot disrupt the harmony within the breast. "Not enter the sacred chamber of the mind" means they do not move the heart. "Harmonious, joyful, flowing"—these three words share a single meaning: *yu* means joy, *tong* means unobstructed. If the heart is unmoved, it naturally becomes harmonious, joyful, and flowing without losing its delight. *Dui* also means delight. This sentence captures the essence of Zhuangzi’s writing—"harmonious, joyful, flowing" is akin to saying "all-pervading and complete," as seen in later passages. "Day and night without interruption" means ever-renewing, without cessation. *Que* means to stop. "Joins with things in springtime" means that wherever one dwells, there is joy. *Wu* refers to things. This "spring" is akin to *dui* (delight). "Respond and give rise to the timely within the heart" echoes the Buddhist sutras' "abiding nowhere yet giving rise to the heart." *Jie* means to be moved; *shi* means the timely, as in "timely action." Responding to the movements of affairs without bias or stagnation—this is called "giving rise to the timely within the heart." *Cai* means substance, as in Mencius' "Heaven bestows substance." "Talent whole" means preserving one’s innate nature in its entirety.

"What do you mean by 'virtue unmanifest'?"
"The level is the fullness of still water. It can serve as a model. Within, it is preserved, and without, it does not sway. Virtue is the cultivation of completed harmony. 'Virtue unmanifest' means things cannot depart from it."

Another day, Duke Ai told Minzi of this, saying: "Alas! I, facing south as the ruler of all under heaven, holding the people’s guiding principle, and worrying over their deaths, believed myself to be thoroughly enlightened. Now I have heard the words of a perfected man, and I fear I lack the substance. I have lightly used my person and nearly lost my state. I and Confucius are not ruler and subject—we are friends in virtue."

The phrase "virtue unmanifest" speaks of virtue having no visible form. When water is still, it becomes level; being level, it can serve as a model. A model is a standard. "Within, it is preserved" means stillness; "without, it does not sway" means cessation. This echoes the earlier reference to "gazing into still water." Below, the text shifts its phrasing: "harmony" refers to the harmony of the center; "completed" means wholeness. To wholly preserve the harmony within one’s nature is the cultivation of virtue. "Virtue unmanifest" follows things and appears in them, meaning there is nowhere it does not go and no single aspect by which it can be named. Thus, it is said, "Virtue unmanifest is what things cannot depart from."

The phrase "holding the people’s guiding principle" is excellent—it is precisely the handle of governing the state. "Worrying over their deaths" means the ability to cherish the people. How could Duke Ai truly "face south as the ruler of all under heaven"? These are all instances where Zhuangzi’s brush overreaches, failing to attend to proper bounds. "Not ruler and subject—friends in virtue" shares the same intent as Mencius’ "befriending," both being allegorical and not to be taken literally.

Yǐnqí, the hunchbacked man with no lips, spoke to Duke Ling of Wei, who delighted in him and, looking upon whole men, saw their necks as too thick. The man with a large goiter spoke to Duke Huan of Qi, who delighted in him and, looking upon whole men, saw their necks as too slender. Thus, virtue may excel while form is forgotten. People do not forget what they forget but forget what they should not forget—this is called "true forgetting."

Yǐnqí means a crooked back; *zhīlí* describes a stooped appearance; *wúshèn* means lipless. A hunched, lipless man is exceedingly ugly. *Jiānjiān* describes a slender, elongated appearance; *wèngfáng* refers to a large goiter. These two lines illustrate how people’s likes and dislikes lie beyond physical form: the hunchbacked and goitered men found favor with their lords, who, looking upon whole men, saw them as inferior. Thus, it is said, "virtue may excel while form is forgotten." People do not forget what they forget but forget what they should not forget. These two lines are superb, echoing Mencius’ analogy of "one finger being inferior to others." What can be forgotten is form; what cannot be forgotten is virtue. "True forgetting" is genuine forgetting—knowing form but not knowing virtue is true forgetting.

Therefore, the sage wanders in knowledge, yet it becomes a snare; in cleverness, yet it becomes glue; in virtue, yet it becomes a bond; in skill, yet it becomes trade. The sage does not scheme—why use knowledge? Does not carve—why use cleverness? Suffers no loss—why use virtue? Does not barter—why use skill? These four are the heavenly market.

The heavenly market.

The heavenly market is the heavenly sustenance. Having received sustenance from Heaven, why rely on man? The sage wanders—this wandering is what is meant by "the mind wandering in Heaven." *Zhi* (knowledge, pronounced in the falling tone) is using wisdom to handle affairs. *Yue* (restraint) is self-discipline through ritual. *Gong* (skill) is craftsmanship. *Nie* is calamity; *jiao* is glue, fixation. *Jie* is attachment to externals while forgetting the internal. *Shang* is trade, as in "buying reputation under Heaven." When the mind wanders in Heaven, one knows these four are all burdens. The sage schemes not in the world, so does not use wisdom; carves not, so does not need restraint; guards the internal and has no concern for externals, so does not rely on virtue; seeks not to sell, so does not employ skill. These four—no scheming, no carving, no loss, no bartering—are the heavenly market, the heavenly sustenance, the heavenly emolument. It is like the heavenly nobility: having received sustenance from Heaven, why seek human titles? The phrase "attachment gives rise to the times in one’s heart" means that when talent is whole and virtue does not manifest, the wisdom known by knowledge—all three characters in the earlier passage were good, but here "attachment" and "virtue" and "wisdom" become bad. This is the brush dancing, not heeding consistency before and after, which is why it is a heterodox text.

One has the form of man but not the passions of man. Having the form of man, one mingles with others; lacking the passions of man, right and wrong do not adhere to the self. How small—thus belonging to man! How great—thus completing one’s Heaven alone! Huizi asked Zhuangzi, "Do men truly have no passions?" Zhuangzi said, "Yes." Huizi said, "If a man has no passions, how can he be called a man?" Zhuangzi said, "The Dao gives him appearance, Heaven gives him form—how can he not be called a man?" Huizi said, "If he is called a man, how can he have no passions?" Zhuangzi said, "This is not what I mean by passions. What I mean by having no passions is that man does not inwardly harm his self with likes and dislikes, always following nature without artificially enhancing life." Huizi said, "If one does not enhance life, how can one have a self?" Zhuangzi said, "The Dao gives him appearance, Heaven gives him form—do not inwardly harm your self with likes and dislikes. Now you, your spirit is externalized, your essence is wearied. Leaning against a tree, you chant; resting on a withered catalpa, you doze. Heaven selected your form, yet you cry out with ‘hard and white’—this is mere disputation."

This passage is Zhuangzi’s dialogue with Huizi. The lines beginning "One has the form of man" are Zhuangzi’s usual words, which Huizi then questioned. "Mingling with others" means being in the same flock as men. "Right and wrong do not adhere to the self" means there is no entry that does not bring self-possession, transcending right and wrong, alone completing one’s Heaven and becoming Heaven’s companion. If man can be external to right and wrong, with no entry that does not bring self-possession, then he becomes Heaven’s companion, and his achievement is great. "Heaven gives him form" is having a thing. "The Dao gives him appearance" means things must have their principles. What I mean by "having no passions" is that man does not inwardly harm his self with the passions of likes and dislikes. If there is enhancement, there is harm; if one always follows nature, there is neither enhancement nor harm. To speak of excess and deficiency is to speak of illness—enhancing life is the illness of excess. If likes and dislikes arise from nature and do not cling, then there is neither harm nor enhancement. Huizi said, "If one does not enhance life, how can one have a self?"—this takes enhancing life as the means to sustain life, which is not Zhuangzi’s intent. Zhuangzi and Huizi were the closest of friends; Huizi was broadly learned and fond of debate, so Zhuangzi mocked him for externalizing his spirit and wearying his essence. "Externalizing the spirit" means the spirit is used externally, like a spirit not guarding its abode. *Gaowu* is a withered catalpa used as a table. *Ming* means weariness. *Jianbai* is the name of a debate. *Xuan* means selection, appointment. It says: Heaven bestowed your form, yet you torment yourself thus—why? Just for one "cry" of disputation, Han Yu drew from this to compose a preface, praising its marvel. How could Zhuangzi not be a master of writing?

*Zhuangzi Kouyi*, Scroll 2

**Inner Chapters: The Great and Venerable Master (Chapter Six)**

"The Great and Venerable Master" is the Dao—just as the sage emulates Heaven, Heaven emulates the Dao, and the Dao emulates spontaneity. To know what Heaven does and to know what man does is perfection.

To know what Heaven does is to be Heaven-born. To know what man does is to use what one’s knowledge knows to nourish what one’s knowledge does not know, thus fulfilling one’s natural lifespan without dying prematurely midway—this is the fullness of knowledge.

Yet there is a danger: knowledge depends on something external to be fitting, but what it depends on is inherently uncertain. How can we be sure that what I call "Heaven" is not "man," or that what I call "man" is not "Heaven"? Only with the true person does true knowledge arise.

Man’s life arises from Heaven, hence it is said: "what Heaven does." Yet dwelling in the world, there are human affairs one must fulfill, hence it is said: "what man does." When human affairs are complete, Heavenly principle appears. Thus, one uses what one’s knowledge knows to nourish what one’s knowledge does not know. Not exhausting oneself to harm life, it is said: "fulfilling one’s natural lifespan." Knowing both Heaven and man, it is said: "the fullness of knowledge."

These words are quite correct, yet the turn beginning with "though there is a danger" is especially subtle. "Knowledge depends on something external to be fitting"—knowledge resides in me, but what it depends on lies outside. Sometimes one attains without seeking, sometimes one must seek to attain—neither can be determined in advance. "Fitting" means both "certain" and "appropriate." Only after a matter is settled does its appropriateness or inappropriateness become clear. This single word is used with great skill. If one believes something comes from Heaven yet must seek to obtain it, or if one believes it comes from man yet sometimes seeks in vain, this is what is meant by "how can we be sure that Heaven is not man, or man is not Heaven?"

For example, longevity and premature death are both fated—nothing is not destiny. Yet it is also said: "Those who know destiny do not stand beneath a crumbling wall." Here we see the uncertainty in what Heaven does and what man does. Zhuangzi’s observation of worldly affairs is most precise; such passages demand careful reflection.

"Only with the true person does true knowledge arise"—this speaks of one who embodies the Dao.

What is a true person? The true persons of old did not resist the few, did not boast of their accomplishments, and did not scheme. If they erred, they did not regret; if they succeeded, they did not take pride. If they ascended heights, they did not tremble; if they entered water, they were not drenched; if they entered fire, they were not burned. Such is the knowledge that ascends to the Dao.

"Not resist the few"—lack is not a deficiency; it means not opposing the natural course. When times are insufficient, one simply follows them. "Did not boast of their accomplishments"—though they succeeded, they did not take it as a boast. *Xiong* means boasting. *Shi* (士) is interchangeable with *shi* (事), as in the *Ode to Dongshan*: "Do not *shi* the marching ranks." *Mo* means scheming—acting without intention, hence "did not scheme." "If they erred, they did not regret"—*guo* means error, like today’s "misstep." "If they succeeded, they did not take pride"—*dang* means fitting, like today’s "just right." Success is not taken as self-satisfaction. Whether things went wrong or right, all was entrusted to spontaneity: not regretting failure, not rejoicing in success.

"Ascended heights without trembling, entered water without being drenched, entered fire without being burned"—this is to be unobstructed in all situations. "Knowledge that ascends to the Dao"—their insight deeply penetrated the Dao. The two "if so" phrases demonstrate Zhuangzi’s literary style. *Zhi* is interchangeable with *zhi* (wisdom). *Jia* means to reach.

The true persons of old slept without dreaming and woke without worry. Their food was not savory, and their breath was deep. The true person’s breath reaches the heels, while the common person’s breath reaches only the throat. Those who submit in fear have throats that sound like retching; those with deep desires have shallow Heavenly mechanism.

Their sleep was dreamless—spirit settled.

The so-called "true person is dreamless"—this is what it means. "Their waking is without worry"—they engage with the world yet do not contend with the heart-mind. "Their food is not savory"—they have no intent to sate hunger, akin to the Chan practice of "filling the hunger wound." "Their breath is deep"—the true person’s breath reaches the heels, while the common person’s reaches only the throat. This is the origin of Daoist cultivation discourse. When the spirit is settled, the breath in its egress and ingress is deep, rising from the heels to the mouth and nose—hence the method of *shuxi* (breath-counting). Without nurturing the spirit, the breath in its egress and ingress halts at the throat alone. Stillness and agitation differ, and what manifests in the body is seen as retching. *Ai* (嗌) means the throat; *yan* (咽) means to swallow. Without true insight, speech remains on the lips, making one easily submissive to others. This line reveals the flavor of Zhuangzi’s words, as in the Chan saying: "The frog Chan leaps but once"—just as retching is easily subdued. "Desires" are human desires; "Heavenly mechanism" is Heavenly principle. "Deep and shallow" refer to the waxing and waning of Heavenly principle and human desire, as the ancients put it. This passage, line by line, is a thread running through Daoist and Buddhist texts alike, showing how this elder’s self-attainment cannot be read carelessly. Alas, we do not see Dahui, Zhang Pingshu, or others debate this with him.

The true persons of old neither delighted in life nor abhorred death. They emerged without precaution and entered without resistance, departing with ease and arriving with ease. They did not forget their origin nor seek their end. They received and rejoiced in it, forgot and returned to it—this is called "not using the heart-mind to harm the Dao" and "not relying on others to assist Heaven." This is the true person. This passage speaks only of life and death: emerging from life, entering death. "Departing with ease and arriving with ease"—not forgetting the origin, not seeking the end—this is what is meant by "tracing the beginning to grasp the end, thus knowing the discourse on life and death." Someone asked Master Zhaozhou, "Where will you go after a hundred years?" He replied, "After the fire burns out, it becomes a stalk of thatch"—this is not seeking the end. "Receiving"—receiving one’s form, bestowed by Heaven—how could one not rejoice? "Returning"—returning whole, without attachment—hence "forgetting and returning." "Not using the heart-mind to harm the Dao" means the heart-mind *is* the Dao; there is no Dao outside the heart-mind. "Not relying on others to assist Heaven" means longevity and early death are fated; human effort cannot add to it. These ten words deserve careful reading. "Not harming" means not departing from it even for a moment.

If so, their heart-mind is steadfast, their countenance serene, their brow prominent. They are chill like autumn, warm like spring. Joy and anger flow with the four seasons, harmonizing with things without fixed limit. *Zhi* (志) means having a settled intent. The meaning of words in this text cannot be sought through the methods of the *Analects* or *Mencius*. The ancients said: "Buddhism speaks of nature but only addresses the heart-mind—since it is already heterodox, how can we seek the meaning of words in our texts through it?" "Serene"—like the nineteen years of facing the wall. This is the serenity of their countenance. *Kui* (頯) means large; *sang* (颡) means the forehead. Their head is held upright, revealing their prominent brow. "Chill" is anger; "warm" is joy. Joy and anger arise without intent, like the seasons of spring and autumn. "Limit" means the point of cessation. "Things" means affairs. They respond to affairs, each fitting its measure, without a fixed place of cessation—this is what is meant by "engaging with things to give rise to the times of the heart-mind."

Thus, when the sage employs troops, he may destroy a state yet not lose the people’s hearts. His beneficence extends to ten thousand generations, yet he is not called loving. Employing troops poisons the world; bestowing beneficence loves the world—both are enacted without intent. Thus, those whose states are destroyed do not resent him, and those who receive his virtue say, "What has the Emperor’s power to do with me?" Our texts also contain this idea, but Zhuangzi’s brush, in its vivid portrayal, goes too far. For example, "beneficence extending to ten thousand generations yet not called benevolent" and "governing the myriad things yet not called righteous"—all belong to this vein.

Therefore, one who delights in harmonizing with things is not a sage; one who has partiality is not benevolent; one who follows the seasons is not worthy; one who does not penetrate profit and harm is not a gentleman; one who acts for fame loses the self and is not a scholar; one who destroys the self is not true and is not a servant of others. Those like Huxie, Wuguang, Boyi, Shuqi, Jizi, Wu Xuyu, Ji Ta, Shentu Di—these are servants of others, conforming to others’ ways and not attaining their own. This passage satirizes the sages and worthies to illustrate the unattainability of the true person. Its meaning is that in a world without true persons, none from the sages downward—great or small—are genuine.

"Delighting in harmonizing with things"—the sage’s heart-mind takes joy in nothing not finding its place. To be content with things’ prosperity or decline and take joy in this is insufficient to be a sage. Without intent, there is no near or far; with near and far, there is intent. With intent, it is not benevolence. "Following the seasons"—acting in accord with the times—is what the worthy take as ability, yet it is not. "Penetrating profit and avoiding harm"—the gentleman can do this, but if he cannot unite profit and harm as one, he is still not a gentleman. The scholar must act for fame; fame is the guest of reality. To act for the guest is to lose the self—hence, not a scholar. "True" means natural. Not knowing the natural and laboring to destroy the self is to be enslaved by others, not to enslave others. These are all excessive arguments. Thus, from Huxie downward—like Boyi, Shuqi, and Jizi—all are mocked as enslaved by others and losing the self. Hence, "not attaining their own way." Though the words are biased, the writing is marvelous. Huxie, Wuguang, Xuyu, Ji Ta, and Shentu Di were all worthies of old who did not attain their own way.

The true persons of old had a demeanor of righteousness yet no cliques, appearing insufficient yet not obsequious. Their edges were sharp yet not rigid, their vastness empty yet not ostentatious. Cheerful, as if pleased; towering, as if compelled; expansive, offering their countenance; yielding, halting their virtue. Stern, as if worldly; aloof, as if uncontrollable; boundless, as if fond of seclusion; forgetful, as if losing their words. They took punishment as their body, ritual as their wings, wisdom as their time, virtue as their path. Taking punishment as their body—they were lenient in their severity. Taking ritual as their wings—they used it to move through the world. Taking wisdom as their time—they acted when unavoidable. Taking virtue as their path—they spoke of it as having feet, reaching the hills, yet others truly took them as diligent practitioners.

This passage of metaphorical description contains moments of warmth and purity, yet its expressions are too vast and boundless—such depictions abound in Buddhist texts.

"Virtuous yet not cliquish" means standing alone without leaning to either side. "Cheerful, as if insufficient yet not obsequious"—*kànrán* suggests a sense of inadequacy without self-debasement; *chéng* in *Zuǒzhuàn* means "to assist," here denoting compliance with a humble demeanor. *Yúhū* describes a leisurely bearing. *Gū* refers to the corners of virtue. "Sharp yet not rigid" means possessing the edges of virtue without harsh angles. *Zhānghū* conveys an expansive, unconstrained appearance. "Empty" means having the substance of nothingness; "not ostentatious" means being substantial. *Bǐngbǐng* describes a joyful countenance, seeming pleased yet not truly so. *Cuīhū* implies an unavoidable response to worldly affairs, much like acting only after hesitation. *Chùhū* means to gather or accumulate, describing a flourishing, radiant presence—its vitality manifesting in one’s countenance, hence "offering their countenance." "Halting their virtue" refers to the auspicious stillness of an empty chamber, where stillness itself is the stopping point. *Yúhū* conveys a self-contented demeanor. "Stern" suggests solemn resolve, appearing worldly in its severity, yet within lies the unavoidable truth of *cuīhū*. Thus, it is said to resemble the world. *Áohū* implies grandeur, unyielding to worldly constraints, hence "uncontrollable." "Fond of seclusion" means reluctance to speak; *liánhū* suggests closeness and secrecy. Before speaking, one seems unwilling to utter a word; after speaking, it is as if nothing was said—hence "forgetful, as if losing their words." These two phrases convey a single idea: *mèn* describes a lowered, humble posture.

"Taking punishment as their body"—the body is the foundation; "wings" are attachments. The sage says, "Understand the five punishments to assist the five teachings," while here it is framed inversely: punishment as the root, ritual as the adjunct. *Chuòhū* describes leniency in severity, ensuring no discord with one’s heart. "Moving through the world" means using ritual to navigate custom. "Time" refers to employing wisdom—acting only when unavoidable in response to affairs.
