May I ask how to cultivate the body so that it may endure for long?"

Guangchengzi rose abruptly and said: "Excellent question! Come, I will tell you of the utmost Dao. The essence of the utmost Dao is profound and distant; the ultimate of the utmost Dao is dark and silent. See nothing, hear nothing, know nothing—your spirit will guard your form, and your form will endure long. It is not called 'ordering the world' but 'cultivating the body,' and thus I consider it an excellent question. '窈窈冥冥' means distant and unfathomable; '昏昏默默' means obscure and invisible. '无视无听' means forgetting both ears and eyes."

The spirit abiding in the heart is called "embracing stillness and non-action," and the form will naturally align. The spirit must be pure and still; the form must not be wearied, nor the qi disturbed—only then can one attain long life. All arts of cultivation and refinement originate from this. Whether immortals or buddhas, they have always existed since ancient times; this is not a teaching invented by Zhuangzi.

"Without toil, without disturbance"—this "without" is akin to "do not," conveying a prohibitive sense. "Eyes seeing nothing, ears hearing nothing, the heart knowing nothing" further explains "seeing nothing, hearing nothing." "Embracing the spirit in stillness"—when the spirit guards the form, one may attain long life. This "spirit" is what modern practitioners of self-cultivation call the "infant."

"Be cautious within, close yourself without." Excessive knowledge leads to ruin. I have led you to the source of great brightness, the origin of utmost yang. I have guided you into the gate of the profound and distant, the origin of utmost yin. Heaven and earth have their offices; yin and yang have their repositories. Guard your body carefully, and things will naturally flourish. I preserve the One and dwell in harmony. Thus, I have cultivated my body for one thousand two hundred years, yet my form has never declined.

"Be cautious within"—do not let the heart be moved. "Close yourself without"—do not allow external things to disturb your heart. Any excess of knowledge becomes a burden. Only when one knows nothing does virtue remain whole; thus, it is said that excessive knowledge leads to ruin.

The beginning of utmost yang is great brightness; the beginning of utmost yin is the profound and distant. "Origin" means beginning. "Above great brightness" is above the great void; "the gate of the profound and distant" is the inception of the boundless. The *Yijing* speaks of "the Dao of one yin and one yang"—this is the same principle. However, its expression is more reserved, while Zhuangzi’s words are more forthright. "For you" means "to teach you"; "led you" means "guided you," akin to "proceeded."

Entering the ultimate—this means desiring to teach you to reach this extremity. The offices and repositories are the organs and viscera. This speaks of how the human body itself possesses heaven and earth, yin and yang. When my heaven and earth each fulfill their offices, when my yin and yang each reside in their proper places, then this body may be guarded with care, and all things will naturally become firm. "Things" refers to all that belongs to this body. Thus it is said, "Things will naturally strengthen themselves." What is guarded is the One, without admixture; what is dwelled in is nothing that is not harmonious and compliant. This is why, though my form has endured for one thousand two hundred years, it has never declined.

"To dwell" means to engage with affairs and things, to respond when stimulated. Heaven and earth are the vigor and compliance of this body. The Yellow Emperor bowed twice, touching his forehead to the ground, and said, "What you speak of, Master Vast Accomplishment, is truly heaven!" Master Vast Accomplishment said, "Come, let me tell you: those things are without end, yet people all take them to be finite; those things are unfathomable, yet people all take them to be limited. Those who attain my Dao become emperors above and kings below; those who lose my Dao appear as light above and become earth below. Now, the hundred flourishing things all arise from earth and return to earth. Thus, I shall leave you and enter the gate of the boundless, to wander in the wilds of the infinite. I share the radiance of the sun and moon, I am constant with heaven and earth. When I coil myself, I am distant; when I obscure myself, I vanish from men. Will they all perish while I alone endure?"

"Master Vast Accomplishment’s words are heaven" means that he may unite with heaven as one. How could things have an end when people insist on seeking their termination? How could things be fathomed when people insist on seeking their limits? Thus, the bounded follows the boundless. These two lines are profoundly meaningful. Spoken crudely, it is like forging iron to make a threshold—when struck, it elicits laughter, yet this is the same idea. The *Yijing* does not end with *Jiji* (Completion) but with *Weiji* (Incompletion), for it knows that things are without end and without measure. When Confucius stood by the river and said, "What passes is like this," he too pointed to their boundlessness and unfathomability.

Above, one may become an emperor; below, one may become a king. These terms "emperor" and "king" refer to the perfection of inner sageliness and outer kingship, as in the chapter "Under Heaven." The emperor embodies non-action; the king embodies action. This is not the Three Sovereigns or the kings of the Three Dynasties. "Appearing as light above" refers to the sun and moon; "becoming earth below" refers to the ground.

Dwelling between heaven and earth, one is muddled and without knowledge—looking up, one sees only the sun and moon; looking down, one sees only the earth below. The hundred flourishing things and the hundred creatures are born from the soil and return to the soil; leaves fall and roots are restored. The putrid transforms into the wondrous, and the wondrous transforms into the putrid—this is the meaning of "depart from you," the meaning of leaving the human realm. The "Gate of the Boundless" and the "Wilderness of the Limitless" refer to what lies beyond heaven and earth.

One may endure as long as the sun, moon, heaven, and earth, thus it is said: "Sharing the light of the sun and moon, becoming constant with heaven and earth." *Mín* is akin to *fáng*, meaning dim and obscure. "Those that encounter me" come toward me; "those that distance themselves from me" turn away from me. The coming and going of things, I remain oblivious and unknowing—thus it is said: "Those that encounter me are dim; those that distance themselves from me are obscure."

Cloud General was roaming eastward when he passed the branch of the *Fuyao* tree and happened upon Hong Hu. Hong Hu was just then slapping his thighs and leaping about in play. Cloud General, seeing him, halted in astonishment and stood motionless, saying: "Old sir, who are you? Old sir, what are you doing?" Hong Hu continued slapping his thighs and leaping without pause. Cloud General said: "I wander." Cloud General said: "I wish to ask you something." Hong Hu looked up at Cloud General and said: "Hmm?" Cloud General said: "The qi of heaven is disharmonious; the qi of earth is pent up. The six qi are out of balance; the four seasons are disordered. Now I wish to blend the essence of the six qi to nurture the multitude of beings. How might this be done?" Hong Hu slapped his thighs, leaped, and shook his head, saying: "I do not know. I do not know." Cloud General could not press his question.

Three years later, Cloud General roamed eastward again and passed through the wilds of Song, where he once more happened upon Hong Hu. Cloud General rejoiced greatly, hastened forward, and said: "Has Heaven forgotten me? Has Heaven forgotten me?" He bowed twice, touching his head to the ground, and wished to ask Hong Hu a question. Hong Hu said: "I drift without knowing what I seek; I roam wildly without knowing where I go. Wandering, I am careworn, observing the unanticipated. What do I know?" Cloud General said: "I too believed myself to be roaming wildly, yet the people follow wherever I go. I cannot escape the people—now they have become my undoing. I wish to hear a single word from you."

Hong Hu said: "You disrupt the warp of heaven and contravene the nature of things. Heaven’s mystery cannot be completed. You dissolve the herds of beasts, and the birds all cry out at night. Disaster befalls the grasses and trees; calamity reaches even the insects. Alas! This is the error of governing men."

The branch of the *Fuyao* tree is the *Fusang*, the place where the sun rises. *Fǔ bì jué yuè* describes his joyful leaping. *Tǎngrán* depicts his sudden loss of composure; *pīrán* depicts his towering stillness. *Sǒu* refers to Hong Hu.

When Zhaozhou met Touzi returning from buying oil, he said: "I have long heard of Touzi—today I see only an oil-buying old man." Touzi replied: "Oil, oil—just look." In Chan, this matter is thus revealed. Cloud General said "wander" (*yóu*), which is Zhuangzi’s way of describing animation. The character for "oil" (*yóu*) differs from "wander" (*yóu*), and is not to be taken as the same. Without pause, he replied: "I wander." Looking up, he said: "Hmm?" The question of nurturing the multitude of beings is the same as the question the Yellow Emperor once posed. *Diào tóu* means to shake one’s head. "Has Heaven forgotten me?"—*zhèn* means "I." He calls Hong Hu "Heaven," saying: "We met once before—do you still remember? How could you have forgotten?" *Fúyóu* means to roam about; *chāngkuáng* means unrestrained and unbridled. "Without knowing what I seek" means having no aim.

"‘Not knowing whither to go’ means having no destination. *Yāngzhǎng fēngǔ* means being overwhelmed and confused. *Wúwàng* is authenticity. Roaming amid a world overwhelmed and confused, one yet observes one’s own authenticity—this is unavoidable in speaking to the people. One wishes to refuse and sever such speech, yet cannot. *Fàng xiào* means to imitate. The people take me as their model. The constant principles of Heaven and the true nature of things are all simply spontaneous. Now, if one acts with intention, this is to disrupt and invert their spontaneity. How can one achieve the transformation of spontaneity? Thus it is said: ‘The mysterious Heaven does not complete’—*xū* means emptiness, akin to ‘prior to Heaven.’ When beasts gather in herds without contention, there is no distinction of ‘you’ and ‘me,’ no division of ‘same’ and ‘different.’ Now, if each departs from its herd, this is to create ‘you and me,’ ‘same and different.’ When birds all cry out at night, it is alarm. If one cannot assist things in preserving their spontaneity, causing them to lose their nature, then grasses, trees, and insects all suffer harm. All this begins with the intention to govern others—just as previously stated, the fault lies in disturbing the human heart."

Cloud General said: "Then what am I to do?"
Hong Hu replied: "Ah! Poisonous indeed! Float away, float away—return!"
Cloud General said: "I have encountered a Heaven-sent difficulty. I wish to hear a single word."
Hong Hu said: "Ah! Nurture your heart-mind. Dwell in solitude, practice non-action, and things will transform of themselves. Cast off your bodily form, expel your cleverness, forget all distinctions, and merge with the great sameness of the primordial vastness. Dissolve your heart-mind, release your spirit, and be utterly without soul. The ten thousand things, teeming and swarming, each return to their root. Each returns to their root yet does not know it—profoundly muddled, they pass their lives without departure. If they knew it, this would already be departure. Do not inquire into their names, do not pry into their natures. Things arise of themselves."

Cloud General said: "Heaven has bestowed virtue upon me and shown me silence. I have sought it in my person, and only now have I attained it." He bowed twice, touched his head to the ground, rose, took his leave, and departed.

"Then what am I to do?" means: now that it is thus, how can it be made right? "Poisonous indeed!"

The phrase "Alas, bitter! Alas, bitter!" is indeed what the stone-head master meant. "Swiftly departing" describes how you, having already poisoned and tormented yourself, should hasten away without further inquiry. This fabricated dialogue resembles the exchanges in the *Lamp Records*. "Nurturing the heart-mind" means that when you cease to nourish this heart-mind, it is already nurtured—it is not called "nurturing the heart-mind" but "heart-mind nurturing," and one must discern this carefully. "Merely" means you should simply abide in non-action, and things will transform of themselves. "Transform" implies the ceaseless coming and going, the self-arising and self-transforming of things. Discard all your former cleverness and leave none of it behind. "Align and merge" means to sink and dissolve, forgetting both self and things, thus merging with the great sameness of the primordial vastness. "Primordial vastness" is formless and traceless, the state before qi arose. "Dissolve the heart-mind" means to dissolve the heart-mind that possesses a heart-mind. "Release the spirit" means to release the spirit that possesses knowledge. "Utterly still" means to settle. "Without soul" means without knowledge. Essence is called *po*; spirit is called *hun*. "Without soul" echoes the earlier phrase "lump-like, standing by its form alone." The heart-mind in "dissolving the heart-mind" differs from that in "nurturing the heart-mind," just as the spirit in "releasing the spirit" differs from that in "embracing the spirit to attain stillness." These terms require careful reflection.

"Teeming and swarming" describes their multitude. Each returns to its root, for what is born must perish. Though it perishes, it does not truly perish, for what perishes is reborn. Thus, each returns to its root yet does not know it—profoundly muddled, without knowledge or awareness, this is the state of *hundun*. In *hundun*, one passes one’s life without departing from the Dao. But if one possesses knowledge and awareness, one becomes divided from the Dao. Thus, "if they knew it, this would already be departure." This line is most precise and demands close attention. "Name" refers to all distinctions; "nature" refers to likes and dislikes. "Pry" means to perceive. Without inquiry or perception, there are no distinctions, no likes or dislikes—this is non-action and spontaneity. If I can embody non-action and spontaneity, then each thing follows its own nature, for this is its inherent condition. Thus, "things arise of themselves." "Inherent" means naturally so.

"Bestowed" means granted to me. "Silence" means non-speech. Heaven granted me the virtue of spontaneity and revealed to me the principle of non-speech. Seeking it within myself, I have now attained it—this is personal realization. "Within myself" means that by seeking within my own person, I have obtained what I sought. Thereupon, he bowed, expressed his gratitude, and departed.

Ordinary people delight in those who agree with them and resent those who differ. They desire agreement and reject difference, for their hearts are set on standing out from the crowd. Yet how can one who sets his heart on standing out ever truly stand out? Relying on the crowd for comfort, his knowledge does not surpass theirs. Yet he desires to govern a state—this is grasping at the benefits of the Three Kings while blind to the perils. To govern a state with such intentions is to rely on luck. How often can one rely on luck without losing the state? The odds of preserving it are less than one in ten thousand, while the odds of losing it are more than ten thousand to one. How lamentable that those who possess lands do not understand this!

From this point to the end of the chapter, Zhuangzi expounds further: desiring others to agree with oneself and resenting their differences is to place oneself above the multitude. Insisting that others conform to one’s own views before feeling at ease, how is one different from the crowd? Though one may wish to stand out, how can one do so? If one claims unique insight, it must be that no one else understands—yet if one desires everyone to agree, then one’s skills are no greater than the multitude’s. Laozi said, "If those who know me are few, then I am noble." Zhuangzi here echoes this sentiment, much like Han Tuizhi’s discussion of literature, which also reflects this idea. With such a mindset, one seeks to govern a state, grasping at the benefits of the Three Kings while blind to the inevitable harm. To govern a state with such intentions is to rely on luck. With luck as one’s aim, one sees only ruin and no success. How can those who possess lands fail to recognize the deception of such men?

Those who possess lands possess great things. Those who possess great things cannot be possessed by things, yet they can master things. Only by mastering things can one perceive the error of those who are mastered by things. How could this apply merely to governing the world and its people? They move in and out of the six directions, roam the nine provinces, coming and going alone—this is called "possessing singularity." Those who possess singularity are called "the most noble."

Those who are mastered by things have intentions and traces; those who are not mastered by things act without acting, spontaneously and naturally. Without acting, there is nothing they do not do. Thus, "not mastered by things, they can master things." If one knows the thing that masters things, how could this apply merely to governing the world? Thus, "they move in and out of the six directions, roam the nine provinces." This speaks of the Dao transcending the myriad things. They move freely within creation, merging with Heaven as one—no one can divide them. Thus, "coming and going alone is called possessing singularity." Such is the most noble.

The teachings of the great person are like the shadow following the form, the echo responding to the sound. When questioned, they respond fully, expressing all they hold within, matching the world as its counterpart. They dwell where there is no echo, move where there is no path. They lead you to return to the restless realm, wandering without beginning or end, entering and exiting without boundary, sharing no origin with the sun. They chant and discourse on the body, merging with the great sameness. In the great sameness, there is no self—how could there be possession? Those who perceive possession are the gentlemen of old; those who perceive non-possession are friends of Heaven and Earth.

The great person is the perfected person, the one who possesses singularity. Form must have shadow; sound must have echo—this is spontaneity. When questioned, they respond fully, expressing all they hold within. This is to face the world alone, bearing its vastness with one’s person. I am the host; the counterpart is the guest. Without echo, without sound, without scent, without trace. "Restless" describes ceaseless activity. "To return" is to go. "Lead" means to guide. "You" refers to all in the world. "Return" means to go back. They guide all in the world to return to the restless realm, meaning that though they transcend the world, they do not depart from it—transcendence and worldliness are not two separate dharmas. "Without beginning" means without origin.

The boundless extends in all four directions—no limits in any quarter. Moving in and out, roaming freely within, day after day, one sees no end, nor can one know the beginning. Thus it is said: "With the sun, without beginning." To speak of the physical form is to praise it—harmonizing within Heaven and Earth, all share this same body. Thus it is said: "Harmonizing," a great ode of praise. Since my body is one with the myriad things, it cannot be selfish—this is the absence of self. Having no self, what then is "having"? It is just as Pang the Layman said: "Empty all that is present; do not substantiate what is absent."

The ancients, the noble ones, saw only the "having" and became friends with Heaven and Earth. Yet only when they saw the "without" did they truly see. When they spoke of "the ancients, the noble ones," from Yao and Shun downward, all were included. That which is base yet cannot be shunned is *things*. That which is lowly yet cannot be forsaken is *the people*. That which is hidden yet cannot be avoided is *affairs*. That which is coarse yet cannot be discarded is *laws*. That which is distant yet cannot be abandoned is *righteousness*. That which is intimate yet cannot be narrowed is *benevolence*. That which is regulated yet cannot be neglected is *ritual*. That which is centered yet cannot be lowered is *virtue*. That which is unified yet cannot be fixed is the *Dao*. That which is numinous yet cannot be left undone is *Heaven*.

Observing this passage, one sees that Master Zhuang still engages with worldly affairs—he does not merely discourse on emptiness and nothingness. Cheng Yi’s remark that the Buddhists have *shangda* (ascending understanding) but lack *xiaxue* (descending learning) is most apt. Yet even in these few lines, there are points akin to *xiaxue*, and an intent that the refined and the coarse are inseparable. If the Dao is esteemed, then things are deemed base—yet how can one abandon things? Thus it is said: "That which is base yet cannot be shunned is *things*"—*ren* (任) means to employ. If the Dao is exalted, then what resides in people is lowly—yet how can one stand apart from people? Thus it is said: "That which is lowly yet cannot be forsaken is *the people*"—*yin* (因) means to rely upon. *Ni* (匿) means concealment, obscurity. The Dao is clarity, but when contrasted with affairs, affairs become obscure—yet how can one entirely forsake worldly affairs? Thus it is said: "That which is hidden yet cannot be avoided is *affairs*." The Dao is the refined; laws are the coarse—yet how can laws be entirely discarded? Thus it is said: "That which is coarse yet cannot be discarded is *laws*." Righteousness is distant from the Dao—yet how can righteousness be abandoned? Thus it is said: "That which is distant yet cannot be abandoned is *righteousness*." The Dao is without partiality, while benevolence entails affection. Though not the ultimate Dao, how can benevolence be forsaken? It must be extended broadly. Thus it is said: "That which is intimate yet cannot be narrowed is *benevolence*." Ritual involves regulation and ornamentation, seeming forced—yet it cannot be neglected. Thus it is said: "That which is regulated yet cannot be neglected is *ritual*." The rituals number three hundred, the deportments three thousand—how could these be accomplished by one person in a single day? Thus it is said: "Accumulate"—virtue is what all people share. Though one may harmonize with the world, there are places where one must stand apart—how can one be the same as others? Thus it is said: "That which is centered yet cannot be lowered is *virtue*"—*zhong* (中) means harmony. That which is unified in spontaneity is the Dao—yet there are times when change is necessary. How can one cling to oneness without transformation? Thus it is said: "That which is unified yet cannot be fixed is the *Dao*." The numinous is that which cannot be known—Heaven’s works are all unknowable. Yet human affairs cannot be left undone—how can one entirely entrust them to the unknowable? Thus it is said: "That which is numinous yet cannot be left undone is *Heaven*."

Therefore, the sage observes Heaven yet does not assist its completion; embodies virtue yet is not burdened; emerges from the Dao yet does not scheme; guards benevolence yet does not rely upon it; values righteousness yet does not accumulate it; responds to ritual yet does not conceal; engages with affairs yet does not yield; aligns with laws yet is not disordered; depends upon the people yet does not slight them; relies upon things yet does not abandon them. Things are not worth doing—yet they cannot be left undone.

Not assisting means not forcing effort. What lies in people cannot be left undone, yet when viewed through the eye of the Dao, though one acts, no effort is forced. Thus it is said: "Observes Heaven yet does not assist"—this *zhu* (助) is the same as in "assisting growth." Not being burdened means not piling up to achieve height. To pile up in order to be high is to harbor intention, which is not spontaneous—*lei* (累) is pronounced like *lei* (垒). Not scheming means having no calculating mind. Not relying means not considering it a personal favor. *Hui* (会) means gathering; *ji* (积) means accumulation that does not transform. Without accumulation, there is transformation. *Bo* (薄) means pressing, near. Though one’s conduct may be near to righteousness, one does not consider it one’s own—if one gathers righteousness, it does not transform. Not concealing means not being constrained by taboos. *Ying* (应) means responding. Bound by ritual forms, one has things to conceal and avoid. What can be done is done, responding to affairs as they arise. Thus it is said: "Responds to ritual yet does not conceal." *Rang* (让) means yielding, retreating. In engaging with affairs, one acts directly without retreating. Thus it is said: "Engages with affairs yet does not yield." Using laws to align things, though amidst complexity, there is a sense of simplicity and directness. Thus it is said: "Aligns with laws yet is not disordered." Though the people may be relied upon, one does not slight them. Though things may be employed, one does not abandon the root to pursue the branches.

From the above lines, all has been exhausted—yet once more, the word *thing* is raised: "Things are not worth doing, yet they cannot be left undone." This *thing* encompasses both the refined—where the Dao resides—and the coarse—where things reside. All affairs and all things are included within. If viewed through the mind of the Dao, none are worth doing—yet there are things that cannot be left undone, which is where the human mind resides. Observing this line, how could Master Zhuang not understand the principle that the refined and the coarse are one?

It is further said: "One who does not understand Heaven is not pure in virtue." Though worldly affairs cannot be left undone, one must know the principle of spontaneity—otherwise, the virtue within oneself is not unified. "Not penetrating the Dao" is the same as not understanding Heaven. "Having no path that is not obstructed" means there is no way forward without hindrance. The earlier statement, "not understanding Heaven, not penetrating the Dao," culminates here in "not understanding the Dao"—thus it is clear that "not understanding Heaven" and "not penetrating the Dao" are but a single idea.

What is the Dao? There is the Dao of Heaven and the Dao of humans. The Dao of Heaven is honored through non-action; the Dao of humans is burdened by action. The ruler follows the Dao of Heaven; the minister follows the Dao of humans. The Dao of Heaven and the Dao of humans are far apart—this cannot go unexamined.

This dual path is most wondrous and most intimately bound to learning, yet readers often overlook it without deep inquiry. "Honored through non-action" is the spontaneity of Heaven’s Dao; "burdened by action" is the inescapable necessity of the human Dao. The former pertains to the mind of Dao; the latter, to the human mind. This single word "burden" nearly approaches the meaning of "peril." The ruler, following Heaven’s Dao, takes the mind of Dao as master; the minister, following the human Dao, makes the human mind obey. These terms "ruler" and "minister" do not refer to courtly ranks—readers who take them as such have long been mistaken. They denote the sovereign and subject within the self. *The Equality of Things* says, "Do they not take turns as ruler and minister?" There is a true sovereign abiding within—this is how it should be understood.

The writings of Zhuangzi generally esteem non-action and disdain action. Having already explained that "matters requiring action cannot be left undone," he now fears readers might conflate action and non-action, and so reiterates: "The Dao of Heaven and the Dao of humans are far apart—this cannot go unexamined." The text’s opening and closing, its restraint and amplification, its forward and backward echoes—if one grasps this, it becomes lively and fluid. Yet its language is tangled, its rhythms shifting, its transformations elusive, so that not all can fully comprehend it. Moreover, passages like "what is distant yet cannot be abandoned" (righteousness) and "what is close yet cannot be left unexpanded" (benevolence) do not align with the sagely canon, thus veering toward heterodoxy. One must not read it as one would the *Analects* or *Mencius*.

From "what is base yet cannot be shirked" through to "this cannot go unexamined," this is the great guiding principle of Zhuangzi’s thought, akin to the *Under Heaven* chapter. Su Dongpo believed Zhuangzi never criticized Confucius, and in *Under Heaven* he was correct. Here, however, one sees that Zhuangzi never failed to recognize the principle of unity between the refined and the coarse, the root and the branch. There is another perspective: the words of sages and worthies endure for all ages without flaw, yet among the Hundred Schools, some passages strike with piercing clarity. Consider the *Book of Changes*: "That which is above form is called the Dao; that which is within form is called the vessel." "To transform and regulate it is called change; to extend and enact it is called penetration; to raise and apply it to the people of the world is called enterprise." Again: "When it is seen, it is called an image; when it takes form, it is called a vessel; when it is fashioned and employed, it is called a method; when its utility enters and exits, and the people all use it, it is called the numinous." Where does it not speak of the refined? Where does it not speak of the coarse? Expressed with such seamless integrity, it remains flawless.

Le Yuexuan said: "When Confucians awaken to the Dao, their minds grow ever more refined; when Chan Buddhists awaken to the Dao, their minds grow ever coarser." This insight penetrates to the marrow of Confucianism and Buddhism, surpassing all that came before. In this passage, Zhuangzi calls the myriad worldly affairs "lowly" and "coarse," yet intersperses them with "cannot but"—such maneuvers are even coarser, leaving no trace of the spirit of "only the refined, only the unified, holding fast to the center." Only by distinguishing these coarse and refined states can one perceive Le Yuexuan’s awakening to the Dao as the work of one with great vision. Others who refute Buddhism grasp only its surface; he, having named it a "transcendent dharma" and condemned its doctrines of severing human relations and abandoning ethical bonds, how could they ever convince him?

**Chapter Twelve: Heaven and Earth (Outer Chapters)**

Though Heaven and Earth are vast, their transformations are uniform; though the myriad things are numerous, their governance is one; though the masses of people are many, their sovereign is the lord. The lord originates in virtue and is completed by Heaven. Thus it is said: "The ancient rulers of the world practiced non-action—this was simply the virtue of Heaven." That their transformations are uniform means all are of primordial qi. That their governance is one: though the myriad things are many, what governs them is singular—creation alone. Though the masses of people are many, their sovereign is the lord, just as Heaven has no second sun, nor the people a second king.

What Heaven bestows upon me is virtue; if I can trace the origin of this virtue, it is all completed by Heaven, and human effort adds nothing. If one who would be a lord can understand this, then non-action and following spontaneity are achieved. Non-action and spontaneity are the virtue of Heaven—profound and distant. "Profound antiquity" means remote antiquity.

Viewed through the Dao, the lords of the world are rectified; viewed through the Dao, the duties of ruler and minister become clear; viewed through the Dao, the offices of the world are well-ordered; viewed through the Dao in its fullness, the responses of the myriad things are complete. Thus, that which flows through Heaven and Earth is virtue; that which moves among the myriad things is the Dao. To govern people is a matter of affairs; to possess a skill is a matter of technique. Technique is encompassed by affairs; affairs are encompassed by righteousness; righteousness is encompassed by virtue; virtue is encompassed by the Dao; the Dao is encompassed by Heaven.

Between Heaven and Earth, where there is qi, there is sound; where there is sound, there is name. When a name is designated as "lord," the divisions of the world are settled. From the very beginning of Heaven and Earth, as soon as sound arose, this was naturally determined—hence it is said: "Viewed through the Dao, the lords of the world are settled." The Dao is spontaneity. Once this division exists, the duties of ruler and minister naturally follow, establishing the hierarchy of high and low, noble and base.

Thus it is said: "Viewed through the Dao, the duties of ruler and minister become clear." The affairs of the world cannot be managed by one person alone; many are employed according to their abilities, fulfilling their offices. What enables them is also bestowed by Heaven, for Heaven produces many people to accomplish many affairs. Hence it is said: "Viewed through the Dao, the offices of the world are well-ordered."

Among the myriad things, nothing exists without its counterpart: where there is cold, there is heat; where there is female, there is male; where there is above, there is below; where there is front, there is back; where there is left, there is right. Each responds to the other, all arising spontaneously. Thus it is said: "Viewed through the Dao in its fullness, the responses of the myriad things are complete." These four phrases are most wondrous, their language pure and unadulterated. Heaven can cover and give life; Earth can bear and complete—together they share this virtue. "Flow through" means to be one with. Among the myriad things, each has its own spontaneous principle, which operates within...

Within this, it is thus said: "That which courses through the myriad things is the Dao."

What the ruler employs to govern—such as ritual, music, punishment, and administration—are all affairs of governance. Within each affair lies its own art and vocation, each following the capacities of the individual: these are human skills. The refined is the essence of virtue and power; the coarse is the realm of affairs and skills. Yet whether refined or coarse, all emerge from spontaneity. Thus, skill is but affair, affair is but art, art is but virtue, virtue is but the Dao, and the Dao is but Heaven. "To encompass" means to unite two as one. The term *he* (合, "to unite") was mistakenly transcribed as *yin* (因, "cause") due to their shared pronunciation.

Hence it is said: "Those who nurtured the world in ancient times desired nothing, and the world was sufficient; they acted not, and the myriad things transformed; they were profound and still, and the hundred clans were settled." The Record states: "Permeated by the One, all affairs are complete; without intent, one attains and even spirits submit." To nurture the world is what Mencius called "nourishing the world with goodness." If I desire nothing, the world naturally suffices; if I act not, the world naturally transforms; if I am still, the people naturally settle. *Yuánjìng* (渊静) means profound stillness. All affairs are but one principle, thus it is said: "Permeated by the One, all affairs are complete." As for what is attained within me: if one can be without intent, not only will people submit, but even spirits will yield. The term *jì yuē* (记曰, "the Record states") signifies an ancient transmission. These words were handed down from high antiquity, and Zhuangzi cited them as his own proof. These five phrases are most pure; the first three closely resemble those of Laozi.

The Master said: "The Dao is that which covers and bears the myriad things—vast and boundless, how great it is! The noble person cannot but hollow out the heart." To act through non-action is called Heaven; to speak through non-speaking is called virtue; to love others and benefit things is called benevolence; to harmonize differences is called greatness; to embrace diversity without boundary is called magnanimity; to possess the myriad differences is called abundance. Thus, to grasp virtue is called discipline; to perfect virtue is called establishment; to follow the Dao is called completion; to remain unshaken by external things is called wholeness. When the noble person comprehends these ten, their mind encompasses all affairs, vast and inexhaustible, flowing forth to embrace the myriad things.

The Master spoke of his teacher: *Kū xīn* (刳心) means to excise the heart of discriminating awareness. Only by removing this heart of knowledge can one enter the Dao and merge with spontaneity. To act in accordance with spontaneity is called Heaven; what is attained within oneself is self-evident, thus it is said: "To speak through non-speaking is called virtue." *Wúwéi yán* (无为言) means speech that requires no utterance. Differences are also sameness, thus it is said: "To harmonize differences is called greatness." *Yá yì* (崖异) refers to the traces of distinction. *Kuān* (宽) means expansive. Though things differ, I encompass them all, thus it is said: "To possess the myriad differences is called abundance"—that is, all things are complete within me. *Jì* (纪) means order: the virtue one grasps, whether great or small, follows its own sequence, hence it is said: "To grasp virtue is called discipline." *Zhuó hū* (卓乎) signifies standing firm, as in the perfection of virtue. To follow the Dao in action is to lack nothing, thus it is called completion. *Bèi* (备) means the fullness of the Dao. *Wán* (完) means wholeness: when external things cannot disturb the mind, what is within remains intact. Thus it is said: "To remain unshaken by external things is called wholeness." The ten are Heaven, virtue, benevolence, greatness, magnanimity, abundance, discipline, establishment, completion, and wholeness.

*Tāo* (韬) means to conceal: to embrace all affairs without omission, all returning to the mind—this mind is vast beyond measure. Thus it is said: "Their mind encompasses all affairs, vast and boundless." *Shì* (逝) means to flow: it flows like this, ever onward.

The myriad things come and go without end, yet I join with them in boundless continuity—thus it is said: "Abundant is their engagement with the myriad things as they flow." Such a one conceals gold in the mountains and pearls in the abyss, finds no profit in wealth, draws no nearness to nobility or riches, takes no joy in long life nor sorrow in early death, feels no glory in success nor shame in adversity. They do not confine the world’s benefits as private gain, nor do they regard ruling all under Heaven as a personal elevation. To be elevated is to be illuminated—all things are a single treasury, and death and life share the same form.

Concealing gold in the mountains and pearls in the abyss is to store wealth within all under Heaven. "Not drawing near" means keeping far away. They do not let longevity or early death dictate joy or sorrow, nor do they allow success or failure to determine honor or disgrace. The character *chǒu* (丑) here conveys a sense of inferiority, surpassing the notion of disgrace. The benefits of an age are shared by all—no one clings to them as personal possession, reflecting the idea that when one loses a bow, another finds it. Though they may rule all under Heaven, they do not consider themselves exalted; the yellow imperial carriage is not the intent of Yao’s heart. The clarity within their breast illuminates Heaven and Earth—this is true elevation, thus they do not regard ruling all under Heaven as exaltation. Gathering the myriad things into one principle, they call it a single treasury. Death and life are vast indeed, yet nothing alters their constancy—viewing them as one, thus it is said: "They share the same form."

The Master said: "The Dao dwells in the profound, its abode still; its clarity flows pure. Without it, metal and stone cannot sound—thus metal and stone have voices, yet without striking, they do not ring. Who can determine the myriad things?" Profound is its dwelling—stillness, the state of rest, of stability. Pure is its clarity—unmixed, unadulterated. The resonance of metal and stone is the natural work of Heaven, thus it is said: "Without it, metal and stone cannot sound." To sound is to be the Dao. Yet though metal and stone have voices, without human striking, they do not ring—human striking is also the mechanism of Heaven. These two lines express a parallel principle, much like the earlier saying: "How do we know what I call Heaven is not human, or what I call human is not Heaven?" Thus it is said: "Who can determine the myriad things?" Heaven is not complete without humanity, just as humanity is not complete without Heaven—this is the same idea, though in this text it is expressed with striking originality.

One of royal virtue moves with unadorned simplicity and feels shame in being entangled by affairs. They establish the root and origin, their knowledge penetrating the divine. Thus their virtue is vast, and from their heart’s emergence, things respond. Without the Dao, form does not arise; without virtue, life is not illuminated. To preserve form, exhaust life, establish virtue, and illuminate the Dao—this is not the work of one without royal virtue. Vast and boundless, they suddenly emerge, suddenly move, and the myriad things follow—this is the one of royal virtue.

"Royal virtue" refers to one possessing the virtue to rule all under Heaven. "Unadorned simplicity" means proceeding with plainness, like the saying "to tread with simplicity." They act without fail yet do not claim credit, thus it is said: "They feel shame in being entangled by affairs." The root is the origin of the myriad things. "Knowledge penetrating the divine" means sincerity like the divine. "Response" means things turn to them, and only then does their heart engage—thus it is said: "From their heart’s emergence, things respond." *Cǎi* (采) means to be moved; *chū* (出) means to answer. All things are born of creation—all that has form shares this Dao. Yet without self-realization, this Dao remains unilluminated, meaning it is not understood. The character *shēng* (生) in the following line refers to receiving the center of Heaven and Earth to live. Preserving one’s form to exhaust the principle of life’s origin, establishing one’s virtue to illuminate the Dao’s naturalness—this is beyond the capacity of any but the sage. "Vast and boundless"—this speaks of their greatness.

Suddenly, it emerges—this is the emergence of all things. With a sudden surge, it moves, compelled to rise by necessity. All things follow it—this is the sage acting and the myriad things beholding. Gazing into the boundless, listening to the soundless: within the boundless, one alone perceives clarity; within the soundless, one alone hears harmony. Thus, delving ever deeper, one can grasp things; refining ever more subtly, one can attain essence. Therefore, in engaging with the myriad things, one reaches utmost emptiness to fulfill their needs, roaming freely to meet their abiding nature—whether great or small, long or short, near or far.

The boundless is the realm of formlessness. To see within the formless and perceive clarity is to witness the elusive and indistinct, wherein images reside. While others deem it soundless, what I alone hear is like the harmony of the eight timbres. This is not seeing *that* but seeing *oneself*; not hearing *that* but hearing *oneself*. Delving ever deeper, entering the profound and wondrous, one can yet respond to things—able to grasp both the refined and the coarse. The spirit is formless; essence is qi. To perceive the formless is to grasp the interplay of qi above and form below. What abides within me is emptiness, yet it responds to things. Without compulsion, it attains utmost emptiness to fulfill the myriad things’ needs, emerging and roaming freely in due time, seizing their ultimate abode. One cannot speak of it as fixed—whether small or great, long or short, near or far—this is the meaning of timeliness. "Far-reaching" complements "near"; its intent is thus complete. Here, "far-reaching" (修远) means "long" (长), clearly encompassing the near as well. Otherwise, the brush would have slipped, losing restraint. Yet these scattered passages are exquisitely precise—how could others wield such a brush?

The Yellow Emperor roamed north of the Red Water, ascended the Kunlun peaks, and gazed southward. Upon returning, he lost his dark pearl. He sent Knowledge to seek it, but it was not found; he sent Li Zhu to seek it, but it was not found; he sent Chi Gou to seek it, but it was not found. Only Xiangwang obtained it. The Yellow Emperor exclaimed, "How extraordinary! Could Xiangwang alone have found it?"

This passage speaks of seeking the Dao: it does not lie in cleverness, nor in eloquence—just as the Buddhist sutras say, "To seek the Great Perfect Enlightenment with a mind of thought is like burning Mount Sumeru with a firefly’s glow." Yet it unfolds a discourse so profound. The dark pearl is the Dao; Knowledge is awareness; Li Zhu is clarity; Chi Gou is eloquence; Xiangwang is non-mind. Neither awareness, clarity, nor eloquence can attain the Dao—only non-mind can. Such metaphors are singularly marvelous.

Yao’s teacher was Xu You; Xu You’s teacher was Nie Que; Nie Que’s teacher was Wang Ni; Wang Ni’s teacher was Pi Yi. Yao asked Xu You, "Could Nie Que be fit to match Heaven? I would rely on Wang Ni to assess him." Xu You replied, "How perilous! How precarious is the world! Nie Que’s nature is keen, wise, and quick—surpassing others. Yet he takes what he receives from man as Heaven. He scrutinizes prohibitions and transgressions but does not know the source of transgressions. Could he match Heaven? He rides upon man yet lacks Heaven; he takes his body as fundamental yet differs in form; he exalts knowledge yet races like fire; he becomes entangled in affairs; he becomes ensnared by things; he looks in all directions, and things respond; he adapts to the needs of the multitude yet lacks constancy. How could he match Heaven? Though he has clan and ancestors, he may be a father to the multitude but cannot be the father of fathers—the leader of order and chaos. He would bring the calamity of facing north and the treachery of facing south."

Passage by passage, it grows ever more extraordinary. Could one say the Outer Chapters are coarser than the Inner? "Matching Heaven" is like the saying in the *Book of Documents*, "The rites of Yin ascend to match Heaven."

To speak of ruling all under Heaven is to seek its attainment through precarious means. "Precarious" and "perilous" both signify danger. "Keenness of perception, clarity of insight, and innate wisdom" describe one’s nature; "quick-wittedness," "urgency," and "keen observation and swift response" describe one’s actions. In responding to affairs, it is by virtue of this innate quickness that one reacts with such agility—this is where one surpasses others. Cultivating human affairs to align with the principles of Heaven is called "taking the human to accord with the Heavenly." To be discerning is to restrain transgressions, yet this remains a matter of holding the mind without transformation. If one understands the origins of transgression, there is no need for restraint.

"Riding upon man yet lacking Heaven" speaks of exhausting one’s active efforts while ignorant of non-action. "Riding" means to act; to act upon human affairs is called "riding upon man." The self is set against things, hence "taking the body as fundamental yet differing in form." "Racing like fire" describes haste; to exalt and hasten the use of one’s knowledge is called "exalting knowledge yet racing like fire." "Entangled in affairs" means being enslaved by trivial matters while forgetting the root, hence "ensnared by the threads of affairs"—this conveys the sense of fragmentation. "Ensnared by things" means being constrained by affairs and objects. Things come from all directions, and one looks about to respond, hence "looking in all directions, and things respond." Each response is measured to its circumstance, hence "adapting to the needs of the multitude." Yet to be submerged by things and lose one’s natural constancy is not true constancy in response, hence "adapting to things yet lacking constancy." "Adapting" means being transformed by affairs and objects; "constancy" is unity, and "lacking constancy" means having no stability.

A single "that" yet sevenfold in aspect, spanning from antiquity to the present—how could such literary skill arise? Though turning once more, it speaks of one who, while not yet matching Heaven, still possesses a venerable quality. When a clan gathers, it reveres its ancestors, hence "there is a clan, there is an ancestor." These four idle words, too, are strangely apt.

The "father of the multitude" emerges from the common people yet may serve as their father—meaning he stands above his generation. The father of the multitude’s father stands yet higher, and the father of the multitude’s father is Heaven, which is natural. He leads and commands.

This person’s role in the world may bring order or chaos: facing north, he is a minister; facing south, a ruler. To employ him as a minister or as a ruler both entail perils, hence "the calamity of facing north" and "the harm of facing south."

Yao observed Hua, and the border guard of Hua said, "Ah! Sage! I offer a blessing to the sage: may the sage live long." Yao declined. "May the sage grow wealthy." Yao declined. "May the sage have many sons." Yao declined.

The border guard said, "Longevity, wealth, and many sons—these are what all people desire. Why do you alone not desire them?"

Yao replied, "Many sons bring many fears; wealth brings many affairs; longevity brings many humiliations. These three are not the means to cultivate virtue, so I decline."

The border guard said, "At first, I took you for a sage, but now you are merely a gentleman. Heaven gives birth to the myriad people and must assign them duties. If you have many sons and assign them duties, what fear is there? If you are wealthy and distribute it among others, what affairs remain? Wealth, longevity, and many sons are what people desire, yet one who studies the Dao considers them insufficient to warrant concern."

Zhuangzi, however, inverts this reasoning, revealing his loftiness. "Heaven gives birth to the myriad people and must assign them duties"—this is like a child falling to earth already apportioned clothing and food, as the mountain valleys say: "A hundred grasses grieve at spring rain." "Wealthy yet distributing it among others" means each is entrusted to others.

The sage dwells like a quail and eats like a fledgling, moves like a bird without leaving a trace. When the world follows the Dao, he and all things flourish together; when the world lacks the Dao, he cultivates virtue and withdraws into obscurity. After a thousand years, weary of the world, he departs as an immortal, riding white clouds to the realm of the Emperor. The three calamities never reach him, and his body remains free from harm—what humiliation could there be?

"Dwelling like a quail" means having no fixed abode. "Eating like a fledgling" refers to a young bird fed by its mother, nourished without seeking it—meaning he is without intention regarding food. "Moving like a bird" means flying without leaving a trace, dwelling wherever he alights without attachment. "Flourishing with all things" means each thing and I attain our proper lives. "Cultivating virtue and withdrawing" means seclusion when the world lacks the Dao. "Weary of the world and ascending as an immortal" conveys the meaning of liberation. "White clouds" and "the Emperor’s realm" refer to the heights of emptiness and non-being.

The three calamities are youth, maturity, and old age. The *Śūraṅgama Sūtra*’s analogy of the Ganges’ waters illustrates these three. "The body remains free from harm" means self-contentment.

Above, it spoke of longevity, wealth, and many sons, yet below, it reverses the order, placing longevity last and expanding on its refusal—this, too, is a pivot of the text’s artistry.

The border guard departed, and Yao followed, saying, "I ask you..." The border guard did not answer but only said, "Withdraw." Yao still wished to ask, but the border guard would not respond, merely saying, "Withdraw"—as if to say, "Leave." When Jieyu hastened to avoid Confucius and the old man with the staff passed by, they moved on. Master Cheng’s inability to share a boat with others stems from this same mechanism.

Yao governed the world, and Bocheng Zigao was established as a feudal lord. When Yao ceded the throne to Shun, and Shun to Yu, Bocheng Zigao resigned his lordship to till the soil. Yu went to see him and found him plowing in the wilds. Yu hastened to approach from the lower position and stood to ask: "In the past, when Yao governed the world, you, sir, were established as a feudal lord. When Yao ceded the throne to Shun, and Shun to me, you resigned your lordship to plow. I venture to ask: what is the reason?" Zigao said: "In the past, when Yao governed the world, he did not reward, yet the people were encouraged; he did not rage, yet the people stood in awe. Now you reward and punish, and the people are no longer humane. Virtue has declined from this, punishments have been established from this, and the disorders of later ages have begun from this. Sir, why do you not depart? Do not hinder my work." He plowed on, head bowed, without looking back.

This passage further speaks of the world’s decline, one age worse than the last. Even in Yu’s time, it was already not equal to the eras of Yao and Shun. "Do not hinder my work" means "Do not abandon my work"—he had no leisure to speak with Yu, lest his plowing be neglected. The posture of plowing with head bowed is called *yiyi*. Yao did not reward or punish, yet now you reward and punish, and the people are not humane. The meaning is that rewards and punishments are not as good as having none, just as the intention behind "There must be no litigation" is expressed through the names of Yao, Shun, and Yu.

In the Great Beginning, there was Nonbeing; Nonbeing had no having, no name. This is the origin of the One. There was the One, yet no form. Things were thereby engendered—this is called *virtue*. Before form, there was division, yet it was so without gap—this is called *ming*. The abiding of movement gives rise to things; when things are completed, the principle of life is called *form*. When the form and body preserve the spirit, each has its proper pattern—this is called *nature*. Cultivating nature returns to virtue; when virtue reaches its utmost, it is one with the beginning. Being one, it is empty; being empty, it is vast. The harmony of beaks’ cries—this harmony unites with Heaven and Earth. Its union is seamless, like stupidity, like darkness. This is called *mysterious virtue*, one with the Great Compliance.

The Great Beginning is the origin of creation. What existed was only Nonbeing—there was not yet a character for "having." If having is like Nonbeing, how could there be a name? This is the origin of the One. This "One" is the character for Nonbeing. Thus, it is said: "There was the One, yet no form; things were thereby engendered"—then there was having. All things each have their having—this is virtue. "Before form" refers to the time when the One arose. If there was division, yet it could not be divided further, it is said: "yet it was so without gap." *Qie* means "yet"; the character *qie* is often followed by another. "Without gap" means undifferentiated; having division is distinct, yet this *ming* is the mandate of Heaven, the mandate of nature. The abiding of movement gives rise to things: the movement of primordial *qi* is ceaseless. When it gives rise to things, its movement abides there—thus it is said: "The abiding of movement gives rise to things." The words "abiding movement" are extremely precise; do not read them carelessly. Movement is yang; abiding is stillness, stillness is yin. This sentence already contains the meaning of yang arising and yin completing. When things obtain it, they are born; once formed, the principle of life is all possessed. The movement of primordial *qi* becomes my life—this is called *form*. Observe how the character *form* is explained here—this is absent in other texts. "When the form and body preserve the spirit, each has its proper pattern"—this is called *nature*. This sentence is like the *Book of Songs*’ "There are things, there are norms," and like the *Zuozhuan*’s "The people receive the mean of Heaven and Earth to live, possessing the norms of movement and bearing." Form and body are *qi*; within *qi* is the spirit. The so-called norms are all enacted by this spirit—this is nature, which inherently contains the meanings of benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and wisdom. If we discuss this text, the first "virtue" is actually "nature," while this "nature" is the function of nature. Thus, it is said: "Cultivating nature returns to virtue"—cultivating this nature to restore its natural virtue. When virtue reaches its utmost, it is complete, then it is one with the beginning of things. "Returns to virtue" is like "restoring propriety." *Zhi* means "utmost." Being one with the beginning of things is emptiness; being empty is vastness. The harmony of beaks’ cries—this harmony unites with Heaven and Earth. Its union is seamless, like stupidity, like darkness. This is called *mysterious virtue*, one with the Great Compliance.

Being vast is the consequence of emptiness. Emptiness and vastness together give rise to speech that is not speech—where beaks meet in silence, silence is the absence of speech, while their cries are speech. This "speech that is not speech" in the three characters below marks the passage’s extraordinary touch. Yet the text then turns again, saying: "the harmony of beaks’ cries." Here, the second *he* ("harmony") differs from the first. It means that when the cries of beaks are expressed as speech that is not speech, they unite with the natural. Through this natural harmony, they unite with Heaven and Earth. Thus it is said: "the harmony of beaks’ cries unites with Heaven and Earth." *Minmin* is like *mimim*—faint, as if stupid, as if dim, describing this state of harmony. This is called *mysterious virtue*, which is one with the Great Compliance. The Great Compliance is the principle of the Great Beginning, the natural order.

Confucius asked Lao Dan: "There is a man who governs the Dao as if imitating others—can this be so or not? Can it be otherwise? The disputers say: ‘Separate hardness and whiteness as if suspended from the heavens.’ Can such a one be called a sage?" Lao Dan replied: "This is the work of clerks, bound by skill, wearied in body, and startled in mind. A hunting dog leashed for the fox grows anxious; the agile monkey, once brought from the mountains, is trapped. I tell you what you cannot hear and speak of what you cannot utter. Those with heads and feet but no heart or ears—multitudes of the formed—along with the formless and shapeless that yet endure, all lack their own movement and rest, life and death, decline and rise. This is not their true nature.

There is governance in man: forget things, forget Heaven—this is called forgetting the self. One who forgets the self is said to enter into Heaven. The idea of "imitating others" refers to emperors and kings sharing a common thread: using what I affirm to clarify what others cannot affirm, and what I deem so to clarify what others deem not so. Though the disputers’ words—hardness and whiteness, sameness and difference—are manifold, I can distinguish them as if suspended in the sky, making them clear and manifest. *Li* means "to separate." *Xuyi* and *jixi* were explained in the previous section. *Chengsi* means being bound by others and thus filled with sorrow. *From the mountains* means captured and brought here. Earlier it said "leashed for the *li*"; here it says "leashed for the fox"—*li* is a scribal error. *What you cannot hear, what you cannot utter* refers to the nature and the Dao of Heaven, which cannot be heard. *Having heads and feet* describes people from crown to heel. *No heart, no ears* means no knowledge, no perception. *Formless and shapeless* refers to the naturally so. Those who see what is below form perceive form; those who see what is above form perceive the formless and shapeless that yet endure. This line is also strikingly phrased: *jin wu* means the world lacks such a person. *Movement and rest* refer to daily life; *decline and rise* to success and failure. In life and death, success and failure, all is naturally so. People know movement and rest, life and death, success and failure as such, but do not know *why* they are so.

Han Yu’s *Preface to Sending Wen Chang* says: "The reason rivers flow and people multiply is also a perceptive remark." But today, people read it carelessly. *Governing* refers to managing affairs. *Man* refers to human affairs. Governing through human affairs leaves no room for personal intent, hence it is said: "there is governance in man." Not only are things forgotten, but even Heaven is forgotten—this is called forgetting the self. Forgetting the self means having no self. *Entering into Heaven* means entering into the natural, as previously called *entering into the non-human*. Earlier it said "forgetting Heaven"; here it says "entering into Heaven." To enter is to become one with Heaven. Only by forgetting can one achieve unity.

However, *Responding to Emperors and Kings* says: "Never yet has one emerged from the non-human"—one who has not yet forgotten Heaven. "Never yet has one entered into the non-human"—emerging above the realm of creation. This is "entering into it."

The discourse of Heaven differs again from this—these are all its stirring, inspiring moments, and one must not cling to them. Clinging makes *Zhuangzi* difficult to read.

Jiang Lümian saw Ji Che and said: "The Lord of Lu said to me, 'I request instruction.' I could not decline the command. Having already spoken, I know not whether it struck the mark. Allow me to present it to you. I said to the Lord of Lu: 'You must practice reverence and frugality, elevate those of impartial loyalty, and harbor no favoritism. Then what commoner would dare not be at peace?'"

Ji Che laughed heartily and said: "If this is what you advise, your words on the virtue of emperors and kings are like a mantis raising its arms in anger to block a chariot’s wheel—it will surely fail the task. Moreover, if one acts thus, one’s own position becomes perilous. The more one displays one’s platform, the more things gather, and the more followers flock to it."

Jiang Lümian, startled, said: "I am utterly at a loss regarding your words. Nevertheless, I wish to hear the drift of your teaching."

*(Annotations within the text: "To present" means to lay out. "Elevate those of impartial loyalty" means to promote the worthy. "Harbor no favoritism" means to have no partiality. "At peace" means settled. "Heartily laughed" describes his manner. The mantis raising its arms to block the chariot’s wheel signifies that small strength is insufficient for such a great task. The phrase "anger and flight" appears in *The Book of Songs*: 'Grass and trees grow in anger.' Zhuangzi delights in using the word 'anger.' 'One’s own position' refers to the place where one stands by one’s own doing. If one displays one’s platform to others, people will flock to it, and those who come treading in its footsteps will grow ever more numerous. 'Many things' refers to the multitude of people. The implication is that the more one’s reputation flourishes, the more the world rushes toward it, and thus one becomes increasingly burdened. 'Startled' describes his expression. Hearing these words, he was left without understanding, hence 'utterly at a loss regarding your words.' 'Drift' refers to the remnant influence, or the general sense.)*

Ji Che said: "The great sage governs the world by swaying and stirring the people’s hearts, shaping them into teachings and transforming customs. He extinguishes their harmful intentions and advances their solitary resolve, as if it were their nature to act thus, and the people remain unaware of how it came to be. If this is so, how could one rank Yao and Shun’s teachings above and place oneself below? Would one not rather align with virtue and rest the heart therein?"

*(Annotations: "Swaying and stirring" means to shift and move. "Harmful intentions" refers to the mind of contrivance. "Solitary resolve" is the resolve of solitary attainment—the solitary vision of one who has attained clarity. Once the people are shaped into teachings and their customs transformed, all selfish intentions are extinguished, and they advance toward the Dao, as if by their inborn nature, unaware of the ruler’s transformative influence. Hence, 'unaware of how it came to be.' To regard Yao and Shun as superior and oneself as inferior is to say, 'I rank Yao and Shun’s teachings above and place myself below.' How could Yao and Shun surpass me? Yet the phrasing here is deliberately provocative. 'Mingxing' conveys the sense of bowing one’s head in submission. 'People' is synonymous with 'human.' If all can act thus, who would willingly rank Yao and Shun’s teachings above and place themselves below? Aligning with the virtue of nature, the heart finds rest. 'Rest' means to dwell in peace. 'Desires' refers to the sage’s wish for the people to be thus.)*

Zigong traveled south to Chu and, on his return to Jin, passed through Hanyin. There he saw an old man tending his garden plot. The man had dug a tunnel to enter the well, where he embraced a jar to draw water and irrigate the rows. He toiled strenuously, yet his achievement was meager.

Zigong said: "There is a device here that can irrigate a hundred rows in a day, requiring little effort yet yielding great results. Would you not wish to use it?"

The gardener looked up at him and said: "How does it work?"

Zigong replied: "Carve wood into a machine, with the rear heavy and the front light. It draws water as if pulling, swift as boiling water. Its name is the well-sweep."

The gardener flushed with anger, laughed, and said: "I have heard from my teacher that where there are mechanical devices, there are mechanical affairs, and where there are mechanical affairs, there is a mechanical heart. When a mechanical heart resides in the breast, unalloyed whiteness is incomplete. When unalloyed whiteness is incomplete, the spirit’s life is unsettled. When the spirit’s life is unsettled, the Dao does not bear it. I am not ignorant of this—I would be ashamed to use it."

Zigong, abashed, hung his head and made no reply.

After a while, the gardener said: "What are you doing?"

Zigong replied: "I am a disciple of Confucius."

The gardener said: "Are you not that learned man who emulates the sages, struts about to overshadow the crowd, and sings mournful songs to sell your name throughout the world? You are about to forget your spirit and qi, cast off your bodily form, and perhaps approach [the Dao]. Yet you cannot even govern yourself—how could you have leisure to govern the world? Be on your way. Do not hinder my work."

Between the ridges, he dug channels to form irrigation ditches—drawing water as easily as pulling it forth, so that it surged and overflowed in abundance. These lines depict the self-satisfaction of one who relies on the well-sweep and other mechanical devices. To use such tools is to engage in mechanical affairs, and what drives their use is the mind. With a mechanical mind, unalloyed whiteness is incomplete—meaning it is not purely empty and luminous. When unalloyed whiteness is incomplete, the spirit’s life is unsettled, unable to embrace stillness or maintain unity. The Dao does not bear such a one—meaning it cannot carry the Way. In seeking learning and cultivation, one must carefully reflect on these points.

*What are you doing?* is akin to the *Analects*’ *From where do you come?* *Emulating the sages* means aspiring to be like the sages. *Strutting about* describes an air of self-importance. *Singing mournful songs alone* refers to reciting one’s own praises when others do not acknowledge them—selling one’s name, seeking fame. The phrase *singing mournful songs alone* is a metaphor; it is not the same as *striking the chime-stones in Wei*. *Forget your spirit and qi* means to set aside one’s cleverness. *Cast off your bodily form* is to forget the self. If you could do this, you might still approach [the Dao]. If not, you cannot even govern yourself—how could you govern others? This is a rebuke to our sage’s teachings. *Do not hinder* means *do not delay*.

Zigong, humbled and crestfallen, lost his composure. He walked thirty *li* before recovering. His disciples asked: "Who was that man earlier? Why did you, Master, change countenance and lose composure, remaining unsettled for the rest of the day?" Zigong replied: "At first, I thought there was only one man in the world—yet I did not know there was another like him. I have heard from the Master that the Way of the sage seeks what is feasible, pursues completion, expends little effort, and achieves much. Now this man is not like that. One who holds to the Dao attains full virtue; with full virtue, the form is whole; with the whole form, the spirit is whole—this is the Way of the sage. He entrusts his life to the people, moving among them without knowing where he goes, vast and perfectly complete. He must have forgotten the mind of profit, skill, and cunning."

*Humbled and crestfallen* describes shame and embarrassment. *Lost his composure* means being at a loss. *Not returning to oneself* means not regaining one’s usual state. *The one man in the world* refers to Confucius. *Seeks what is feasible* means acting only when it can be done. *Expending little effort and achieving much* is like the well-sweep’s efficiency. *Now this man is not like that* refers to the gardener of Hanyin. *Entrusts his life to the world* means living among people without knowing his own direction—wandering aimlessly, like one who does not know where to go. *Vast and perfectly complete* means pure, unified, and whole. *He must have forgotten the mind of profit, skill, and cunning* means this man’s heart is free of such concerns. Here, *forgotten* is the same as *lost*—meaning *without*.

Such a man does not go where his will does not lead, does not act where his heart does not incline. Though the world may praise him, he remains unmoved by what he deems right; though the world may condemn him, he remains untroubled by what he deems wrong. The world’s praise or blame neither benefits nor harms him—this is what it means to be a man of full virtue. I am but one tossed by the winds and waves of the world.

*Such a man* refers to the gardener of Hanyin. He does not let praise or blame affect him. He would not even heed praise—how much less blame? What he says and does in the world is called *attaining what he deems right*; what he does not say or do is called *losing what he deems right*. *Tossed by the winds and waves* means being driven by worldly affairs without self-mastery.

Returning to Lu, Zigong reported this to Confucius. Confucius said: "He is one who temporarily practices the arts of Hundun. He grasps one aspect but not the other—cultivating his inner self but not his outward conduct. That man of clarity, simplicity, non-action, and returning to the uncarved block—embodying his nature, holding fast to his spirit, and wandering among the common world—how could you not be startled? Moreover, what do you or I know of the arts of Hundun?"

*Temporarily* means *greatly*. *Practices the arts* means *greatly cultivates*. *Hundun* refers to the primordial state of heaven and earth. *Arts* means *the Way*. *Grasps one aspect* means holding to purity and unity. *Not the other* means the mind is undivided. *Inner* refers to the original heart; *outward* refers to external things. *Clarity* allows one to enter simplicity. *Simplicity* is the uncarved block. *Non-action* is returning to the natural simplicity of the uncarved block. *Embodying his nature* means preserving his nature whole. *Holding fast to his spirit* means unity. *How could you not be startled?* means it is fitting that you were startled—you do not yet know this Way, so it is natural to be astonished.

Zhun Mang was traveling east to the Great Valley when he encountered Yuan Feng by the eastern sea. Yuan Feng asked: "Where are you going?" He replied: "To the Great Valley." "What will you do there?" "The Great Valley—it is a thing that..."

The Great Valley—it is a thing that, though poured into, never fills, and though drawn from, never depletes. I shall wander there."

Yuan Feng said: "Do you have no concern for the horizontal-eyed people? I wish to hear of sagely governance."

Zhun Mang replied: "Sagely governance? Offices are established without failing their proper roles; the capable are promoted without failing their talents. All matters are seen in their true nature, and actions are taken as they ought to be. Words and deeds arise from oneself, and the world transforms accordingly. With a wave of the hand or a glance, the people of the four directions all come forth—this is called sagely governance. The Great Valley is the great sea. 'Horizontal-eyed people' is a term coined to describe the common folk. To wander in the Great Valley is to say that the world is not worth observing, and one will instead observe the sea. 'Offices are established without failing their proper roles' means each position is fitting to its task. 'The capable are promoted without failing their talents' means no talent is overlooked. 'Matters in their true nature' refers to the reality of affairs. Seeing all matters clearly, one acts according to what is fitting—thus it is said, 'All matters are seen in their true nature, and actions are taken as they ought to be.' What is done and said arises from oneself, not for others—thus the world naturally transforms. 'From oneself' means acting for oneself, not for others. 'A wave of the hand' means a gesture. With a wave or a glance, the people all respond. The *Book of Documents* says, 'Only when moved is there great response, awaiting the will.' 'A wave of the hand or a glance' conveys the idea of beckoning or bowing—this is how the sage governs the world. This refers to the ancient emperors and kings."

"I wish to hear of the virtuous person."

"The virtuous person dwells without thought, acts without concern, and harbors no judgments of right or wrong, beauty or ugliness. Within the four seas, all share in its benefits and rejoice; all are provided for and at peace. They are forlorn, like an infant who has lost its mother, or bewildered, like a traveler who has lost the Way. Yet their resources are abundant, though they know not whence they come; their food and drink are sufficient, though they know not from where. This describes the demeanor of the virtuous person—whether in stillness or motion, they hold no intent in their heart. Thus it is said, 'Dwells without thought, acts without concern.' They harbor no judgments of right or wrong, beauty or ugliness—this is what Buddhists call 'thinking neither good nor evil.' 'Shared benefits and provision' means rejoicing with others. 'Forlorn' describes their demeanor, like an infant who has lost its mother or a traveler who has lost the Way—both express their detachment from the world, though not without a sense of inevitability. Resources and sustenance come to them unbidden, for they are without intent. The virtuous person surpasses sagely governance by yet another level."

"I wish to hear of the spirit person."

"The supreme spirit rides the light, and form perishes and vanishes—this is called 'illuminating the vast' and 'fulfilling destiny to the utmost.' Emotions are fully realized, heaven and earth rejoice, and the myriad affairs dissolve. The myriad things return to their true nature—this is called 'primordial chaos.' 'Supreme spirit' speaks of their spirit soaring above. Beyond heaven and earth, even the light of sun and moon lies beneath them—thus it is said, 'rides the light.' 'Form perishes and vanishes' means that though they have a body, it seems as if they do not. 'Illuminating the vast' means great clarity. 'Fulfilling destiny' means exhausting the mandate of heaven. 'Emotions are fully realized' means fully realizing the emotions inherent in one’s nature. This 'emotion' is akin to Mencius’ 'if one follows their nature, they can do good.' Following the Dao of heaven and earth, they rejoice, and the myriad affairs no longer burden them—thus it is said, 'heaven and earth rejoice, and the myriad affairs dissolve.' 'Return to true nature' means returning to reality. When the myriad things all return to reality, they become one with the self. 'Primordial chaos' is the undifferentiated—this is the so-called 'Hun Dun.' The spirit person surpasses the virtuous person by yet another level, distinguishing those beyond the reach of even the ancient emperors and kings."

Men Wu Hui and Chi Zhang Manji observed the armies of King Wu. Chi Zhang Manji said: "Are they not inferior to the era of Youyu? Thus they have fallen into this calamity."

Men Wu Hui said: "When the world is equally governed, does Youyu govern it? Or does he govern it only after it has fallen into chaos?"

Chi Zhang Manji replied: "The world universally desires governance—why then calculate whether Youyu is the remedy for Youyu’s own ailment? A bald man seeks a wig; the sick seek a physician. A filial son prepares medicine for his compassionate father, yet his countenance remains scorched with worry. The sage feels shame at this. Manji’s words, though not entirely correct, employ striking analogies to advance his argument. In his view, the question of whether military might falls short of yielding courtesy stems from Wu Hui’s query, which further denigrates Youyu’s governance. The world yearns for order, yet when Youyu governs it, this very governance becomes a burden.

Why prescribe medicine if not bald? Why wear a wig if not hairless? Why seek a physician if not ill? To call governing the world an illness is itself the sickness. Governance through non-action incurs no illness. A filial son who prepares medicine for his father remains disquieted—how much better if the father were never ill! Thus the sage deems it shameful to harbor the intent to govern the world.

Though his words are not entirely orthodox, his analogies are singular and instructive. The character *xiu* (羞) here means shame. In the age of utmost virtue, worthies are not exalted, nor abilities employed. The ruler is like a bare branch; the people, like wild deer.
