They are upright yet unaware of righteousness; they love one another yet unaware of benevolence; they are sincere yet unaware of loyalty; they act appropriately yet unaware of trustworthiness. The living move and employ one another, yet do not regard it as a favor. Thus their conduct leaves no trace, their affairs no residue.

The world is uniformly pure, devoid of the names of worthies or abilities. Hence it is said: worthies are not exalted, abilities are not employed. *Biaozhi* (标枝) means a withered branch—only its limbs are visible, not its leaves—an analogy for being without emotion or desire. Uprightness refers to cultivating the self; mutual love, to intimacy; sincerity, to the substance of the heart. Loyalty means following the heart; appropriateness, acting as circumstances demand. The four "unawares" below—unaware of benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, and trustworthiness—indicate that in that era, such names did not yet exist. *Chundong* (蠢动) refers to all living beings; *xiangshi* (相使), to mutual assistance. Not regarding it as a favor means not treating it as a kindness. Conduct leaving no trace, affairs leaving no residue—this describes an age without judgments of right or wrong, praise or blame. These all depict the era of great antiquity.

A filial son does not flatter his parents; a loyal minister does not fawn upon his lord—this is the height of ministerial and filial virtue. If a parent’s words are heeded and their conduct is good, the world calls the child unfilial. If a lord’s words are heeded and their conduct is good, the world calls the minister disloyal. Yet how can this be necessarily so? What the world deems right, they deem right; what it deems good, they deem good. Yet they are not counted among those who guide and restrain others."

Yet does custom truly command greater reverence than parents, greater honor than lords? To be called a guide of others is to flush with anger; to be called a restrainer of others is to bristle with indignation—yet all one’s life one guides others, all one’s life one restrains others. Only by neither restraining nor flattering can one admonish one’s lord or father. To follow their words as right, their conduct as good, is not to admonish at all. In the eyes of lord and father, the admonisher is right and the non-admonisher wrong, yet in my dealings with the world, I follow what it deems good and affirm what it deems right—does this not reverse the world’s reverence for lord and father?

This suggests that what people today call the Dao is merely what the world universally affirms, not something attained in solitude and shared with the Creator. *Dao* means to guide and follow; *fang* means to restrain and flatter. If my so-called Dao aligns only with the world’s norms, then my actions merely guide and restrain the world. Should others apply the labels of "guide" or "restrainer" to me, I would surely resent it—yet all my life, I cannot escape guiding or restraining, for I cannot differ from the world.

The sage takes what is universally practiced as the Dao, but Zhuangzi holds that the Dao must transcend the age. Thus, he regards the ancient emperors and sages as inferior, unfolding his argument with such sweeping force that none can match it—though his words may go too far.

Gathering analogies, embellishing rhetoric, assembling followers: this is to begin with lofty aims yet end unable to rise above the age, so that one’s origins and outcomes, roots and branches, fail to align. Hence, they do not correspond. Donning robes and adornments, altering one’s countenance to charm the world, yet never calling oneself a guide or restrainer—such a one joins the crowd in affirming and denying, yet never admits to being one of them. What greater folly could there be?

"Gathering analogies" means compiling the world’s metaphors to construct an argument; "embellishing rhetoric" means refining one’s words; "assembling followers" means drawing all scholars to oneself. Though one’s initial intent may surpass the age, in the end, one cannot escape the people of the time—thus, beginning and end, root and branch, do not cohere. Hence, they do not correspond. "Donning robes and adornments, altering one’s countenance" refers to the Confucians’ attire and ornamentation, their measured demeanor in instructing disciples, which is taken as charming the world. All this mocks the intent of our sages: what I affirm, my followers affirm; what I deny, my followers deny. Those who study under me are all common folk—if my affirmations and denials align with theirs, then I too am common. Yet though I walk among the common, I do not call myself common: this is the height of folly, utterly lacking insight.

Zhuangzi’s meaning is that what he alone has attained, others do not know, so he differs from them and thus speaks in such frustrated indignation. But this is not sound reasoning. To know one’s folly is not great folly; to know one’s confusion is not great confusion. The greatly confused never awaken; the greatly foolish never enlighten. If three walk together and one is confused, the destination may still be reached—for confusion is the minority. If two are confused, the journey is labored and the goal unattained—for confusion prevails. But now, the whole world is confused; though I have a direction, how can I attain it? Is this not lamentable?

Great music does not enter the ears of village folk; they laugh uproariously at *Zhe Yang* and *Huang Hua*. Thus, lofty words do not lodge in the hearts of the common; ultimate words do not surpass vulgar speech. Two jars and a bell may bewilder, making the path unknowable—yet now, the whole world is confused. Though I have a direction, how can it be attained? Knowing it cannot be attained, to force it is yet another confusion. Better to release it and not press forward. If I do not press, who will share my sorrow?

"Never awaken, never enlighten" means not knowing oneself. *Qi xiang* means direction. If three walk together and two are confused, the journey is labored and the destination unreached—yet now, the whole world is confused by its doctrines. Though I alone have a direction, how can I turn the age? This "I" is Zhuangzi speaking of himself. *Zhe Yang* and *Huang Hua* are names of village tunes; "great music" refers to ancient music, an analogy for his most profound teachings.

To speak to those whose hearts remain unaligned with the multitude is to speak in vain. *Zhe Yang* and *Huang Hua* are but vulgar tunes—when vulgar speech prevails, the most profound words are silenced. "Hanging one’s heels" means sitting with feet dangling, refusing to walk; "two who hang their heels in confusion" refers to the earlier mention of two who are bewildered. "Unable to reach one’s destination" echoes the earlier "labored journey, destination unreached." Scribal errors have miswritten "hanging" as "jars" and "heels" as "bells," both unintelligible—yet comparing the preceding and following phrases, "hanging heels" is clearly the correct reading. Knowing it cannot be attained and yet forcing it is yet another confusion. This is a sigh of self-reproach: though I know it cannot be conveyed, I persist in trying to convey it—thus adding another layer of confusion. "Release it" means to let go; "not press forward" means not to insist on expounding. "Share" means to draw near. To leave it unspoken is to distance oneself from sorrow. This is self-explication.

A leper gives birth in the dead of night, hastily kindling a torch to examine the child, anxious lest it resemble himself. A leper is a detestable person—here, the insertion of "之" mirrors the earlier "骊姬之姬," a feature of the text’s style. A detestable man fears his child will resemble him, for he knows his own vileness. If even he knows himself, while the confused of the world remain self-ignorant, they are worse than the leper. Earlier, he spoke of "great confusion, never awakened" and "great folly, never enlightened," yet here he offers two analogies without drawing a conclusion—this is but playful phrasing.

A century-old tree, hewn into sacrificial goblets, adorned with blue and yellow patterns, is no different in essence from its severed trunk cast into a ditch. Though the goblet and the ditch-bound wood differ in beauty and ugliness, their loss of nature is the same. Robber Zhi and the virtuous Zeng and Shi may differ in conduct, yet their loss of nature is equal. Moreover, there are five ways to lose one’s nature: first, the five colors confuse the eyes, dulling their clarity; second, the five sounds confuse the ears, dulling their acuity; third, the five odors cloy the nose, congesting the sinuses; fourth, the five flavors clog the mouth, distorting its sense; fifth, preferences and aversions agitate the heart, scattering the nature. These five are all harms to life, yet Yang Zhu and Mo Di strut about, believing themselves to have attained something—this is not what I call attainment. If distress can be called attainment, then a turtledove or owl in a cage may also be said to have attained something.

The wood cast into the ditch is but the remnant of that carved into goblets. The same tree may become a goblet or be discarded in a ditch—though honor and disgrace differ, both are but withered wood. This is akin to the parable of Zang and Gu losing their sheep. The five colors, five sounds, five odors, and five flavors are all products of human artifice, thus they disrupt the nature. These four, along with preferences and aversions, are mentioned together to censure them. "Congested" means obstructed; "sinuses" refers to the passage from the nose to the forehead. "Clogging the mouth" means defiling it; "distorting its sense" means perverting it. Preferences and aversions are matters of right and wrong, likes and dislikes. When preferences and aversions muddle the heart, the natural nature is lost—hence, "preferences and aversions agitate the heart, scattering the nature." The teachings of Yang Zhu and Mo Di are precisely those that agitate the heart with preferences and aversions, yet they claim to have attained something. If their doctrines can be called attainment, then beasts in cages may also be said to have attained something—this is a severe rebuke.

Furthermore, preferences and aversions, sounds and colors, barricade the inner self; caps of skin and kingfisher feathers, sashes and tablets, long belts—these constrain the outer self. Within, the heart is hemmed in like a stockade; without, it is bound by layers of restraint. Though enmeshed in these bonds, one believes oneself to have attained something—this is like a convict with arms bound and fingers trussed, or a tiger or leopard in a sack or cage, yet still claiming attainment.

Preferences and aversions manifest in speech and countenance, contending with others over right and wrong, leaving the heart obstructed—hence, "preferences and aversions, sounds and colors, barricade the inner self." Caps of skin and kingfisher feathers, sashes and tablets, long belts are the attire of Confucians. Clothing and ritual forcibly constrain the self—hence, "constrain the outer self." "Sashes and tablets" refer to holding tablets; "long belts" refer to the extended sash. Within, the heart is cramped and congested like a stockade; without, it is fettered by ritual and form like a convict in bonds. "Ropes and snares" refer to being bound; "睆睆" describes the gaze of one so constrained. Though one suffers as if bound, one still believes oneself to have attained something—would a convict or a caged beast also claim attainment? This is an extreme denunciation of Yang Zhu and Mo Di. "Arms bound" means hands tied; "fingers trussed" means fingers so bound they can be counted. "Sack and cage" are mentioned together, akin to the common saying, "a monkey in a sack."

**Zhuangzi Kouyi, Scroll Five**

**Outer Chapters, "The Dao of Heaven" (Thirteenth)**

The Dao of Heaven operates without accumulation, thus all things are completed. The Dao of the Emperor operates without accumulation, thus the world submits. The Dao of the Sage operates without accumulation, thus the realm obeys. One who is enlightened by Heaven, attuned to the Sage, and permeates the six directions and four openings through the virtue of emperors and kings—his gaze is dimmed, yet nothing is not at rest.

The stillness of the sage is not stillness for stillness’ sake; it is stillness because it is good. Nothing in the myriad things suffices to disturb his heart, thus he is still. When water is still, it clearly reflects the beard and brows; its level surface serves as the standard for the great craftsman. If still water can be so luminous, how much more so the spirit? The heart of the sage is still—it is the mirror of Heaven and Earth, the looking glass of the myriad things.

The Dao of the Emperor and the Dao of the Sage are difficult to distinguish. Zhuangzi’s intent is likely to regard the Emperor as the Three Sovereigns and the Sage as the Five Emperors. To "operate without accumulation" is simply the pure and unceasing; the phrase "without accumulation" makes this even clearer. The central idea here, however, lies in the word "stillness." Within utmost stillness, operation without accumulation—how could this be like withered wood or dead ashes? Yet readers often fail to perceive this.

"Six directions and four openings" means east, west, south, north, above, and below—unobstructed in all ways. "Dimmed" conveys the sense of obscurity. "The stillness of the sage is not stillness for stillness’ sake; it is stillness because it is good"—this line is most vital. It means the sage does not favor stillness as an end in itself; rather, he desires this stillness because nothing in the myriad things suffices to disturb his heart. Thus, he does not seek stillness, yet is naturally still. The analogy of water and mirror for stillness is drawn from everyday speech, yet the phrasing is exquisitely precise.

Now, emptiness, stillness, tranquility, indifference, quiescence, and non-action—these are the equilibrium of Heaven and Earth and the ultimate of the Dao and virtue. Thus, emperors, kings, and sages rest in them. To rest is to be empty; to be empty is to be full. Fullness is the principle of order. To be empty is to be still; to be still is to move; to move is to attain. To be still is to be non-active; in non-activity, those who handle affairs bear responsibility. In non-activity, one is at ease; one at ease cannot be afflicted by care, and thus enjoys long life.

Emptiness, stillness, tranquility, indifference, quiescence, and non-action—these are the root of the myriad things. Understanding this, one faces south as Yao did to be a ruler; understanding this, one faces north as Shun did to be a minister. With this, one embodies the virtue of the Son of Heaven and the Emperor on high; with this, one embodies the Way of the obscure sage and the unadorned king. With this, one retires to leisurely wander among rivers, seas, mountains, and forests; with this, one advances to govern the world, achieving great merit, illustrious fame, and the unity of all under Heaven.

"Emptiness, stillness, tranquility, indifference, quiescence, and non-action" expand the single word "stillness" into eight characters to make the meaning clear. "Equilibrium" means settled; "ultimate" means supreme.

This is the unchanging principle of Heaven and Earth, the ultimate attainment of the Dao and virtue. "Rest" means cessation—it speaks of the hearts of emperors, kings, and sages coming to rest here, just as it is said, "resting in the highest good." When there is rest, there is emptiness, and only the Dao gathers in emptiness; auspiciousness comes to rest where it rests.

Yet below this, it further states that emptiness gives rise to fullness—fullness is the proper order of things. When the spirit is empty, it becomes full, just as the Chan school speaks of "true emptiness and then the existence of reality." "Proper order" refers to principle; within the fullness of principle, there is inherent pattern—this is the radiance within the undifferentiated.

The previous line expounded "emptiness gives rise to fullness," and the next line speaks of "emptiness gives rise to stillness, stillness gives rise to movement." This is the mutual rooting of movement and stillness. When movement is without misstep, it is said, "in movement, one attains." "Those who take up affairs bear responsibility"—this means each fulfills their duties and responsibilities, which is non-action that leaves nothing undone.

"Yu-yu" describes a state of ease and joy; "worries and troubles cannot abide" means they do not enter into one. "Abide" carries the sense of sinking into; when worries and troubles cannot enter, this is the unanxious heart of the benevolent. Longevity is the reward of stillness.

These four lines develop the meaning through the sequence of "emptiness," "stillness," and "non-action"—this is the stylistic technique of *Zhuangzi*. Here, it once again raises the eight characters—"emptiness, stillness, tranquility, indifference, quiescence, and non-action"—and concludes with "the root of the myriad things." "Root" means origin, speaking of this principle as emerging from the time before the existence of the myriad things.

To dwell above is to face south as a ruler; to dwell below is to remain in reclusion. "Obscure sage and unadorned king" refers to one who possesses the virtue of a sage but not the position. "Retiring to leisurely wander" describes those who roam rivers and seas; "advancing to govern the world" describes those who serve their time.

Gazing upon this single phrase, how could its intent not desire engagement with the world? How could it not regard movement and stillness as one? In stillness, one becomes a sage; in movement, a king. "Non-action" is revered, and "simplicity" is such that none in the world can rival its beauty. One who clearly comprehends the virtue of Heaven and Earth—this is called the Great Root, the Great Ancestor, the one who harmonizes with Heaven. Thus, they harmonize and regulate the world, and in harmonizing with others, this is called human joy; in harmonizing with Heaven, this is called Heavenly joy.

Stillness makes one a sage; movement makes one a king—this is precisely the four characters "inner sageliness, outer kingliness." "Non-action" is revered: "revered" means esteemed, for among the world’s ways, none is more esteemed than non-action. "Simplicity" means unadorned, without ornament. Though it may seem plain, none in the world surpasses its beauty, hence it is said, "simplicity, such that none in the world can rival its beauty." "Clearly comprehending" means understanding this with perfect clarity. If one knows the virtue of Heaven and Earth, one may walk as Heaven’s companion, hence it is said, "the one who harmonizes with Heaven." "Harmony" means union. The Great Root and Great Ancestor are praises of Nature’s virtue, akin to the meaning of "self-rooted, self-founded." To harmonize and regulate the world is to unite with others, much like Yao’s words: "You unite with Heaven; I unite with humanity." Having spoken of Heavenly harmony and human harmony, it further speaks of human joy and Heavenly joy, its brushwork soaring and transcendent—generally thus.

*Zhuangzi* says: "My master! My master! Who pulverizes the myriad things yet is not cruel, who bestows blessings upon ten thousand generations yet is not benevolent, who is older than high antiquity yet is not long-lived, who covers and bears Heaven and Earth, carves and sculpts the forms of things yet is not skillful—this is called Heavenly joy." These several lines are identical to those in the *Great Master* chapter, yet here they are prefaced with "Zhuangzi says," whereas earlier they were attributed to Xu You’s words. Clearly, each is a parable—how could they be taken as literal speech?

Thus it is said: One who knows Heavenly joy, in life follows the Heavenly course, and in death transforms with things. In stillness, they share virtue with yin; in movement, they flow with yang. Therefore, one who knows Heavenly joy harbors no resentment toward Heaven, no blame toward others, no entanglement with things, no reproach from spirits. Hence it is said: In movement, they are Heaven; in stillness, they are Earth. With a single mind settled, they rule the world; their spirits are unharmed, their souls unwearied. With a single mind settled, the myriad things submit. This means applying the principle of emptiness and stillness to Heaven and Earth, penetrating the myriad things—this is called Heavenly joy. Heavenly joy is the heart of the sage, by which they nurture the world.

"The Heavenly course" means following the natural principle of Heaven. "Transformation with things" means changing along with the myriad things. In stillness, they are yin; in movement, they are yang, flowing together. The Confucian school speaks only of "not resenting Heaven, not blaming others," but here two more phrases are added: "no entanglement with things, no reproach from spirits," further heightening its vigor. When spirits manifest in others, it is called "haunting"; when their spirits remain unharmed, it means their essence is concealed and not exposed. "Their souls unwearied" means their spirit is not exhausted. "Spirits" and "souls" refer to the same essence. When the mind is settled, the spirit is naturally settled, and the myriad things naturally submit. Applying the principle of emptiness and stillness to move between Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things, hence it is said, "applying to Heaven and Earth, penetrating the myriad things." "Nurturing the world" means governing the world by benevolently cultivating others.

Now, the virtue of emperors and kings takes Heaven and Earth as its model, the Dao and virtue as its master, and non-action as its constant. In non-action, they employ the world with ease; in action, they are employed by the world and find it insufficient. Thus, the ancients prized non-action. The superior practices non-action, and the inferior does likewise—this is the inferior harmonizing its virtue with the superior. When the inferior harmonizes its virtue with the superior, it does not act as a subject. The inferior practices action, and the superior does likewise—this is the superior aligning its way with the inferior. When the superior aligns its way with the inferior, it does not act as a ruler. The ruler must practice non-action to employ the world; the subject must practice action to be employed by the world—this is an unchanging principle.

Heaven, Earth, the Dao, and virtue are all principles of non-action. Here, it once more contrasts non-action with action, taking non-action as the ruler’s way and action as the subject’s way. "When the inferior harmonizes its virtue with the superior, it does not act as a subject" means the subject should labor. "When the superior aligns its way with the inferior, it does not act as a ruler" means the ruler should be at ease. Employing the world is the ruler’s role; being employed by the world is the subject’s role. Here, ruler and subject form a single idea, which cannot be conflated with the *Innate Capacity* chapter’s discussion of the unity of Heavenly and human ways. If one clings rigidly to this, one cannot read *Zhuangzi* properly. For though this chapter speaks of the ruler practicing non-action and the subject practicing action, an earlier passage says, "Understanding this, one may face north and serve as Shun’s subject," and further, "Applying this to advance and govern the world, one’s achievements will be great and one’s name illustrious"—thus, even the subject’s way may be non-action. How could this be self-contradictory? Therefore, if one reads *Zhuangzi* with such rigidity, one cannot grasp its meaning.

Thus, the ancient kings who ruled the world, though their wisdom encompassed Heaven and Earth, did not rely on their own plans; though their eloquence adorned the myriad things, they did not delight in their own words; though their abilities exhausted the world, they did not act for themselves. Heaven does not produce, yet the myriad things transform; Earth does not grow, yet the myriad things flourish. Emperors and kings practice non-action, yet the world’s achievements are complete. Hence it is said: None is more divine than Heaven, none richer than Earth, none greater than emperors and kings. Thus, the virtue of emperors and kings matches Heaven and Earth. This is riding Heaven and Earth, driving the myriad things, and employing the human way.

"Encompassing Heaven and Earth" means embracing them. "Adorning the myriad things" speaks of their artistry. Things arise of themselves, not because Heaven produces them; things grow of themselves, not because Earth makes them grow. Hence it is said: Heaven does not produce, Earth does not grow. Emperors and kings, through non-action, complete the work of Heaven and Earth, thus harmonizing with them. "Riding Heaven and Earth" is like saying "riding the six dragons to govern Heaven." "Driving the myriad things" means commanding all that moves. Here, it is merely praising the ruler’s way of non-action.

The root lies above, the branches below; the essential lies in the ruler, the detailed in the subject. The deployment of the three armies and five weapons is the branch of virtue. Rewards and punishments, benefits and harms, the five punishments and corporal penalties are the branch of teaching. Ritual, laws, measures, and standards, the comparison of names and forms are the detailed aspects of governance. The sounds of bells and drums, the forms of feathered banners are the branch of music. Mourning garments of varying degrees, the rituals of weeping and wailing are the branch of mourning. These five branches require the operation of the spirit and the movement of the mind’s art before they can be followed. The branches are things the ancients possessed, but they are not what should come first.

From this point onward, it once more discusses action, for while non-action is the root, action is the branch. The essential lies in the ruler’s way of non-action.

The details lie with the ministers, for the ministers’ Way is action. The assistance of martial might and civil virtue is why it is said: "The deployment of the three armies and the five weapons is the branch of virtue." The five weapons are the bow, the *shu*, the spear, the dagger-axe, and the shield. Clarifying punishments to aid teaching is why it is said: "Rewards and punishments, benefits and harms, the five punishments are the branch of teaching." Measures and standards are gradations; "names and forms" refer to the names of things. *Bi* means analogy, and "details" means the most minute particulars. Ritual, laws, measures, and standards, bells and drums, feathered banners—none of these are the root of ritual and music. As it is said: "How could it be merely about jade and silk, bells and drums?" This is the branch of mourning. "Rather than exchange it,宁戚’s meaning in these lines is most straightforward: the operation of the spirit and the movement of the mind’s art must come first, for all arises from the inner heart and is not imposed from without. The branches are things the ancients possessed, but they are not what should come first." This line is especially fine—how could Zhuangzi ever have intended to entirely discard weapons, punishments, ritual, and music?

The ruler leads and the minister follows; the father leads and the son follows; the elder brother leads and the younger brother follows; the elder leads and the younger follows; the man leads and the woman follows; the husband leads and the wife follows. Precedence and subordination are the natural course of Heaven and Earth. Thus the sage takes them as a model. Heaven is noble and Earth is base—this is the position of the numinous. Spring and summer come first, autumn and winter follow—this is the sequence of the four seasons. The myriad things transform and arise, each with its own form, flourishing and declining in due measure, flowing in ceaseless change. Even Heaven and Earth, most numinous of all, have their order of precedence and subordination—how much more so the human Way? Ancestral temples honor kinship; courts honor rank; village communities honor age; affairs honor worthiness. This is the sequence of the Great Way. To speak of the Way while violating its order is not the Way; to speak of the Way while not following the Way—how can one claim to have attained it?

Following the "lead" and "follow" above, many analogies are given, for what should come first comes first, and what should come after comes after—all is the natural principle of Heaven and Earth. Thus the sage takes them as a model. Heaven and Earth, the four seasons—these are also metaphors. "Transform and arise" means to come into being; as the *Book of Songs* says, "The *wei* also arises." *Meng* means sprouts; *qu* means differentiation. Things are born, each with its distinct form. Changing with the seasons, first flourishing then declining—this too is an analogy for the sequence of precedence. Flourishing does not last forever, nor does decline—all has its proper order. Thus it is called "the gradation of flourishing and decline." From precedence and subordination, we come to nobility and baseness, for nobility and baseness are also matters of precedence.

"In affairs, honor worthiness" means that in assigning duties, the worthy come first. Age, rank, kinship, and worthiness are all natural principles of the world, hence they are called "the sequence of the Great Way." "How can one claim to have attained the Way?" means that if one does not know this sequence, how can one possess the Way? Thus the ancients who illuminated the Great Way first illuminated Heaven, then the Dao and virtue; once the Dao and virtue were illuminated, then benevolence and righteousness followed; once benevolence and righteousness were illuminated, then the division of duties followed; once the division of duties was illuminated, then names and forms followed; once names and forms were illuminated, then the assignment of tasks followed; once the assignment of tasks was illuminated, then investigation and reduction followed; once investigation and reduction were illuminated, then right and wrong followed; once right and wrong were illuminated, then rewards and punishments followed.

Once rewards and punishments were illuminated, the foolish and the wise were placed appropriately, the noble and the base occupied their stations, the benevolent and the worthy, the unworthy and the dissolute all followed their natures, each according to their abilities, each by their names. With this, one served superiors, nurtured inferiors, governed things, and cultivated the self. Wisdom and schemes were not employed, and all returned to their Heavenly nature. This is called the Great Peace, the ultimate of governance.

This passage speaks of the sequence of governance, which has nine levels: Heaven is the first, the Dao and virtue the second, benevolence and righteousness the third, the division of duties the fourth, names and forms the fifth, the assignment of tasks the sixth, investigation and reduction the seventh, right and wrong the eighth, and rewards and punishments the ninth. "Division of duties" means the guarding of offices. "Names and forms" refers to names. "Assignment of tasks" means assigning great responsibilities according to one’s office. *Yuan* means to exempt; *sheng* means to reduce. If one is not up to the task, they are exempted and their duties reduced. "Right and wrong" means distinguishing the good from the bad. "Rewards and punishments" means using the whip to mark them, or chariots and robes to make them manifest.

Zhuangzi speaks of the sequence of governance in this way. How could Heaven’s punishment of the guilty and Heaven’s mandate of virtue not involve rewards and punishments? Must one go through nine transformations before reaching them? Such discussions stray far from the sages. Yet to say "first illuminate Heaven, then the Dao and virtue," and then list these subsequent levels—this is not abandoning the coarse to seek the refined. "The foolish and the wise placed appropriately" means being suited to one’s task; "occupying their stations" also means being in the proper position. *Xi* means to follow.

When their true dispositions are at peace, the noble and the petty each have their proper place. This necessarily follows from their names—by adhering to names, one holds them accountable to reality. When schemes and plans go unused, they must return to Heaven. Though all affairs have their proper places, there is no room for personal intent; all simply return to spontaneity—this is the age of Great Peace.

Thus, the ancient texts say: "There are forms and names." Forms and names existed among the ancients, but they were not what came first. Those who spoke of the Great Dao in ancient times described five transformations before forms and names could be established, and nine transformations before rewards and punishments could be discussed. To abruptly speak of forms and names is to ignore their root; to abruptly speak of rewards and punishments is to ignore their origin. To invert the Dao in speech and act contrary to it is what people manage—how can it manage people? To abruptly speak of forms, names, rewards, and punishments is to possess the tools of governance, not the Dao of governance. These may be applied to the world, but not used to embrace the world—this is what is called a debater, a one-sided person.

Rites, laws, measures, and degrees—along with the detailed comparisons of forms and names found in the ancients—are what the inferior use to serve the superior, not what the superior uses to nurture the inferior. The *Book* refers to ancient texts. Though forms and names appear within ancient texts, they never abandoned the root to pursue the branch. Thus, it is said: "They are not what comes first." If one does not know the sequence of priority and speaks abruptly, one loses the root and origin.

*Inverted* means to place things upside down; *contrary* means to go against. To act contrary to this natural Dao and invert its order is to be governed by others—this is to be used by the world, not to use the world. To regard forms, names, rewards, and punishments as the tools of governance and to take the division of duties and benevolence and righteousness as the Dao of governance—how could this be mistaken? Yet it remains a jumbled and fragmented approach, one-sided and partial.

What the superior uses to nurture the inferior is the way of the ruler; what the inferior uses to serve the superior is the way of the minister.

In ancient times, Shun asked Yao: "How does the Son of Heaven apply his mind?"
Yao said: "I do not slight the helpless, nor abandon the destitute. I grieve for the poor who suffer unto death, cherish the young, and pity women—this is how I apply my mind."
Shun said: "It is fine, but not yet great."
Yao said: "Then what should it be like?"
Shun said: "Heavenly virtue emerges in tranquility; the sun and moon shine, and the four seasons proceed. Like the constancy of day and night, the clouds move and the rain falls."
Yao said: "Then I am but entangled in turmoil! You unite with Heaven, while I unite with man."
Now, Heaven and Earth are what the ancients revered most, what the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun all praised together. Thus, those who ruled the world in ancient times—what did they do? They simply followed Heaven and Earth.

*Arrogance* means contempt; *suffering* evokes compassion.

"Jia" means to praise; "fujin" refers to widows. Though the term "widow" is not explicitly paired with "young child," its meaning is self-evident. "Heavenly virtue" is the virtue of spontaneity. "Emerges in tranquility" means it stands foremost among the myriad things, bringing peace to all under heaven. As the sun sets, the moon rises; as cold departs, heat arrives—thus the sun and moon shine, and the four seasons proceed. Day follows night, and night follows day, ever constant and unchanging. Clouds move and rain falls, following the seasons naturally. All these describe the meaning of "acting without acting."

"Jiaojiao raorao" means turmoil and disturbance. Yao said: "What I have done does not measure up to you; I cannot avoid self-generated turmoil. Thus, I unite only with man, not yet with Heaven." The following three sentences are Yao’s sigh of self-reproach.

"Heaven and Earth" are what the ancients revered most, for the principle of Heaven and Earth’s spontaneity has been the greatest from antiquity to the present. "Shared praise" means they are equally admired. Those who ruled the world did nothing but model themselves on Heaven and Earth.

The earlier passage already contrasts Yao and Shun, yet here the Yellow Emperor is included as well—there is no distinction in weight. If one clings to names and titles, the meaning becomes obstructed and impassable.

Confucius once sought to deposit books in the Zhou archives. Zilu advised: "I have heard that among the Zhou’s archivists, there is an elder named Lao Dan who has retired and resides at home. If you wish to store these books, Master, you might visit him." Confucius said: "Very well." He went to see Lao Dan, but Lao Dan refused. Thereupon, Confucius expounded the Twelve Classics to persuade him. Lao Dan countered, saying: "This is too reckless. I would hear only the essentials." Confucius replied: "The essentials lie in benevolence and righteousness." Lao Dan asked: "Are benevolence and righteousness part of human nature?" Confucius said: "Indeed. The noble person who lacks benevolence cannot be perfected; without righteousness, they cannot live. Benevolence and righteousness are the true nature of humanity. What else could they be?"

Lao Dan said: "May I ask what benevolence and righteousness are?" Confucius replied: "To be joyful at heart, harmonious with all things, to love universally without partiality—this is the essence of benevolence and righteousness." Lao Dan said: "Your words approach the mark. Yet is not universal love impractical? And is not what you call 'impartiality' itself a form of partiality?"

Should you wish the world never to lose its shepherding, then know that Heaven and Earth have their constancy, the sun and moon their brightness, the stars and constellations their ordered ranks, birds and beasts their flocks, and trees their rootedness. If you but follow virtue and walk the Way, you will have arrived at perfection—why then this restless striving? To brandish benevolence and righteousness is like beating a drum to seek a lost child. I fear you would disorder human nature.

The phrase "to store books in the Zhou court" means that Lao Dan traveled west to Zhou intending to examine its archives. "Turning and returning" describes his repeated explanation. "Hitting the mark" refers to Confucius’ words reaching only halfway before Lao Dan deemed them too prolix, too reckless, too diffuse. "Harmonious with all things" signifies delighting in things and becoming one with them. "Later words" refers to superficial remarks. "Approaching the mark" means precarious. How can universal love be applied to things that are inherently unequal? This is the impractical, convoluted doctrine. Once the name "impartiality" is claimed, a "partial" thought already lodges in the breast. The very notion of "impartiality" betrays intent—hence, "impartiality is itself partiality."

"Shepherding" means nurturing. If you wish the world never to lose its nurture, then within Heaven and Earth every thing possesses its natural endowment—how could force be applied? One must only rely on the spontaneous power of nature and follow the natural course of the Dao. To do so is already the utmost attainment—thus, "you will have arrived at perfection." "Lost child" means one who has fled.

Striking the drum to seek words is to toil and disturb the common customs of the world—such is the way to disorder human nature, hence the sigh and the meaning of the sigh. "Master" is like "my son." *Jiejie* describes the appearance of laborious exertion.

Shi Chengqi saw Laozi and asked, "I have heard that you, Master, are a sage. I did not hesitate to travel a great distance to come here, wishing to meet you. I have lodged a hundred nights, my calloused feet layered thick, yet dared not rest. Now, observing you, I see you are no sage. You have surplus grain and vegetables yet abandon your younger sister—this is not benevolence. You do not finish the food set before you yet hoard without limit." Laozi remained silent and did not respond.

The next day, Shi Chengqi saw him again and said, "Yesterday, I reproached you, but now my heart is at ease. Why is that?" Laozi replied, "Those cunning in knowledge, spiritually sagacious—I believed myself free of such things. Formerly, when you called me an ox, you named me an ox; when you called me a horse, you named me a horse. If one truly possesses a reality, others may give it a name, but if one does not accept it, to accept it twice invites calamity. I submit—constantly submit. I do not submit because there is submission."

"A hundred lodgings, calloused feet layered thick, yet dared not rest" describes his toil. *Juen* refers to thickened skin on the heels.

The leftover vegetables discarded in dark, obscure places—*mèi* (obscurity) shares its meaning with *mèi* (dimness)—this is not cherishing things, and thus is deemed unbenevolent. "Not finishing the food set before you yet hoard without limit" speaks of his surplus accumulation. *Shengshu* refers to raw and cooked foods placed before one, yet he does not use them fully, still endlessly gathering and storing—hence "hoarding without limit." Laozi remained silent and did not respond, thus refusing to answer.

*Cì* means to reproach; *qì* means to retreat. Formerly, there was reproach, but now his heart has fully receded, leaving nothing—after the meeting, he suddenly awakened. *Qiǎo zhī shén shèng* refers to the learning of deliberate action. *Tuō* means to depart, to rise above. I am without intent—whether you call me ox or horse, I merely listen. "If one truly possesses a reality, others may give it a name, but if one does not accept it, to accept it twice invites calamity"—this line is most pure. If I truly had such a matter and rejected another’s reproach, it would be a double transgression: first the fault, then the denial. *Fú* means to submit, to act. My conduct is constantly thus—not because I deem it right to act so, but because I do not know otherwise. Thus, "I submit—constantly submit. I do not submit because there is submission." That is to say, it is not stillness, yet the meaning of stillness is precisely this. The four instances of *fú* (submit) here are all masterful strokes.

Shi Chengqi walked in goose-step, avoiding his shadow, treading cautiously as he advanced and asked, "How should one cultivate the self?" Laozi replied, "Your countenance is haughty, your eyes piercing, your forehead protruding, your mouth agape, your demeanor rigid—like a horse tethered yet straining to bolt, moving yet restrained, hair-trigger perceptive, cunningly vigilant at every defense. All this betrays a lack of trust. At the borderlands, there is one called the Thief." *Yànxíng bì yǐng* describes his sidling posture; *lǚxíng* means stepping cautiously, one foot after the other. *Lǚxíng suì jìn* depicts his gradual, hesitant advance. *Yárán* conveys an aloof, detached air; *chōngrán*, a piercing gaze; *kuǎnrán*, a gaping mouth; *yìrán*, an unyielding stance. A horse’s nature is to run, and though tethered, it still strains to bolt—this is the meaning of "sitting yet galloping." The description is most apt. *Dòng ér chí* means to move with restraint, to act with affected composure. *Fā* refers to this.

The term *jī* refers to what is called "its trigger like a crossbow’s mechanism"—this describes how he governs right and wrong. *Chá ér shěn* means he favors keen discernment and meticulous scrutiny, leaving nothing concealed. *Zhī qiǎo ér dǔ yú tài* indicates that he relies on his cunning and displays arrogance outwardly. All these ten traits arise from a lack of sincerity, hence it is said, "All this betrays a lack of trust." Lack of trust stems from insincerity. If one perceives the true principle, this flaw would not arise. At the borderlands, if such a person exists, he is surely labeled a thief, for his scheming heart is too heavy, failing to follow the natural way of the world—such conduct invites disaster.

The Master said: The Dao is great yet does not end in the vast, small yet does not omit the minute; thus, the myriad things are complete within it. Vast indeed, it contains all; profound indeed, it cannot be fathomed. Manifest virtue, benevolence, and righteousness are but the remnants of its wondrous workings. Who but the perfected person can truly discern this? The Master—Laozi—speaks of the great as boundless, calling it "great without end," and of the small as all-encompassing, calling it "small without omission." Thus, it is said that nothing is too vast to bear it, nothing too minute to shatter it. No thing exists outside this Dao, hence "the myriad things are complete." "Vast indeed" speaks of its magnitude; "profound indeed," of its depth. When it takes form, it becomes virtue, benevolence, and righteousness—these are but the remnants of its marvelous workings. *Xíng* means manifestation; *shén*, the wondrous workings. *Dìng* means to discern clearly. Who but the perfected person can determine its root and branches?

The perfected person engages with the world—is this not vast? Yet it does not burden him. Though the world erects defenses, he does not join in their vigilance. He scrutinizes without pretense and does not shift for profit. He exhausts the true essence of things and guards his root, thus remaining untroubled by the external—transcending heaven and earth, forsaking the myriad things—while his spirit never encounters distress. In harmony with the Dao, aligned with virtue, he sets aside benevolence and righteousness, treats rites and music as guests. The heart of the perfected person is thus settled.

To "engage with the world" means to possess the world. Though the world is vast, it does not burden his heart. *Fèn fáng* refers to the defenses of power. Though the world vigorously enforces its safeguards, his heart does not follow their course—this means his heart remains unmoved. *Bù yǔ lì qiān* means he does not calculate gain or loss. *Jí wù zhī zhēn* means he exhausts the true principle of things, thus guarding his fundamental stillness. *Wài tiāndì yí wànwù* means he remains unmoved by external things. If his heart is unmoved, how can his spirit be distressed? *Tōng* means to be in accord; the Dao and virtue are natural. *Tuì rén yì* means he places benevolence and righteousness after the natural. *Bīn lǐ yuè* means that what governs is the nature and emotions, while rites and music are secondary. *Dìng* means stillness—this is why the heart of the perfected person is tranquil and settled.

What the world values in the Dao are its texts. Yet texts are but words, and words have their worth.

What is valued in words is their meaning. Meaning has its source, but what meaning follows cannot be transmitted through speech. Yet the world prizes the transmission of words through texts—though it values them, they are not truly worthy of esteem. For what it values is not what should be valued.

Thus, what can be seen are forms and colors; what can be heard are names and sounds. How lamentable that the world takes forms, colors, names, and sounds as sufficient to grasp the true nature of things! If forms, colors, names, and sounds are truly insufficient to grasp that nature, then the wise do not speak, and those who speak are not wise—how could the world recognize this?

Texts can convey the Dao, which is why the world values them. Yet what is valued lies in the Dao, not in the texts themselves. Because the Dao is expressed in words, those words may be deemed worthy—but what is truly worthy is the meaning, not the words. The meaning points in a direction words cannot fully capture; thus, neither words nor texts are truly worthy of esteem. To value them in this way is to value what is not truly valuable. Hence it is said: what is valued is not what should be valued.

Names are but words. Forms and colors can be seen; names and sounds can be heard. How could the Dao possess form, color, name, or sound? That the world seeks to grasp its true reality through what can be seen and heard—how lamentable! The true nature of things is their essence.

Decisiveness indeed! Since what is perceived through seeing and hearing is fundamentally insufficient to grasp the Dao, those who truly know it must remain silent, while those who speak cannot truly know it. How could the understanding of people today possibly reach this insight? How lamentable!

Duke Huan was reading in the hall while Wheelwright Bian carved a wheel below. Setting down his mallet and chisel, Bian ascended and asked the Duke: "May I dare ask what words Your Lordship is reading?"
The Duke replied: "The words of the sages."
Bian asked: "Are the sages still alive?"
The Duke said: "They are already dead."
Bian said: "Then what Your Lordship reads is but the dregs and lees of the ancients!"

The Duke said: "How can a wheelwright presume to criticize what I read? If you have an explanation, speak; if not, you die!"
Wheelwright Bian said: "From the perspective of my craft, when I carve a wheel slowly, it is smooth but not secure; when I carve quickly, it is rough and does not fit. Neither too slow nor too fast—I grasp it in my hands and respond with my heart, yet my mouth cannot express it. There is a knack to it that resides within, which I cannot convey to my son, nor can my son receive it from me. Thus, at seventy years of age, I am still carving wheels in my old age. If the ancients, together with what could not be transmitted, have died, then what Your Lordship reads is but the dregs and lees of the ancients!"

This extends the earlier analogy, illustrating through this example how the Dao cannot be transmitted through words. The metaphor is exquisitely precise: *sweet and smooth* refers to the ease of a loose fit, while *bitter and astringent* describes the difficulty of a tight one. *Slow* denotes a relaxed approach.

Swiftness is tightness. Loose yields sweet smoothness, easy entry yet lacking firmness; tight yields astringency, difficult entry. The key lies in neither loose nor tight—there exists a measure inherent within. Yet this knack cannot be conveyed, even from father to son. What books record are but the words of the ancients; if the person is no longer present, how can one obtain what cannot be transmitted? Feeding on dregs and lees, how can one know the taste of wine?

If the Dao could be offered to others, would one not offer it to one’s lord? If it could be transmitted to others, would one not pass it to one’s son? The same principle applies. Generally, what books record and expound upon is never confined to a single matter. This text, when turned over and over, speaks only of the principle of spontaneity, yet it spins forth many words—stranger with each turn—without a second theme. Viewed thus, the incomparable depth of Zhuangzi becomes ever more apparent. The same holds for those who read Buddhist scriptures.

**Outer Chapters, "Heaven’s Motion" (Chapter Fourteen)**
Does heaven move? Does earth abide? Do the sun and moon contend for their places? Who presides over this? Who maintains its order? Who, without purpose, propels it forward? Is there some mechanism that compels it, unable to rest? Or does it revolve of itself, unable to halt? Are clouds the cause of rain? Or is rain the cause of clouds? Who brings them forth? Who, without purpose, indulges in excess and urges them on? The wind rises from the north, now west, now east, swirling aloft—who exhales and inhales it? Who, without purpose, stirs and scatters it?

These lines are exquisitely precise—five instances of *hu* (乎), unmatched by any before or since. Does heaven move in a daily revolution of its own accord? Does earth, with its fourfold motion, truly abide in stillness? The sun departs, the moon arrives—yet this is called "contending for their places," as though they were locked in pursuit. Who could have coined these three words—*presides*, *maintains*, *order*—with such force? *Mechanism that compels, unable to rest; revolves of itself, unable to halt*—these words suggest it acts not by its own will. Heaven’s qi descends, earth’s qi ascends, giving rise to clouds and rain—but which gives rise to which? Such a question is indeed extraordinary. *Brings forth* means to rise; *stops* means to cease, akin to tension and release. Who causes it to act or cease? *Indulges in excess* means to be unrestrained; *urges* means to encourage. Who engages in wanton play and aids in the formation of clouds and rain?

The winds arise from all four directions—yet when we speak of their origin in the north, this follows the celestial form in its description. As heaven leans toward the north, winds naturally come from the north, sometimes from the west, sometimes from the east, sometimes ascending, sometimes descending, drifting and wandering in their comings and goings. The text speaks of "above" but not "below"—such is the stylistic convention.

*Rustling and swaying*—this describes their motion. One dares to ask: why is this so? Wu Xian of the Shao clan replied, "Let me tell you: heaven has six poles and five constants. When emperors and kings follow them, there is order; when they oppose them, there is chaos. The affairs of the Nine Luo bring governance to completion and virtue to fulfillment, illuminating and overseeing the earth below, so that all under heaven revere them. This is what is called the Supreme Sovereign."

The questioner does not name a person—another shift in stylistic technique. The *six poles* are the six qi; the *five constants* are the five phases. Both the six qi and the five phases are the natural principles. The *Nine Luo* refers to the nine provinces; *Luo* means to gather, interchangeable with *luo* (to fall), as the ancient characters are mutually used. *Governance to completion and virtue to fulfillment* means that when emperors and kings follow these natural principles to govern the nine provinces, their achievements are perfected and their virtue is fulfilled. They oversee all under heaven, and the people revere them—these are the men above the Three Sovereigns. Thus it is said: this is called the Supreme Sovereign.

The Grand Steward Dang of Shang asked Zhuangzi about *ren* (benevolence). Zhuangzi said, "Tigers and wolves possess *ren*." Dang asked, "What do you mean?" Zhuangzi replied, "Father and son show affection for one another—how is this not *ren*?" Dang said, "May I ask about perfect *ren*?" Zhuangzi said, "Perfect *ren* has no partiality." The Grand Steward said, "I have heard that without partiality, there is no love; without love, there is no filial piety. Can perfect *ren* be unfilial?" Zhuangzi said, "Not so. Perfect *ren* is loftier still—filial piety is insufficient to describe it. This is not a matter of surpassing filial piety, but of falling short of it."

Taking tigers and wolves as examples of *ren* aligns with the idea that even bandits have their *Dao*. These are all critiques aimed at the Confucians. Though Zhuangzi’s words may be one-sided, they still hold their own logic. The saying goes, "Even fierce tigers do not eat their young"—is this not the *ren* of tigers and wolves? *Perfect ren has no partiality* means that while *ren* is rooted in mutual affection, one who embodies perfect *ren* does not rely on such affection—this is the ultimate *ren*. *Filial piety is insufficient to describe it* does not mean it is unfilial, but that when one reaches perfect *ren*, filial piety need not be spoken of. Perfect *ren* stands above filial piety, surpassing it. The Grand Steward’s question, however, reflects a failure to grasp filial piety—he has not yet fully realized *ren*, and thus falls short of filial piety. One who fully embodies *ren* transcends it.

One who travels south to Ying, facing north, cannot see Mount Ming—why is this? Because it is too far away. Thus it is said: replacing reverent filial piety with loving filial piety is difficult; replacing loving filial piety with forgetting one’s parents is difficult; replacing forgetting one’s parents with making one’s parents forget oneself is difficult; replacing making one’s parents forget oneself with mutual forgetting with all under heaven is difficult; replacing mutual forgetting with all under heaven with making all under heaven forget oneself is difficult.

Virtue surpasses that of Yao and Shun yet is not performed; beneficence extends to ten thousand generations, yet none under heaven know of it—how could one merely sigh and speak of *ren* and filial piety? Filial piety, brotherly respect, *ren*, righteousness, loyalty, trustworthiness, integrity, and incorruptibility—these are all self-exhortations that labor one’s virtue, and are not worth esteeming. Thus it is said: the most noble is when state rank is discarded; the richest is when state wealth is discarded; the most desired is when fame and reputation are discarded. Only then does the Dao remain unchanging.

Mount Ming lies in the north. Traveling south to Ying, one cannot see the northern mountains—this is because they are too distant, not because they are insufficient. This is a simple analogy to illustrate surpassing and falling short of filial piety, and it is indeed extraordinary. *Reverent filial piety* still leaves traces; *loving filial piety* leads to mutual forgetting. From this point onward, the text speaks of forgetting one’s parents, forgetting all under heaven, and all under heaven forgetting oneself—each step is higher than the last. The stylistic technique of this text is such that having traces is inferior to having none, having intention is inferior to having none, and discarding is the ultimate aim.

To scorn Yao and Shun as unworthy of being called virtuous, to see beneficence extending to ten thousand generations as insufficient to be called *ren*—how could one boast of *ren* and filial piety? Sighing in admiration is self-praise. Filial piety, brotherly respect, *ren*, righteousness, loyalty, trustworthiness, integrity, and incorruptibility—these eight are what the world considers fine virtues, but in truth, they are merely self-exhortations that labor one’s virtue. Thus it is said: *self-exhortations that labor one’s virtue are not worth esteeming*. *Labor* means to toil; *not worth esteeming* means not worth valuing.

The utmost nobility I possess—why seek it in state ranks? The utmost wealth I possess—why seek it in state wealth? The utmost aspiration I possess—why seek it in fame and reputation? All these are cast aside, discarded in word and deed.

Supreme nobility, supreme wealth, supreme aspiration—these belong to the Dao of non-action. State wealth is merely the wealth of the state. Unchanging and immutable, this is what is meant by *constant thusness*. The eight virtues are actions that labor the self, while I remain ever in non-action.

Beimen Cheng asked the Yellow Emperor, saying: "When Your Majesty performed the music of *Xianchi* in the wilds of Dongting, at first I heard it and was afraid; then I heard it again and grew weary; finally, I heard it and was perplexed. Adrift and silent, I could no longer find myself." This is but another fabricated tale, a peculiar account—first fear, then weariness, and finally confusion. When I heard this music, my state changed thrice: adrift, my spirit scattered; silent, my mouth sealed; ill at ease, I could not find peace, so startled was I by this music.

The Emperor said: "Perhaps it was indeed so for you. I performed it with human artistry, harmonized it with Heaven, conducted it with ritual and righteousness, and established it in the Great Purity. The four seasons arise in succession, the myriad things follow their birth, now flourishing, now declining. Civil and martial follow their order, now clear, now turbid. Yin and Yang harmonize, their radiance flowing as sound. Hibernating creatures stir, and I startle them with thunder. In the end, it has no tail; in the beginning, it has no head. Now dying, now living, now collapsing, now rising—ever constant and inexhaustible, yet never to be awaited. Thus you were afraid.

Perhaps it was indeed so for you. My music, when you heard it, should have brought these three transformations." *Performed* means to play; *harmonized* refers to the markers on a zither. *Conducted* and *established* mean to set in motion and elevate. *Human* refers to human affairs.

The "Heaven" here refers to heavenly principle; *ritual propriety and righteousness* denote the orderly progression of sound. *Great Purity* aligns with the workings of creation. The initial sound is thus balanced and upright. From "the four seasons arise in succession" onward, it speaks of the time of activation, when transformations stir and astonish, delighting and startling, now arising, now ceasing—yet without any sign of a final destination.

*Flourishing* pertains to the civil; *withering* pertains to the martial. *Order* refers to sequence. The four seasons give life and take it, and the myriad things follow their sequence in growth, flourishing and then declining, just as music has its civil and martial order. The zither possesses civil and martial markers, which is precisely this civil-martial sequence—hence it is said, "Civil and martial follow their order." *Flowing radiance* means smooth and luminous. Harmonizing the sounds of yin and yang, clear and turbid, it flows thus luminously. When hibernating creatures are about to stir and thunder resounds, one meets it without seeing its beginning, follows it without seeing its end—hence it is said, "In the end, it has no tail; in the beginning, it has no head." *Head and tail* are simply *beginning and end*. *Dying and living, collapsing and rising* are ever constant and inexhaustible—this speaks of how it now acts, now ceases, both constant and ever-changing, so its constancy is boundless. Seeking its place of return to unity yet finding none, it is said, "Yet never to be awaited." This is why you were afraid upon first hearing it.

I then performed it with the harmony of yin and yang, illuminating it with the brightness of sun and moon. Its sound could be short or long, soft or firm, its transformations uniform and unconfined—hence it is ever-present. Filling the valleys, filling the ravines, filling the crevices, the spirit guards it, measured by things. Its sound soars and lingers, its name lofty and luminous. Thus do ghosts and spirits guard its depths, while the sun, moon, and stars follow their courses. I halt it at the bounded, yet let it flow into the boundless. You may ponder it yet cannot know it, gaze upon it yet cannot see it, pursue it yet cannot reach it. Suddenly, it stands in the Dao of the four voids, leaning against a withered catalpa, chanting. The eye exhausts itself in what it seeks to see, strength fails in what it seeks to pursue. Since I cannot reach it, my form fills the emptiness, and I yield and drift. You, too, yield and drift—hence your negligence.

The harmony of yin and yang and the brightness of sun and moon are merely the meaning of harmonious flourishing and luminous radiance. Long and short, soft and firm, all are transformations—none can be fixed—hence it is said, "Its transformations are uniform and unconfined." *Uniform* means the same. *Hence* refers to what was said before. *Unconfined* means ever-renewing.

Filled to every ravine and valley—this speaks of its plenitude throughout Heaven and Earth. Obstructions and crevices block one’s hearing and clarity; *xi* (郄) is interchangeable with *xi* (隙), referring to the seven apertures. Diminish your hearing and clarity, and guard them with spirit. Follow the myriad things, measuring them—this speaks of my making of music: not employing cleverness or skill, but following nature.

Its sound, resonant and expansive, arises naturally, bearing the name of loftiness. *"Spirit guards its depths"*—this is that very loftiness. It does not harm the soul, nor does it weary. The sun, moon, and stars move in their courses, their coming and going natural. As if halting, yet also as if without halt—hence it is said, *"It halts at what is bounded, flows without cease."* To ponder yet not know, to gaze yet not see, to pursue yet not reach—all describe how it seems to be a thing yet is not a thing.

The *four voids* are the Great Void. At that moment, I stand within the Great Void, leaning against a withered catalpa, chanting. Though I long to see, it cannot be exhausted; though I long to pursue, it cannot be reached. My form, though full, forgets itself as if empty. Thus I yield and drift—how much more so for you? It is precisely this yielding and drifting that makes you negligent.

*Tangran* (傥然) describes a state without intent. Again, I play music without negligence, tuning it to the command of nature. Thus it seems to mingle and surge like thickets and forests, music without form, spreading and unfurling without drag, dark and dim yet soundless, moving without direction, dwelling in profound obscurity. Some call it death, some call it life; some call it substance, some call it glory. Flowing, scattering, shifting—without fixed sound, the world doubts it. Yet the sage examines it: the sage is one who penetrates to reality and fulfills destiny.

The heavenly mechanism is not displayed, yet the five senses are all complete—this is called *heavenly music*. Though wordless, the heart delights. Thus the Lord of Yan sang its praise:

*"Hear it yet hear no sound,
See it yet see no form.
Filling Heaven and Earth,
Enveloping the six directions—
You long to hear it yet find no point of contact,
And so remain perplexed."*

Without negligence, it is ceaseless.

The natural mandate is none other than the natural principle. "Mixed and pursuing, thronging and growing" describes the myriad things thronging and growing in mutual pursuit. "Forest music" speaks of a music so abundant and pervasive that all is music. Yet no form is seen; it spreads and unfurls without the need for force to drag it. Dark and dim, it cannot be heard. It moves without fixed direction, dwelling in the profound obscurity of the unfathomable and unsearchable. It is neither life nor death, neither glory nor substance. Flowing, scattering, shifting—it does not adhere to any constant sound. When the world reaches this point, it congeals in incomprehension and turns to the sage for inquiry. *Ji* means to examine. To "penetrate to reality" is to penetrate to the true principle; to "fulfill destiny" is to reach the ultimate of the natural.

The five senses are all complete, yet the heavenly mechanism does not move—this is what is meant by the ears, eyes, hands, and feet all being present, yet seeing, hearing, and movement all occurring without self-awareness. Thus one attains the joy of the natural, which is called *heavenly music*. As the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* says: "When the backward-flowing current returns to perfect unity, the six senses cease to function"—this is the meaning of "the heavenly mechanism does not move, yet the five senses are all complete." "Though wordless, the heart delights" speaks of a joy beyond words. Though you long to hear it, there is no point of contact, and so you remain perplexed.

Here, another eulogy is composed—a marvelous example of textual elaboration. "Filling Heaven and Earth, enveloping the six directions" means it pervades all. These four lines of the eulogy contain no separate meaning; by adding a turn, they form a rhythm—this is the art of composition.

As for joy: it begins with awe. Awe gives rise to reverence; reverence leads to negligence; negligence leads to escape; escape culminates in perplexity; perplexity culminates in ignorance; and ignorance culminates in the Dao. Only then can it be carried and journeyed with. Earlier, awe, negligence, and perplexity did not reveal their meaning; it is only at the point of culmination—ignorance—that one may enter the Dao. This turn is especially ingenious, for it speaks of the stages through which one must pass in seeking the Dao before making progress. Reverence conveys solemnity; negligence leading to escape is the moment of being unable to stop; perplexity leading to ignorance is the moment when consciousness and the six senses cease to function. Observing these three stages, one sees the workings of the Chan school. Though the joy is expressed through three hypotheticals, there is no great difference—only the stirring of its words.

When Confucius traveled west to Wei, Yan Yuan asked Shi Jin, "What do you make of the Master’s conduct?"
Shi Jin said, "Alas! Your Master is in dire straits."
Yan Yuan said, "How so?"
Shi Jin said, "Before the straw dogs are displayed, they are kept in fine baskets and covered with embroidered cloth. The invocator fasts and purifies himself to present them. But once they have been displayed, passersby trample their heads and backs, and gatherers take them to burn. If one were to gather them again, place them in fine baskets, cover them with embroidered cloth, and wander or rest beneath them, one would surely dream incessantly—or at the very least, suffer from blurred vision.

Now your Master has taken the straw dogs of the former kings—already displayed—and with his disciples wanders and rests beneath them. Thus he was assaulted by the felling of trees in Song, had his traces erased in Wei, and was impoverished in Shang and Zhou. Is this not his dream? Besieged between Chen and Cai, he went seven days without cooking a meal, with death and life as neighbors. Is this not his blurred vision?"

This hypothetical discussion shows that even in Confucius’ time, there were sages like the Old Man Carrying Reeds, Jieyu the Madman of Chu, and the recluses Changju and Jieni—all of this kind. Straw dogs are made of bound grass to dispel misfortune. Once used in sacrifice, they are discarded. *Qie* and *yan* are baskets.

Grass is gathered for straw. *Mi* means dust entering the eyes. This is to say that what the Confucians study are all the stale words of antiquity, useless in the present age. Now, in water, nothing is better than a boat; on land, nothing is better than a cart. Because a boat can travel on water, if one seeks to push it onto land, it will never move an inch in a lifetime. Yet antiquity and the present are not like water and land, nor are Zhou and Lu like boats and carts. To insist on practicing Zhou’s ways in Lu is like pushing a boat onto land—laborious yet fruitless, and one will surely bring misfortune upon oneself. They do not understand the transmission of the boundless Way, which responds to things without exhaustion.

The analogy of rivers and land, boats and carts, speaks of the difference of times. The transmission of the boundless Way does not cling to a single path. Since antiquity, what has been transmitted is precisely a Way that adapts to the times without clinging to one path, thus responding to the world without exhaustion.

Have you alone not seen the well-sweep? When pulled, it bows; when released, it rises. What pulls it is not the pull of others. Thus it bows and rises without offending anyone. Bowing and rising in accord with others, with no place for personal inclination—this is the analogy of responding to things without fixed direction.

Therefore, the rites, righteousness, laws, and standards of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors do not pride themselves on uniformity but on governance. Thus, the rites, righteousness, laws, and standards of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors are like crabapples, pears, oranges, and pomelos: their flavors differ, yet all are pleasing to the mouth. Thus rites, righteousness, laws, and standards are things that change with the times. Crabapples, pears, oranges, and pomelos—all are praised by people, yet their flavors differ. This illustrates the meaning that the Three Kings had different rites and the Five Emperors different music. *Zha* is a kind of fruit resembling a pear but sour.

Now, if one takes a gibbon or macaque and dresses it in the robes of the Duke of Zhou, it will surely bite, tear, and rip them off until they are completely cast aside and only then be satisfied. To observe the difference between antiquity and the present is like the difference between a gibbon or macaque and the Duke of Zhou. To force people of today to practice the rites and music of the ancients is like forcing a gibbon or macaque to wear human clothes—yet here it is not called "human clothes" but "the robes of the Duke of Zhou," with the intent to mock the sages. The Duke of Zhou established rites, including the regulations for caps, crowns, robes, and skirts, hence "the robes of the Duke of Zhou."

Thus, when Xishi was afflicted with heart pain and knit her brows in her village, the ugly women of her village saw it and thought it beautiful. Returning home, they too clutched their chests and knit their brows. The rich people of the village, seeing this, firmly shut their doors and would not come out. The poor people, seeing it, took their wives and children and fled. They knew that knitting brows was beautiful but did not know why knitting brows was beautiful. How pitiful! And how straitened is your Master!

*Pin* means to knit the brows. For people of today to imitate the ancients is like the village women imitating Xishi’s knitting of brows. The reason knitting brows is beautiful is that there must first be a Xishi; the reason the Way is practicable is that there must first be the ancients. Yet your Master says, "You, sir, are my Master." This hypothetical discussion employs six analogies in succession, each finely crafted. Nothing is more difficult than analogies. Wang Quxuan once said, "All my life, I have wanted to create my own analogies, but every time I think of one, it turns out to have been used by someone before." In the *Zhuangzi*, every analogy is extraordinarily unique.

Confucius, at the age of fifty-one, had still not heard the Way. He went south to Pei to see Lao Dan. Lao Dan said, "Have you come? I have heard that you are a worthy man of the north. Have you also attained the Way?" Confucius said, "I have not." Laozi said, "How have you sought it?" Confucius said, "I sought it in measures and numbers, but after five years I had not attained it." Laozi said, "How else have you sought it?" Confucius said, "I sought it in yin and yang, but after twelve years I had still not attained it." Laozi said, "Indeed! If the Way could be offered, there is no one who would not offer it to their lord. If the Way could be presented, there is no one who would not present it to their parents. If the Way could be told to others, there is no one who would not tell it to their brothers. If the Way could be given to others, there is no one who would not give it to their children and grandchildren."

*Measures and numbers* refer to rites and music; *yin and yang* refer to the principles of the myriad things. The five and twelve years have no particular significance; they merely say that he sought it diligently for a long time without attainment. From "If the Way could be offered" onward, the four sentences are exquisitely phrased. This is precisely how the Way cannot be transmitted, and such language brings it forth.

Yet it cannot be so for no other reason than this: what is within has no master and does not abide; what is without has no standard and does not proceed. What issues from within is not received from without—thus the sage does not expound. What enters from without has no master within—thus the sage does not retain it.

*What is within has no master and does not abide* means it is not self-evident or self-realized. It speaks of those who study the Way: though they may hear something from without, if within they have no master, it is not something they have attained themselves. Though they may wish to retain it, it will not stay.

*What is without has no standard* means there is nothing to verify or correct. This is what the Chan school calls "confirmation." If within me I have already attained something myself and verify it with a person of the Way, then I can proceed on my own. If I have no attainment, then how can I be confirmed by others? Though these two sentences distinguish between inner and outer, in truth they both emphasize self-attainment.

*What issues from within is not received from without*—this speaks of teaching others. Though my words issue from within, if you cannot receive them, then the sage will not speak to you. When I spoke with Yan Hui all day, he never opposed me—he was able to receive. If you cannot receive, then the sage will not tell you.

Thus it is said, "The sage does not expound." *What enters from without has no master within*—this speaks of receiving teaching. Though my words enter from without, if in your hearing you have no insight and within you have no master, though you hear the words, you will gain nothing. This is what the Chan school means by "entering by the gate is not the family treasure." Since you have no attainment, you merely take the sage as retaining it. In truth, the sage does not retain it.

Do you disciples take me as retaining it? I do not retain it. You are this—this is the meaning. These four sentences are all profoundly subtle; you must examine them carefully. The reason the Way cannot be transmitted has no other cause—its flaw lies in these four sentences alone. Therefore, it first says, "Yet it cannot be so for no other reason than this."

Fame is a public vessel; it cannot be taken in excess. Benevolence and righteousness are the travelers’ huts of the former kings. One may stay in them for a night but cannot dwell in them for long. The perfected persons of antiquity borrowed the Way from benevolence and lodged in righteousness to wander in the realm of carefree ease, to eat in the fields of simplicity, and to stand in the gardens of non-transaction. Carefree ease is non-action; simplicity is easy nourishment; non-transaction is no expenditure.

The ancients called this "the wandering of gathering the genuine." *Fame cannot be taken in excess*—this mocks the Confucians’ love of fame.

The *qulu* is a thatched hut—benevolence and righteousness cannot be dwelled in long, for wherever there are traces, one cannot remain for long. *Gou* means "to see"; as soon as there are sounds and traces to be seen, calamity and disaster arise from them. Hence it is said, "The more one sees, the more one demands." Borrowing the Way and lodging in righteousness cannot be a long abode—this is the meaning of "transforming when one goes too far."

*Goujian* means "careless and provisional," speaking of adapting to the times to make provision easy. *Bu dai* is like the common saying "not losing one’s capital"—easy to nourish, easy to suffice. "No expenditure" means no exertion, no cost to oneself. "Gathering the genuine" means gathering the truth of reality.

Those who take wealth as right cannot yield emolument; those who take prominence as right cannot yield fame. Those who cling to power cannot share authority. When they grasp it, they tremble; when they relinquish it, they grieve—and in all this, they have nothing to reflect upon, gazing ceaselessly at what they cannot cease pursuing.
