Those who come are not barred; those who go are not stopped—this means following nature’s course without welcoming or sending off.

The strong and unyielding depart, while those who bend and cling seek to attach themselves to me; I follow and yield to them all, letting them be as they are. "Self-exhausting" means coming of its own accord. Whether compliant or contrary, in the end, nothing is sought, yet all arrives naturally—hence it is said, "following its self-exhaustion." Though I levy and gather, not a single hair of the people is harmed—thus, "not a hair is damaged." The "great path" refers to matters that proceed smoothly and without obstruction; simply handle them with a mind devoid of intention, and they are swiftly accomplished.

Confucius was besieged between Chen and Cai for seven days without cooked food. Taigong Ren went to console him, saying, "You nearly died, did you not?" Confucius replied, "Yes." "Do you detest death?" "Yes." Ren said, "I once spoke of the way to avoid death. In the Eastern Sea there is a bird called *Yidai*. As a bird, it flies weakly and feebly, as if incapable. When taking flight, it relies on others to lead; when perching, it is pressed and constrained. It dares not advance first nor retreat last; in feeding, it dares not taste first but must take the leavings. For this reason, it is never singled out in formation, and others ultimately cannot harm it—thus it escapes misfortune. The straight tree is the first felled; the sweet well is the first drained. You, sir, cultivate knowledge to startle the foolish, refine your conduct to expose the tainted—shining brightly as if carrying the sun and moon in your stride, how could you avoid peril? Long ago, I heard from a man of great completion: 'Those who boast of themselves achieve no merit; those who achieve merit ruin their names; those who attain fame stumble. Who can relinquish merit and fame and return to the common? The Dao flows yet remains obscure; one attains it yet is unrecognized; one acts yet is unnamed.' Pure and constant, one is likened to the mad—erasing traces, discarding influence, and not pursuing merit or fame. Thus, no one can reproach him, nor does he reproach others. The perfected man remains unknown—why should you rejoice?"

Confucius said, "Excellent!" He then parted from his acquaintances, dismissed his disciples, and fled to the great marshlands. Dressed in coarse cloth, feeding on acorns and chestnuts, he entered among beasts without disturbing their herds, among birds without disrupting their flocks. Neither birds nor beasts shunned him—how much less would men? "Do you detest death?" means: in such dire straits, does your heart also loathe them? "The way to avoid death" refers to self-contentment free from calamity.

*Yidai* is today’s swallow. *Fenfen-zhizhi* describes its manner of flight. "Drawing support" means flying in flocks. "Pressed and constrained in perching" means nesting near humans. "Daring not advance first nor retreat last" means it does not contend in coming and going. *Xu* means leavings—taking insects that others have discarded. "Not singled out" means it is not numerous.

Though they form ranks, they are not as numerous as the flocks of crows and geese. Each relies on human households, yet others do not harm them—this is the metaphor of the straight tree and the sweet well, which become known by their very nature.

The *Greatly Accomplished* is one who embodies the great Dao, a scholar of the Way. Those who boast and claim merit will never succeed; those who delight in fame and achievement will ultimately harm themselves. *Huikui*—all self-inflicted damage. "Returning to speak with the multitude" means withdrawing to be as one with them. Moving in accord with the Dao, one remains dim and self-effacing. Thus it is said: the flow of the Dao is not manifest. Though one may act according to one’s will in the moment, one does not exalt oneself through fame. Thus it is said: when dwelling in what is fitting, one acts without claiming a place; when not dwelling in what is fitting, one does not possess it. *Chunchun* and *changchang* are one and the same—comparable to madness, as if without mind. Erasing one’s traces, relinquishing power, and setting aside thoughts of merit and fame—this is transformation without leaving a mark. I do not reproach others, and others forget me: such is the *Perfect Person*. If the Perfect Person desires no renown in the world, why should you, Master, rejoice in fame?

The final lines echo the passage where "eating pork is like eating human flesh," borrowing Confucius’s name to expound the teaching—this is reiteration for emphasis.

Confucius asked Zisang Hu, "I was twice exiled from Lu, had my tree felled in Song, erased my traces in Wei, and was impoverished in Shang and Zhou, besieged between Chen and Cai. Having endured these many hardships, my close associates grew more distant, and my disciples and friends scattered. Why is this?"

Zisang Hu replied, "Have you not heard of the man of Jia who fled? Lin Hui abandoned a jade disc worth a thousand gold pieces to carry a newborn child and flee. Someone asked, 'Was it for the sake of its value? The child’s value is slight. Was it for the sake of its burden? The child’s burden is great. Why abandon a jade disc worth a thousand gold pieces to carry a child and flee?' Lin Hui said, 'The jade was bound by profit; the child was bound by Heaven. Those bound by profit abandon one another in straits, calamity, and harm. Those bound by Heaven gather together in straits, calamity, and harm. The difference between gathering and abandoning is vast. Moreover, the friendship of the noble is as bland as water; the friendship of the petty is as sweet as sweet wine. The noble are bland yet intimate; the petty are sweet yet easily severed. Those who unite without cause will part without cause.'"

Confucius said, "I respectfully receive your instruction." He walked slowly and wandered home, abandoned his learning, discarded his books, and his disciples no longer bowed before him, yet their affection for him deepened.

*Zisang Hu* is *Hu* (door). *Jiaren* refers to a man of a fictitious state. Abandoning the jade and carrying the child is the finest metaphor: those bound by Heaven must always gather, while those bound by profit must abandon one another. The friendship of the noble is bland yet intimate; the friendship of the petty is sweet yet easily severed—this exhausts the human condition. Though these words are spoken of others, Mencius also said, "Those who unite without cause will part without cause," as seen in the *Odes of Bin*. This line is another fine thread of coherence. "No longer bowing before him" means not being constrained by the formalities of bowing in his presence, yet their mutual affection grew deeper.

Another day, Zisang Hu said, "When Shun was about to die, he truly admonished Yu, saying, 'Be vigilant! In form, nothing surpasses following; in emotion, nothing surpasses compliance. Following, one does not depart; complying, one does not labor. Not departing, not laboring—then one does not seek adornment to match form. Not seeking adornment to match form—then one does not depend on external things.'"

*Ling* (clear) is pronounced *ling* (to understand). He instructed Yu with the true and real Dao, hence "truly admonished." *Yuan* means to follow its natural course; *shuai* means to comply with its natural tendency. Not departing is to be one with the Dao. *Xing* (form) is the self; *wen* (adornment) is what is external to the self. Not using what is external to adorn the self—thus it is said, "one does not seek adornment to match form." Today, when people host guests, they say "to await guests"—this is the meaning of *dai* (to await). Not using external adornments means having no need for things. Thus it is said, "one fundamentally does not depend on things." This *dai* (to await) is the sense of "not using." The three instances of *dai* take on two meanings.

Zhuangzi wore a robe of coarse cloth patched with hemp, tied his shoes with cords, and passed by the King of Wei. The king said, "Why is the Master so weary?"

Zhuangzi said, "It is poverty, not weariness. When a scholar possesses the Dao and virtue but cannot put them into practice, this is weariness. Wearing tattered clothes and threadbare shoes is poverty, not weariness. This is what is called 'not encountering the right time.' Have you alone not seen the gibbon? When it obtains *nan*, *zi*, *yu*, and *zhang* trees, it grasps the vines, swings through the branches, and reigns supreme among them—even Yi or Peng Meng could not take aim at it. Yet when it finds itself among thorny *zhe*, *ji*, *zhi*, and *gou* trees, it moves cautiously, glances warily, trembles and quakes. Not that its sinews and bones have suddenly stiffened and lost their suppleness, but the circumstances are unfavorable, and it cannot display its abilities. Now, dwelling among dark rulers and chaotic ministers, how could one not be weary? This is like the heart of Bi Gan being carved out—clear proof!"

*Dabu* is coarse cloth; *zheng* (to tie) is a belt. *Kuai* (to fasten) is tied in a knot at the waist. *Xilü* means the shoes are worn out and strung together with cords. *Bei* means affliction. *Lan* means to grasp; *man* means to entwine. These two words describe the gibbon in the trees—it is not careless. *Wangchang* means its spirit is exuberant and its will fulfilled. *Zhe*, *ji*, *zhi*, and *gou* are thorny trees. *Zhendong* means fear; *daoli* means trembling. The phrase "not supple" is preceded by "suddenly stiffened"—this is excellent. Medical texts describe a condition of stiff neck and back, which is stiffened and not supple. Using this to describe the gibbon is especially vivid. *Zheng* (proof) means to compare Bi Gan’s case to show its verification—these three words are also striking.

Confucius was stranded between Chen and Cai, going seven days without cooking a meal. Leaning on a withered tree with his left hand and striking its withered branches with his right, he sang the airs of the *Yan* clan. There was the form of the song but not its meter, the sound but not the tones of gong and jue. The sound of wood and the sound of man blended harmoniously, resonating deeply in the hearts of others. Yan Hui stood with hands clasped and turned his gaze to observe. Fearing that Hui would exalt him and thereby reach excess, or love him and thereby reach sorrow, Confucius said, "Hui, it is easy not to suffer the harm of Heaven, but difficult not to benefit from men. Nothing begins that does not end. Man and Heaven are one. Who is it that sings now?"

*Gaomu* is a withered tree; *gaozhi* is a withered branch, as in the *Qiwulun* ("The Equality of Things"), where it is called *fangzhi*. Striking the withered branch against the withered tree—thus it is said, "there was the form." Though he struck, there was no rhythm, hence "not its meter." Without gong and jue, it means not conforming to the five tones. The sound of wood is the striking; the sound of man is the singing. *Liran* means precise and fitting. *Guangji* means to honor me. If one seeks from the intention of honoring me, what is reached has no bounds—thus it is said, "fearing that he would exalt me and thereby reach excess." If one ponders from the intention of loving me, it must lead to sorrow—thus it is said, "loving me and thereby reaching sorrow." *Zao* is pronounced *cuo*. "Man and Heaven are one" means that what is in me is all Heavenly principle. The singer now is not me—thus it is said, "Who is it?"

Yan Hui said, "May I ask how to remain untouched by Heaven’s diminishment?"
Confucius replied, "Hunger and thirst, cold and heat, constraints and blockages—these are the movements of Heaven and Earth, the outflow of the turning of things. To speak of going along with them is what is meant. As a minister, one does not dare abandon them; holding to the Dao of the minister is already thus—how much more so for how one awaits Heaven? What is meant by remaining untouched by man’s augmentation is difficult?"
Confucius replied, "At first, one’s path opens in four directions; ranks and emoluments arrive together without end—what things deem beneficial is not one’s own. My mandate lies in what is external. The noble man does not act as a thief; the worthy does not act as a bandit. If I were to take these, what would I do? Thus it is said: No bird is wiser than the swallow. What its eyes deem unsuitable, it does not even glance at; though the fruit falls before it, it abandons it and flees—such is its awe. Yet it nests among men, and the altars of state endure. What do you mean by ‘there is no beginning that is not an end’?"
Confucius replied, "The myriad things transform, yet one does not know who succeeds them. One knows where they end; one knows where they begin—simply align with them and await them, that is all. What is meant by ‘man and Heaven are one’?"
Confucius replied, "There is man, and there is Heaven; there is also Heaven alone. That man cannot possess Heaven’s nature—this is why the sage calmly embodies the passing and comes to rest. *Tian sun* means adversity in time; *wu shou* means poverty yet joy. *Ren yi* means the conferral of wealth and honor; *wu shou* means wealth and honor without excess. Ordinary discourse holds that remaining unexcessive amid wealth and honor is easy, while finding joy in poverty is difficult. Yet Zhuangzi reverses this—how profoundly meaningful! In times of Heaven’s diminishment, affairs do not proceed by one’s will. Though one may wish not to receive, how can one not receive? One cannot but endure poverty. Thus it is said to be easy. As for man’s augmentation, as wealth arrives daily and rank rises daily, increasing month by month, I wish to decline yet cannot. Thus honor does not await arrogance to become arrogant; wealth does not await extravagance to become extravagant. Thus it is said to be difficult. *Qiong zhi* means blockage and obstruction; *bu xing* means one cannot push them away. *Yun wu* means the turning of qi."

Release and dispersion—this is the outflow of the turning of things, the coming and going of the numerical cycles of qi, which is Heaven’s doing. I too move in concert with it, and thus too am released with it. Hence it is said, "to depart together," which is precisely what is meant by "moving in step with the times" and "reaching the limit together with the times." The lord’s command to his minister cannot be disobeyed—how then can man disobey the command of Heaven? This is the meaning of "ease in receiving nothing."

"Fourfold reach" means that wherever the mind turns, there is no obstruction. "First use" means that as soon as this mind stirs, affairs follow and gather without obstruction. "Arriving together without exhaustion" and "converging without cease" describe this. I do not seek the profit of things, yet profit comes of itself—hence it is said, "not of oneself." Rank and emolument both come from without, brought about by the timing of fate. Thus it is said, "My fate lies outside myself." A gentleman feels shame at receiving emolument without merit, regarding it as theft. Though I may wish not to accept it, there is that which cannot be pushed away. When Gongsun He was appointed minister, he wept—was this not a case of one who could not receive, finding the augmentation of man difficult?

The *yiyi* is indolence of intent. "Insufficient to regard" means not worth looking at. A place not fitting for one’s dwelling—though the eye may see it, one still dismisses it as unworthy of regard and departs. When the fruit falls, the bird must take flight in alarm, fearing harm to itself. Thus it is said, "Abandoning it, it flees." Though its intent is to avoid man, it ends up dwelling near him—hence it is said, "nesting among men," meaning it enters their midst. The altars of soil and grain, though nothing to fear, are also nothing to take; people respect and preserve them. The swallow in a household, though neither beneficial nor harmful, is still tolerated. This suggests that if one in wealth and honor could be like the *yiyi*—neither beneficial nor harmful—then none would revile or despise him. Yet once called wealthy and honored, how can one be without benefit or harm? Hence it is said to be difficult.

"Without beginning yet not without end" means one knows neither its start nor its finish. The transformations of the ten thousand things succeed one another in turn—who knows their end, who knows their beginning? One simply abides in the center and awaits them. This is the true mean, dwelling within the workings of creation.

What does it mean to say "man and Heaven are one"? Man is what Heaven produces—hence it is said, "There is man, and there is Heaven." Heaven too is what creation makes—hence it is said, "There is Heaven, and there is Heaven." Nature is the nature mandated by Heaven. This character *xing* (nature) is the same as *sheng* (life): what man’s nature and life possess from birth are all received from Heaven. How could man presume to interfere? The sage alone knows what man cannot possess, and thus abides in it with equanimity, exhausting his years to the full. Mencius said, "This is nature, yet there is fate in it. The gentleman does not call it nature"—meaning precisely that man cannot possess Heaven’s nature.

"Composed and at ease"—this is to dwell in accord with the times and follow their course to the end of one’s days. Hence it is said, "embodying the passing and coming to an end."

Zhuang Zhou was wandering in the thicket of Diaoling when he saw an unusual magpie coming from the south. Its wings spanned seven feet, its eyes measured an inch across, and it brushed past Zhou’s forehead before alighting in the chestnut grove. Zhuang Zhou said, "What bird is this? Its wings are vast yet it does not fly far, its eyes are large yet it does not see clearly." He hitched up his robe, strode forward, took up his sling, and waited. He saw a cicada that had just found a fine shade and forgotten itself; a mantis, seizing the opportunity, grabbed it, forgetting its own form in its eagerness. The strange magpie, seeing its advantage, swooped in for the gain, forgetting its true nature in pursuit of profit. Zhuang Zhou shuddered and said, "Ah! Things indeed entrap one another—two creatures summoning disaster upon themselves." He cast aside his sling and turned to flee, but the gamekeeper pursued him with curses.

Zhuang Zhou returned home and for three months did not emerge into the courtyard. Lin Qie asked him, "Master, why have you been so withdrawn of late?" Zhuang Zhou replied, "I guarded my form yet forgot myself. I gazed into muddy water and became lost in clear depths. Moreover, I have heard from the Master that one should enter a custom and follow it. Now I wandered in Diaoling and forgot myself; the strange magpie brushed my forehead, and I wandered in the chestnut grove, forgetting my true nature. The gamekeeper of the chestnut grove took me for a thief—I am thus withdrawn." Diaoling is a place name; *fan* refers to the garden’s fence. "Brushed Zhou’s forehead" means it flew past his brow. *Yin* means vast; *shi* means to depart.

The wings were vast yet could not advance; the eyes were large yet could not see—such was the state of being led astray by things while pursuing them. Holding the sling and lingering, he sought to seize the prey. The mantis, intent on the cicada, was so fixated on gaining it that it forgot its own form; the strange magpie, in turn, coveted the mantis and forgot its true nature. Thus arose the state of neither advancing nor seeing. Mantis and magpie, though of different kinds, summoned one another—both forgot their form, forgot their true nature, and so became entangled.

The gamekeeper, guardian of the garden, cursed and berated him. *Not emerging into the courtyard* means not stepping into the open space before one’s dwelling. To *guard the form* is to cultivate life. I, who study the cultivation of life, carelessly pursued the magpie and forgot myself—this is to be led by desire and thus drowned in delusion. *Muddy water* is a metaphor for human desire; *clear depths* for the heavenly principle. The *Master* is Laozi. *Entering a state and inquiring into its customs* means learning its prohibitions—thus it is said, "Enter its custom and follow its custom." Another’s garden, into which I mistakenly wandered, is a transgression of the prohibition. *Took me for a thief* means I was humiliated by the gamekeeper.

This is but an allegory: whether great or small, all things that are pursued lead to delusion—this is a maxim for the scholar’s practice.

Yangzi lodged at an inn in Song. The innkeeper had two concubines—one beautiful, the other plain. The plain one was favored, while the beautiful one was slighted. Yangzi asked the reason, and the innkeeper’s servant replied: “The beautiful one is beautiful in her own eyes, but I see no beauty in her. The plain one is plain in her own eyes, but I see no plainness in her.”

Yangzi said: “Disciples, take note: act with virtue and abandon self-regard. Wherever you go, who will not love you? The beautiful one, in her self-regard, is proud and boastful. The plain one, in her self-deprecation, humbly considers herself unworthy. To *act with virtue and abandon self-regard* means to possess the power of the worthy without the conduct of self-importance—then, wherever you go, all will delight in you.”

This passage, too, offers an intimate lesson for practice. Reading these several chapters, one might wonder if the “Outer Chapters” were truly not composed by Zhuangzi.

Yangzi Fang sat in attendance upon Marquis Wen of Wei, and several times praised Xi Gong. The marquis said: “Is Xi Gong your teacher?” Yangzi Fang replied: “No. He is a villager from my hometown. He often speaks of the Dao, and his words are apt, so I praise him.”

The marquis said: “Then have you no teacher?” Yangzi Fang said: “I do.” The marquis asked: “Who is your teacher?” Yangzi Fang said: “Dongguo Shunzi.” The marquis said: “Then why have you never praised him?” Yangzi Fang said: “His way of being is that of a true person: his appearance is human, yet his nature is of Heaven; he is empty and follows things, preserving his authenticity; he is pure and accommodates all. When others act without the Dao, he merely adjusts his countenance to awaken them, and their misguided intentions dissolve. How could one such as Xi Gong be worthy of praise?”

Yangzi Fang departed. The marquis, lost in thought, remained silent the entire day. He summoned his attendant minister and said to him: “How distant is the gentleman of perfect virtue! At first, I believed that the words of sagely wisdom and the conduct of benevolence and righteousness were the ultimate. But when I heard of Yangzi Fang’s teacher, my form dissolved, and I had no desire to move; my mouth was sealed, and I had no desire to speak. What I have learned is but a clod of earth—how the state of Wei has truly become a burden to me!”

When Wenbo Xuezi traveled to Qi, he lodged in Lu. A man of Lu requested an audience with him. Wenbo Xuezi said: “It will not do. I have heard that the gentlemen of the Central States are enlightened in ritual and righteousness but coarse in understanding the human heart. I do not wish to meet them.”

When he returned to Qi and again lodged in Lu, that same man requested another audience. Wenbo Xuezi said: “In the past, he sought to see me; now, he seeks to see me again—he must have something to invigorate me.” He went out to meet the guest and, upon returning, sighed. The next day, he met the guest again and, upon returning, sighed once more. His servant asked: “Every time you meet this guest, you return and sigh. Why is that?” He replied: “I already told you: the people of the Central States are enlightened in ritual and righteousness but coarse in understanding the human heart. Those who came to see me before moved with the precision of compass and square, their demeanor now like a dragon, now like a tiger. Their admonitions were as a son’s, their guidance as a father’s—this is why I sighed.”

Confucius met him but did not speak. Zilu said: “You have long wished to see Wenbo Xuezi. Now that you have met him, why do you not speak?” Confucius replied: “In such a man, the Way is present the moment one’s gaze falls upon him—there is no need for words.”

*Bo* was his given name, and *Xuezi* his courtesy name. Ritual and righteousness are the studies of deliberate action; to be coarse in understanding the human heart is to be deficient, meaning one fails to recognize the fundamental mind. *To invigorate* means to bestow virtue, implying he must have something beneficial to offer. *Moved with the precision of compass and square* describes conduct that accords with ritual propriety in every motion. *Compass and square* signify regulated standards. *Now like a dragon, now like a tiger* refers to the manifestation of patterned excellence—this is what is meant by *the great man’s transformation like a tiger’s*. *Admonitions as a son’s, guidance as a father’s* describes speaking deeply despite a shallow acquaintance. *The Way is present the moment one’s gaze falls upon him* echoes the earlier idea of *correcting one’s demeanor to enlighten others, causing their misgivings to dissolve of themselves*. *No need for words* means no need for verbal expression.

Yan Yuan asked Confucius: “When you walk, I walk; when you hasten, I hasten; when you run, I run. Yet when you gallop, leaving all dust behind, I can only stare blankly from afar.”

Confucius said: “What do you mean, Hui?”

Yan Yuan replied: “When you walk, I walk; when you speak, I speak; when you hasten, I hasten; when you debate, I debate; when you gallop, I gallop; when you discourse on the Way, I too discourse on the Way. Yet when you gallop, leaving all dust behind, I can only stare blankly from afar. For you, *without speaking you are trusted, without intimacy you are all-encompassing, without implements the people are equipped*—yet I remain ignorant of how this comes to be.”

Confucius said: “How could one not examine this? The greatest sorrow is nothing other than the death of the heart, and the death of the person is secondary to it. The sun rises in the east and sets in the westernmost reaches—nothing in the myriad things does not follow this pattern. All that have eyes and limbs depend upon it to accomplish their ends. When it emerges, they exist; when it sets, they perish. The myriad things are thus: they depend upon it. Death, too, depends upon it, as does life. Once I received this completed form, I did not transform but awaited its end, moving in response to things, active day and night without pause, yet unaware of where it would conclude. Vaporously, this form took shape. Knowing fate, I could not plan for what lay ahead. Now, with each passing day, I draw nearer to my end. To have walked alongside you for a lifetime, only to lose you in the span of an arm’s length—how could this not be sorrowful? You are on the verge of illumination. What I have illuminated—it has already come to its end.”

Yet your seeking treats it as something existent—this is like searching for a horse in a roadside market. I submit to you utterly, and you forget utterly what I submit. Yet why should you fret? Though forgotten, there remains within me what cannot be forgotten. Without comparison, it naturally pervades all; words need not rely on close affinity for its truth to spread in perfect harmony. What has no form cannot be traced by name. The people tread forward—words alone draw them to return.

By this, one measures the Master’s unattainability. “Yet unaware of why it is so”—these words mean I have reached a point where I no longer know how it is. Galloping, flying, racing—leaving dust behind in such swift departure that no trace remains. Staring with wide eyes—all who walk, hasten, or race use the horse as their metaphor.

“How could one not examine this?” means one must scrutinize it with precision. “The death of the heart” means seeing nothing. To live yet see nothing is worse than death. Thus it is said: “No sorrow is greater than the death of the heart, and the death of a person is secondary to it.”

“Can be measured”—when the sun is bright, the length and size of all things can be fully seen. Thus it is said: “None do not follow this pattern.” Rising in the east and setting in the west—from dawn to dusk. Creatures with eyes and limbs—all living things—must see the sun before their affairs can proceed. They depend on it, depend on the sun. Thus it is said: “They depend upon it to accomplish their ends.” When it emerges, they exist; when it sets, they perish. Human affairs rise and fall with the sun’s movement—rising to work at sunrise, resting at sunset. The myriad things’ dependence on the Dao is like human affairs’ dependence on the sun. Thus it is said: “The myriad things are thus.” Life and death both follow the Dao’s natural course. Thus it is said: “Death, too, depends upon it, as does life.”

Once born and receiving this form, the Dao abides within the body without change, awaiting its end. Thus it is said: “Once I received this completed form, I did not transform but awaited its end.” To “effect” means to imitate. To act in imitation of things without allowing the heart to interfere. Thus it is said: “Moving in response to things.” “Without pause” means without interruption. “Unaware of where it would conclude” means without end. Harmoniously, this body embodies nothing but the principle of compliance. Thus it is said: “Vaporously, this form took shape.” Though knowing all things are fated, in daily life one does not use fate as a measure—this is what is meant by “the sage does not speak of fate.” “With each passing day” means each day is like this, advancing together without cease. “To have walked alongside you for a lifetime” means standing side by side. Having accompanied you all my life, yet you have not attained this Dao. Thus it is said: “Only to lose you in the span of an arm’s length.”

“Illumination” refers to what is visible. You see only what I make visible, unaware of what remains unseen. Thus it is said: “You are on the verge of illumination.” “What I have illuminated”—exhaustion means nothingness. The Dao must reach nothingness before it is complete. You seek it as something existent, so you cannot see its completion. Thus it is said: “What I have illuminated—it has already come to its end.”

“Yet your seeking treats it as something existent”—a market is a place for selling horses. “Tang” refers to a roofless structure, as in the *Book of Songs*: “In the central hall, there are tiles.” Today, it would be called a roadside pavilion. Those who sell horses come and go unpredictably; to seek one in such a market is like carving a mark on a boat to find a lost sword.

“Forgetting” means beyond knowing. “Utterly forgotten” means reaching the limit of the unknowable. What I submit to you must reach the limit of the unknowable, and what you submit to me must also reach the limit of the unknowable. Thus it is said: “I submit to you utterly, and you forget utterly what I submit.” This means that this matter cannot be explained to you, nor can you explain it to me—it must reach the point of forgetting words before it is complete.

Yet, turning further: though you have not yet reached this point, why should you worry? Since you now know the one who gallops away leaving no dust, staring in astonishment, you have grasped one layer of understanding, though not yet the whole. If you can forget what you once knew, even if my present state differs from what you see today, what remains unforgotten within me endures. As the Buddhists say: “After awakening, one still relies on what was known before.” Some believe that only when one sees nothingness is the Dao complete, yet this “nothingness” is still a kind of “something.” Thus it is said: “Though forgotten, there remains within me what cannot be forgotten.”

These two instances of “I” refer to Yan Hui’s own experience, differing from the earlier “I submit to you” and “you forget what I submit.” Confucius visited Lao Dan, who had just washed his hair and was letting it dry, sitting solemnly as if not human. Confucius withdrew and waited. After a while, he saw Lao Dan and said: “Was I deluded, or is it true? Just now, Master, your form was withered like dry wood, as if you had left the world of men and stood in solitude.”

Lao Dan said: “I let my heart wander in the beginning of things.”
Confucius said: “What do you mean?”
Lao Dan replied: “My heart is blocked and cannot know; my mouth is shut and cannot speak. Let me try to explain it to you.”

The most yin arrives with solemn stillness; the most yang blazes with radiant brilliance. This solemn stillness emerges from Heaven; this radiant brilliance arises from Earth. When the two intermingle and harmonize, things come into being. Some call this their governing principle, yet none see its form—its ebb and flow fill emptiness and fullness, its darkening and brightening alternate like day and night. Things transform daily, yet none see its work. Life has its sprouting; death has its return. Beginning and end stand opposed, yet without origin, and none know where it ends. If not this, then what is its source?

Letting the hair loose to dry—this is what *Li Sao* calls "drying the hair." *Zhire* describes the stillness of standing in concentration, as if not human, still unpaired with others. *Juewu* means rigid and unmoving. *Yiwu* means leaving external things behind; *liren* means leaving the crowd of people; standing in solitude means rising above the world’s common measure.

"The beginning of things" refers to the origin before things existed. *Pi* means closed—when the heart knows nothing, the mouth desires no speech, hence "blocked" and "shut." "Near" means approaching, for the profound and wondrous are hard to express, so one can only approximate their semblance. Thus it is said: "Let me try to explain it to you." The earlier "its" and "its wind" refer to this transformation of phrasing.

Solemn stillness and radiant brilliance—these are the meanings of yin and yang, which is what is called the Dao. Thus, the four lines below: when yin and yang harmonize, the myriad things are born. They intermingle and interact, for yin alone cannot generate, nor yang alone complete—hence "intermingle and harmonize." *Ji* means the guiding thread, the principal support, as if something governs yet remains unseen. Thus: "Some call this their governing principle, yet none see its form." The one who governs is the work of creation.

One darkening, one brightening—these are day and night. The ebb and flow of fullness and emptiness—these are the movements of the four seasons. Things change daily, yet none see its work. Each day it acts thus, and the work of creation—who can name it? Beginning and end are not the same, yet their origin cannot be traced. For example, the sparrow transforming into a clam: the sparrow’s end is the clam’s beginning, and the clam’s beginning is the sparrow’s end. Even in the grand succession of emperors, it is the same. How can one see it all? Thus: "Beginning and end stand opposed, yet without origin, and none know where it ends." This clearly speaks of the Creator, yet without naming it, it then says: "If not this, then what is its source?" The source is the Creator; the source is also the Creator. It says: "If not this, then what is its master?" This is how Zhuangzi’s writing lives—every sentence is like this.

Confucius said: "May I ask about this wandering?"
Lao Dan said: "To attain this is the utmost beauty, the utmost joy. To attain the utmost beauty and wander in the utmost joy—this is called the Perfect Person."
Confucius said: "I wish to hear the method."
Lao Dan said: "Beasts that eat grass do not dislike changing marshes; creatures that live in water do not dislike changing streams. They undergo small changes but do not lose their great constancy. Joy and anger, sorrow and happiness do not enter their breasts. For the world is where the myriad things are one. To grasp this oneness and be the same as it—then the four limbs and hundred bones become dust and dirt, and life and death, beginning and end become like day and night, which cannot disturb it. How much less can the distinctions of gain and loss, fortune and misfortune? One who discards rank is like one who discards mud and dirt, knowing the body is nobler than rank. Nobility lies within me and does not lose itself in change. Moreover, the myriad transformations have no end—how could they trouble the heart of one who has attained the Dao?

This is the praise of the utmost beauty and joy of the Dao. "Do not dislike" means not being weary. "Small changes" refers to changing marshes and streams. "Not losing their great constancy" means their water and grass remain. The life of the myriad things all lies under Heaven, so one must follow Heaven’s doing—how can one be different? Thus: "The world is where the myriad things are one." Knowing this oneness comes from Heaven and is no different, then not even life and death can disturb the heart—how much less gain and loss, fortune and misfortune? *Jie* means a splinter or obstacle. *Dian* means a servant or subordinate.

The servant discards and comes as one discards mud and mire—because I am noble while they are base. Yet if one knows that the true nobility of the Dao lies within oneself, how could the transformations of the myriad things ever strip away one’s utmost beauty and joy? Between Heaven and Earth, change follows upon change, and so it has been for ten thousand ages—when will it ever end? Gain and loss, fortune and misfortune are nothing but the natural course—how could they trouble the heart? Thus it is said: "The myriad transformations have no end." Who, then, could disturb the heart? Only those who unite their person with the Dao can truly understand this.

This is the self—when the self and the Dao are one, it is called "the self attaining the Dao." Confucius said: "The Master’s virtue matched Heaven and Earth, yet he still relied on profound words to cultivate his heart—how could the noble men of old have been free of this?" Lao Dan replied: "Not so. Water, when drawn, does nothing yet its nature is spontaneous. The perfected person’s virtue requires no cultivation, yet things cannot depart from it. Just as Heaven is naturally high, Earth naturally thick, and the sun and moon naturally bright—what need is there for cultivation?" Confucius went out and told Yan Hui: "My grasp of the Dao is like a gnat in vinegar—how slight the Master’s words have revealed to me! I did not know the great wholeness of Heaven and Earth."

*Jiajie* means to borrow. *Zhiyan* refers to the many words above. It means that even Laozi, with such virtue, could not depart from words to cultivate his heart—how could others escape this? *Shuo* means to be free, the same as *tuo*. Lao Dan’s "Not so" means that relying on words to cultivate the heart is mistaken. *Zhuo* means to draw, the same as *zhuo*. The rivers and seas can be drawn from endlessly because their essence is effortless and natural. *Cai* means nature—water is water because of its natural essence. The perfected person’s virtue is rooted in spontaneity; though it requires no cultivation, external things cannot separate from it. Heaven, Earth, the sun, and moon are also natural—what room is there for effort? Thus it is said: "What need is there for cultivation?" *Ximei* are midges in vinegar, confined within the jar—how could they know the vastness beyond? This speaks of narrow vision.

Zhuangzi saw Duke Ai of Lu. The Duke said: "Lu has many Ru scholars but few who follow your *fang*." Zhuangzi said: "Lu has few Ru." The Duke said: "The whole state of Lu wears Ru robes—how can you say there are few?" Zhuangzi said: "I have heard that the Ru wear round caps to know the seasons, square shoes to know the earth’s forms, and jade pendants that move slowly to decide matters when they arise. Those who possess the Dao are not necessarily known by their robes, and those who wear the robes do not necessarily know the Dao. If you truly do not believe me, why not issue a decree throughout the state: 'Those without this Dao who wear these robes will be put to death'?" The Duke issued the decree, and after five days, no one in Lu dared wear Ru robes. Only one man, dressed as a Ru, stood at the palace gate. The Duke summoned him and questioned him on state affairs, and his answers were inexhaustible, shifting through a thousand turns without end. Zhuangzi said: "With only one Ru in Lu, can you call that many?"

*Fang* refers to methods—it means the Ru of Lu practiced different arts from the Master. *Huan pei jue* means their movements were slow and they wore jade pendants. *Jue* takes its meaning from decisiveness. *One husband* refers to Confucius. The implication is that many wear Ru robes but do not know the Dao.

Baili Xi’s rank and salary did not enter his heart, so he fed cattle and made them fat. This caused Duke Mu of Qin to forget his lowly status and entrust him with governance. The Lord of Yu disregarded life and death, so he could move others. When feeding cattle, did he have any thought of seeking rank or salary? It was precisely because he did not seek them that he was employed by Duke Mu. *Moving others* means influencing and transforming them. *Disregarding life and death* means acting without acting, the heart undisturbed. Here, these two lines are spoken casually.

When the Lord of Song was about to have a painting made, all the artists arrived, bowed, and stood ready. Half of them were outside preparing brushes and ink. One artist arrived late, unhurried, did not bow, and did not stand still. He was given lodging, and when the Lord sent someone to observe him, he was found sitting with his clothes off, legs sprawled. The Lord said: "He is the true painter."

*Chanchán* means leisurely and at ease. *Receiving the bow without standing* means he returned the bow but did not remain still. *Panbo* describes sitting with legs spread. *Luo* means bare. This speaks of having no mind for seeking recognition—only then is one a true painter. Su Dongpo’s description of painting bamboo—"With spirit at ease and will settled, one stroke completes it"—approaches this idea.

King Wen observed at Zang and saw a man fishing. Yet his fishing was no ordinary fishing—where he cast his line, there was indeed fishing. This was constant fishing.

King Wen wished to elevate the man and entrust him with governance, yet feared his ministers and kinsmen would not accept it. He wished to release him and let him go, yet could not bear that the people would be left without a ruler. Thus, at dawn, he gathered his ministers and said: "Formerly, I dreamed of a worthy man, dark of complexion and with a prominent forehead, riding a piebald horse with one red hoof. He declared: 'Entrust governance to the Elder of Zang—perhaps the people may yet recover.'"

The ministers, startled, said: "This was your late father, the former king."

King Wen replied: "Then let us divine his will."

The ministers said: "The former king’s command leaves no room for doubt—what need is there for divination?"

Thereupon, they welcomed the Elder of Zang and entrusted him with governance. No statutes were altered, no decrees were issued. After three years, King Wen surveyed the realm and saw that the ranks of scholars had dissolved, factions had scattered, and officials no longer cultivated virtue. *Yǔ*-measures and *hú*-bushels dared not cross the four borders. When the ranks of scholars dissolved and factions scattered, unity prevailed. When officials no longer cultivated virtue, their duties aligned. When *yǔ*-measures and *hú*-bushels dared not cross the borders, the feudal lords harbored no divided loyalties.

King Wen then bowed northward and, addressing him as Grand Preceptor, asked: "Can this governance extend to all under Heaven?"

The Elder of Zang gave no response, then casually excused himself from court. That night, he fled and was never heard from again.

This passage recasts the tale of the Grand Duke, weaving it into a different narrative. *Constant fishing* means the fishing rod is always in hand. Though the rod remains in hand, there is no intent to fish—thus it is said: "He did not hold to his fishing, yet there was indeed fishing." Such phrasing holds its own excellence.

*Without a ruler* means the people would have no master. *One red hoof* means only one hoof was crimson. *The former king* refers to King Wen’s father.

"Unchanging statutes" means no alteration of laws and institutions. "No partial decrees" means no single matter was ever issued as an edict. That only one matter is mentioned in the decrees is called "partial decrees." "Uprooted pillars and scattered flocks" means no factions were established. "Unfulfilled virtue" means not claiming personal success—akin to the *Yi*’s saying: "Some follow the king’s service without accomplishment." "Shared endeavor" means working together with the multitude without setting oneself apart. *Yu* is *yu* (a grain measure); foreign *yu*-*hu* differ in size, yet none dared enter his borders, so the feudal lords all knew where to pledge allegiance. Thus it is said: "harbored no divided loyalties." "Morning decree" refers to hearing King Wen’s command regarding governance extending to all under Heaven, prompting his flight that night, never to be heard from again—like the *Book of Documents*’ line: "To his life’s end, no renown."

*Dan*’s retainers: the ancient text writes *fu-fu* (夫夫). Sima [Biao] says the first *fu* is written as *da* (大), reading *fu* as "one great." The Qin stele on Mount Tai reads: "The censor, *fu-fu*," where *fu* in seal script resembles *da*, as seen in the *Wenjian*.

Yan Yuan asked Confucius: "Was King Wen still incomplete? Then why did he dream?" Confucius replied: "Silence! Say no more. King Wen fulfilled it all—what criticism is there? He merely followed the moment." "Followed the moment" means he complied with temporary measures to make things easier for the people—how could this be faulted?

Lie Yukou drew his bow to full draw for Bohun Wuren, placing a cup of water on his elbow. He loosed the arrow, and as it flew, another took its place, then another lodged in the target. At that moment, he was like a wooden figurine. Bohun Wuren said: "This is the archery of archery, not the archery of non-archery. I once asked you: could you shoot while climbing a high mountain, treading perilous rocks, or standing over an abyss of a hundred fathoms?" Thereupon, Wuren ascended the high mountain, trod the perilous rocks, stood over the abyss, then turned and retreated until two-tenths of his feet hung over the edge. Beckoning Lie Yukou forward, Yukou prostrated himself, sweating to his heels. Bohun Wuren said: "The perfected person gazes upward into the azure sky, delves downward into the Yellow Springs, roams to the eight limits—yet their spirit and qi remain unchanged. Now you tremble with fear in your eyes. Your inner strength is perilous indeed!"

"Drew his bow to full draw" means drawing the bow to its utmost. "The front hand straight and the elbow level" allows placing a cup of water atop it—indicating steadiness. "Loosed" means to shoot. "Flew away" means the arrow departed.

"沓 means layered or again. When one arrow has just departed and another already rests upon the bowstring—this is the layered presence of arrows upon the bowstring, where the departing arrow is scarcely gone before the next arrives to take its place. This describes the divine swiftness of shooting arrow after arrow in unbroken succession. 象人 refers to a wooden figurine. 背逡巡 means facing the high mountain while one’s back hangs over the abyss, retreating without cease—hence the term 逡巡. When two-tenths of the feet hang over the void and only one-tenth remains on solid ground, this is the utmost peril, yet Bohun Wuren could do it—this is what is called the steadfast holding of pure qi.

Shooting while standing on level ground is ordinary shooting. Thus it is said to be ‘the shooting of non-shooting.’ When the spirit can guard unity, then though one gazes upward into the azure sky, descends to the Yellow Springs, or roams to the eight limits, the heart remains unmoved, as if the terrain of danger or safety were one and the same. If, at the sight of peril, the eyes tremble and the gaze wavers, this shows one has not yet grasped the learning of the perfected person. To practice shooting in this manner and seek the essence of hitting the mark is indeed difficult. Thus it is said: ‘Your inner strength is perilous indeed!’

怵 means fear. 恂目 means the eyes flicker with apprehension."

Shoulder Wu asked Sunshu Ao, “You have thrice served as Prime Minister yet shown no elation, and thrice been dismissed without a trace of sorrow. At first I doubted you, but now I see your face suffused with ease—how do you alone manage this in your heart?”

Sunshu Ao replied, “How do I surpass others? I accept that what comes cannot be refused, and what goes cannot be halted. I regard gain and loss as no concern of mine, and so remain untroubled. How do I surpass others? Moreover, I do not know whether honor or disgrace lies with them or with me—whether it is theirs to lose or mine to lose. While I hesitate and look about in all directions, how can I find time to weigh what men call noble or base?”

The ease in his face arose not from external things but from within, from a spirit that nourished itself. If the honor of the Prime Ministership belonged to the office itself, it had no bearing on me; if what was noble in me belonged to me, it had no bearing on the office. Thus he said: “Is it theirs to lose, or mine? Is it mine to lose, or theirs?” These words capture the essence. To hesitate and look about is to gaze far into the vastness of heaven and earth—how could one know what men call noble or base?

When Confucius heard of this, he said: “The true persons of old could not be swayed by the persuasions of the wise, seduced by the allure of beauty, robbed by bandits, or befriended by Fuxi or the Yellow Emperor. Life and death are great matters indeed, yet they remained unchanged—how much less would they be moved by rank or emolument? Such persons pass through the great mountains without obstruction, enter deep springs without getting wet, dwell in lowly and narrow places without weariness, and fill heaven and earth, ever more abundant even as they give to others.

The wise cannot sway them, for words cannot exhaust their depth. Beauty cannot seduce them, for sensual pleasures cannot corrupt their integrity. Bandits cannot rob them, for force cannot bend their will. Fuxi and the Yellow Emperor could not befriend them, for they withdrew from the world and held it lightly. *Jie* means obstruction, like a stone that, though seamless, can be drilled through. Thus it is said they pass through the great mountains without obstruction. Dwelling in poverty and lowliness, they do not take it as affliction. Thus it is said they dwell in narrow places without weariness. To fill heaven and earth is the Dao. When the Dao within oneself is already full, it extends to transform others, and its use is inexhaustible. Thus it is said: ‘Even as they give to others, they become ever more abundant.’

The King of Chu was seated with the Lord of Fan. After a while, the King’s attendants said, ‘Fan has perished three times.’ The Lord of Fan said, ‘The perishing of Fan is not enough to diminish what I possess. If the perishing of Fan is not enough to diminish what I possess, then the survival of Chu is not enough to preserve what I am.’ From this perspective, Fan has never truly perished, and Chu has never truly existed.”

This is like the man who, though his foot was cut off, still valued his foot—only here, the analogy shifts to say that the Dao within oneself is unaffected by whether one has a state or not. If Fan’s loss does not mean loss, and Chu’s survival does not mean survival, then the world’s gains and losses, fortunes and misfortunes, are all external things. Yet the meaning still hinges on the phrase “the survival of Chu is not enough to preserve what I am.” If loss is not enough to cause self-reproach, then gain is not enough to cause self-aggrandizement. *Self-reproach* means to feel remorse; *self-aggrandizement* means to boast. These words carry particular savor—they are the language of learning that bears directly on one’s own person.

---

*Outer Chapters: "Knowledge Wanders North," Chapter Twenty-Two*

Knowledge wandered north to the Dark Waters, ascended the hill of Kunfen, and there encountered Non-Action. Knowledge said, “I wish to ask you: What thoughts, what reflections lead to knowing the Dao? Where does one abide, what practices lead to peace in the Dao? From what source, by what path does one attain the Dao?” Three questions, yet Non-Action did not answer—not that he would not answer, but that he did not know how.

Knowledge, unable to obtain an answer, returned to the south of the White Waters, ascended Fox Tower, and there saw Mad Jue. Knowledge repeated his questions to Mad Jue. Mad Jue said, “Ah! I know, and will tell you”—but mid-speech, he forgot what he wished to say. Knowledge, unable to obtain an answer, returned to the palace of the Yellow Emperor and asked him. The Yellow Emperor said, “Without thoughts, without reflections, one begins to know the Dao. Without abode, without practice, one begins to be at peace in the Dao. Without source, without path, one begins to attain the Dao.”

Knowledge asked the Yellow Emperor, “You and I know this, but those two do not—who is correct?” The Yellow Emperor said, “Non-Action is truly right; Mad Jue is somewhat close. You and I will never come near it.”

The names before and after are all allegorical, yet these three have distinctions. *Knowledge* is one who possesses a thinking mind. *Non-Action* is spontaneity itself. *Mad* is wildness; *Jue* is like a withered branch—stiff and unknowing. In this book, the term *mad* is akin to the “floating and wandering” in *Free and Easy Wandering*. Mad and stiff, he has the appearance of one without knowledge. This is merely to say that those who know do not speak, and those who speak do not know. Thus, when asked, he could not answer—like a monk with no elder before him, no preceptor. When he began to answer but forgot his words, it was as if he still knew there was a question. Thus it is said: “Non-Action is truly right; Mad Jue is somewhat close.”

Those who know do not speak; those who speak do not know. Thus the sage practices the teaching without words. The Dao cannot be attained; virtue cannot be reached. Benevolence can be practiced, righteousness can be diminished, ritual is mutual pretense. Thus it is said: “Lose the Dao, and virtue follows; lose virtue, and benevolence follows; lose benevolence, and righteousness follows; lose righteousness, and ritual follows. Ritual is the flower of the Dao and the beginning of chaos.” Thus it is said: “Those who practice the Dao daily diminish. Diminish and further diminish, until they reach non-action. With non-action, there is nothing that is not done.” Now, having become entangled in things, to return to the root—is this not difficult? Yet how easy it is for the great person!

Those who know do not speak—this is Bodhidharma’s coming from the West without establishing words, directly pointing to the human mind, seeing one’s nature and becoming a Buddha. The teaching without words is the Vimalakīrti’s non-dual Dharma gate.

The Dao cannot be attained—it cannot be reached through words. Virtue cannot be reached—it cannot be sought through traces.

Righteousness, propriety, and ritual—all leave traces. Where there are traces, the Dao is ruined. Zhuangzi regarded ritual as a forced imposition upon the world, comparing it to righteousness and propriety, yet its traces are even more pronounced. Thus it is said: “The flower of the Dao is the beginning of chaos.” The flower is outward adornment without substance. From outward adornment arises falsity, and from falsity arises deceit. Thus it is called “the beginning of chaos.” To dismiss cleverness and cast off artificiality—this is the daily diminishing of the Dao. Diminish and further diminish until one reaches nothingness, then forget one’s former self. When one can act without contrivance, one follows the natural principle of Heaven, and there is nothing that cannot be done.

Things are but traces. To seek the Dao while still clinging to traces is to remain on par with things, and thus to perceive the root and origin of the self is rightly difficult. “To return to the root” means to gather in and revert to the state before things existed. The great person embodies non-action. For the great person, this is easy—so easy! (In Zhuangzi’s phrasing, if it were another, it would read: “Only the great person finds it easy.”)

Life is the companion of death; death is the beginning of life. Who knows their order? The life of humans is the gathering of qi. When it gathers, there is life; when it scatters, there is death. If life and death are companions, what cause for concern? Thus the myriad things are one. What they deem beautiful is wondrous; what they deem foul is rotten. Yet the rotten transforms again into the wondrous, and the wondrous transforms again into the rotten. Thus it is said: “The world is united by a single qi.” The sage therefore values oneness.

Life is the companion of death; death is the beginning of life. The latter phrase is easy to explain, but the former is difficult. Consider the flowering of plants into branches and leaves—this is their life. Yet what has already flourished will inevitably perish, so even this life is but death. As Master Yichuan said: “The breath that returns is not the breath that was exhaled.” This is precisely the meaning. The unripe fruit that remains is the sprout of renewal. Though called the “unripe fruit,” it is already dead. When planted, it revives—is this not death giving rise to life? The cycle of life and death pervades all things. Who knows the principle that governs it? The “order” is the governing thread, the master that directs it.

The gathering and scattering of qi give rise to life and death—this all know. Yet if one understands that life and death are but a single principle, what cause for concern? The companion of life is death, and death is one with life. Life and death are fundamentally one principle, shared by all things. Yet people distinguish between beauty and ugliness, good and evil. When flowers are in full bloom, they are deemed wondrous; when they fall to the ground, they are called rotten. They do not realize that when leaves fall and nourish the roots, a new beginning arises—thus the rotten transforms again into the wondrous. Yet once bloomed and fallen, the wondrous transforms again into the rotten. From ancient times to the present, back and forth, there is only this single qi. The sage, knowing this, does not distinguish between life and death, success and failure, fortune and misfortune. Thus it is said: “The sage therefore values oneness.” Oneness means no distinctions.

Huangdi said: “I asked Wuwei. Wuwei said, ‘Do not respond to me.’ Not that he did not respond to me, but that he did not know how to respond. I asked Kuang Qu. Kuang Qu wished to tell me but did not tell me. Not that he did not tell me, but that in wishing to tell, he forgot it. Now I ask you—you know, so why do you not come close?” Huangdi said: “He is truly so because he does not know. This one seems so because he has forgotten. You and I will never come close because you know.” Kuang Qu heard this and considered Huangdi’s words to be wise.

These lines clarify the preceding meaning with great clarity. Heaven and Earth possess great beauty yet do not speak; the four seasons have bright patterns yet do not debate; the myriad things have inherent principles yet do not explain. The sage traces the beauty of Heaven and Earth and comprehends the principles of the myriad things. Thus the perfected person embodies non-action, and the great sage does not act—this is called “observing Heaven and Earth.”

Now, that numinous clarity and utmost subtlety, along with the transformations of the hundred things—life and death, square and round—none know their root. Yet all things have existed since ancient times, abiding as they are. The Six Directions are vast, yet nothing lies beyond their bounds. The tip of an autumn hair is minute, yet it awaits its completion as a form. In the world, none do not rise and fall, yet throughout life, nothing remains fixed. Yin and yang, the four seasons, move in their courses, each maintaining its order. Obscure yet present, formless yet spirit-like, the myriad things are nurtured without awareness—this is called the root. One may observe Heaven thereby.

Heaven and Earth possess great beauty yet do not speak—this is like the *Book of Changes*, which “benefits all under Heaven with beauty yet does not speak of what it benefits.” How great indeed! The “bright patterns” refer to the cycles of cold and heat, fullness and emptiness, growth and decline—all have clear, unchanging laws. Why would they require deliberation? Thus it is said: “They do not debate.” Whether the duck’s legs are short or the crane’s long, whether wheat droops or millet stands tall, whether things are cold or warm, bitter or sweet—all are natural principles. How could one explain their length or shortness, sweetness or bitterness? Thus it is said: “They have inherent principles yet do not explain.” “Not acting” is non-action. Non-action and not acting both follow the natural. The sage’s way of following the natural is simply to emulate Heaven and Earth. Thus it is said: “This is called observing Heaven and Earth.”

“Numinous clarity and utmost subtlety” refers to the wondrous principle. “The transformations of the hundred things” refers to the transformations of all things. The first “that” refers to Heaven; the second “that” refers to things. Whether things live or die, whether in life they are square or round—all are shaped by the numinous and utmost subtlety. Yet once they exist, who can fathom their root? Thus it is said: “The things that have already lived and died, that are square and round—none know their root.” “Flitting” means moving without cease, like the ceaseless flow of things. This is what the *Analects* means by “passing away like this.” Without insight, one could not speak of it thus. The Six Directions are vast, yet nothing lies beyond the bounds of creation. The tip of an autumn hair is minute, yet it awaits its completion as a form. If there were no form of the autumn hair, there would be no name for the autumn hair—just as in the world, nothing is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, and Mount Tai is small. “Rising and falling” means coming and going. “Nothing remains fixed” means ever-renewing.

The myriad things come and go without end, day after day thus—hence it is said: “Nothing in the world does not rise and fall.” Throughout life, nothing remains fixed; only because nothing remains fixed do the four seasons move in their proper order.

Obscure, it cannot be seen—yet there is a flourishing vitality. As if absent yet present, the dead are companions of the living. Without form, the spirit does not rely on form to stand; it does not perish with life. To nurture is to cultivate. That which nurtures the myriad things is the Dao, yet people do not know it—this is the root of creation. Observing Heaven, one grasps no more than this principle; thus it is said: “One may observe it in Heaven.”

Nie Que asked the Way of Bei Yi. Bei Yi said: “Straighten your form, unify your gaze. Heaven’s harmony will come. Gather in your knowledge, unify your judgment. The spirit will arrive. Abandon virtue, and it will become your beauty. The Dao will become your dwelling. You will stare like a newborn calf, without seeking its former state.”

Before his words were finished, Nie Que fell asleep. Bei Yi rejoiced greatly, singing as he departed: “His form like withered bones, his heart like dead ashes—truly, his knowledge does not cling to the old. Vague and dim, dark and obscure, without mind, he cannot be schemed with. What manner of man is this?”

Here, another pair of those who know the Dao is introduced, conversing together. As the Buddhists say: “A master’s hand reveals a master’s hand; a red heart reveals a red heart.” “Straighten your form, unify your gaze” is to forget the body, the ears and eyes. “Gather in your knowledge, unify your judgment” is to cast aside thought, deliberation, and consciousness.

"To transcend thought is transcendence itself. Heavenly harmony is the primordial qi. Forget the body, the ears and eyes, and the primordial qi is preserved whole. The spirit is what the Buddhists call the 'master within'—it comes and goes without fixed time, its whereabouts unknown, thus it does not come to dwell. 'Virtue will become your beauty' means virtue moistens the self. 'The Dao will become your dwelling' means dwelling in the vast abode of the world. To stare like a newborn calf is to gaze directly without knowledge. At birth, a calf does not fail to see, yet what does it truly see? The infant is the same—it does not seek its former state, for how can one know the reason for its gaze? This depicts the appearance of a mindless state. That his words were not yet finished and Nie Que fell asleep shows that his response was not yet complete when he drifted off. Their exchange was so perfectly attuned that words were unnecessary. 'Truly, his knowledge does not cling to the old' means he truly perceived the reality of this principle. Matters and things do not enter his heart, so he does not rely on the past to sustain himself—this is the meaning of 'not clinging to the old.' Vague and dim, dark and obscure, without form or sight. Since he is without mind, and I am not, words are impossible—thus 'without mind, he cannot be schemed with.' That such a person exists between heaven and earth—'What manner of man is this?'—is an expression of profound admiration.

Shun asked his minister, 'Can the Dao be possessed?' The minister replied, 'Your body is not your own possession—how can you possess the Dao?' Shun said, 'If my body is not mine, then whose is it?' The minister said, 'It is the form entrusted by heaven and earth. Life is not yours—it is the harmony entrusted by heaven and earth. Nature and destiny are not yours—they are the compliance entrusted by heaven and earth. Children and grandchildren are not yours—they are the shedding entrusted by heaven and earth. Thus, your actions are not of your own direction, your dwelling is not of your own choosing, your food is not of your own savoring. Heaven and earth are the strong yang qi—how can you possess them?' 'Entrusted' means gathered together. The four great elements temporarily combine to form this body, hence 'entrusted form.' The harmony of yin and yang gives rise to life, hence 'life is entrusted harmony.' 'Compliance' is principle—nature and destiny reside within me, thus they are the principle of creation, hence 'entrusted compliance.' The succession of generations is like the molting of a cicada, hence 'children and grandchildren are entrusted shedding.' Strong yang qi is the qi of life—movement is yang. A person’s actions, dwelling, and eating are all driven by this qi, none of which are truly mine. As the *Sutra of Perfect Enlightenment* says, 'Where is this illusory body now?'—this is the same idea. This passage is also uniquely profound, for it speaks of 'not knowing what to hold onto,' meaning there is no attachment.

Confucius asked Lao Dan, 'Today I have leisure—may I inquire about the supreme Dao?' Lao Dan said, 'Purify your mind through fasting, cleanse your heart through bathing, and refine your spirit. Shatter your knowledge. The Dao is profound and hard to describe—I will tell you its rough outline. The luminous arises from the obscure, order arises from formlessness, spirit arises from the Dao, and form arises from essence. All things give birth through form. Thus, those with nine orifices are born from the womb, and those with eight orifices are born from eggs.' 'Purify through fasting' means to guide and unblock. 'Cleanse through bathing' means to wash and purify. 'Shatter' means to cast aside. 'Profound' describes its depth. 'Outline' refers to its boundaries—when the profound is hard to express, one can only speak of its edges and rough contours. The luminous is what can be seen; the obscure is what cannot. What can be seen and distinguished is called 'order'—the myriad things. Formlessness is creation. Spirit resides within humans. Form is visible; essence is not. Nine orifices belong to humans; eight orifices belong to birds. Since humans and birds are mentioned together, the text humbles them. The Buddhist sutras speak of birth from the womb, from eggs, and from moisture—all originate from this idea. The meaning here is that though humans are nobler than other beings, their birth is fundamentally the same. Thus, one should abandon the physical body to seek the Dharma-body. Zhuangzi’s intent is the same.

Its coming leaves no trace, its going no boundary. Without doors or chambers, it is vast and all-pervading. Those who encounter it here find their limbs strong, their thoughts penetrating, their ears and eyes sharp and clear. Their use of the mind is effortless, their response to things without fixed method. Heaven cannot but be high, earth cannot but be broad, the sun and moon cannot but move, and the myriad things cannot but flourish—this is the Dao.

'Its coming leaves no trace, its going no boundary' speaks of creation—where things depart and arrive cannot be traced. 'Vast and all-pervading' describes the great void. A person’s dwelling has doors and chambers, but in the great void, one sees only its boundless vastness—how can one know where it enters or exits? 'Those who encounter it here' means those who seek and find this Dao. 'Limbs strong' is what the *Sutra of Perfect Enlightenment* calls 'the body light and at ease.' 'Penetrating' means unobstructed. 'Effortless' means following nature. 'Without fixed method' means it is not predetermined but arises in response to encounters. If not for this Dao, who would truly bring about heaven, earth, the sun, moon, and the myriad things? These four lines merely describe how this Dao pervades all, above and below.

Moreover, extensive learning does not necessarily mean knowledge, eloquence does not necessarily mean wisdom—the sage has already settled this. As for what is increased yet not augmented, diminished yet not reduced, this is what the sage preserves. Profound like the sea, towering like a mountain, it begins and ends in the same place. It measures and sustains the myriad things without exhaustion—this is the Dao of the noble person. Is it external? All things rely on it without exhaustion—this is the Dao. Within the world, there are those who are neither yin nor yang, dwelling between heaven and earth, simply being human. Yet they return to the source. Observing from the root, life is but a sigh, a breath—though there are differences in longevity, how much do they truly differ? The saying of 'a moment' is sufficient—why distinguish between Yao and Jie?

'Extensive learning' does not mean true knowledge. People’s eloquence is all boasting of their own abilities, yet it does not necessarily arise from their own wisdom—their wisdom is bestowed by creation. Thus, the sage judges by creation, not taking increase as increase or decrease as decrease. What is preserved lies within me, and external things cannot add to it—this is the sage’s affair. 'Begins and ends in the same place' means it is pure and unceasing. 'Measures and sustains the myriad things without exhaustion' means responding to things without limit. 'Measures' means to apply and assess—this still involves intention, so it is only the Dao of the noble person, for it speaks of traces. If I respond to things, it is 'measuring and sustaining the myriad things.' If things come and I respond, it is 'all things rely on it.'

"

This is "responding only after being moved, acting only under compulsion"—if such a way does not exhaust itself, it is called the Dao. The Dao is without intention, without traces. Within the world, there is a being called the "perfected person at the center of Heaven and Earth," neither yin nor yang—words cannot point to or name it. Though possessing human form, its heart roams at the origin of things, merely lodging its form between Heaven and Earth. Thus it is said: "Straightforward and human, it will return to the source." The source is the origin of the myriad things. Obstruction and stagnation of qi are what cause disharmony. When the qi of the human body is disharmonious, it produces warts and tumors; when the qi of creation generates humans, it too is a case of disharmony. Thus it is said: "Viewed from the root," meaning observed from the origin of Heaven and Earth.

This idea seems to denigrate the human body—it is akin to the Buddhist notion of a "skin-bag filled with blood." Examining closely, much of the discourse in the *Tripitaka* stems from this. Yao and Jie, right and wrong—these are judgments of the human world, arising only after the existence of this body. Within a hundred years, though lifespans may vary in length, compared to Heaven and Earth, they are but a fleeting moment. These words are also apt: fruits and melons have their principles; human relationships, though difficult, are how we rank one another. The sage encounters them without resistance, passes them without attachment, and harmonizes with them in response—this is virtue. To respond by chance is the Dao. It is how emperors rise and kings emerge.

Human life between Heaven and Earth is like a white colt passing through a gap—suddenly, it is gone. Bursting forth, all things emerge; gently, smoothly, all things return. Fruits and melons are the most insignificant of things—yet even their growth...

At times, their seeds are sown—from ancient times to the present, their kinds remain unmingled. Is this not the principle of spontaneity? Speaking of the most insignificant, the greater may be understood. Within human relationships, though many hardships arise—such as the restraints between high and low, the oppressions between strong and weak, the sorrows and joys of long and short lives—these are all hardships. Yet, dwelling together within the cosmos, all take their place in the order of things: ruler and minister, father and son, the civilized and the barbarian—all are but creatures within the workings of creation. The sage says: things of the same kind gather together, beings form groups by their kind. Thus, whether refined or coarse, self or other, all are said to take their place in the order—this, too, is a lofty discourse.

To encounter without resistance is to meet the times, whether favorable or adverse, and simply follow them. To pass without attachment is to let what passes transform. To harmonize, to chance upon, to respond with each stimulus, to join in accord—this is the spontaneity of virtue and the Dao. The rise of emperors and kings does not exceed this principle.

That which is sudden is the meaning of "a fleeting moment": emergence is birth, extension, coming; entering death is contraction, departure, going.

The state of sudden surging forth—pushing, crowding, bursting out—is like oil flowing smoothly, alive and ripe. This is the extension of what departs and the contraction of what arrives, precisely what the *Yi* means by "exhausting the spirit and knowing transformation." Having transformed, it gives birth; having transformed again, it dies. Living beings mourn this; people grieve over it. They loosen their bow-cases and cast off their book-wrappers, entangled and confused. The soul and spirit are about to depart, and the body follows—this is the great return to the origin of things. Originally, birth arises from nothing into being; death transforms from being back into nothing. Though the principle is the same, humans and creatures take it as sorrow and delusion. *Taō* is the bow-case; *zhì* is the wrapper. The deluded still cling to something, remaining unclear. If one can awaken, they will untie the bow-case and discard the wrapper—casting it off, abandoning it. *Fēn* and *wǎn* describe transformation: the soul and spirit disperse, and the body follows. Thus, it is called the great return, meaning the return to one’s true dwelling.

The formless taking form and form returning to formlessness—this is universally known, not the concern of those who are about to reach the ultimate. This is the common discourse of the multitude. Those who reach it do not discuss it; those who discuss it do not reach it. The formless form is the unseen. Within form, there is an unseen form—this is what the Buddha calls the *Dharmakāya*, eternally abiding and indestructible. Yet though all know this, they cannot depart from form to seek it, and so they do not attain it. To make it one’s pursuit—this is learning, and to approach the ultimate, what one engages in does not end here. Thus, it is said: this is not the concern of those who are about to reach it. The multitude all speak of this, yet none have attained it. Hence, it is called the common discourse of the multitude. Expounding further: those who attain it do not discuss it; to have such discourse is to not have attained it. Thus, it is said: those who reach it do not discuss it; those who discuss it do not reach it. For the formless form is fundamentally easy to know and requires no explanation. To take this as a topic of discussion is to have not yet reached its most wondrous state—this is speaking at a yet higher level.

Clear insight finds no encounter; disputation is inferior to silence. The Dao cannot be heard; hearing is inferior to blocking it. This is called great attainment. To see and have an encounter is a seeing with traces. The Dao cannot be perceived through form or traces, hence there is no encounter. Thus, it is said: clear insight finds no encounter. Disputation is inferior to silence; to engage in disputation is already wrong. *Mò* means not speaking. The so-called Dao is not heard from others but heard by oneself. To call it "hearing" is already not the Dao. To have heard is not as good as not having heard; to block the ears and have no hearing is best. Thus, it is said: the Dao cannot be heard; hearing is inferior to blocking. *Dà dé* means profound attainment.

Dongguo Zi asked Zhuangzi, "Where does the so-called Dao reside?"
Zhuangzi said, "There is nowhere it does not reside."
Dongguo Zi said, "Specify a place, and then it can be so."
Zhuangzi said, "It is in the ants."
"How can it be so low?"
"It is in the weeds."
"How can it be even lower?"
"It is in the tiles and bricks."
"How can it be even more so?"
"It is in excrement and urine."
Dongguo Zi did not respond.
Zhuangzi said, "Your question fundamentally does not reach the essence. When Zheng Huo asked the market inspector about weighing a pig, the lower he went, the clearer it became." This is a well-crafted fabrication, though it may seem like an extreme statement. Yet in things, whether refined or coarse, the same principle emerges—this is one point of discourse.
