Thus it is said: form inevitably produces form—it is fixed. To fix the heart in one place without transformation is to invite conquest, resentment, and desire to arise, wounding what is within. Thus it is said: completion inevitably gives rise to conquest, and change arises from what is external, disordered by external things.

When the heart contends with things, it is called "external warfare." The crane formation resembles the fish-scale array—both are names of battle formations. Foot soldiers are infantry; swift steeds are cavalry. The *Li Qiao* is the gate of palace towers; the *Zi Tan* is the site of sacrificial altars. The ancients performed sacrifices in the roadside chamber, meaning within the palace. The intent is this: if a ruler’s heart engages in struggle with things, then even within a single chamber, all appears as if infantry and cavalry array themselves in battle before him, with nothing but a realm of contention. This is what the Śākya meant by "all is created by the mind."

To gain is to lose—gaining is a favorable circumstance, losing an adverse one. Without gain, there is no loss. Thus it is said: "Do not store up adversity in gain." The following line—"gain is also clever cunning"—refers to the machinations of the heart. Schemes arise from cleverness, and warfare arises from schemes. Seeking victory over others through this, even if one slays their people and seizes their land to gratify one’s private desires of ear and eye, though one may appear victorious, one does not realize that one’s own breast is disturbed by things. The form contends with the spirit; though outwardly victorious, the spirit is wearied. To triumph over others while exhausting one’s own spirit—where lies the gain or loss? Thus it is said: "One does not know which is better." How can this be called victory? Thus it is said: "Where lies the evil of victory?" It lies in not being oneself. The ruler should not act thus. Simply cultivate one’s original sincerity to respond to the natural reality of Heaven and Earth, and do not clash or conflict with things. This is victory without contention. If I can achieve victory without contention, the people will escape death and each attain life—what need is there to seek disarmament?

When the Yellow Emperor was about to visit the Great Wei on Mount Juci, Fang Ming drove his chariot, Chang Fang rode as the outrider, and Zhang Ruo, Xi Peng, Kun Hun, and Hua Ji followed in the rear carriage. Arriving at the wilds of Xiangcheng, the Seven Sages all became lost, with no one to ask for directions. They happened upon a boy herding horses and inquired of him. The boy said, "Do you know Mount Juci?" "Yes," they replied. "Do you know where the Great Wei resides?" "Yes," he said. The Yellow Emperor exclaimed, "How extraordinary! This young boy not only knows Mount Juci but also knows where the Great Wei resides. Allow me to ask about governing the world." The boy said, "Governing the world is no different from this. What more is there to do?" "When I was young, I roamed within the Six Directions, but I suffered from a disorder of confusion. An elder taught me, saying, 'If you ride the chariot of the sun and roam the wilds of Xiangcheng, your illness will slightly improve.' Now that my illness has somewhat healed, I am about to roam beyond the Six Directions. Governing the world is no different from this—what more is there to do?" The Yellow Emperor said, "Governing the world is indeed not your concern. Nevertheless, allow me to ask about governing the world." The boy declined. The Yellow Emperor asked again, "How does governing the world differ from herding horses?" The horse-herder replied, "It is merely a matter of removing what harms the horses." The Yellow Emperor bowed twice, touched his forehead to the ground, called him the "Teacher of Heaven," and withdrew.

The Seven Sages refer to the Yellow Emperor, Fang Ming, Chang Fang, Zhang Ruo, Xi Peng, Kun Hun, and Hua Ji—all these names are allegorical. To take the Great Wei as the "great Dao’s ruggedness" is a forced interpretation. *Mao* means blurred vision. "Riding the sun" means advancing with the sun, that is, daily renewal. To say that within the Six Directions one has not departed from things is to suffer from self-inflicted confusion. To be able to depart from this illness and roam in spontaneity is to be beyond the Six Directions. The meaning is that governing the world is the same—simply free from entanglement within the realm of things. "Not your concern" means you are a person beyond things; though you need not partake in this, you must still explain it to me. Horses are herded in groups, each following water and grass. Simply follow their nature and cause them no harm, and the way of herding horses is complete. This is also the meaning of herding sheep by driving them from behind. "Teacher of Heaven" means that the heavens and humans can be one’s teachers.

Scholars who lack the transformations of thought are not joyful; debaters who lack the order of discourse are not joyful; inspectors who lack the affairs of scrutiny are not joyful—all are confined by things. The transformations of thought refer to the hundred kinds of mental shifts; the order of discourse means that speech attains coherence; *ling* means overbearing, *sui* means interrogation. Those who delight in scrutiny contend with others over the smallest details. All three follow their strengths and take pride in them, so that a single day without them brings no joy. These are people ensnared by the desires of things. Thus it is said: "confined by things."

Those who summon the world serve in the court; those who honor the common people glory in office; those of physical strength boast of difficulty; the brave delight in peril; warriors rejoice in war; the withered and emaciated cherish fame; legalists expand governance; those who respect appearances value propriety and benevolence; and those who esteem connections prize relationships. "Summoning the world" means rising to stand in the court; "honoring the world" refers to those who establish their reputation through their descendants—these are the vain. "Common people" are the mediocre; "glory in office" means taking rank and salary as honor. "Physical strength" refers to those with talent and ability; "boasting of difficulty" means taking the resolution of crises as a source of pride. "Brave" are warriors; "delighting in peril" means rejoicing in danger. The withered and emaciated are recluses; "cherishing fame" means being preoccupied with reputation. "Legalists" are those of the legalist school; "expanding governance" means seeking to manage many affairs. "Respecting appearances" means maintaining a dignified demeanor as external adornment; "esteeming connections" means valuing social relations.

Farmers without the affairs of tilling and weeding are not content; merchants without the affairs of markets and streets are not content. The common people have their daily occupations and thus encourage the hundred crafts; artisans have the skill of tools and thus take pride. "Tilling and weeding" refers to the work of cultivation; "markets and streets" refer to the affairs of commerce. "Daily occupations" means accumulating surplus day by day; "encourage" means delighting in and applying oneself. Artisans take pride in their abilities. Without the accumulation of wealth, the greedy worry; without the prominence of power, the boastful grieve. The more extreme the circumstances, the greater their joy in change. The boastful and deceitful flock to power; a single setback brings them sorrow. *You* means extreme; the desire for ever-increasing prominence. Those who rely on something are called *shi*; those who accumulate are called *wu*. The flocking followers are those who attach themselves to the gates of the rich and powerful. They delight in change, taking deceit as pleasure. Petty men who attach themselves prefer activity over stillness, often serving as retainers in households, for only through action can they achieve their ambitions. Thus it is said: "Those who rely on power and things delight in change." From this point onward, the passage on "not being joyful" shares the same meaning, merely varying in length and phrasing.

When circumstances call for action, one cannot remain inactive—all this is merely following the sequence of the seasons, not freely transforming through the changes of things. They exhaust their physical nature, submerged in the myriad things, never returning to themselves throughout their lives—how lamentable!

"When circumstances call for action" means that the times compel them, leaving their own bodies unfree; though they may wish to practice non-action, they cannot. It is like the growth and completion of all things within a year, each following its proper order. What changes and transforms is not freely determined by the things themselves. Thus it is said: "following the sequence of the seasons, not freely transforming through the changes of things." This phrase serves as a metaphor for the preceding statement. "Not freely transforming through the changes of things" means that the transformations are not self-determined by the things.

"Exhausting their physical nature" means wearing out their bodies and minds. "Submerged in the myriad things" means being engulfed, drowned in the midst of the ten thousand things, spending their entire lives without knowing how to return. "Return" here is akin to the Buddhist expression "turning the light inward to illuminate oneself."

Zhuangzi said: "An archer who hits the target without aiming beforehand is called a skilled archer—could all under heaven then be Yi?" Huizi said: "They could." Zhuangzi said: "If there is no universally accepted standard under heaven, and each takes their own as correct, could all under heaven then be Yao?" Huizi said: "They could." Zhuangzi said: "Then, with the Confucians, Mohists, Yangists, Gongsun Long, and you, that makes five—who is truly correct? Or is it like Lu Ju?" Lu Ju’s disciple said: "I have grasped the Master’s Dao! I can warm a cauldron in winter and make ice in summer." Lu Ju said: "This is merely summoning yang with yang and yin with yin—it is not what I call the Dao. Let me show you." Thereupon, he tuned two zithers, placing one in the hall and one in the inner chamber. When he struck the *gong* note on one, the *gong* note on the other resonated; when he struck the *jiao* note, the *jiao* note responded—such is the harmony of sound. But if one alters a single string so that it does not correspond to any of the five notes, and then strikes it, all twenty-five strings will vibrate. Though this differs from the resonance of *gong* answering *gong* or *jiao* answering *jiao*, is the ruler of sound not still bound to the strings? How is this different from summoning yin with yin and yang with yang? Yet Lu Ju considered himself superior to his disciple, each taking their own as correct and rejecting the other’s truth. Is this not the same as Huizi’s position?

"Aiming beforehand" means having a designated target. Only with a target can one demonstrate skill. If one shoots without a target, then all who hit it would be Yi. This phrase serves as a metaphor for the following statement, and its phrasing is most ingenious. Since there is no single, universally accepted standard under heaven, and each holds to their own, then all could be Yao.

Yang refers to Yang Zhu; Gongsun Long is Gongsun Long. The Confucians, Mohists, Yangists, Gongsun Long, and Huizi make five—since their teachings differ, who is truly correct? In the cold of winter, to warm a cauldron without fire, or in the heat of summer, to make ice without water—such defiance of the seasons seems impossible. Yet on the winter solstice, yang qi has already begun to grow, and on the summer solstice, yin qi has already begun to grow. Summoning yang with yang can dispel winter’s cold, and summoning yin with yin can alleviate summer’s heat. Though it appears to defy the seasons, there is a principle by which they can be summoned. Thus it is said: "This is not what I call the Dao," meaning their technique is not yet refined.

"Placing" means setting down. One zither is set in the hall, another in the inner chamber. Though they are far apart, when one is struck, the other responds—*gong* answering *gong*, *jiao* answering *jiao*—because their sounds are the same, as in the principle of resonance. But if one adjusts a single string so that it does not correspond to any of the five notes, and then strikes it, even the distant twenty-five strings will vibrate. This is more difficult than *gong* answering *gong* or *jiao* answering *jiao*. Yet, in principle, whether *gong*, *shang*, *jiao*, *zhi*, or *yu*, all are sounds responding to sounds, and none depart from the resonance of the strings’ notes. Thus it is said: "Though they have not begun to differ from sound." How is this different from summoning yin with yin and yang with yang? Lu Ju took himself to be superior to his disciple, each insisting on their own correctness and rejecting the other’s truth. Is this not the same as Huizi’s position?

Huizi said: "Now, the Confucians, Mohists, Yangists, and Gongsun Long all contend with me in debate, opposing my words, overpowering me with their arguments, and never conceding that I am wrong—what is to be done about this?"

Zhuangzi said: "A man of Qi entrusted his lame son to Song to serve as a gatekeeper, not expecting him to fully guard the gate or seek a *xing* bell, but merely to bind and restrain him in seeking a lost child—yet he never left the domain and still lost something. The man of Chu who was exiled and served as a gatekeeper fought with the boatman in the dead of night when no one was around. Though he never left the cliff, he still managed to incur resentment."

"Opposing my words" means contending with language. "Overpowering me with their arguments" means subduing with reputation. "Never conceding that I am wrong" means ultimately insisting on their own correctness.

*Zhi* (蹢) is pronounced like *zhi* (掷), and in the *Shuowen*, it means "to halt the foot." A *zhi* son is one who cannot walk. The man of Qi entrusted his lame son to Song, thinking he could serve as a gatekeeper. To guard a gate, one need not be whole—thus, he considered himself correct. Yet when he sought a *xing* bell, he realized the need to bind and restrain him. Why value things over one’s own child? He had never considered himself wrong. A *xing* bell is a small bell. *Tang* refers to loss. To seek a lost child only within one’s own domain is delusion—yet he never considered himself deluded. This final phrase, "still lost something," does not relate to the preceding *zhi* son. *Yi* (遗) means "to omit," and *sì* () means "to resemble."

These three matters all slightly resemble the followers of Hui Shi, Yang Zhu, and Mo Di—hence the saying, "there are omissions and resemblances." This is akin to the earlier statement, "if so." Yet though it does not culminate in resentment, what precedes it first gives rise to entanglement—precisely the artistry of composition.

Consider the lodger: in Chu, there was a lame gatekeeper sent abroad who could not return on his own. He boarded a boat to come back, and just as they reached the shore in the dead of night, he quarreled with the boatman, forgetting the kindness that had carried him across—thus turning gratitude into enmity. The bank was near; the boat had not yet left the shore, so this was no case of long neglect. *Zhi* means "to halt the foot"—a man with a lame foot who served as a gatekeeper, hence called the *zhi*-gatekeeper. In their nighttime quarrel, he surely believed himself correct. Yet when dawn came and he saw clearly, could he feel no shame? During their fight, he too took himself to be right.

These several lines all employ analogies to mock Hui Shi’s self-righteousness. But because Hui Shi loved debate, Zhuangzi crafted these cunning and elusive words—some too obscure to grasp at once—to confound him. Such was the playful banter between the two in life. One may compare this to Dongfang Shuo’s disputes with his retainers, which share a similar spirit.

When Zhuangzi passed by Hui Shi’s grave during a funeral procession, he turned to his followers and said: "A man of Ying daubed his nose-tip with white clay as thin as a fly’s wing and had Carpenter Shi shave it off. Carpenter Shi swung his axe with such force that the wind whistled, yet he sliced away every trace of clay without harming the nose. The man of Ying stood perfectly still, his composure unshaken. When the Lord of Song Yuan heard of this, he summoned Carpenter Shi and said, 'Try it for me.' The carpenter replied, 'I once could do it—but the one who stood as my target has long been dead. Since the Master’s passing, I have had no one to work with, no one to converse with.'"

*E* is white clay; he daubed his nose-tip with it, so thin it resembled a fly’s wing, then had Carpenter Shi pare it away. "Swinging the axe with force" describes the swiftness of his stroke. The clay was removed without harming the nose—cleaving was difficult enough, yet the man’s steadiness was even harder. This was the very ground for skill. The meaning is this: only with Hui Shi’s eloquence could I exhaust my arguments; now that he is dead, there is no one left to engage with.

When Guan Zhong fell ill, Duke Huan asked him, "Your illness has grown grave—can it not be said that it has reached a critical stage? If it worsens further, where should I turn?"

"When asked to whom he would entrust the state, Guan Zhong replied to the Duke, 'Whom do you desire?' The Duke said, 'Bao Shuya.' Guan Zhong said, 'He will not do. His character is pure and upright, a fine gentleman. Toward those who fall short of him, he does not associate; moreover, once he hears of a man’s faults, he never forgets them for life. If he were to govern the state, above he would constrain his lord, below he would oppose the people. The people would offend him, and their punishment would not be long in coming.'

The Duke said, 'Then who is suitable?'

Guan Zhong replied, 'If you must choose, then Xi Peng will do. His character is such that above he forgets his rank, below he distances himself from subordinates. He feels shame at falling short of the Yellow Emperor, yet pities those who fall short of him. To divide among others by virtue is called sageliness; to divide among others by wealth is called worthiness. To rule over others with worthiness has never won men’s hearts; to humble oneself before others with worthiness has never failed to win them. In the state, there are things he does not hear; in his household, there are things he does not see. If you must choose, then Xi Peng will do.'

To entrust the state is to entrust the governance of the state. *Not associating* means not frequently counting a man’s faults. *Constrain* means to bind and restrict. *Oppose* means to force the people with ritual and righteousness. All these phrases describe his tendency to distinguish too sharply between black and white. *Above he forgets his rank* means he forgets his own position. *Below he distances himself* means he keeps his distance and makes no demands of his subordinates. *Distances* means to separate. *To divide among others by virtue* means virtue descends to embrace the common people. *To divide among others by wealth* means not to be selfish. *To rule over others with worthiness* means to monopolize reputation and pride in one’s superiority. *There are things he does not hear, things he does not see* means he is not overly scrutinizing. This account does not appear in other texts and is found only in the *Liezi*—it is but an allegory, a saying meant for me. Thus it is said, 'Can it not be said that it has reached a critical stage?'"

The King of Wu floated upon the river and ascended the Mountain of Monkeys. The troop of monkeys, seeing him, in alarm abandoned their fruits and fled into the dense thickets. There was one monkey, however, that moved with leisurely grace, leaping and grasping at branches. Seeing how skillful the king was at archery, it swiftly caught the arrows he shot. The king commanded his attendants to hasten and shoot together. The monkey, though nimble, could not match their combined strength and was killed. As it died, it was seized, and turning to its companions, it said with a grimace, "This monkey trusted in its skill, relied on its agility, and scorned me—thus it has met its doom! Take heed! Alas, do not let your demeanor grow arrogant toward others!"

Yan Buyi returned home and studied under Dong Wu to uproot his haughty bearing. He forsook pleasure, renounced honor, and after three years, the people of the state praised him.

Later, Nanbo Ziqi sat leaning against his table, gazing upward and sighing. Yan Chengzi entered and said, "Master, you are the most extraordinary of men—can your form truly be made like withered bones, your heart like dead ashes?"

Ziqi replied, "Once I dwelt at the mouth of Shansong. At that time, when Tian He caught sight of me, the people of the state all congratulated him. I always took the lead, and thus they knew me; I always made myself known, and thus they acclaimed me. Had I not shown myself, how could they have known me? Had I not made myself known, how could they have acclaimed me? Alas, I grieve for those who lose themselves, and I grieve even more for those who grieve for others’ grief. Since then, with each passing day, I have drawn farther away."

When Confucius traveled to Chu, the King of Chu offered him wine. Sun Shu’ao stood holding the goblet, while Shinan Yiliao received the wine and poured a libation, saying, "The ancients spoke thus..." and then declared, "As for me, Qiu..."

Have you not heard of the speech that speaks not? Has it never been spoken of here? When Shinan Yiliao juggled his pellets, the feud between the two houses was resolved; when Sun Shu’ao slept sweetly, holding his feather fan, the men of Ying cast down their weapons. I, Qiu, would wish for a beak three feet long—what they call the Dao that is not the Dao, this is what they call the eloquence that speaks not.

Thus virtue gathers where the Dao is one, and speech ceases where knowledge reaches its limit. The Dao is one, yet virtue cannot equal it; what knowledge cannot know, eloquence cannot express. Names like "Confucian" or "Mohist" bring only misfortune. Thus the sea does not refuse the eastward flow—such is the utmost of greatness. The sage embraces heaven and earth, bestowing blessings upon the world, yet none know his name. Therefore, in life he bears no rank, in death he receives no posthumous title; he does not amass wealth, nor does he establish a name—this is called the Great Man.

A dog is not deemed good for its fine barking, nor a man for his fine words—how much less so for greatness? To be great is not enough to be called great—how much less so for virtue? Greatness is complete, none surpassing heaven and earth. What is there to seek? And yet greatness is complete. One who knows completeness seeks nothing, loses nothing, discards nothing, does not alter himself for things. Turning back to himself, he is inexhaustible; following antiquity, he does not wear thin. Such is the sincerity of the Great Man.

The ancients, ah!

Here, these words suggest that while drinking wine, one may engage in lively conversation—even the ancients did so. The Master replied: "I possess words that go unspoken, which I have never shared with others. Now, in this moment, I speak of juggling balls and playful matters. Holding a feather fan, one may sleep sweetly, harboring no intent to act. You two have already mastered the art of non-action—what need have you for me? The one with a three-foot beak speaks of having no such long beak. The deeds of Yiliao and Shu’ao differ from the historians’ accounts—these are but allegories. The Dao’s unity is natural. Virtue is attainment, what resides within oneself. What belongs to the unity of creation differs from what is made by man. Thus it is said: virtue cannot be the same. Observe how this term *virtue* differs from the *attainment* found elsewhere in this book. Names like those of the Confucians and Mohists are not the unspoken discourse—hence it is called inauspicious. None know his lineage; the people have no way to name him. *Not amassing* means that though one may possess goodness, one does not claim it for oneself. Even the worthy do not regard eloquence as ability—how much less the Great Man? To bear the name of greatness is insufficient to be called great—how much less can the natural virtue be named? *Great completeness* is great perfection. Only through seeking nothing does one lose nothing, discard nothing, and not alter oneself for things—this is because the self is nobler than things. *Following antiquity* means proceeding in accord with the ancient Way. *Not wearing thin* means not forcing oneself."

Gongsun Qi had eight sons. When he arrayed them before him, he summoned Jiufang Yin and said, “Examine my sons for me and tell me which is auspicious.” Jiufang Yin replied, “Kun is auspicious.” Gongsun Qi started in surprise and joy, asking, “In what way?” Jiufang Yin said, “Kun will share the ruler’s table and feast for the rest of his life.” Gongsun Qi sighed deeply and wept, saying, “What has my son done to reach such an extreme?”

Jiufang Yin said, “One who shares the ruler’s table brings blessings to three generations—how much more to his parents? Now, sir, you hear this and weep—this is to reject fortune. Your son is auspicious, but you are not.” Gongsun Qi said, “Yin, how could you understand that Kun is auspicious? His fortune will be exhausted in wine and meat, entering only his nose and mouth. How could you know its origin? I have never herded sheep, yet ewes were born in the inner chamber; I have never hunted, yet quails hatched in the secluded corner. Why should this be strange? What I share with my sons is to wander in Heaven and Earth. With them, I roam in joy beneath Heaven; with them, I roam in sustenance upon the Earth. I do not engage with them in affairs, nor plot with them, nor marvel with them at anomalies. With them, I ride the sincerity of Heaven and Earth without allowing things to clash with them. With them, I drift and meander without engaging in affairs—this is as it should be. Yet now there is a recompense from the vulgar world.

Whenever there are strange omens, there must be strange conduct—perhaps this is not the fault of my sons and me, but Heaven’s doing. That is why I weep.”

Before long, Kun was sent on a mission to Yan, where bandits seized him on the road. To sell him whole would be difficult, but to cut off his foot would be easy. So they severed his foot and sold him in Qi, where he happened to end up on Duke Qu’s street. There, he ate meat for the rest of his life and died.

Wine and meat entered his nose and mouth, yet he never knew whence they came—how could one say he had truly gained anything? *Zang* means a ewe; *ao* means the southwest corner.

The northeast corner of a room is called *yao*. Never tending flocks nor tilling fields, yet this creature suddenly arose within the chamber—how strange an affair! This is meant to illustrate that my sons and I sought nothing from the world; how could we have obtained such unexpected joy from Heaven? To follow Heaven and delight in oneself—this is to be nourished by the earth without other desires. To serve the world is to serve; to scheme for oneself is to scheme. When one serves the world and schemes for oneself, it becomes a perversion of the natural Dao. Yet I have never done this with my sons, for we are without intention toward the world.

Thus it is said: we do not engage in its affairs, we do not partake in its schemes, we do not share in its anomalies. To drift and meander is to follow the natural course. We do not seek to respond to affairs, nor do we know whether affairs are fitting or not—hence it is said, “we do not engage in its affairs as they should be.” *Chang* means to repay a debt. While I delight in non-action, their association with me and the lord’s shared table means that within the allotment of our fate, this worldly debt remains unpaid. Such is the mutual strangeness of these omens.

My sons ought not to have received this—what comes must harbor some discordant anomaly. Thus it is called “strange conduct.” Duke Qu’s street refers to a gate facing the thoroughfare, where he served as a gatekeeper. This passage further speaks of how human affairs may yield the unexpected—such is destiny.

When Nie Que encountered Xu You, he asked, “Where are you going?”
Xu You replied, “I am fleeing from Yao.”
Nie Que said, “What do you mean?”
Xu You answered, “Yao, with his boundless benevolence, makes me fear he will become a laughingstock to the world and later generations. When people devour one another, the common folk are not hard to gather. If you love them, they draw near; if you benefit them, they come; if you praise them, they are encouraged; but if you bring about what they detest, they scatter. Love and benefit arise from benevolence and righteousness, yet those who abandon benevolence and righteousness are few, while those who profit from them are many. The practice of benevolence and righteousness lacks sincerity and is but a pretense. The greedy, like birds and beasts, exploit it as a tool. Thus, when one man’s judgment is used to benefit the world, it is like a single slice—all under heaven is severed. Yao knows that worthy men benefit the world, yet he does not realize they also harm it. Only those who stand beyond worthiness understand this.

If you love them, they draw near; if you benefit them, they come; if you praise them, they are encouraged; but if you bring about what they detest, they scatter. Knowing these four, one can gather the people. Yet to bring about what they detest is not what they desire. If you impose what they detest, the people will not return. To follow their likes and dislikes in seeking their allegiance is to indulge in calculation. The practice of benevolence and righteousness is an external, deliberate act—hence it is said to lack sincerity. The greedy, like birds and beasts, may borrow the name of benevolence and righteousness for their own ends—hence it is said to be a pretense. A *mie* means a cut. A single *mie* is like a single slice. If one acts with intent to judge and control, using this to benefit the world, then the world’s pure and natural essence is all sliced apart. Only those who stand beyond worthiness—above the worthy—can see that those who act with intent to benefit the world instead harm it.

There are those who are *nuan shu*, those who are *ru xu*, and those who are *juan lou*. The *nuan shu* are those who study the words of a single master, then glow with private delight, self-satisfied, believing themselves complete—unaware that nothing has truly begun. Thus they are called *nuan shu*. The *ru xu* are like lice on a pig: they choose sparse bristles, thinking it a vast palace or great park; they nestle in the crooks of hooves, between teats and thighs, believing it a safe and advantageous dwelling—unaware that one day the butcher will roll up his sleeves, spread straw, and wield fire, and they will burn together with the pig. This is advancing or retreating within bounds—what is called *ru xu*. The *juan lou* is Shun. Mutton does not long for ants, but ants long for mutton because mutton is rank. Shun had a rank nature, and the people delighted in him. Thus, when he moved thrice, he founded a city, and by the time he reached Deng’s ruins, a hundred thousand households had gathered. Yao, hearing of Shun’s worthiness, raised him from the barren land, saying, ‘I hope to receive his beneficent influence.’ Shun was raised from the barren land when his years were already advanced, his hearing and sight already dimmed.”

The so-called *juan lou* is one who cannot rest or return—this describes the self-satisfaction of shallow vision. Here, it satirizes those who delight in learning yet do not understand the words of the unknowing: "There has never been a thing." They do not grasp the wonder of non-being. *Ru xu* refers to one who is mired and dependent, a person clinging to power and profit. *Shu lie* means the sparse bristles of a pig; *qu wei*, the crooks of its hooves; *gu jiao*, the area beneath the belly near the legs—this is like a beggar warming himself by a fire or leaning on an iceberg, for what one relies upon is not truly reliable. *Yu* means confining one’s heart within the bounds of wealth and honor without self-awareness. Thus it is said: advancing or retreating within bounds. *Juan lou* describes one who stoops and labors, tormenting himself. Its meaning is this: those who cultivate virtue believe themselves renowned, and the people flock to them, only to become a burden, toiling endlessly without respite. This is used to mock and ridicule emperors and kings.

*Tong tu* means barren land, referring to the place where one first dwelled—an uninhabited waste. Thus the spiritual person shuns the multitude, for where the multitude gathers, there is no harmony; without harmony, there is no benefit, only self-harm. Embracing virtue and warming harmony to comply with the world—this is called the true person. With ants, they abandon knowledge; with fish, they gain strategy; with sheep, they abandon intention. The true person’s eyes see with the eyes, ears hear with the ears, and the heart reflects with the heart. In this way, their equilibrium is as level as a carpenter’s line, and their changes follow the natural course.

The true person of old awaited Heaven and did not impose human will upon it. In life, they gained it; in death, they lost it. In death, they gained it; in life, they lost it. Where the multitude gathers, it is where people converge. Without harmony, there is no benefit—only self-harm. Embracing virtue and warming harmony means nurturing one’s power without display; *yang* refers to inner warmth. Ants are the most insignificant creatures, yet even they cannot fully abandon knowledge. Sheep are the most foolish, yet even they cannot fully abandon intention. Only the true person is without knowledge, without intention. Thus it is said: with ants, they abandon knowledge; with sheep, they abandon intention. Fish in water are leisurely and content; the true person’s self-strategy is like that of a fish. Here, water is likened to the Creator, and the fish to the self.

Ants and sheep seek sustenance externally and cannot be without desire, unlike fish. The true person’s heart, ears, and eyes are the same as others’, but they do not employ them with intention. Thus it is said: the eyes see with the eyes, the ears hear with the ears, the heart reflects with the heart. Their equilibrium is as level as a line, and their changes follow the natural course. They do not impose human will upon Heaven. In life, it may seem like gain or loss; in death, it may seem like gain or loss. They do not regard life and death as gain or loss, allowing whatever comes—whether life is called gain or death is called gain, whether death is called loss or life is called loss.

Medicine is called by one name, yet its substance may be *jin*, *jie geng*, *ji yong*, or *shi ling*. At times, it serves as the emperor. What can be said of this? *Jin* is Sichuan aconite; *ji yong*, the seed of the fox nut; *shi ling*, the fungus *Polyporus umbellatus*. Physicians prepare medicines according to their use, each with its own purpose. The primary ingredient is called the emperor; the others, ministers—what is called medicine is in truth the same, differing only in weight according to use. This is like people in the world: when their time comes and they are employed, they are noble; when their time does not come, they are base. Yet in themselves, they are neither noble nor base. These few lines are extraordinary.

Goujian relied on three thousand men in armor and shields, taking refuge at Mount Kuaiji. Only Fan Li knew how to preserve the state from ruin; only Fan Li did not know how to spare himself from sorrow. Thus it is said: the owl’s eyes have their use, the crane’s legs have their joints to be severed—how lamentable! Minister Fan Li enabled Goujian to avenge Wu from the brink of destruction, which was wise indeed, yet he did not realize that this would lead to his own demise. When Fan Li was first employed, he was the emperor of the medicine; when he was later killed, it was another time. The owl’s eyes are useful at night but not by day—this too depends on the time. The crane’s legs, though long, cannot be severed; if severed, they are no longer useful. This means the crane’s stance, with legs sometimes extended or bent, must also adapt to the time.

Thus it is said: when the wind passes over a river, it diminishes it; when the sun passes over a river, it diminishes it. If only the wind and sun were to remain together by the river, the river would not yet feel their encroachment. This is because it relies on its source. The wind and sun over the river both diminish the water, yet the river does not feel diminished because its source is long. Its source arises from the natural, so though things may diminish it, it remains untroubled. These five lines form a single idea: *zhi* means only; *qing* means to cause. It speaks of the wind and sun remaining together by the river without departing.

Thus water guards earth, the shadow guards the person, and things guard things—this is certain. Water and earth naturally intermingle; form and shadow naturally depend on one another, guarding without separation. Things guard things as water flows to the wet and fire seeks the dry—what is of Heaven inclines upward, what is of Earth inclines downward. *Shen* means certain, true. It speaks of an unchanging principle in the world, one that cannot be altered. From these three *shen* characters, one understands that in the seventh chapter, *yuan ming zhi shen* cannot be replaced with *pan*.

Thus the eyes’ reliance on brightness is perilous; the ears’ reliance on sharpness is perilous; the heart’s pursuit of things is perilous. All abilities within the organs are perilous. When peril accumulates, it cannot be remedied; calamity grows ever more concentrated. *Dai* means danger. To employ brightness with intention, to employ sharpness with intention, to pursue things with intention—none of these are the way to self-preservation. Thus it is said: all abilities within the organs are perilous. *Fu* refers to the organs; wisdom arises from the chest and organs, yet those who believe themselves capable are all in danger. Thus it is said: all abilities within the organs are perilous. *Bu ji* means insufficient. Once danger has formed, it is too late to change. *Zi cui* means ever-increasing. Its reversal follows from seeking merit; its fruition depends on long scheming. Yet people regard this as their treasure—is this not lamentable? Thus there are those who lose their states and slaughter their people without end, never questioning the cause.

Its reversal comes from pursuing merit; *yuan* means to follow. Following the heart that schemes for merit will inevitably lead to self-destruction. *Guo* means inevitable. Those who scheme for the long term harden their hearts and do not change—all this harms the self, yet people delight in it as if it were a treasure. Thus it is said: people regard it as their treasure. From ancient times to the present, those who have lost their states or suffered punishment follow one another without end, all because they do not question this—meaning they do not follow the Way.

Thus, when the feet tread upon the earth, though they tread but little, they rely on what they do not tread to achieve breadth. Human knowledge is scant, yet only by relying on what they do not know do they come to know what Heaven intends. When a person walks upon the earth, the ground their two feet tread is but a small portion; if all the earth were shaved away, leaving only enough to hold the feet, walking would become difficult. To journey far, beyond what the feet tread, there must be ground the feet do not tread—only then can one travel great distances. *Tian* here also means "to tread," and this sentence serves as a metaphor for the one below. How much can a person truly know? What they do not know is all of Heaven. If one does not rely on what they know but instead on what they do not know, then they know Heaven.

To know the Great Oneness, to know the Great Yin, to know the Great Eye, to know the Great Balance, to know the Great Square, to know the Great Faithfulness, to know the Great Constancy—this is perfection. The Great Oneness unites all; the Great Yin dissolves all; the Great Eye sees all; the Great Balance follows all; the Great Square embodies all; the Great Faithfulness verifies all; the Great Constancy upholds all.

The Great Oneness is the movement of creation and transformation—Heaven first divides creation from the One. Yin is quiescence; the Great Yin is ultimate quiescence. When quiescence reaches its extreme, there is nothing it does not dissolve—*jie* here is pronounced like "crab," akin to what Buddhist texts call *vimokṣa* (liberation). The Great Eye sees broadly. The Great Balance is the great apportionment; *yuan* means to follow. The Great Square is the Great Void, without corners, a single undifferentiated whole—thus it is called the Great Square. To embody it: the Great Faithfulness is the principle of truth and reality. *Ji* means to decide; knowing this true principle, there is nothing left to doubt. The Great Constancy is the constancy inherent in all things; *chi* means to uphold. To uphold all things under Heaven is this single constant principle.

When things reach their utmost, Heaven’s decree appears—thus it is said: "Utmost, there is Heaven." When human affairs are exhausted, Heaven’s principle becomes manifest. Following the natural course, good and ill fortune, honor and disgrace, gain and loss—all their principles become visible—thus it is said: "Following, there is illumination." Within darkness, there is always one who grasps the pivotal essence—this is what is meant by "holding the reins and guiding the net." Thus it is said: "In darkness, there is a pivot." The beginning of all things must have something that begins them. The *Qi Wu Lun* says: "Without that, there is no self; without the self, there is nothing to grasp"—this is the meaning of *bi* ("that"). Thus it is said: "Beginning, there is that." That is the natural principle of creation. Whether called Heaven, illumination, pivot, or that—though it may be dissolved and known, it seems as though it cannot be dissolved or known. To say one does not dare to regard it as knowable or dissolvable is to truly know it. Only by taking the unknown as known does one attain true knowledge.

In questioning it—it cannot be bounded, nor can it be unbounded. It is slippery and real, unchanging from ancient times to the present, yet it cannot be diminished. Can this not be called a great discourse?

Why is this questioning? It is to resolve confusion. To dissolve confusion is to return to a state without confusion—this is the greatest absence of confusion. The questioner inquires into the principle of creation. To say, "I wish to question the principle of creation," one cannot regard it as bounded, nor can one regard it as unbounded. *Xie* means stubborn; *hua* means to revolve. The wonder of creation is beyond grasp—ungraspable, it seems as though it were nothing, yet it is truly real. Thus it is said: "Slippery and real." From ancient times to the present, there has only ever been one creation, never replaced, and its use is inexhaustible. How could it ever suffer the slightest diminution? Thus it is said: "Unchanging from ancient times to the present, yet it cannot be diminished." Considering this principle, is this not a grand topic of discussion? *Yang* means to raise; *que* means to expound and debate. Why is this so?

This is the principle of creation—why not inquire into this principle of creation, and what doubt remains? Thus it is said: "What confusion?" Now, by means of this principle of non-doubt, one resolves the doubts of the world and returns once more to the ground of non-doubt, approaching thereby the state of great non-doubt.

When Zhaozhou asked Nanquan about the Way of non-doubt, his intent was precisely these few words—indeed, it comes close. The two characters "non-doubt" were drummed forth by Zhuangzi, who then composed these several sentences to conclude the entire essay. Truly extraordinary! How does this essay differ from those in the Inner Chapters?

In the "Miscellaneous Chapters," "Zeyang" (Chapter Twenty-Five): Zeyang was traveling in Chu when Yijie spoke of him to the king. The king had not yet met him. Yijie returned to Pengyang, who then saw the king. The king said, "Why did you not speak to me of this Master?" Pengyang replied, "I am not the equal of Gong Yuxiu." Pengyang then asked, "What does Gong Yuxiu do?" He said, "In winter, he spears turtles in the Jiang; in summer, he rests in the mountains. When someone passing by asked, 'This is my dwelling,' he replied, 'Yijie was already incapable—how much more so I? I am not the equal of Yijie.' Now, Yijie’s character: though lacking in virtue, he possessed knowledge. He did not esteem himself, yet through this, his interactions became dark and confused. In the realm of wealth and honor, rather than aiding others through virtue, he aided them through dissipation. The frozen borrow clothing in spring; the scorched revert to winter. Cold and wind—such is the nature of the King of Chu. His form is august and severe; in matters of punishment, he grants no pardon, fierce as a tiger. If not for flatterers and those of upright virtue, who could sway him? Thus, when the sage is in straitened circumstances, he causes his household to forget their poverty; when he prospers..."

He causes lords and nobles to forget their ranks and emoluments, transforming their arrogance into humility toward all things. In his dealings with the world, he delights in the free flow of things while preserving himself. Thus, at times, without speaking, he offers others harmony through drink; standing beside them, he transforms them, bringing about the proper order between father and son—how could this not be so? Returning home, he remains in quietude, his influence effortless. His effect on others’ hearts is as distant as this. Hence it is said: As for Gongyue Xiu, his surname was Yang, his given name Pengyang, and his courtesy name Yang. Yijie once recommended Yang to the King, but he was not employed and returned home. "This is my dwelling" refers to his lack of a fixed abode. Pengyang was fond of advancement, so he used the words of a recluse to admonish him, hoping he would awaken on his own.

"Lacking virtue but possessing knowledge" means not recognizing the principles of Heaven and relying solely on private cleverness. "Spirit" refers to what is natural within oneself. To be "dark and confused in interactions" in the realm of wealth and honor is to become obstinately attached, losing one’s original heart and no longer knowing the natural spirit within. Thus it is said, "He did not esteem himself, yet through this, his interactions became dark and confused." In his dealings with others, rather than mutually cultivating goodness, he led them into a path of self-diminishment. Hence it is said, "Rather than aiding others through virtue, he aided them through dissipation."

The following lines illustrate this: The frozen, upon receiving clothing, feel the warmth of spring; the scorched, upon receiving wind, feel the chill of winter. This speaks of how people should assist one another by using their surplus to relieve others’ deficiencies. Pengyang’s fondness for advancement was his deficiency, and my warning him to withdraw was like offering a fan to one scorched by heat or clothing to one freezing—it would benefit him.

"His form is august and severe" means he relied on his power to overawe his subordinates. "In matters of punishment, he grants no pardon, fierce as a tiger" shows his lack of benevolence. "To sway" means to humble oneself. If not for flatterers and those of upright virtue, who could bend him to their will? Here, "those of upright virtue" refers to true petty men.

The following lines all speak of the sage who, though reclusive, harbors no desire for advancement or employment: Lords and nobles are exalted, yet he makes them forget their ranks and emoluments, humbling themselves to scholars and transforming their arrogance into humility. He exhausts the principles of all things to find joy for himself, hence it is said, "In his dealings with the world, he delights in the free flow of things while preserving himself." In his interactions with others, he follows the principles of all things without obstruction, preserving his true nature and finding joy in it. Hence it is said, "He delights in the free flow of things while preserving himself."

There is a teaching without words that can enlighten others, like offering them the purest harmony to drink—what the Buddhist scriptures call "drinking the finest ghee." A glance conveys the Dao; a composed demeanor influences others’ intentions. Thus it is said, "Standing beside them, he transforms them." As the *Book of Songs* says, "That man—if he were to return and dwell at home..." This line is inverted; the meaning is that if that man were to return home, the proper order between high and low, elder and younger would be established. Hence it is said, "bringing about the proper order between father and son—how could this not be so?" Returning home, his influence is effortless, hence it is said, "he remains in quietude, his influence effortless." This means that whether at home or in his village, all is in harmony.

"His effect on others’ hearts is as distant as this" means that people’s capacities differ so greatly. This refers to the vast difference between Gongyue Xiu’s heart and Pengyang’s. "I am not the equal of Yijie" means that Yijie was a flatterer, also fond of advancement. He recommended you to the King—how could I be like him? This expresses disdain for Yijie.

[The line "bringing about the proper order between father and son—how could this not be so? Returning home" is a single sentence.]

When the sage prospers, he weaves all things together, exhausting their unity without being aware of it—this is his nature. He moves and acts, taking Heaven as his teacher. Others follow and name him as such. Yet how can one who is troubled by knowledge ever find rest in their actions? How can they cease?

"Weaving together" refers to the ceaseless interplay of yin and yang in creation. "Unity" means the fusion of the refined and the coarse. The sage comprehends the principles of creation, exhausting the wondrous unity of the refined and the coarse. He follows nature without being aware of it, hence it is said, "this is his nature." "Nature" is what is natural. "Moves and acts" refers to activity and action. All activity and action return to the mandate of Heaven, taking nature as their master, hence it is said, "taking Heaven as his teacher." "Names him" means to bestow a title. People follow the sage’s example and name him as such—what intention did the sage originally have? Hence it is said, "Others follow and name him as such."

"Troubled by knowledge" means that private cleverness gives rise to endless worries, with countless calculations. How many of these calculations can be realized? Hence it is said, "their actions are rarely successful." If I intend to act but am hindered by fate, others are the same. Why is this? Because fate has its limits. "How can they cease?" refers to fate and limits. These two lines thoroughly explore the human condition, tracing all afflictions to the beginning of knowledge. If one knew what one does not know, there would be no worries.

Thus, the following uses the analogy of a beautiful mirror: One who is beautiful from birth is given a mirror; if not told, they do not know their beauty surpasses others. Whether they know or do not know, hear or do not hear, their joy is endless. Others’ fondness for them is also endless—this is their nature. The sage’s love for others is given a name; if not told, they do not know of his love for others. Whether they know or do not know, hear or do not hear, his love for others is endless. Others’ comfort in this is also endless—this is their nature.

Beauty arises from ugliness; if not told of their ugliness, they would not know their own beauty. The distinction between beauty and ugliness, good and evil, is the source of worries. Hence it is said, "Whether they know or do not hear, their joy is endless." Since I make no distinction between beauty and ugliness and interact with things without intention, others’ fondness for me is also endless—this is the principle of nature. The analogy of the beautiful mirror also extends to the sage’s love for others. The meaning is that if love for others becomes a name, it involves intention, and intention departs from the original true nature.

Gazing upon one’s old state and old capital brings joy. Even if nine-tenths of the hills, grass, and trees were to encroach upon them, the joy would remain. How much more so for what one sees and hears? A hundred-foot tower stands amidst the crowd. Ran Xiangshi grasped the center of the ring, adapting to all things without end or beginning, without limit or time. He merged with the transformations of things, becoming one with them—unchanging himself. He once abandoned this.

Returning from a long journey to behold one’s old state and old capital must evoke a sense of joy—this speaks of the stirring of feeling. Even if, upon entering the old state, its people and things have changed, and the hills are overgrown with grass and trees, nine-tenths altered from former days, so long as a single part remains familiar, that joy persists. How much more so for one who seeks the Dao, who suddenly awakens to perceive what they have always seen and hear what they have always heard—all things in their original, inherent state? Could they not rejoice? This is what the Buddha meant by "original face" and "native scenery"—precisely this meaning. The hundred-foot tower is its highest point.

"County" refers to the display of music; "among the crowd" means the interweaving of reed pipes and bells. Standing in so lofty a place, hearing the layered, alternating music, one may stir the ears and eyes of the common world. How much more so for the ancient sages, who followed the principle of emptiness, non-action, and naturalness, delighting in all things—how exalted was their station! The analogy of the ring’s center is that of emptiness. Without end, without beginning, end and beginning are as one. Without limit, without time, there is no past or present. "Limit" refers to the changes of seasons. "Daily transforming with things" means moving together with them, ever renewing. Yet what one attains remains unchanging—this is how it is put into practice.

"To abandon" means to leave; "why" asks for what reason. It questions why worldly people do not cast off their habitual ways and return to the ultimate Dao. Ran Xiangshi was an ancient sage. To take Heaven as one’s teacher yet fail to truly follow Heaven is to be enslaved by things in one’s affairs. What can be done about this? The sage never begins with Heaven, never begins with man, never begins with a beginning, never begins with things. They move with the world without ceasing, their conduct complete yet not confined to any one path. How could it be otherwise?

Tang received Yi Yin as his charioteer, with Menyin Dengheng as his tutor, learning from his teacher without being bound by him, attaining the ability to follow transformations—this was his office in name. "To take Heaven as one’s teacher yet fail to truly follow Heaven" means to take naturalness as one’s model yet not be burdened by the name of naturalness, merely harmonizing with things. Thus it is said, "to be enslaved by things." If one has intention in one’s affairs, what can be done? The moment there is intention in affairs, it is no longer natural.

Man has action; Heaven has non-action. Not only are there no traces of action, but even the absence of action is absent. Thus it is said, "never begins with Heaven, never begins with man"—these are traces. "Never begins with things" means no traces of things. Not only are there no traces of things, but even the absence of traces is absent. Thus it is said, "never begins with a beginning, never begins with things." Moving through this world, they are never apart from others in the human realm, never neglecting affairs. Thus it is said, "they move with the world without ceasing," without neglect. All actions are complete yet not attached to any single one. Thus it is said, "their conduct is complete yet not confined." *Equalizing Things* speaks of this as "old and confined"—"confined" meaning mired and drowned in attachment.

To be one with the Dao is to unite without seeking; if one seeks to unite with the Dao, it cannot be attained. Thus it is said, "how could it be otherwise?" In Tang’s case with Yi Yin, he studied under him and later made him his minister. Zhuangzi, however, altered the names and titles, calling his office "Charioteer" and saying "Menyin Dengheng"—these are merely such strange and deceptive words. "Tutor" means assistant; it speaks of Yi Yin assisting Tang. Though Tang took Yi Yin as his teacher, he was not confined by him.

Thus it is said: "to follow a teacher yet not be confined." Tang’s non-action was such that he grasped the inherent principles of the myriad things and followed them, abiding in the realm of non-action and spontaneity. He allowed his assisting minister Yi Yin to bear the name of office, hence it is said, "he attained their following and completion, appointing them to their names." This speaks of Tang’s non-action and Yi Yin’s action—Tang without name, Yi Yin with name. *Si* (司) means "to preside"; it speaks of Menyin bearing many names of action. These names are *ying* (嬴), a surplus, meaning "excess." It is to say that such names in the world are superfluous, like "long things." *Liang jian* (两见) means "to see both," body and name as two. If one has intent toward making a name, one cannot attain the undifferentiated unity. Thus it is said, "he attained their duality."

Yi Yin’s bearing of these names was not yet extraordinary, yet Confucius again admired him, exhausting his thoughts and plans to serve as an assistant in this world—this speaks of the Master desiring to do as Yi Yin had done. This is mockery of the sage. Rongchengshi borrowed the names of ancient sages. Combining three hundred and sixty days makes one year; if one removes them day by day, one can only call them "days," not a "year." Thus it is said, "remove the days, and there is no year." This line is excellent. Laozi said, "count the spokes, and there is no wheel"—it is of the same meaning. The name of "external" arises from the "internal"; without the internal, there is no external. Thus it is said, "without internal, without external." These two lines demonstrate the meaning of spontaneity.

Wei Ying (King Hui of Wei) made a pact with Tian Mou (King Wei of Qi), but Tian Mou betrayed it. Wei Ying, enraged, was about to send an assassin. Xishou, hearing of this, found it shameful and said, "You are a lord of ten thousand chariots, yet you would follow the path of a commoner in seeking vengeance? Let me request two hundred thousand armored troops to attack him, capturing his people, seizing his oxen and horses, and making his lord’s back break out in boils. Only after he flees his state will I strike his back and break his spine." Jizi, hearing of this, found it shameful and said, "To build a city wall seventy feet high, then tear it down—this is the suffering of penal laborers. Now, for seven years, there has been no war; this is the foundation of your rule. Yan (Xishou) is a disturber of order and cannot be heeded." Huazi, hearing of this, found it disgraceful and said, "Those who speak well of attacking Qi are disturbers of order; those who speak well of not attacking are also disturbers of order. To say that both attacking and not attacking are disturbances—this is yet another disturbance. My lord, you should seek the Dao alone."

Wei Ying was King Hui of Wei; Tian Mou was King Wei of Qi. *Xumi* refers to those sentenced to penal labor, who suffer when a completed wall is torn down. Seven years without war was a fine achievement of the King of Wei, yet Xishou urged him to use troops, like tearing down a completed wall. Yan was Xishou’s name. Huazi’s words implied that any mention of "attack" involved intent, so all three were disturbers of order. With the Dao, one does not speak of troops at all. Thus it is said, "My lord, you should seek the Dao alone."

Huizi, hearing this, went to see Dai Jinren. Jinren said, "There is a creature called the snail—do you know of it?" The king said, "Yes." Jinren continued, "On the left horn of the snail is a state called Chushi; on the right horn is a state called Manshi. They often fought over territory, leaving tens of thousands of corpses, and pursued the fleeing army for fifteen days before returning." The king said, "Alas! Are these empty words?" Jinren replied, "Let me make them real for you. In your mind, do the four directions, above and below, have limits?" The king said, "They are limitless." Jinren said, "To roam the mind in the limitless and return to the state of passage—does it seem to exist or not?" The king said, "Yes." Jinren said, "Within the state of passage is Wei; within Wei is Liang; within Liang is the king. Is there any difference between you and Manshi?" The king said, "There is no difference." The guest departed, and the king was lost in thought, as if something were missing.

When the guest left, Huizi saw the king and said, "That guest is a great man—even a sage is not his equal." Huizi said, "Blowing into a pipe produces a sound, but blowing into a sword’s hilt produces only a faint *xue* sound. Yao and Shun are praised by people, but to speak of Yao and Shun before Dai Jinren is like that faint *xue* sound." This passage is excellent. Huizi, hearing Huazi speak of seeking the Dao, recommended Dai Jinren to the king. Dai Jinren was a man of the Dao. The snail’s horn analogy seems like empty words, but what follows makes it real. Thus it is said, "Let me make them real for you." The limitless is the great void; the "state of passage" is the central kingdom. Viewing the central kingdom from the great void makes it seem tiny, as if existing or not. Thus it is said, "Does it seem to exist or not?" Du Fu said, "Looking down, there is only qi"—this is the same meaning. Viewing Wei from the central kingdom makes it small; Liang is its capital. Within Wei, the capital is even smaller; within the capital, the king’s person is even more minute. From the great void above, descending step by step, the king’s person and the snail’s Manshi and Chushi are no different. Thus it is said, "Is there any difference?" *Changran ruo you wang* means being lost in thought, realizing the insignificance of their conflict.

A pipe has holes, like a flute or reed; though it lacks melody, blowing into it still produces a sound. But blowing into a sword’s hilt produces only a faint *xue* sound, meaning it is entirely without sound. This implies that before a man of the Dao, even speaking of benevolence, righteousness, the Dao, or principle would have no place for sound.

When Confucius traveled to Chu, he lodged at the thatched hut of Ant Hill. A neighbor, a man with his wife, concubine, and servants, climbed to the roof. Zilu said, "What is this crowd doing?" Confucius said, "This is the servant of a sage. He buries himself among the people, hides in the wilderness, his voice silenced, his ambitions boundless. Though he speaks, his heart never speaks. He goes against the world, his mind disdaining to follow it—this is one who sinks in the land." Zilu said, "Is this Shina Yiliao?" Zilu asked to summon him. Confucius said, "Enough. He knows I am known to him, knows I am traveling to Chu, and thinks I will surely have the King of Chu summon him. He would consider me a flatterer. If that is so, he would be ashamed to hear my words, let alone meet me in person. How could he still be there?" Zilu went to see, but his house was empty.

At Ant Mound there lived a family that sold broth. The Master lodged at their home. Those who climbed to the roof ascended to its highest point to gaze upon the people below—so many, so bustling. The "servant of a sage" refers to a disciple of the sage, one who buries himself among the people, concealing himself among his neighbors, unknown even to those nearby. "His voice silenced" means he flees from fame. "Sinking" is not in water but on land, likening his concealment to one who hides in the marketplace. This man must be a disciple of Shina Yiliao. Yiliao, surnamed Xiong, dwelled in the southern market of Chu. "Known to him" means he surely knows me. A "flatterer" is one who speaks excessively. "How could he still be there?" means he must have departed and not remained. His house was empty because he fled, fearing the Master would speak of him to the King of Chu and summon him, so he escaped.

The Warden of Changwu asked Zilao, "When governing, do not act recklessly; when ruling the people, do not act carelessly." He continued, "In the past, when I cultivated grain, if I plowed recklessly, the harvest repaid me recklessly. If I weeded carelessly, the harvest repaid me carelessly. The following year, I changed my methods: I deepened the plowing and thoroughly harrowed the soil, and the grain flourished and grew abundant. I was sated for the entire year."

Zhuangzi heard this and said, "Nowadays, when people cultivate their bodies and order their minds, many resemble what the Warden describes: they flee from their Heaven, depart from their nature, extinguish their emotions, and lose their spirit, taking the common as their norm. Those who recklessly treat their nature allow the sprouts of desire and aversion to become their nature. Like reeds and rushes, like bulrushes and reeds, they first sprout, then support our form, gradually uprooting our nature. Together they fester and leak, erupting without choosing where, giving rise to wandering sores, scabies, ulcers, internal abscesses, and wasting diseases—such is the result."

The Warden used plowing to illustrate governance; Zhuangzi, in turn, used it to illustrate learning. Su Dongpo’s *On Farming* follows this same pattern. "Changed his methods" means altering his approach. "Sated" means being full from eating. "Taking the common as their norm" means such people are numerous in the world. "Aversion" refers to dislikes. "Sprouts" are pernicious growths. The harm of likes and dislikes obstructs and blocks our original nature, like reeds choking a heart. Once nature is obstructed, the growth of deluded desires, like the first sprouts of bulrushes, fills the body—every part becomes consumed by human desire. "Support" means to aid. When desires assist the form, sight, hearing, speech, movement, rest, and diet all lose their natural principles. Thus, it is said, "gradually uprooting our nature." "Gradually" means little by little; "uprooting" means to pull out. At first, true nature is merely obstructed, but as it worsens, it is gradually torn away, until Heavenly principle is utterly destroyed. Once true nature is lost, qi also becomes diseased, giving rise to simultaneous festering and leakage, eruptions without choosing where—any contact breeds illness. "Simultaneous festering" refers to wandering sores, scabies, and ulcers—diseases of pus and blood. "Leakage" refers to internal abscesses and wasting diseases—what we now call diabetes. This parable serves to warn those in the world who indulge their passions and neglect the Dao, for in the end, they will surely destroy themselves.

Bo Ju studied under Lao Dan, saying, "I request to travel throughout the world." Lao Dan replied, "Enough! The world is all like this." Bo Ju again entreated Lao Dan, "Where should I begin?" Lao Dan said, "Begin with Qi."

Upon arriving in Qi, Bo Ju saw a condemned man. He pushed forward and forced his way through, removed his court robes to cover the man, and wailed to Heaven, crying, "O man! O man! The world suffers great calamity, yet you alone have met it first! Do not steal, do not kill—only when honor and disgrace are established do people see what afflicts them; only when wealth and property are amassed do people see what they contend over. Now, by establishing what afflicts people and amassing what they contend over, you exhaust their strength without respite—how could this not reach such a state?"

*"The world is all like this"* means that the world is everywhere thus. *"Do not steal, do not kill"* means: was it for stealing or for killing that you were punished and imprisoned? *"Do not"* here signifies *"was it not thus?"* Honor and disgrace are names; wealth and property are profit. Affliction and harm arise from these. Those above prize names, and thus these afflictions and harms follow; rulers covet amassing wealth, and thus these contentions arise—such matters all begin from above.

Laozi said, *"Do not exalt the worthy, and the people will not contend; do not prize goods hard to obtain, and the people will not steal."* This is the same idea: using fame and profit to enslave people, driving them to self-exhaustion without end—how could it not reach such a state? His meaning was that in the great antiquity, there were no names, no profits, and so customs were pure and honest, states had no punishments, and people no crimes.

The rulers of old took success as belonging to the people and failure as their own; they took uprightness as belonging to the people and crookedness as their own. Thus, if even one person’s form suffered harm, the ruler would withdraw and take the blame himself. Now, however, it is not so.

*"Now, however, it is not so"* refers to later ages. They conceal matters to deceive the people, calling those who do not know *"foolish"*; they impose great and difficult tasks, blaming those who dare not undertake them as *"guilty"*; they assign heavy burdens without measuring people’s strength, punishing those who cannot bear them; they send people on distant journeys, executing those who do not arrive. The people, knowing their strength is exhausted, resort to deception to continue. Day by day, deceit multiplies—how could the people not deceive? When strength is insufficient, they feign ability; when knowledge is insufficient, they cheat; when wealth is insufficient, they steal. To whom can the blame for theft and deception be laid?

The two lines *"success and failure, uprightness and crookedness"* mean that if the common people have faults, it lies with *"me alone."* If even one person’s form does not obtain its life, the ruler withdraws and takes the blame himself, as if he had cast a commoner into a ditch without bestowing grace upon them. *"Now, however, it is not so"* refers to later generations.

The ruler sends people on distant journeys without calculating their travel capacity, forcing them to do what they cannot and punishing those who fail, executing those who do not arrive. Those in high position issue decrees day by day, each more deceptive than the last—how could the people not resort to deception? When forced to do what their strength cannot bear, they must respond with pretense; when compelled to do what their knowledge cannot reach, they must respond with fraud. Excessive exactions without restraint drive them to theft to meet demands—it is I who make them deceive, cheat, and steal. Whom else can blame be laid upon?

These three phrases form a single idea, leading to the following line on theft, where the meaning becomes clear—this is also a matter of literary structure. When Qu Boyu reached sixty, he transformed sixty times, never failing to begin with what he took as right and end by rejecting it as wrong. How could he know that what he now called right was not the wrong of his fifty-ninth year? At sixty, his insights each year surpassed the last, yet how could he be certain that the rightness of his sixtieth year was truly right? This is but one example.

All things have life, yet none see their roots; all things emerge, yet none see their gates. People all honor the knowledge of what they know, but none know to rely on the knowledge of what they do not know—can this not be called a great delusion? Enough, enough! There is no escape from this—is this what is meant by "so it is, so it is"?

That things have life must have roots; that they emerge must have gates—only people do not see them. This is what lies beyond knowing. For people to know what they know yet not know what they do not know is the height of subtlety—such are the truly deluded. "There is no escape" means that it is naturally so, an unknowing knowledge that pervades past and present, above and below. Where is there a place not governed by this principle? How could one escape it? "So it is, so it is?" is a concluding phrase, asking whether what is called "so" is truly so. When Zigong replied, "So it is, is it not?" he meant precisely this. (See the *Wei Ling Gong* chapter; *ran yu* is pronounced *yu*.)

Confucius asked the Grand Historian Da Tao, Bo Chang Qian, and Xi Wei: "Wei Ling Gong indulged in wine and pleasure, neglecting state affairs; he hunted and fowled without responding to the affairs of other lords. How then did he come to be called 'Ling Gong'?" Da Tao said, "It was because of this." Bo Chang Qian said, "Ling Gong had three wives, with whom he bathed in debauchery. When Historian Fang presented himself in audience, Ling Gong had attendants support him with gifts in hand—his dissipation was extreme, yet his reverence toward worthy men was like this. This is why he was called 'Ling Gong.'" Xi Wei said, "When Ling Gong died, divination for burial in the ancestral tomb was inauspicious, but burial at Sha Qiu was auspicious. When they dug several fathoms deep, they found a stone outer coffin. Washing it, they saw an inscription: 'Do not rely on his descendants; Ling Gong will seize and bury it.' Ling Gong’s being called 'Ling' had long been so—how could these two understand it?"

"Fowling" refers to hunting birds and beasts. Ling Gong did not respond to the rituals of interstate relations—how could a man like this be posthumously titled "Ling"? It means the title was not sufficient to match his faults. Da Tao said, "This was also because the people of the state universally agreed to title him thus." (Here, *shi* "this" means the same as *ci* "this.") "Presenting what was presented" refers to the place where he resided. "Attendants" is like what is now called "summoning for audience." "Grasping gifts" means holding the ceremonial silk presented upon an audience, and Ling Gong had people support him—this was a sign of propriety. "Reverence" means solemn respect. Sha Qiu was an ancient burial site. Since Ling Gong’s name was already fixed before his birth, how could human effort have determined it? This is a metaphor for all worldly affairs arising from spontaneity. "These two" refers to Da Tao and Bo Chang Qian. "Do not rely on his descendants" means his descendants could not be entrusted with it, so Ling Gong seized and buried it. (*Feng* means "to rely on.")

Little Knowledge asked Grand Duke Diao: "What is meant by 'the words of the village'?" Grand Duke Diao said: "A village combines ten surnames and a hundred names to form its customs. It unites differences to make sameness and disperses sameness to make differences. Now, if you point to the hundred parts of a horse but do not get the horse, yet when a horse stands before you, you assemble its hundred parts and call it a horse—this is the principle. Thus, hills accumulate the low to become high; rivers combine waters to become great. The great man unites and combines to become public-spirited. Therefore, what enters from without has a master but is not grasped; what issues from within has a norm but is not resisted. The four seasons have distinct qi, yet Heaven does not bestow them, so the year is completed. The five offices have distinct duties, yet the ruler does not favor them, so the state is well-governed. The virtues of Wen and Wu were not bestowed, so their power was complete. The myriad things have distinct principles, yet the Dao does not favor them, so it is nameless. Nameless, it does nothing; doing nothing, yet nothing is left undone. Times have endings and beginnings; the world has changes and transformations. Fortune and misfortune flow ceaselessly. Where there is obstruction, there is also what is fitting; where there is self-sacrifice for distinct faces, there is also what is correct and what is deviant. Compared to the great marsh, all materials find their measure. Observing the great mountain, trees and stones share the same foundation—this is what is meant by 'the words of the village.'"

"Gathering wells makes a mound; gathering mounds makes a village"—hence the term "village." Within one village, there are ten surnames and a hundred names. Though people differ, their customs are the same—this illustrates uniting differences to make sameness. "The words of the village" are the common words of a village. Uniting differences to make sameness means the myriad things share one principle. Dispersing sameness to make differences means each thing possesses its own principle. Assembling the hundred parts to make a horse—yet the name "horse" does not reside in any single part—this is dispersing sameness to make differences. Only when the hundred parts are assembled is it called a horse—this is uniting differences to make sameness. Accumulating to make a mountain and combining to make water follow the same principle. Uniting and combining to become public-spirited means uniting the differences of the myriad things to make sameness. "Having a master but not grasping" means what is mastered resides within, yet nothing is grasped—grasping would not be spontaneous. "Norm" refers to the principle of the myriad things. What issues from the heart shares the same principle as the myriad things, naturally harmonizing without resistance. Not grasping, not resisting—this is following spontaneity without the intent of sameness or difference. Heaven does not bestow—it does not claim merit. The five offices are arranged in ranks of five, each performing its duty—how could the ruler favor one over another? The great man embodies the virtues of Wen and Wu—when the time is right for Wen, he acts as Wen; when the time is right for Wu, he acts as Wu—this is not a matter of bestowal. Thus, his virtue is complete. The myriad things each have their own principle—hence "distinct principles." The Great Dao unites them to become public-spirited—hence "does not favor." "Nameless" means it cannot be named.

The flowing and unceasing movement is natural. The arrival of fortune and misfortune, blessing and calamity, depends on hidden interdependence without constancy—sometimes what seems contrary may in fact be fitting, like the old man who lost his horse, then regained it. "Contrary" means thwarted, not as one wishes; "fitting" means as one wishes. If people cling to their own minds, it is like their faces—all different.
