To have something one corrects is to fixate and become rigid. To be rigid is to err, as people today say, "to force an analogy is to miss the mark." Thus, it is said: to have something one corrects is to have something one errs in—this is a comparison. For example, in a great marsh, the materials of a hundred things each fit their measure, whether small or great, all can be used.

"Same altar" means the same ground. Wood and stone originally reside on one mountain—initially, what distinction is there? This is uniting the different to become the same. Lesser Knowledge said: "Then is this sufficient to be called the Dao?" Grand Duke Mou replied: "No. Now, the number of things is not limited to the myriad things, yet we call them 'the myriad things'—this is naming them by their great number. Thus, heaven and earth are the greatest of forms, yin and yang are the greatest of qi, and the Dao is their shared principle. To name them by their greatness is acceptable. But if one already has this, how can it be compared? To use such analogies is like comparing dogs and horses—they fall far short.

Things are not limited to the myriad, yet we speak of 'the myriad things'—this is their total number, an approximation, a shorthand. Heaven and earth, yin and yang, are likewise general names for forms and qi. Forms and qi are not limited to heaven and earth or yin and yang, but we speak of them by their greatness. The Dao as the shared principle is also spoken of by borrowing from their greatness. Though the name 'Dao' already exists, how can it be compared and spoken of in this way? Thus, it is said: if one already has this, how can it be compared? Dogs and horses cannot be made the same—this is the case here. To compare them and engage in such debate is like the difference between dogs and horses—they cannot be united, nor are they comparable, and the distance is great indeed."

Lesser Knowledge said: "Within the four directions and the six conjunctions, where do the myriad things arise?" Grand Duke Mou replied: "Yin and yang illuminate and respond to each other, cover and combine, regulate and transform. The four seasons alternate, give birth and kill, desire and aversion, departure and approach arise from this. Male and female unite in pairs, and thus there are constantly shifts between safety and danger, fortune and misfortune, urgency and ease, gathering and scattering—forming the names and realities that can be recorded, the subtleties that can be noted. Following the sequence, they regulate each other; arising and operating, they employ each other. When exhausted, they return; when ended, they begin anew—these are the inherent patterns of things, the utmost of speech and knowledge, the limit of what can be known. Only the things themselves. Those who perceive the Dao do not follow what decays nor trace what arises—this is where their discourse ends.

Where do the myriad things begin? Thus, it is said: where do they arise? They illuminate and respond to each other, cover and combine, regulate and transform—grow and diminish. The four seasons alternate: spring gives birth, autumn kills, each following its time. From this, desire and aversion, departure and approach, male and female, union and separation, safety and danger, fortune and misfortune, urgency and ease, gathering and scattering arise—these are the affairs of the human world following the existence of heaven and earth, yin and yang. All these are differences within sameness, arising like a bridge arching high. 'Pieces' means division; 'pairing' means union. 'Constantly' means always. 'Forming' means completing each other—here, only the character is changed for literary effect. From desire and aversion to gathering and scattering, their names and realities can be recorded, their subtleties can be noted—each can be seen, not only spoken of but also written down. Following the sequence of time, they regulate each other. Arising and operating, they employ each other in growth and diminution. When exhausted, they return to openness; when ended, they begin anew—these are the necessary patterns of the myriad things. Speech that reaches its limit arrives at this; knowledge that attains its utmost arrives at this. To exhaust heart and strength is only to grasp the character of 'things.' Thus, it is said: the limit is only the things themselves. Only those who know the Dao do not follow what decays nor trace what arises—they attribute all to the absence of origin, to spontaneity. Thus, their discourse ends here."

Lesser Knowledge said: "Ji Zhen’s 'non-action' and Jie Zi’s 'contingent causation'—whose discourse aligns with reality, whose principle is partial?" Grand Duke Mou replied: "The crowing of roosters and the barking of dogs are known to all. Even the most knowledgeable cannot describe in words how they transform themselves; people cannot anticipate in thought what they will do. Yet to analyze this precisely is to reach the boundless, to encompass the immeasurable. 'Contingent causation' and 'non-action' are still bound by things and ultimately considered flawed.

Ji Zhen and Jie Zi were two contemporaries, each with their own theory. One spoke of 'non-action,' meaning that within all occurrences, there is initially no controller—all is accidental. The other spoke of 'contingent causation,' meaning there is a controller, and nothing is not caused—what moves is caused to move, what stops is caused to stop. 'Aligns with reality' means it accords with the facts. 'Partial in principle' means it is a biased view."

Should one affirm or reject either of these two theories? The analogy of the crowing rooster and barking dog illustrates their divergence. What people know differs, so even the wisest cannot fully articulate or grasp the subtleties of self-transformation. How can one recite another’s words to comprehend the marvel of their insight? How can one fathom the intentions behind another’s actions? This is the principle at hand.

To analyze it precisely is to speak of the great and the small, for its depths cannot be exhausted. "Without measure" refers to the extreme of the minute; "unfathomable" to the extreme of the vast. Both theories remain entangled with things and ultimately harbor flaws—each suffers from inherent limitations.

The theory of "contingent causation" is substantive; that of "non-action" is empty. What has form and reality is bound to things; what is nameless and formless resides in their absence. Yet both can be expressed in words and conceived in thought, and thus both remain distant from the Dao.

The unborn cannot be prevented; the dead cannot be obstructed. Life and death are not distant—their principle is not visible. "Prevention" means prohibition. Before birth, one cannot avoid coming into being; once born, death cannot be defied or resisted. The principle of life and death lies before us, not far away, yet it cannot be seen—hence it is said to be "not visible."

The theories of "contingent causation" and "non-action" are but provisional explanations. Observing their origins, I see their past is boundless; seeking their ends, their future is endless. Boundless and endless, they are as insubstantial as words, sharing the same principle as things. If one insists on "contingent causation" or "non-action," worldly doubts arise from these very assumptions—how can one claim to be free from entanglement?

The "root" is the state before movement; the "end" is the state after cessation. Observing the root, one sees its past is boundless; observing the end, one sees its future is endless. Only by dissolving all words can one align with the myriad things and unify their principle—hence it is said that words are insubstantial, sharing the same principle as things.

"Contingent causation" and "non-action" are but verbal expedients for things, their beginning and end. The Dao cannot be affirmed as existent, nor can it be denied as nonexistent. The term "Dao" is but a provisional name for its operation. Both theories, in their partiality, remain mired in things, seeing only their beginning and end. If one clings to things, how can one speak of the Dao as existent? Thus, the Dao cannot be said to exist. Yet if it exists, how can it be said to be nonexistent? Existence cannot be negated—hence it is said that existence cannot be denied. Viewed in truth, the word "Dao" is but a provisional name for its operation in the world.

Both theories are entangled with things, confined to a single corner—how can they be called the Great Dao? A corner is but a fragment; the Great Dao is all-encompassing. Having concluded the above, the text shifts to another subtle point:

If words suffice, then speaking all day long exhausts the Dao; if words do not suffice, then speaking all day long exhausts only things. The ultimate of the Dao and things cannot be conveyed by speech or silence alone—neither words nor silence can fully express it. This aligns with the previous statement.

Yet if I truly perceive, then even speech can exhaust the Dao—speaking all day does no harm. Thus, it is said: "If words suffice, then speaking all day long exhausts the Dao." If I perceive nothing, then words cannot exhaust the Dao—no matter how much one speaks, it remains mere semblance. Thus, it is said: "If words do not suffice, then speaking all day long exhausts only things." The Dao is subtle; things are coarse. Seeking their extremes, neither words nor silence suffice to contain them—hence it is said they are "not in this." Between words and silence lies the ultimate discourse.

The Buddhist analogy of pressing a finger to reveal the ocean’s reflection or a lamp’s light—where your mind stirs and dust arises—expresses this same idea. The Buddha also said, "I am the Dharma King, autonomous in the Dharma." This means that one who embodies the Dao is free, while one who has not yet embodied it remains bound. How does this differ from the Inner Chapters?

**Miscellaneous Chapters: External Things (Chapter 26)**

External things cannot be relied upon. Thus, Longfeng was executed, Bigan was killed, Jizi feigned madness, and E Lai died—Jie and Zhou perished. No ruler fails to desire loyal ministers, yet loyalty does not guarantee trust. Thus, Wu Yun was exiled to the Yangtze, and Chang Hong died in Shu, his blood stored for three years before transforming into jade. No parent fails to desire filial children, yet filial piety does not guarantee love. Thus, Xiaoji grieved, and Zeng Shen mourned.

External things are matters beyond oneself, not sought within. In the time of Jie and Zhou, both worthy and unworthy suffered the same calamities—this cannot be relied upon. The examples here pertain to Zhou, but Jie is included by analogy.

Chang Hong was exiled and returned to Shu, where he disemboweled himself and died. The people of Shu placed his blood in a casket, and after three years, it turned into jade. This account differs slightly from the *Zuozhuan*, which seems fantastical. During the Jin Emperor Yuan’s reign, when grain transports failed to arrive, he executed his minister, and the blood spurted upward against a pillar. The Qi killed Hulü Guang with the sword *Mingyue*, and his blood soaked the ground, refusing to fade—such things occur in the world.

Xiaoji was the son of King Gaozong of Yin, exiled by his stepmother. Zengzi’s sorrow is said to stem from his father wielding a large staff, prompting him to flee. Readers of this text should grasp its intent rather than cling to specifics. Loyalty and filial piety are esteemed, yet they may harm one’s person—such are external things, which cannot be relied upon.

When wood rubs against wood, it ignites; when metal and fire stay together, the metal melts. When yin and yang clash in their movements, heaven and earth are thrown into great turmoil—thus arise thunder and lightning. Fire appears in water, burning great locust trees. When wood rubs against wood, fire emerges of itself—today’s boatmen use elm and willow in the same way. Fire and metal kept together cause smelting. Wood, though inherently without fire, generates it through friction; metal, though supremely hard, flows when exposed to fire—this too expresses the idea that things cannot be taken for granted. Great turmoil brings great anomalies. During violent thunderstorms, trees may be set ablaze, hence the saying, “fire appears in water, burning the great locust.” It does not speak of other trees but specifically of the locust because the locust can generate fire; thus, the locust is mentioned. The *Huainanzi* states, “Old locust trees produce fire,” as seen in the *Fan Lun* chapter—this does not refer solely to the burning of great locust trees. All these are instances of yin and yang clashing in their movements, resulting in calamities that are rarely seen—again illustrating that things cannot be taken for granted.

There is profound sorrow when one is trapped in a double peril with no escape, restless and unsettled, unable to find peace of mind. The heart hangs suspended between heaven and earth, stifled and mired in distress. As advantages and harms clash, they generate abundant fire, and the multitude burns away harmony. The moon, by nature, cannot withstand fire—thus, one becomes utterly undone, and the Way is exhausted.

Profound sorrow is extreme sorrow. The double peril refers either to the afflictions of human society or to the calamities of yin and yang. The *Human World* chapter of the *Zhuangzi* speaks of these two perils—this is the same idea. Restlessness and unease describe the state of alarm and insecurity. “Unable to find peace” means that profound sorrow, with no escape, disrupts one’s emotional equilibrium. “The heart hangs suspended between heaven and earth” describes a heart bound and tormented by its own suffering. Stifled and mired refer to oppression and entanglement in danger. As advantages and harms wage war within the breast, the inner self is scorched—more intensely than by searing fire, hence “generating abundant fire.” These are all common people, those who do not understand the Way. Unaware that external things cannot be taken for granted, they overtax their minds and thus reach this state, burning away the harmonious qi within their breasts. Hence, “the multitude burns away harmony.” The moon’s nature refers to the innate harmony people receive from heaven, which is complete and resembles the moon. Yet when obscured by worldly desires, its brilliance is eclipsed by the flames of craving, and what should be the moon cannot withstand them, leading to the burning of harmony. As the poet of the mountains and valleys said, “The original mind is like the sun and moon; desires eclipse it”—this is the same idea. Utterly undone describes a state of collapse and abandonment. “The Way is exhausted” means that heavenly principle is extinguished. This refers to the multitude, who, drowned in desire, remain deluded their entire lives, only ceasing when heavenly principle is utterly destroyed.

Zhuangzi was poor, so he went to borrow grain from the Marquis of the River. The marquis said, “Very well. When I receive the tax revenue from my fief, I will lend you three hundred pieces of gold—will that do?” Zhuang Zhou flushed with anger and said, “On my way here yesterday, I heard someone calling from the middle of the road. I looked and saw a minnow in the rut of a cart wheel. I asked it, ‘Minnow, what are you doing here?’ It replied, ‘I am a wave-official from the Eastern Sea. Do you have a pint or a quart of water to keep me alive?’ I said, ‘Very well. I am about to travel south to persuade the kings of Wu and Yue to channel the waters of the Western River to welcome you—will that do?’ The minnow flushed with anger and said, ‘I have lost my usual element and have nowhere to stay. I could be kept alive with a pint or a quart of water, but you say such things—you might as well go look for me in a dried-fish shop!’”

The Marquis of the River may refer to Marquis Wen of Wei, though this is not certain. Alternatively, it may be an official overseeing the river, addressed as “marquis.” If not, then “marquis” may be his surname. “Tax revenue” refers to the tribute from his fief. “Wave-official” is akin to saying “water official.” This passage must have been a jest circulating at the time, hence its inclusion here—it conveys the modern saying, “distant water cannot quench a nearby fire.” The “dried-fish shop” implies that by the time the water arrives, the minnow will already have become dried fish. “Usual element” refers to what one is accustomed to.

Master Ren made a great hook with a massive black rope and used fifty oxen as bait. Crouching on Mount Kuaiji, he cast his line into the Eastern Sea, fishing day after day for a year without catching anything. Then a great fish took the bait, dragging the massive hook down into the depths. It surged and thrashed, its fins erect, white waves rising like mountains, the sea churning with a sound like thunder, striking terror for a thousand miles. Master Ren caught the fish, sliced it, and dried it. From the Zhi River eastward to north of Cangwu, there was no one who did not eat their fill of it. Later, those of mediocre talent and pedantic scholars all marveled and spread the tale.

To raise a pole and chase after minnows in ditches, guarding them—how difficult it is to catch a great fish! To adorn petty words to seek high office—how far this is from great understanding! Thus, those who have never heard of Master Ren’s customs are far from being able to navigate the world. The massive black rope refers to a thick, dark cord. The character for “ox” is pronounced *jie*.

The term *fang* is synonymous with *xian*, meaning "to sink." The sea water churned violently, its sound akin to thunder—this describes how the fish’s thrashing stirred the sea, its roar striking terror. *Dan he* means "fear and dread," for people a thousand *li* away heard its sound and trembled. *Yan yan* means "to eat one’s fill." *Quan cai* refers to those of shallow judgment and limited vision. *Feng yu* describes those who parrot hearsay, knowing only the commonplace and not the extraordinary, seeing only the small and not the great—hence their astonishment and mutual warnings. *Lei* means "to coil," and *guan* means "to pour." *Guan du* refers to small streams, while *ni fu* are tiny fish. *Xian ling* is akin to modern proclamations. *Xian* is synonymous with *xuan* ("to hang"), and *xian jie* denotes official decrees, much like today’s reward notices. This speaks of petty men who adorn their words to curry favor with superiors, seeking to align with the decrees they display. Even if they succeed, how much can they truly gain? Thus it is said: "How far they are from great understanding!"

*Su* refers to worldly scholars. Such scholars cannot be spoken to about the Dao of governing the world, hence it is said: "Those who cling to worldly ways are far indeed from being able to navigate the world." *Yuan yi* means "exceedingly so."

The Confucians who rob graves with *Odes* and *Rites*:
A great Confucian announced: "The east is stirring—what is to be done?"
A lesser Confucian replied: "He has not yet removed his undergarments, but there is a pearl in his mouth."
The *Odes* indeed say:
*"The green, green wheat grows on the hillside mound.
If one does not give in life, why hold a pearl in death?"*
The great Confucian then seized the corpse’s hair, pressed down its chin, and with a metal mallet pried open its jaw. Carefully parting its cheeks, he ensured the pearl in its mouth remained unharmed.

This passage likely satirizes scholars who misuse the words of the sages and worthies in the *Odes* and *Books* to cloak their villainy. *Lu* means "to announce from above to below," while *ju* means "to report from below to above." *Lu chuan* refers to a great Confucian leading and instructing his disciples. *"The green, green wheat grows on the hillside mound"* is a verse about grave fields. *"If one does not give in life, why hold a pearl in death?"* mocks the miserly rich. This poem consists of only four lines—whether it is an ancient verse or composed by Zhuangzi himself is uncertain. The lines from *"seizing its hair"* onward are the great Confucian’s instructions to the lesser one: *jie* means "to grasp," *ye* means "to press with the hand," and *hui* refers to the chin. *Kong qi hui* means "to force open the jaw." *Bie* also means "to open," implying that by reciting this poem, he teaches his disciple to carefully extract the pearl without damage. The *Odes* say: *"Why hold a pearl in death?"*—thus, taking it now aligns with the poem’s intent.

When Lao Lai’s disciple went out to gather firewood and encountered Confucius, he returned and reported: "There is someone over there—tall above, stooped below, his back hunched, his ears turned as if surveying the four seas. I do not know whose disciple he is."
Lao Lai said: "That is Qiu. Summon him here."
When Confucius arrived, Lao Lai said: "Qiu, shed your bodily pride and your cultivated demeanor—then you may be called a gentleman."
Confucius bowed and withdrew, his expression altered. He asked: "May I advance in my studies?"
Lao Lai replied: "One who cannot bear the harm of a single generation yet hastens to inflict suffering for ten thousand generations—is this not obstinate and narrow-minded? Or does he simply lack the capacity? To take joy in kindness as if it were arrogance is a lifelong disgrace. The conduct of the common people advances thus: they draw one another by reputation, bind themselves with profit, and in praising Yao while condemning Jie, they would do better to forget both and close their mouths to praise. For all their actions are crooked, and nothing they do is free from error. The sage hesitates to initiate affairs, yet often succeeds—how is this so? His bearing remains ever modest. Your carriage is forever laden with self-importance."

*Chu xin* means "to go out and gather firewood." *Xiu shang* means "tall above."

Swift in lowering his steps, his gait rings with urgency—this describes the slight hunch of his back, a subtle curvature seen only from behind. When viewed face-on, his ears are not visible. His gaze seems to survey the four seas, his eyes brimming with the sorrow of one who gazes upon the world’s woes with deep concern.

*Gong jin* refers to the bearing of self-importance in your person. *Rong zhi*: *rong* means outward adornment; *zhi*, contemplation. "Can the *Dao*-practice be advanced?" asks whether the study of the *Dao* and its cultivation may be pursued.

"A single generation’s harm" speaks of the suffering of people in one’s own time, a pitiable affliction. *Ao* conveys arrogance and heedlessness: you fret over the present, exhausting your mind, yet leave calamity for future generations—all while remaining haughtily indifferent. If this is so, your *Dao* is rightfully exhausted. *Ju* means "exhausted"; *gu*, "fitting." Your *Dao* is so impoverished because you fail to grasp that worldly affairs lie beyond the reach of mere cunning—hence, "does he simply lack the capacity?" *Wang* here means "to forget."

*Hui* is to bestow kindness upon others; *huan*, to seek their favor. To take pride in winning others’ approval through such acts is arrogance, and to parade this before the world is a lifelong disgrace. The conduct of the common people advances thus, ever mired in such pursuits—hence, "the conduct of the common people advances thus." *Er* is a particle; *zhong min* refers to the mediocre masses.

They draw one another by reputation and bind themselves with schemes of profit—this depicts the ways of the common people. To forget both Yao and Jie is to be free not only of blame but also of praise—hence, "close their mouths to praise." To act contrary to nature is to invite harm to the *Dao*; to favor restlessness over stillness is to stray into crookedness.

The sage is not thus: *chou chu* conveys hesitation, the reluctance to proceed. He initiates affairs only when unavoidable, responding as necessity demands. Precisely because he acts without self-interest, he often succeeds. *Zai* means "to bear"; here, it signifies self-importance. How, then, can you remain forever laden with such conceit? Hence, "how is this so?" "His bearing remains ever modest"—this closing phrase is striking in its placement.

The Lord of Song dreamed in the dead of night of a man with disheveled hair peering through the side gate, who said: "I come from Zailu Deep. As an envoy of the Clear River, I was caught by the River Lord’s fisherman, Yu Qie. I am about to be taken." The Lord awoke and had the dream interpreted, and was told: "This is a divine turtle."

The Lord asked: "Is there a fisherman named Yu Qie?"
His attendants replied: "There is."
The Lord said: "Summon Yu Qie to court tomorrow."

The next day, Yu Qie appeared before the Lord.
The Lord asked: "What did you catch in your fishing?"
Yu Qie replied: "I cast my net and caught a white turtle, five feet in circumference."
The Lord said: "Present this turtle to me."

When the turtle arrived, the Lord wavered—first wanting to kill it, then to spare it. His mind unsettled, he divined with it, saying: "Killing the turtle for divination will bring good fortune." So he carved the turtle, drilling seventy-two holes without a single miscalculation.

Confucius remarked: "The divine turtle could appear in a dream to the Lord of Song yet could not escape Yu Qie’s net. It could foresee seventy-two divinations without error yet could not avoid the disaster of having its entrails carved out. Thus, knowledge may be constrained, and even the divine may have its limits. Though one may possess supreme wisdom and a thousand advisors, fish do not fear nets but fear pelicans. Discard petty knowledge, and great wisdom will become clear; abandon contrived goodness, and true goodness will arise of itself.

An infant, born without a teacher of stone, learns to speak by being among those who can speak. The crooked staff is straight in its own way."

The Gate of Crooked Alignments is the gate of winding paths; Zailu Yuan is a renowned abyss. The spirit of the Qing River sent me as an emissary to the River Lord, who wavered between killing and sparing me, hesitating repeatedly without resolve. Divination deemed killing auspicious, so he slew me, drilling seventy-two holes—meaning the turtle was used for seventy-two divinations.

Though the turtle’s spirit surpasses man’s, it could not save itself. Thus it is said: knowledge may be constrained, and even the divine may have its limits. This implies that when knowledge is named as such, there comes a time when it is exhausted. The following lines broadly illustrate worldly affairs to substantiate this:

Though one may possess supreme wisdom, how can a single person prevail against the schemes of thousands? The pelican drains the water to consume all the fish—this is a deliberate act of harm, unlike the net. The above speaks of others harboring intent to harm my singular wisdom, which I cannot resist. This in turn means that if I act with intent, others will respond in kind. Thus the analogy: only by discarding petty knowledge and entrusting oneself to the natural can great wisdom become clear.

Abandon the notion of contrived goodness and the name it carries, and true goodness will arise of itself. *Shi* (stone) is interchangeable with *shuo* (great); a "stone teacher" is a great teacher who instructs others. An infant learns to speak not by seeking a teacher but by being among those who can speak. Great wisdom and inherent goodness are principles of nature, just as the uninstructed ability to speak is a natural analogy.

Hui Shi said to Zhuangzi, "Your words are useless."
Zhuangzi replied, "Only when one understands the useless can one begin to speak of the useful. The earth is neither narrow nor small, yet what man uses of it is but the space to stand. If one were to dig away all the earth beyond where the feet rest until reaching the Yellow Springs, would man still have use for it?"
Hui Shi said, "It would be useless."
Zhuangzi said, "Then the usefulness of the useless is thus made clear."
*(Digging away is called "dian." Beyond the space for the feet lies the abyss, where one cannot tread. This is the meaning of "the use of the useless" from the "Xu Wu Gui" chapter.)*

Zhuangzi said, "Is there a man who can wander yet does not wander? Is there a man who cannot wander yet does wander? Those with the will to flee and the resolve to sever ties—alas, are they not far from the burden of supreme wisdom and profound virtue? They fall and do not return, rush like fire and do not look back. Though they may for a time be lord and subject, when their lives end, what difference remains between noble and base? Thus it is said: the perfected person does not linger in their steps. Those who exalt the past and belittle the present are the way of scholars. Yet if one views the present age through the lens of the times of the Shiwei clan, who could avoid being swept away? Only the perfected person can wander through the world without bias, follow others without losing themselves. Those who can wander, wander; those who cannot, remain unable. This speaks of those in the world who are enlightened and those who are not. *You* means to delight in oneself. *Liudun* is to chase things and forget to return. *Juejue* is to stand apart from the world, utterly different. *Ren* means to act. Those of supreme wisdom and profound virtue, who follow nature, do not err in fleeing or severing ties. *Fuzhui* means to sink into worldly entanglements. *Huochi* means to be driven by the world like fire. These are all those burdened by the vulgar who cannot turn back to reflect on themselves—thus they do not return, do not look back, meaning they cannot reverse the light to illuminate their own nature. Though for a time there are distinctions of noble and base, called lord and subject, after death, what remains of noble or base? Kings and lords perish like ants, leaving only mounds of earth. Only the perfected person’s actions leave no lingering attachment to the world—thus it is said: the perfected person does not linger in their steps. The passions of people in past and present are largely the same; where is the difference between simplicity and decadence? Scholars exalt the past and belittle the present because they do not understand the changes of the world. The Shiwei clan lived before the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors. If one views the present through the beginning of heaven and earth or the age of high antiquity, all are those who have been swept away and lost their nature. Thus it is said: who could avoid being swept away? Scholars take the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors as the beginning of past and present—this is to mock and disparage the ancient emperors and kings. *Pian* means bias. To wander through the world without leaning toward any bias, not taking past or present as right or wrong, though one may merge with the dust and shine with the same light, not clashing with the world, what one preserves remains intact—thus it is said: to follow others without losing oneself. What they teach, they take as right; I do not study it, yet I comply with their intent without distinction between self and other—this is the meaning of *equalizing things* and *following what is so*. Thus it is said: to comply with their intent without opposing them.

The eye that is *che* is clear; the ear that is *che* is keen; the nose that is *che* is sharp; the mouth that is *che* is sweet; the mind that is *che* is wise; wisdom that is *che* is virtue. Wherever the Dao is, obstruction is undesirable. Obstruction leads to choking; choking without cessation leads to trampling. Where trampling occurs, myriad harms arise. Those with knowledge rely on their breath, yet if it is not abundant, is this heaven’s fault? Heaven bores through the apertures day and night without ceasing. It is man who, looking back, blocks his own holes. *Che* means to penetrate. Grasping the principle of nature and achieving great penetration, the ear and eye perceive true keenness and clarity; the nose and mouth discern true sharpness and sweetness; what the mind knows is true wisdom; virtue is the highest virtue. *Yong* means blockage and obstruction. *Geng* means choking and not flowing. *Tian* refers to the traces of footsteps. If my understanding of the Dao is blocked and choked, unable to awaken, then I am burdened by form and traces. Not ceasing means delusion without knowing to stop. Burdened by form and traces, myriad harms arise. *Xi* means life. That which is called life is nature. All people possess it. Only after having this nature of receiving life does one have knowledge and awareness. What is called knowledge and awareness relies on this breath. No one lacks it, yet some act contrary to principle—is this because heaven begrudges them its abundance? The principle in the human mind is revealed day and night through its apertures—when has it ever ceased? Thus it is said: heaven bores through them day and night without ceasing. *Che* means the apertures of the mind. *Wu jiang* means without cessation. *Dou* also means the apertures of the mind. Man, deluded by material desires, obscures himself—this is to block his own apertures. *Gu* means "then."

The womb has layered membranes, the heart roams freely in heaven. If the chamber is not empty, mother and daughter-in-law quarrel; if the heart does not wander in heaven, the six apertures contend. The great forests and mountains are good for people—yet the spirit is overcome, virtue overflows into fame, fame overflows into violence. Schemes are delayed by subtlety, knowledge arises from contention, firewood is born from guarding office, and affairs are settled by the crowd.

In the timely rains of spring, plants and trees flourish. Hoes and plows begin to be used. Yet more than half of the planted grasses and trees perish, and none know why.

*Bao* refers to the membranes. Within the human body’s flesh lies a layered membrane enveloping the self. *Chong lang* means spaciousness. Within the body, such vastness exists, yet if the heart, as sovereign, delights in heavenly principle, this is called "roaming in heaven." *Bo xi* means strife. In a cramped dwelling, mother and daughter-in-law constantly bicker. The six apertures—the six roots: eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind—if the chamber is not empty, then superiors and inferiors clash; if the heart is not empty, the six apertures seize one another. If the heart could be empty, how could external things disturb it?

Goodness is love. When the heart is not empty, the six dusts disturb it. Thus, those who love mountains and forests do so because the spirit cannot endure the toil of ceaseless labor. When they suddenly behold a vast, open landscape, the heart must rejoice—yet this joy is followed by sorrow.

The great transformation subtly shifts, and one is merely turned by things. Stillness can mend illness, rest can rejuvenate age, and tranquility can halt haste. Yet these are the tasks of the toiling, not the idle who have never inquired.

*Jing ran* means serenity. To mend illness is to discard the old and return to the new, abandoning the branches to return to the root. If this heart can be serene, then past losses can be repaired and preserved. *Zi* (眦) is pronounced *jian*; *mie* () is pronounced *mie*. *Zi mie* means to cast aside material desires and preserve heavenly principle, allowing one to wander freely into old age. *Ju* means urgency. To calm the heart is to halt haste.

What startles the world is what the sage employs; the divine person has never inquired. What startles the age is what the worthy employs; the sage has never inquired. What startles the state is what the noble person employs; the worthy has never inquired. What aligns with the times is what the petty person employs; the noble person has never inquired.

In Yanmen, there was one whose parent died, and for his exemplary mourning, he was enfeoffed as an official. Among his peers, some mourned to death. *Xia* is synonymous with *hai* (startle). The sage governs the world with benevolence and righteousness—this startles it. The divine person has no such concerns. The worthy astonishes the age with abundant virtue; the sage has no such concerns. The noble person startles the state with reputation; the worthy has no such concerns. The petty person busies himself to conform to the times; the noble person has no such concerns.

Yanmen is a place name. *Shan hui* means filial mourning. For his filiality, he gained rank and became an official. His peers, admiring him, even mourned to death—this speaks of the burden of fame. *Guan shi* is akin to what is now called an official.

Yao offered the world to Xu You, who fled from it. Tang offered it to Wu Guang, who grew angry. When Ji Tuo heard of this, he led his disciples to crouch by the Kuang River. The feudal lords mourned him for three years. Then Shentu Di, admiring their reclusion, threw himself into the river. *Cun* is synonymous with *dun* (crouching), implying disdain. Ji Tuo’s intent was for the feudal lords to yield their states to him, yet they merely pitied his suffering—how laughable! After three years, Shentu Di, admiring the fame of reclusion, drowned himself in the river. This illustrates the extreme burden of fame.

The fish trap exists for the fish; once the fish is caught, the trap is forgotten. The rabbit snare exists for the rabbit; once the rabbit is caught, the snare is forgotten. Words exist for meaning; once the meaning is grasped, the words are forgotten. Where can I find a person who has forgotten words, that I might speak with them?

The above has thoroughly expounded the matter, concluding with the analogy of the trap and snare—echoing the earlier passage’s structure: "Words suffice, yet words are insufficient; embodiment suffices." The fish trap and rabbit snare are tools for catching fish and rabbits. Once obtained, they are useless. Words convey meaning; once the meaning is grasped, words are forgotten. Those who cannot forget words become mired and lose the meaning. Only one who has forgotten words can truly converse.

This passage’s subtlety lies in the intent: the rabbit’s aim is to catch the rabbit.

From the *Imperially Commissioned Siku Quanshu*: *Zhuangzi Kouyi*, Volume Nine
By Lin Xiang of the Song Dynasty
Miscellaneous Chapters: "Yu Yan" (Chapter Twenty-Seven)

This chapter begins with Zhuangzi’s own explanation of the three types of discourse in his book:

**Yu yan** (parables) are one’s own words spoken through the names of others—nineteen out of ten instances in this text are of this kind, meaning parables dominate. Examples include the dialogues of Nie Que, Wang Ni, and Gengsang Chu.

**Chong yan** (weighty words) borrow the names of ancient sages to lend authority, such as the Yellow Emperor, Shen Nong, and Confucius—seventeen out of ten instances in this text are of this kind.

**Zhi yan** (goblet words) are like a goblet: anyone may drink from it, and the more one drinks, the more flavor it yields. "Issuing forth daily" means every matter contains such words. *He* (harmony) is the act of blending; *tian ni* (the Heavenly Equilibrium) is the principle of Heaven.

In parables, even a father would not act as his own son’s matchmaker—no father’s praise carries the weight of an outsider’s. If it is not my fault, it is the fault of others. When something aligns with oneself, one responds; when it does not, one resists. What aligns with oneself is deemed right; what differs from oneself is deemed wrong.

To harmonize the hearts of all people with the Heavenly Principle is to borrow—borrowing means not issuing from oneself but from others, hence called "borrowing from without." For instance, if a father praises his own son to seek a marriage alliance, others will not believe him; he must borrow another’s praise. This is the nature of parable.

This fault does not lie with me but with others’ lack of trust, hence the use of parables. If one assumes it issues from oneself, others will inevitably divide into agreement and disagreement, responding to what aligns with them as right and what differs as wrong. This is the self-serving view of others.

"Seventeen out of ten" in *zhong yan* (weighty words) refers to one’s own speech being affirmed as that of elders—those whose years precede but who lack the warp and woof of beginning and end, merely reaching the age of *qiyi* (a hundred years). Such elders, though senior in years, have no precedence in learning; their age alone does not make them exemplary. A person who cannot surpass others fails to fulfill the Way of humanity—this is what is called a "worn-out person." A "worn-out person" is one who lingers in the world, long-used and of no value.

The purpose here is to halt—one’s own words can end disputes. By borrowing the weight of elders, listeners dare not deem it wrong, thus silencing their objections. The ancient sage-kings and worthies were all elders, possessing the warp and woof of constancy and change, beginning and end. *Qiyi* refers to the age of a hundred. Though one’s years may precede, if one’s learning offers no insight, merely being called an elder by virtue of age is insufficient to claim precedence. A person who cannot surpass others cannot fully realize the human Dao—this is merely a "worn-out person."

The *zhi yan* (goblet words) issue forth daily, harmonizing with the Heavenly Equilibrium, endlessly unfolding to exhaust the years. Without speech, all is equal; with speech, equality is lost. Speech that aligns with equality does not align; equality that aligns with speech does not align. Thus, "without speech" means speech without intent; "speaking all one’s life" means never truly speaking. "Never speaking all one’s life" means never not speaking, for even in silence, principle may be grasped.

There is always an origin—what people deem right or wrong, so or not so, all have their sources. Each affirms what it affirms; how can I alone determine what is right? I can only follow what is deemed right and affirm it, follow what is deemed wrong and negate it. Things inherently have their "so-ness"; things inherently have their "admissible-ness." Thus, no thing is not so, no thing is inadmissible.

This is discussed in detail in the "Equalizing Things" chapter. The phrase *"zhi yan* issue forth daily, harmonizing with the Heavenly Equilibrium—who attains its enduringness?" means I do not use natural speech to harmonize all mouths. If I were to align with their judgments of right and wrong, how could I claim lasting validity? For the natural principle is unassailable across all ages.

All things share a common origin from the Creator, yet their forms differ and succeed one another between Heaven and Earth. People see grass as grass, trees as trees, birds as birds, beasts as beasts—only their forms differ, unaware that all emerge from the primordial *qi* and share the same origin. All things in Heaven and Earth cycle through beginning and end like a ring, their profound order beyond human comprehension. This is called the Heavenly Equality—equality in the Heavenly Principle.

Zhuangzi said to Huizi: "Confucius lived sixty years, and at sixty, his views transformed. What he once affirmed, he later negated. Who knows if what he now calls right is not what he deemed wrong at fifty-nine?" Huizi replied: "Confucius diligently applied his will and served his knowledge." Zhuangzi said: "Confucius has renounced that. He never spoke of it. Confucius said: 'One receives talent from the great root and revives the spirit to live. To cry in accord with the pitch, to speak in accord with the law, to present profit and righteousness before others—this merely pleases their mouths. It makes people submit in word but not dare to oppose, thus establishing the world’s standards. Alas! How can I compare to him?'

*Fu zhi* means to serve; *zhi* means knowledge."

To diligently apply the mind in pursuit of knowledge and perception is called "extensive learning." *Xie* means to relinquish. This is to say, Confucius had already relinquished the pursuit of extensive learning and advanced toward the Dao, though he never spoke of it to others. When Zhuangzi cited Confucius, he was quoting Confucius’ own words.

"Receiving talent from the great root" means receiving one’s nature from the Great Origin. The "great root" is the Creator. *Ling* is the nature of awareness. *Fu* means to return—to revert to the original nature of awareness, for only then can one fully realize the Way of human life. Thus, it is said, "revives the spirit to live." *Ming* also means "to speak." *Lü* is the law. *Dang* means that all accords with principle.

To present profit and righteousness before others and thereby establish likes and dislikes, right and wrong, is merely to please their mouths. It makes people submit in word but not in heart. One must relinquish profit and righteousness and forget likes and dislikes, right and wrong, before others can submit in heart without daring to oppose. Only then can the world’s settled principles be established. *Wu* is pronounced *wu*; it means opposition, defiance. *Wu li* means to stand face-to-face, where I am compliant and the other defiant. The *Rites of Zhou* says, "to receive the opposition of the feudal lords," meaning those who come toward me are defiant.

After quoting the Master’s words, Zhuangzi sighed to Huizi: "Alas! Alas! How can I compare to Confucius?" From this alone, it is clear that Zhuangzi was not one who failed to revere our Sage.

Zengzi took office twice, and his heart transformed twice. He said: "When I served my parents, three measures of grain brought joy to my heart. Later, when I served with a salary of three thousand *zhong*, it did not reach my heart with sorrow." A disciple asked Confucius: "Can Zeng Shen be said to be free from entanglement in fault?" Confucius replied: "He is already entangled. How could one free from entanglement feel sorrow? To him, three measures or three thousand *zhong* were like watching sparrows or mosquitoes pass before him." *Bu ji* means not reaching one’s parents. "Free from entanglement in fault" means being without the fetters of attachment. The question was whether Zengzi’s words revealed such fetters, for his heart had changed twice—now sorrowful, now joyful. "He is already entangled" means that even this sorrow and joy are fetters. If one were truly free from entanglement, the weight of external things passing before one would be like birds or insects—how could one feel sorrow or joy? To feel sorrow or joy is to have a heart.

Yan Cheng Ziyou said to Dongguo Ziqí: "Since I heard your words, in the first year I became rustic; in the second, compliant; in the third, penetrating; in the fourth, like a thing; in the fifth, things came to me; in the sixth, the spirit entered; in the seventh, I became one with Heaven; in the eighth, I knew neither death nor life; in the ninth, I attained the great mystery."

In the first year, he became rustic—returning to simplicity. In the second, compliant—without opposition to right or wrong, like or dislike. In the third, penetrating—thoroughly enlightened. In the fourth, like a thing—like withered wood or dead ashes. In the fifth, things came to him—within stillness, there was that which was not still, what Chan calls "the great death and yet alive." *Jue ru* means to take the transformations of creation into one’s breast. "One with Heaven" means unity with Heaven. "Knowing neither death nor life" means being at ease in all circumstances. "The great mystery" means the utmost profundity. From the first to the ninth year, these are stages, but such matters cannot be measured by years.

"Life is as death. I urge you to embrace death—yet life has its source. Yang arises, but from what? Is it truly so? Where does it go? Where does it not go? Heaven has its celestial reckoning; Earth has its human records. Where should I seek it? I know not its end. How can it be said to be without fate? I know not its beginning. How can it be said to have fate? There is that which responds—how can it be without spirit? There is that which does not respond—how can it be with spirit?"

These lines speak of the principle of neither life nor death. "Life is as death" means to take life as real—if there is life, there is death. To hold such a view is self-serving. If one urges another with the utmost impartiality, one would have them know that among the works of creation, nothing is immortal. Thus, it is said, "I urge you to embrace death." Yet to call it death is to imply it has a source. If death has a source, then life, at its first stirring, has no source. If its beginning is without life, how can there be death? This is the beginning of Yang’s movement. Speaking of life and death in this way, how can one know if it is truly so or not? Where it goes is so; where it does not go is not so. Yet when one observes it in its entirety, where is it so? Where is it not so? To call it being is wrong; to call it non-being is also wrong. Thus, it is said, "Is it truly so? Where does it go? Where does it not go?"

"Heavenly reckoning" refers to the movements of stars, sun, and moon as recorded in almanacs. "Human records" refer to the traces of human activity as documented in maps and records. If one seeks the principles of Heaven and Earth through celestial reckoning and human records, can they truly be exhausted? Thus, it is said, "Where should I seek it?" Between Heaven and Earth, days pass and months depart—who knows their end? Their movement must have a Creator. How can it be said to be without fate? Yet in the vastness of the beginning, originally there was nothing—how can it be said to have fate? The seasons arrive, and qi responds without the slightest deviation. How can it be said to be without spirit? Yet the humble are not always blessed, the benevolent not always long-lived. Between the seen and unseen, there is sometimes no correspondence. How can it be said to have spirit? These lines elucidate the unknowability of creation.

The Many *Wangliang* asked the Shadow: "A moment ago, you were bowing; now, you raise your head. A moment ago, your hair was tied; now, it is loose. A moment ago, you were sitting; now, you stand. A moment ago, you were walking; now, you stop. Why is this?" The Shadow replied: "Trivial! Why ask such trifles? I have it, yet I know not why. I am like the cicada’s shell, the snake’s slough—seemingly so, yet not so. In fire and sunlight, I gather; in darkness and night, I am replaced. Do I depend on something? How much more so for those who depend on things! When it comes, I come with it; when it goes, I go with it. When it is strong and bright, I am strong and bright with it. Why ask about strong brightness?"

"Trivial!"—this conveys the sense of fleeting visibility and manifestation. "Why ask such trifles?"—it is a casual, offhand remark, an expression of careless spontaneity, as if to say: *Why do you suddenly ask this?* What I possess, I do not myself know why it is so; hence, "I have it, yet I know not why." The cicada has transformed, yet its shell remains; the snake has transformed, yet its slough remains. This analogy compares the movement of form to the life of the cicada or snake, and the shadow to the shell or slough. "Seemingly so, yet not so"—this means that while the comparison is apt, it is not entirely accurate. Within sunlight and fire, this shadow exists; hence, "I gather" (gathering together). When darkness falls and no fire is lit, the shadow becomes invisible—this is "replaced." "That" refers to form; "I" refers to the shadow. It says: *Do I depend on that?* Hence, "Do I depend on something?" Yet the movement of form itself depends on something else; thus, "How much more so for those who depend on things!" "Strong brightness" refers to movement. Form moves by relying on the qi of strong brightness; the coming and going of form depend on strong brightness. Form moves because of strong brightness, and I follow it. But the nature of strong brightness is not something form itself knows—why then do you ask me?

This passage parallels *The Equality of Things*, though it adds the details of strong brightness, fire, and sunlight, playing with the brush as Chan Buddhists do in their repetitive gāthās.

When Yang Ziju journeyed south to Pei, and Lao Dan traveled west to Qin, they met at the outskirts of Liang. Midway, Laozi looked up to the sky and sighed, saying: "At first, I thought you could be taught, but now I see you cannot." Yang Ziju made no reply. Upon reaching their lodging, he washed his hands and face, combed his hair, removed his shoes, and, bowing deeply outside, approached and said: "Earlier, your disciple wished to ask you a question, but as you were walking without pause, I dared not speak. Now that you have paused, may I ask: What is my fault?" Laozi said: "Your haughty gaze, your overbearing demeanor—who would wish to dwell with you? The purest white seems sullied; the fullest virtue seems insufficient." Yang Ziju’s expression changed abruptly, and he said: "I humbly receive your instruction." When he had first arrived, the innkeeper had welcomed him, the master of the house had laid out his mat, his wife had offered the towel and comb, the guests had vacated their seats, and the cook had left the stove—all out of respect. But upon his return, the innkeeper and guests vied with him for a place to sit.

"What is my fault?"—this means: *You say I cannot be taught; where is my error?* "Haughty gaze, overbearing demeanor"—this describes a stiff, self-important bearing, as if one cannot relax in the company of others. "Who would wish to dwell with you?"—this means one has not forgotten the distinction between self and others, always acting as if in the presence of company. "The purest white seems sullied"—this conveys the idea of brilliance concealed. "The fullest virtue seems insufficient"—this means that though one possesses it, one does not flaunt it. "Welcomed him"—refers to seeing him off and receiving him. "Master of the house"—the host of the inn. "Laid out his mat, offered the towel and comb"—acts of deference. "The cook"—the one who tends the stove. "Vacated their seats, left the stove"—signs of respect. "Vied for a place to sit"—this means they no longer regarded him as someone to be revered. Before hearing Laozi’s words, he had carried himself with self-importance, so people treated him with respect. After his transformation, he concealed his brilliance, and people saw him as ordinary. The style of this passage is also refined.

**Chapter 28: Yielding the Throne** (from the *Miscellaneous Chapters*)

Yao offered the empire to Xu You, who refused it. He then offered it to Zizhou Zhipu, who said: "If you were to make me Son of Heaven, it would be acceptable. However, I happen to suffer from a hidden affliction and am presently treating it. I have no leisure to govern the empire. The empire is the heaviest of burdens, yet I would not let it harm my life—how much less would I let other things do so? Only one who does not treat the empire as a possession can be entrusted with it."

Shun offered the empire to Zizhou Zhibo, who said: "I happen to suffer from a hidden affliction and am presently treating it. I have no leisure to govern the empire." Thus, the empire is a great vessel, yet one would not exchange one’s life for it—this is what distinguishes those who follow the Way from the common crowd.

"A hidden affliction"—akin to what is now called a concealed illness. "One who does not treat the empire as a possession"—this means only one who does not desire to be Son of Heaven can be entrusted with the empire, for such a person holds the empire without clinging to it. "Distinguishes from the common crowd"—this means they differ from worldly people.

Shun offered the empire to Shan Juan, who said: "I stand in the midst of the cosmos. In winter, I wear furs; in summer, I wear coarse or fine linen. In spring, I plow and sow—my body is sufficient for labor. In autumn, I harvest and store—my person is sufficient for rest. I rise with the sun and rest with its setting. I roam freely between heaven and earth, and my heart is content. Why would I desire the empire? Alas, you do not understand me!" Thereupon, he refused it and departed, entering the deep mountains, where no one knew his whereabouts.

Shun offered the empire to his friend, the farmer of Shihu. The farmer of Shihu said: "How earnest and toilsome is the ruler’s labor!" He deemed Shun’s virtue insufficient and so, with his wife carrying their child on her head and he bearing their belongings on his back, they fled to the sea, never to return.

"Earnest and toilsome"—describes one who labors diligently. "Deemed Shun’s virtue insufficient"—this means it was not natural virtue. Both men fled, one with his wife carrying their child on her head, the other bearing their belongings on his back. These two passages lack concluding remarks, as their meaning is the same as the preceding.

King Tai of the Zhou dwelt in Bin. The Di people attacked, and though he offered them furs and silks, they refused; he offered them dogs and horses, they refused; he offered them pearls and jades, they refused. What the Di people sought was land. King Tai said: "To dwell with another’s elder brother and kill his younger brother, to dwell with another’s father and kill his son—I cannot bear it. All of you, do your best to remain here. Whether you serve as my subjects or as subjects of the Di, what difference is there? Moreover, I have heard that one should not harm what one nurtures with what is used for nurturing." Thereupon, he took up his staff and departed. The people followed in a continuous stream, and they established a state at the foot of Mount Qi. King Tai can indeed be called one who knew how to honor life. One who honors life, though rich and noble, does not let what sustains him harm his person; though poor and lowly, does not let profit burden his form. The people of today who hold high office and exalted rank all fear losing them, and in their pursuit of profit, they lightly risk their lives—are they not deluded?

"What is used for nurturing"—this refers to what one relies on for sustenance, namely, land. "What is nurtured"—the people. "Honor life"—this means valuing one’s person above external things. This passage criticizes those of the time who were obsessed with loss.

The people of Yue assassinated their ruler for three generations. Prince Sou, fearing this, fled to Danru. But Yue, left without a ruler, searched for Prince Sou and could not find him. They pursued him to Danru, but Prince Sou refused to emerge. The people of Yue fumigated him with mugwort and carried him out in a jade carriage. Prince Sou grasped the reins, mounted the carriage, looked up to the sky, and cried: "Rulership! Rulership! Could you not spare me?" Prince Sou did not hate being a ruler; he hated the calamities that come with rulership. One like Prince Sou can indeed be said not to have let the state harm his life. This was precisely what the people of Yue desired—to make him their ruler.

"Rulership! Rulership!"—these words mean: "Do you wish me to be the ruler of the state?" Only one who has no desire for rulership can truly be entrusted with the state. Thus it is said that the people of Yue desired to make him their ruler.

Han and Wei contended over disputed territory. Master Zihua visited Duke Zhaoxi, who wore a troubled expression. Master Zihua said: "Suppose now that the world inscribed a contract before you, its words stating: 'If you seize it with your left hand, your right hand will be severed; if you seize it with your right hand, your left hand will be severed. Yet whoever seizes it shall possess the world.' Would you seize it?" Duke Zhaoxi said: "I would not." Master Zihua said: "Excellent. From this perspective, both arms are weightier than the world, and the body is weightier still than both arms. How much lighter, then, is Han compared to the world! And what you now contend over is far lighter than Han. Yet you grieve, harming your life with sorrow and distress—this is truly misguided."

*攫 (jué) means to seize or grasp. 铭 (míng) is like a contract. 废 (fèi) means to sever and discard. To seize the contract is to gain the world, yet one who cherishes his body would not seize it—how much less, then, when comparing Han to the world, is it worth the loss! To grieve over not obtaining it, to the point of harming one’s life, is to bring about one’s own ruin—this is weightier even than losing an arm. Thus it is said: to know the weight of things. This analogy is of great benefit to the common world. This passage resembles an Inner Chapter.*

When the Lord of Lu heard that Yan He was a man who had attained the Dao, he sent an envoy bearing gifts ahead to him.

Yan He dwelt in a humble lane, clad in coarse cloth of hemp and ramie, tending cattle with his own hands. When the envoy of the Lord of Lu arrived, Yan He himself received him. The envoy asked, "Is this the home of Yan He?" Yan He replied, "This is my home." The envoy presented the gifts, but Yan He responded, "I fear the messenger may have misheard and bring blame upon you. It would be better to verify." The envoy returned and confirmed the matter, then came back to seek him—but Yan He could no longer be found. Thus one such as Yan He truly despised wealth and honor.

Therefore it is said: the true essence of the Dao is for cultivating the self; its remnants and surplus may be used to govern the state. The chaff and husks may be used to govern the world. From this perspective, the achievements of emperors and kings are but the leftover affairs of sages—never the means to perfect the body or nourish life.

Yet today, the gentlemen of the common world often endanger their bodies and abandon their lives in pursuit of external things—is this not lamentable? In all the actions of sages, they must examine their purpose and their means. Now, suppose there were a man here who used the pearl of the Marquis of Sui to shoot a sparrow a thousand *ren* high—the world would surely ridicule him. Why? Because what he employed was weighty, while what he sought was trivial. How much more so is life itself, which far surpasses even the pearl of the Marquis of Sui!

*Hempen cloth of coarse weave. "Mishearing" refers to a misunderstanding of words.*

The term *tu zha* (土苴): the first character is pronounced *che* (上音撦), the second *zhi ya* (下知雅反), meaning dregs or糟粕. This implies that the achievements of emperors and kings in governing the world and the state are, within the Dao of sages, merely leftover affairs. The body is the foundation of the world and the state; cultivating the self enables one to govern the world and the state—this is the discourse of sages and worthies.

Zhuangzi’s words make such distinctions, and people often assume he divides matters into refined and coarse, splitting them into two separate realms. Yet they fail to grasp his true intent: that one who understands the Dao is not burdened by external things in their fundamental mind. Thus, Yao’s rejection of the yellow imperial carriage, or Shun and Yu’s non-attachment to possessing the world—only thus can the governance of non-action be fully realized. However, his rhetoric may at times be overly emphatic.

The four characters *xu yu tu zha* (绪余土苴) arise from these leftover affairs, much like saying dust, filth, chaff, and husks can be molded into Yao and Shun. Where his phrasing exceeds propriety, it is of this kind. Wang Anshi’s scholarship truly takes this as a division into two realms, then seeks to apply it by frequently citing the terms *xu yu* and *tu zha*. This is why Zhu Xi deeply debated the matter.

Zhuangzi’s excessive rhetoric may mislead later generations and thus seems blameworthy, yet his true intention was not so. To endanger the body and abandon life in pursuit of external things is precisely to burden the mind with externals.

The phrase *suo yi zhi* (所以之) means "that toward which one proceeds."

The phrase *suo yi zhi suo yi wei* ("that toward which one proceeds, that by which one proceeds") expresses but a single idea. To shoot a sparrow with a pearl—no one would willingly do so. To burden the body with external things—yet people fail to recognize this. The analogy of the arm is most clear and apt.

This passage resembles those in the "Inner Chapters." In *Liezi*, when Qiong’s appearance showed the signs of hunger, a guest spoke of it to Ziyang, the ruler of Zheng: "Lie Yukou is a man of the Dao. Living in your state, he suffers privation—does this not suggest you do not esteem men of worth?" Ziyang immediately ordered an official to send him grain. Liezi bowed twice to the messenger and declined. When the messenger left, Liezi entered his home, where his wife, striking her breast, said: "I have heard that the wife and children of a man of the Dao all enjoy ease and happiness. Now you show the signs of hunger. The ruler, recognizing his error, sent you food, yet you refused it—is this not fate?" Liezi laughed and replied: "The ruler does not know me himself. He sent me grain only because of another’s words. When he punishes me in the future, it will likewise be on the basis of another’s words. This is why I did not accept it." In the end, the people indeed rose in rebellion and killed Ziyang.

The minister of Zheng said: "Ziyang was Liezi’s ruler. He sent grain on the basis of another’s words, showing he did not truly know him. If one is not truly known, then praise may be believed, but so too may slander." This reasoning is also most apt.

This passage is similar to one in *Liezi*. When King Zhao of Chu lost his state, a butcher who slaughtered sheep fled with him. When the king returned to his state and was about to reward those who had followed him, the butcher came forward and said: "When the great king lost his state, I lost my butcher’s stall. Now that the great king has returned, I too have regained my butcher’s stall. My rank and emolument have been restored—what reward is there to give?" The king said: "Insist that he accept." The butcher replied: "The great king lost his state not through any fault of mine, so I dared not submit to punishment. The great king’s return is not through any merit of mine, so I dared not claim reward." The king said: "Let me see him." The butcher said: "According to the laws of Chu, only those who have rendered great service may be granted an audience. My wisdom was insufficient to preserve the state, and my courage was insufficient to die defending it. When the Wu army entered Ying, I fled in fear of danger—not because I deliberately followed the great king. Now, if the great king wishes to set aside the law and break precedent to see me, this is not what I have heard is right under heaven." The king said to Sima Ziqi: "The butcher’s station is lowly, yet his exposition of principle is lofty. You must secure him for me with the rank of the Three Standards." The butcher said: "I know the rank of the Three Standards is nobler than my butcher’s stall, and the emolument of ten thousand bushels is richer than my butcher’s profit. Yet how could I greedily accept rank and emolument and thereby cause my lord to gain a reputation for reckless bestowal? I dare not accept. I wish only to return to my butcher’s stall." He thus declined the offer.

When the great king returned to his state, the butcher regained his stall—each returned to his proper place. The Three Standards refer to the Three Dukes. The carriages and robes of the Three Dukes each have their own distinguishing banners, hence the term "Three Standards." This passage is also excellent.

Yuan Xian lived in Lu in a walled hut with a circumference of one *du*. The roof was thatched with cogon grass, the door was incomplete, and the hinge was made of mulberry wood. A jar served as the window for two rooms. Coarse cloth stopped the gaps above, while below, dampness seeped through. Yet he sat upright and sang. Zigong arrived in a grand carriage, his inner robe dark blue and his outer robe white, the canopy too wide to pass through the alley. He went to see Yuan Xian. Yuan Xian, wearing a cap of rushes, shoes of hemp, and leaning on a staff of bramble, came to the gate. Zigong said: "Alas! Master, what ails you?" Yuan Xian replied: "I have heard that to lack wealth is called poverty, and to study yet be unable to practice is called affliction. Now, I am poor—not afflicted." Zigong stepped back, his face showing shame. Yuan Xian laughed and said: "To act in pursuit of worldly favor, to befriend for mutual advantage, to study for others, to teach for oneself, to use benevolence and righteousness as a pretext, and to adorn oneself with carriages and horses—these are things I cannot bear to do."

*Ci* means thatch; to cover a house with grass.

The two chambers of their dwelling both used jars as windows—hence "two chambers with jar-windows." Walls were hollowed out to admit light, called *you*; old clothes were used to seal these windows against wind and rain—hence "coarse cloth to block them." *Kuang* means to sit upright. *Gan* is a deep blue-red color. *Biao su* refers to wearing white as an outer robe. "The canopy too wide to pass through the alley" describes the narrowness of the lane compared to the carriage. *Hua guan* means a cap made of birch bark. *Xi lv* describes dragging one’s hemp shoes. "To act in pursuit of worldly favor" means conducting oneself to curry favor with the age. "To befriend for mutual advantage" means associating with unworthy people. "To study for others, to teach for oneself" means learning not for one’s own sake but for others, and teaching not for the Dao but for profit. To "use benevolence and righteousness as a pretext" is to employ them to gloss over wickedness—hence "the wickedness of benevolence and righteousness."

When Master Zeng resided in Wei, his quilted robe had no outer layer, his complexion was swollen, his hands and feet calloused. For three days he did not kindle a fire, and for ten years he did not make new clothes. When he straightened his cap, its strings snapped; when he grasped his lapel, his elbow showed; when he put on his shoes, the heels split. Yet as he dragged his hemp shoes, he sang the *Odes of Shang*, his voice filling heaven and earth as if issuing from metal or stone. The Son of Heaven could not make him a minister, nor could the feudal lords befriend him. Thus, those who cultivate the will forget the body; those who cultivate the body forget profit; those who attain the Dao forget the mind.

A *yun* robe is today’s padded garment. "No outer layer" means the outer fabric was worn through, exposing the padding. *Zhong kuai* describes a swollen, puffy appearance. "Straightening his cap, the strings snapped" means that as he adjusted his cap, its ties broke—the ties being what secure the cap. "Elbow showing" means the sleeves of his lapel were torn. "Heels split" means the backs of his shoes were broken. *Ye xi* means to drag oneself along. *Shang song* refers to the songs he sang. "As if issuing from metal or stone" describes the rhythmic quality. "Those who cultivate the will forget the body" means they do not burden their minds with nurturing the body. "Those who cultivate the body forget profit" means they do not exhaust themselves chasing external things. "Those who attain the Dao forget the mind" means that without a mind, one draws near the Dao.

Confucius said to Yan Hui, "Hui, your family is poor and your station low—why do you not take office?" Yan Hui replied, "I do not wish to. Outside the city walls, I have fifty *mu* of fields, enough to provide gruel and porridge; within the city walls, ten *mu* of fields, enough for silk and hemp. Playing the zither is enough for my amusement, and what I have learned of the Master’s Dao is enough for my joy. I do not wish to take office." Confucius’s expression changed as he sighed, "How excellent is Hui’s intent! I have heard that those who know contentment do not burden themselves with profit, that those who are truly self-possessed do not fear loss, and that those who cultivate virtue within are not ashamed without rank. I have recited this for a long time, but only now do I see it in you—this is my gain."

"Fields outside the city walls" refers to farmland; "within the city walls," to gardens. Yan Hui may not have actually possessed these—Zhuangzi’s words may not be entirely trustworthy. "What I have learned of the Master’s Dao is enough for my joy"—but what is this joy? Thus, the Cheng brothers often instructed others to seek Yan Hui’s joy, a matter not to be dismissed lightly. "Those who know contentment do not burden themselves with profit" means that those content with themselves have no need of external things. "Truly self-possessed" means that if what is within is genuinely sufficient, the loss of external things brings neither joy nor fear. "Not ashamed without rank" means not feeling shame at being unknown. "Recited this for a long time, but only now do I see it" means having heard these words before but only now witnessing them in a person. "This is my gain" means truly having gained a friend.

Prince Mou of Zhongshan said to Zhanzi, "Though my body dwells by rivers and seas, my heart remains in the palace halls of Wei—what is to be done?" Zhanzi replied, "Value life, and profit will become light." Prince Mou said, "Though I know this, I cannot overcome myself." Zhanzi said, "If you cannot overcome yourself, then follow your spirit—why resent it? If one cannot overcome oneself yet forcibly resists, this is called double injury. Those doubly injured do not enter the ranks of the long-lived."

"Heart remains in the palace halls" means being unable to forget wealth and rank. "Value life, then profit becomes light" means that if one recognizes the preciousness of the original mind, external things grow light. "Though I know this, I cannot overcome myself" means that principle has not yet triumphed over desire. "If you cannot overcome yourself, then follow" means that if the mind cannot yet master itself, one should listen and comply for the time being. This refers to dwelling by rivers and seas while such thoughts occasionally arise—there is no need to forcibly suppress them. If one forcibly suppresses them, it may internally harm the spirit and even lead to illness. Hence, "If you cannot overcome yourself, then follow"—following causes no harm to the spirit, so "why resent it?" "Cannot overcome oneself" is one injury. This refers to the moment when such thoughts arise. If, when these thoughts arise, one forcibly suppresses them instead of complying, the struggle with self-control is a second injury. Hence, "double injury"—this is not the way to longevity. "Do not enter the ranks of the long-lived" means not joining the category of those who live long.

Prince Mou of Wei was the son of a ruler of ten thousand chariots, yet he retired to cliffs and caves—something difficult for a commoner. Though he had not yet reached the Dao, he could be said to have the intent. These words align with the *Doctrine of the Mean*’s encouragement to practice.

When Confucius was besieged between Chen and Cai, for seven days he ate no cooked food, subsisting on unsalted vegetable broth. His complexion was deeply fatigued, yet he sang in his chamber while playing the zither. Yan Hui was picking vegetables, while Zilu and Zigong discussed, saying, "The Master was twice expelled from Lu, his traces erased in Wei, his tree felled in Song, and now he is trapped between Chen and Cai. Those who would kill him bear no guilt; those who would lend him aid face no prohibition. Yet he sings and plays the zither without ceasing—can a gentleman be so shameless?"

Yan Hui had no reply. He entered and told Confucius, who pushed aside the zither and sighed deeply, "You and Ci are petty men! Summon them, and I will speak with them." When Zilu and Zigong entered, Zilu said, "In such circumstances, one could truly be called destitute." Confucius said, "What words are these? When a gentleman is in accord with the Dao, that is called accord; when he is cut off from the Dao, that is called destitution. Now, I embrace the Dao of benevolence and righteousness yet encounter the calamities of a disordered age—how can this be called destitution? Thus, when I examine myself, I am not cut off from the Dao; when facing adversity, I do not lose my virtue. When the cold arrives and frost and snow descend, I thereby know the flourishing of the pine and cypress. The straits of Chen and Cai may be my good fortune!"

Confucius then composed himself, returned to the zither, and sang. Zilu, emboldened, took up a shield and danced. Zigong said, "I did not know the height of heaven or the depth of the earth!"

Those of old who attained the Dao found joy in poverty and joy in prosperity—their joy did not depend on poverty or prosperity.

When the Dao and virtue are present in this way, then destitution and success become as orderly as the sequence of cold and heat, wind and rain. Thus, Xu You found joy in Yingyang, and Gong Bo found contentment in Qiushou. "A broth of greens without a grain of rice"—this speaks of having vegetables but no rice, yet borrowing from others to press upon them is not forbidden, nor is it deemed a fault. When the cold arrives, one knows the flourishing of the pine and cypress—this is what is meant by "only when the year grows cold do we know the pine and cypress." Through the straits of Chen and Cai, the Way of the sage in enduring destitution can manifest itself and serve as a model for later generations. Thus it is said, "How fortunate for me in this!"

*Xiaoran* suggests a carefree and unconstrained manner; *fan qin* means to take up the zither again and play. *Guran* describes a leaping or exultant movement—Zilu, upon hearing these words, rejoiced. The following lines from Zigong indicate his enlightenment through this. Qiushou is the name of a mountain; the so-called Gong Bo may not necessarily refer to the Gonghe Regency—most of these are likely allegorical and difficult to verify in fact. The intent is that Zigong, overjoyed, spoke thus, praising the likes of Xu You who could remain joyful in destitution by delighting in their Way. Xu You and Gong Bo are both invoked through Zigong’s words. Shang and Zhou refer to the Zhou capital, which included the former lands and people of Shang.

Shun wished to yield the world to his friend, Beiren Wuze. Beiren Wuze said, "How strange is the ruler of later times! Dwelling in the fields and furrows, yet wandering at Yao’s gate—this alone would not suffice. Now he further wishes to smear me with his disgraceful conduct. I am ashamed to see him!" Thereupon he cast himself into the Qingling Abyss.

*"This alone would not suffice"* means that Shun’s actions were already improper; your own failings are yours alone to bear—why further defile me? Thus he drowned himself. This account appears nowhere else in the classics and is likely allegorical. *"Disgraceful conduct"* refers to base virtue.

When Tang was about to attack Jie, he consulted Bian Sui, who said, "This is not my affair." Tang asked, "Who would be suitable?" Bian Sui replied, "I do not know." Tang then consulted Wu Guang, who said, "This is not my affair." Tang asked, "Who would be suitable?" Wu Guang replied, "I do not know." Tang said, "What of Yi Yin?" Wu Guang said, "He is strong and enduring of filth—I know nothing else of him." Tang then conspired with Yi Yin to attack Jie, defeated him, and offered the throne to Bian Sui.
