chunks.original_text: 且得无言乎 一与言为二二与一为三自此以往巧历不能得而况其凡乎 故自无适有以至于三而况自有适有乎 无适焉 因是已此两句虽是设喻以明是非有无之理然此语极天下之至理前乎 庄子未有此言也 后乎 庄子亦未有此言也 可谓千百年独到之论秋毫之末至小也 而谓之莫大太山至大也 而谓之为小其意盖谓既名曰秋毫才大些个便不可以秋毫名之矣 太山才小些个便不名为太山矣 若以太山为大天地更大故太山谓之小亦可殇子为名则是极殇子之数矣 更多些个则不名殇子矣 彭祖虽曰至寿比之天地彭祖为夭矣 此两句细看得出便是若是而可谓成乎 虽我亦成也 若是而不可谓成乎 物与我无成也 若人防如此看则大而天地与我并生于太虚之间天地亦不得为大而万物又与我并生于天地之间虽一草一木一禽一虫亦与我相故曰天地与我并生万物与我为一说了个一字却就此一字粘起曰既为一矣 且得有言乎 意谓既是混然为一则和个一字亦不当有今既有一字矣 则安得谓之无乎 以混然之一与此名一之言自是两个故曰一与言为二既有此二矣 又有一与言为二一句则成三个矣 自此三个但管生将去自千而万自万而兆直至巧于历者亦算不尽而况凡常人乎 若如此看得来当初因个无字引起遂至于有自有而一自一而二自二而三已自如此言之不已何况更自有而生有乎 以此而观则惟无适为是何以谓之无适即因是而已自个是字说来到这里又结一结 夫道未始有封言未始有常为是而有畛也 请言其畛有左有右有伦有义有分有辩有竞有争此之谓八德此段又自是字上生起有封即有彼我也 有常有主也 至道至言本无彼此因人心之私有个是字故生出许多疆界畛疆界也 八德之名只是物我对立之意却鼓舞其文做出四句左右彼此对立之名也 伦理也 义事宜也 才有彼此对立则说理说事各有主意也 分分析也 辩辩别也 分辩皆同但字有轻重才有主意则各自分析辩别也 竞争亦一意但竞则甚于争尔既有分辩则大者必竞小者必争也 看此等文字即就字义上略摆拨得伶俐便自好若道伦又如何义又如何分又如何辩又如何争又如何竞又如何便非庄子之意矣 且伦字义字分字辩字竞字争字本无甚分别如何名以八德看得他文字破不被他鼓舞处笼罩了方是读得庄子好虽使庄子复生亦必道还汝具一只眼 六合之外圣人存而不论六合之内圣人论而不议春秋经世先王之志圣人议而不辩故分也者有不分也辩也者有不辩也曰何也圣人懐之众人辩之以相示也故曰辩也者有不见也 上面既说了彼我是非到这数句又别生个说话来发明此老胸中多少玲珑多少快活六合之外天地之外也 存而不论即释氏所谓四维上下不可思量也 六合之内宇宙之间也 宇宙之间合有许多道理圣人何尝不说但不立此议以强天下之知春秋史书之名也 此一句又是既有君臣上下凡见于史册者皆是先王经世之意圣人岂容不立此议而何尝与世人争较是非盖天下之理惟其不言则为至言才到分辩处便是你胸中自见得不透彻也 故曰分也 者有不分也 辩也 者有不辩也 到这里又自发一个何也 之问懐之者退藏于密之意也 圣人于此卷而懐之众人于此则必辩而明之以相夸示才有分辩便是无见识处故曰有不见也 夫大道不称大辩不言大仁不仁大廉不嗛大勇不忮道昭而不道言辩而不及仁常而不成廉清而不信勇忮而不成五者园而几向方矣
chunks.translated_text:
Moreover, can there be no speech? One and speech make two; two and one make three. From this onward, even the most skillful mathematician cannot reckon, let alone the common person. Thus, from non-being proceeding to being, reaching three—how much more so from being proceeding to being? There is no proceeding at all. This is simply following what is.

These two lines, though presented as an analogy to clarify the principle of being and non-being, express the ultimate truth of all under heaven. Before Zhuangzi, no one had spoken thus; after Zhuangzi, no one has spoken thus. Truly, this is a singular insight spanning centuries. The tip of an autumn hair is most minute, yet it is called "nothing greater"; Mount Tai is most vast, yet it is called "small." The intent here is that once named "autumn hair," even if slightly larger, it can no longer be called "autumn hair." Once named "Mount Tai," even if slightly smaller, it can no longer be called "Mount Tai." If Mount Tai is deemed great, yet heaven and earth are greater, then calling Mount Tai "small" is permissible. If "child who dies young" is a name, it denotes the utmost brevity of life; any longer, and it is no longer called a "child who dies young." Though Pengzu is said to be long-lived, compared to heaven and earth, he is short-lived.

Examining these two lines closely, one sees that if something can be called "completed," then even I am completed. If it cannot be called "completed," then things and I are without completion. If one guards against viewing it thus, then, vast as heaven and earth are, born together with me in the great void, they cannot be called great. And the myriad things, born together with me between heaven and earth—even a single blade of grass, a single tree, a single bird, a single insect—are all equal to me. Thus it is said: "Heaven and earth were born together with me, and the myriad things and I are one." Having spoken of "one," it then clings to this "one," saying: "Since we are already one, how can there be speech?" The meaning is that if we are wholly undifferentiated as one, then even the word "one" should not exist. Yet since there is already the word "one," how can it be said there is none? This undifferentiated "one" and this named "one" of speech are already two things. Thus, "one and speech make two." Once there are these two, adding the phrase "one and speech make two" makes three. From these three, generation proceeds endlessly—from thousands to tens of thousands, from tens of thousands to trillions—until even the most skillful reckoner cannot exhaust them, let alone the common person.

If one views it thus, then initially, from the word "non-being," speech arises, proceeding to being, from being to one, from one to two, from two to three. Once speech begins, how much more will being generate being without end? Observing this, only "no proceeding" is correct. What is meant by "no proceeding"? It is simply following what is.

Now, the Dao has never had boundaries, and speech has never had constancy. To affirm "this" is to create divisions. Let us speak of these divisions: there is left and right, there are principles and duties, there are distinctions and debates, there are competitions and conflicts—these are called the eight virtues. This passage arises from the word "this." Where there are boundaries, there is self and other; where there is constancy, there is a master. The ultimate Dao and ultimate speech originally have no self and other. It is due to the selfishness of the human heart that the word "this" arises, giving birth to many boundaries and divisions. The names of the eight virtues merely express the opposition of self and other, yet the text animates them with four pairs: left and right, opposing terms; principles (ethics) and duties (righteousness); distinctions and debates, both similar but with varying emphasis—once there is self and other, principles and affairs each have their own intent; competitions and conflicts, both of the same meaning, but competition is more intense than conflict. Once there are distinctions and debates, the greater must compete, and the lesser must contend.

When reading such passages, if one merely skims the surface of the words, one may appear clever, but if one asks, "What is ethics? What is duty? What is distinction? What is debate? What is competition? What is conflict?"—then one has missed Zhuangzi’s intent. Moreover, the words for ethics, duty, distinction, debate, competition, and conflict have no great difference in themselves. How can they be named the "eight virtues"? Only by seeing through the text’s embellishments and not being confined by its rhetoric can one truly read Zhuangzi well. Even if Zhuangzi were to return to life, he would surely say, "You possess a discerning eye."

Beyond the six directions, the sage preserves but does not discuss; within the six directions, the sage discusses but does not debate. The *Spring and Autumn Annals* embodies the intent of the former kings to order the world; the sage debates but does not argue. Thus, where there are distinctions, there are also non-distinctions; where there is debate, there are also non-debates. Why is this? The sage cherishes them in secret, while the common people debate them to display to one another. Thus, it is said: "Where there is debate, there is also non-perception."

Having already spoken of self and other, right and wrong, these several lines introduce another perspective to reveal the boundless clarity and freedom in this old man’s heart. "Beyond the six directions" refers to beyond heaven and earth—what the Buddhists call the four directions, above and below, beyond thought. "Within the six directions" refers to the cosmos. Within the cosmos, there are many principles; how could the sage not speak of them? Yet he does not establish debates to force understanding upon all under heaven. The *Spring and Autumn Annals* is the name of a historical record; this line means that all matters of ruler and subject, high and low recorded in history embody the intent of the former kings to order the world. How could the sage not establish debates? Yet how could he contend with the world over right and wrong? For the principles of all under heaven, silence is the ultimate speech; once distinctions and debates arise, it is because one’s own understanding is not thorough. Thus, it is said: "Where there are distinctions, there are also non-distinctions; where there is debate, there are also non-debates."

Here, another question arises: "Why is this?" "Cherishing them" means withdrawing and concealing them in secrecy. The sage rolls them up and cherishes them, while the common people must debate and clarify them to boast and display. Where there are distinctions and debates, there is a lack of insight. Thus, it is said: "Where there is debate, there is also non-perception."

The great Dao is not called great; great eloquence does not speak; great benevolence is not benevolent; great integrity is not modest; great courage is not aggressive. The Dao, when illuminated, is not the Dao; speech, when debated, does not reach; benevolence, when constant, is not complete; integrity, when pure, is not trustworthy; courage, when aggressive, is not accomplished. These five, though round, nearly approach squareness.

chunks.original_text: 故知止其所不知至矣 孰知不言之辩不道之道若有能知此之谓天府注焉 而不满酌焉 而不竭而不知其所由来此之谓葆光对立者曰称谓之大道则无对立者矣 不言之中自有至言故曰大辩不言无仁之迹而后为大仁嗛满也 猴藏物曰嗛以廉为廉则有自满之意国语曰嗛嗛之德不足就也 言其自小即此嗛字清畏人知清畏人不知皆不得为大廉矣 不忮者不见其用勇之迹也 既说此五句下面又再解一转昭者明也 道不可以指名昭然而指名则非道矣 故曰不道言而形诸辩则是自有见不及处矣 常者可见之迹也 有可见之迹则非仁之大成矣 廉而至于有自洁之意则不诚实矣 清自洁意也 信实也 勇而见于忮则必丧其勇矣 园圆也 言此以上五者皆是个圆物谓其本混成也 若稍有迹则近于四方之物矣 谓其有圭角也 几近也 向字与于字同意天下之真知必至于不知为知而止则为知之至矣 不知之知便是不言之辨便是不道之道若人有能知此则可以见天理之所防矣 故曰此之谓天府天府者天理之所防也 天理之所防欲益之而不能益故曰注焉 而不满欲损之而不能损故曰酌焉 而不竭至理之妙无终无始故曰不知其所由来葆光者滑疑之耀也 葆藏也 藏其光而不露故曰葆光 故昔者尧问于舜曰我欲伐宗脍胥敖南面而不释然其故何也 舜曰夫三子者犹存乎 蓬艾之间若不释然何哉 昔者十日并出万物皆照而况德之进乎 日者乎 昔者上着一故字便是因上文而引证也 宗脍胥敖之事无经见亦寓言耳 不释然者不悦也 蓬艾之间喻其物欲障蔽而不知有天地也 谓彼之三国物欲自蔽未能向化而我才有不悦之心则物我亦对立矣 十日并出亦见淮南子此盖庄子寓言淮南子又因之而妆撰也 言日于万物无所不照况我之德犹胜于日而不能容此三子者乎 此意盖喻物我是非圣人所以置之不辨者照之以天也 十日之说即莫若以明之喻也 啮缺问乎王倪曰子知物之所同是乎曰吾恶乎知之子知子之所不知邪曰吾恶乎知之然则物无知邪曰吾恶乎知之虽然尝试言之庸讵知吾所谓知之非不知邪庸讵知吾所谓不知之非知邪 此段又自知止其所不知上生来又自前头是字上引伸之以道一篇只是一片文字啮缺同是之问王倪不知之对便即是知止其所不知但如此撰造名字鼓舞发挥此所以为庄子也既曰吾恶乎知之又曰虽然尝试言之此皆转换妙处知之非不知不知之非知此两句发得知止其所不知又妙其意盖谓不知便是真知也 且吾尝试问乎汝民湿寝则腰疾偏死防然乎哉木处则惴栗恂惧猨猴然乎哉三者孰知正处民食刍豢麋鹿食荐蝍蛆甘带鸱鸦耆鼠四者孰知正味猨猵狚以为雌麋与鹿交防与鱼游毛嫱丽姬人之所美也鱼见之深入鸟见之高飞麋鹿见之决骤四者孰知天下之正色哉自我观之仁义之端是非之涂樊然殽乱吾恶能知其辩 且吾尝试问乎 汝者又为发端之语也
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, to know where to stop in what one does not know is the utmost. Who knows the eloquence of non-speech, the Dao of non-Dao? If one can know this, it is called the Heavenly Storehouse—poured into yet never full, drawn from yet never exhausted, and one knows not whence it comes. This is called preserving the light.

To those who would oppose it, it is said: if one names the great Dao, there are no oppositions. Within non-speech lies the most profound speech, hence it is said: "Great eloquence does not speak." Only when no traces of benevolence remain does great benevolence arise. *Qian* (modesty) implies concealment—like a monkey hiding things, it is called *qian*. To take modesty as modesty is to harbor self-satisfaction. The *Guoyu* states: "The virtue of *qianqian* is insufficient to achieve." Whether one fears others knowing or fears others not knowing, neither qualifies as great integrity.

"Not aggressive" means no traces of courage are seen. Having explained these five phrases, another layer of interpretation follows: *Zhao* means illumination. The Dao cannot be pointed to and named; if it is illuminated and named, it is no longer the Dao. Thus, it is said: "not the Dao." Speech, when shaped into debate, reveals where one’s understanding falls short. "Constant" refers to visible traces; where visible traces exist, benevolence is not fully realized. Integrity, when tainted by self-purification, is not sincere. *Qing* means self-purification; *xin* means sincerity. Courage, when manifested in aggression, must lose its true nature.

"Round" means circular, indicating that these five are originally undifferentiated. If even slight traces appear, they approach the squareness of things—meaning they develop edges and corners. *Ji* means "nearly"; *xiang* shares the meaning of *yu* (toward).

The true knowledge of the world must reach the point where "not knowing" is knowing, and there it stops—this is the pinnacle of knowledge. "Not knowing" is the eloquence of non-speech; it is the Dao of non-Dao. If one can know this, one can perceive where Heaven’s principle is guarded. Thus, it is said: "This is called the Heavenly Storehouse." The Heavenly Storehouse is where Heaven’s principle is guarded. Heaven’s principle cannot be added to, hence "poured into yet never full"; it cannot be diminished, hence "drawn from yet never exhausted." The subtlety of the supreme principle has no end or beginning, thus "one knows not whence it comes." *Baoguang* is the radiance of elusive brilliance—*bao* means to conceal, to hide one’s light without revealing it, hence "preserving the light."

Thus, in ancient times, Yao asked Shun: "I wish to attack Zong, Kuai, and Xu’ao, yet when I face south, I feel unsettled. What is the reason?" Shun replied: "Those three rulers still exist among the weeds and brambles. Why are you unsettled? In ancient times, ten suns appeared together, and all things were illuminated—how much more so for the advance of virtue?" The word *zhe* (者) above "in ancient times" indicates this is cited from the preceding text.

The affairs of Zong, Kuai, and Xu’ao are not recorded in the classics; they are likely allegorical. "Unsettled" means displeased. "Among the weeds and brambles" metaphorically describes being obscured by desires, unaware of heaven and earth. It suggests that those three states, self-obscured by desires, have not turned toward transformation, and if I feel displeased, then subject and object remain opposed. The tale of the ten suns also appears in the *Huainanzi*; this is likely a parable from Zhuangzi, which the *Huainanzi* later embellished. It means that the sun illuminates all things without exception—how much more should my virtue, surpassing the sun, tolerate these three? This implies that the sage’s refusal to debate right and wrong is to illuminate them with Heaven.

The saying of the ten suns is akin to the metaphor of "illuminating with brightness." Nie Que asked Wang Ni: "Do you know what all things agree upon as right?" Wang Ni replied: "How would I know?" "Do you know what you do not know?" "How would I know?" "Then do things have no knowledge?" "How would I know? Nevertheless, let me try to speak: How do I know that what I call knowing is not not-knowing? How do I know that what I call not-knowing is not knowing?"

This passage arises from "knowing where to stop in what one does not know," expanding upon the earlier "is" (*shi* 是). The entire essay is a single, continuous text. Nie Que’s question about agreement and Wang Ni’s response of not knowing exemplify knowing where to stop in what one does not know. The invented names and lively expressions are characteristic of Zhuangzi. Though he says, "How would I know?" he then adds, "Nevertheless, let me try to speak"—these are masterful turns of phrase. "Knowing is not not-knowing; not-knowing is not knowing" brilliantly develops the idea of knowing where to stop in what one does not know, for its meaning suggests that not-knowing is true knowledge.

Moreover, let me ask you: When people sleep in damp places, they develop lower back pain and partial paralysis—is this so? When monkeys live in trees, they tremble with fear—is this so? Of these three, which knows the proper place to dwell? People eat the flesh of livestock; deer eat grass; centipedes delight in snakes; owls and crows relish mice. Of these four, which knows the proper taste? Monkeys and apes mate with female monkeys; deer consort with deer; loaches swim with fish. Mao Qiang and Li Ji are considered beautiful by people, yet when fish see them, they dive deep; when birds see them, they fly high; when deer see them, they flee swiftly. Of these four, which knows the true beauty of the world? From my perspective, the beginnings of benevolence and righteousness, the paths of right and wrong, are tangled and confused—how could I know their distinctions?

Moreover, let me ask you...

Is the loach at ease in water? Are the monkeys at ease in trees? How could people dwell in such places? Yet each finds ease in its own place of ease, and none can find ease in what is not its place of ease—thus, of these three, none truly knows the proper place. How then could humans be any different from apes or loaches?

Grass and wood are the food of livestock, while meat is the food of humans. *Jian* is grass; *dai* is snake. Deer eat grass, centipedes eat snakes, owls and crows eat mice, and humans eat livestock—each finds its own taste sweet and fine, yet of these four, which truly knows the proper taste? *Biandan* and *gezang* are types of apes. Apes mate with apes, deer consort with deer, and loaches swim with fish. Yet when it comes to Mao Qiang and Li Ji, whom humans deem beautiful, fish dive deep at the sight of them, birds take flight, and deer flee swiftly. Of these four, which truly knows the world’s true beauty?

Swift and sudden—such is their flight. These three passages all serve as metaphors for right and wrong, self and other, thus concluding: from my perspective, the distinctions of benevolence and righteousness, the debates of right and wrong, are tangled and confused—how could one possibly discern their order?

*Fan* means entangled, *yao* means mixed. Nie Que said, "If you do not know benefit and harm, does the perfected person truly not know benefit and harm?" Wang Ni replied, "The perfected person is divine. When great marshes burn, they cannot be scorched; when the Milky Way freezes, they cannot be chilled; when thunder splits mountains and winds shake the seas, they cannot be startled. Such a one rides the clouds and qi, mounts the sun and moon, and roams beyond the four seas. Death and life bring no change to them—how much less the beginnings of benefit and harm?" Wang Ni is the perfected person. *Divine* means their wonder pervades the ten thousand things without trace. Unscorched, unchilled, unstartled—this is to roam the mind in the beginning of nothingness. Even the great matters of death and life do not move their heart—how much less benefit, harm, right, and wrong? This sentence serves as a plain and solid conclusion.

Ju Quezi asked Chang Wuzi, "I have heard from the Master that the sage does not engage in affairs, does not pursue benefit, does not avoid harm, does not delight in seeking, does not follow the Dao, is without words yet speaks, speaks yet is without words, and roams beyond the dust and grime. The Master considered these reckless words, but I believe they describe the wondrous practice of the Dao. What do you think?" Chang Wuzi replied, "Even the Yellow Emperor would be perplexed by such words—how could Confucius possibly understand them?"

This further raises the question of the sage, critiquing the scholars of the Confucian school who busy themselves with affairs. *Does not engage in affairs* means not taking them to heart. To *pursue* or *avoid* is to know benefit and harm—if one does not know benefit and harm, what is there to pursue or avoid? *Seeking* refers to things that come to me, yet the sage does not delight in them. *Does not follow the Dao* means leaving no trace of practice. *Without words yet speaks* and *speaks yet is without words* refer to speech that is not speech. *Menglang* means unreal. *The Master* refers to Confucius. To say that the sage’s affairs are spoken of as the wondrous Dao, yet Confucius deemed them unreal—what do you think? *You* here refers to Chang Wuzi. *Ying* means clarity. Only the Yellow Emperor could listen and attain clarity—how could Confucius understand?

"You are far too hasty in your judgments—seeing an egg and demanding the crowing of the rooster at dawn, seeing a slingshot and craving a roasted owl. Let me speak to you recklessly, and you may listen recklessly—how about that? Why not embrace the sun and moon, clasp the cosmos to your bosom, and make them fit seamlessly? Set aside the murky and turbid, and with *you* as the measure, treat others with deference. The common people toil endlessly, while the sage appears foolish and dull, merging the myriad ages into a single completion. The ten thousand things are all complete, yet they encompass one another.

*Far too hasty in your judgments* means your words are like this, yet you already deem them the wondrous practice of the Dao—this is seeing little and thinking much. The rooster has not yet hatched from the egg, yet you demand its crowing at dawn; you have not yet obtained the owl, yet you crave it roasted—this is the metaphor of hasty judgment. *I speak to you recklessly, and you listen recklessly*—how about that? *Recklessly* means not taking it as entirely true. *Why not embrace the sun and moon*—*pang* means to attach. *Clasp the cosmos*—the cosmos is held in one’s embrace. *Fit seamlessly* means to merge without gaps, as if the principle is naturally one. *Murky* means turbid, *turbid* means obscure. The turbid and obscure *you* of the human world, with which people defer to one another, are all set aside and unspoken. Scholars defer to great officers, great officers defer to ministers, ministers defer to rulers—each defers to the other, yet all claim superiority. The common people are deluded by worldly affairs and toil endlessly, while the sage, with a mind that does not know, appears foolish and dull. *Merge* means to unite. The myriad ages are united into a single completion, and the ten thousand things are all complete, yet they encompass one another.

Uniting the myriad ages in a single vision—this principle admits no admixture, hence it is called "a single completion, pure and undivided." That the ten thousand things are each complete in themselves means each thing is as it is in its own way. Yet all people harbor private intentions, and so between heaven and earth, from ancient times to the present, countless instances of "this" accumulate without end. Thus it is said: "by 'this' they enfold one another." To enfold one another is to say they layer and press upon one another.

How do I know that delight in life is not delusion? How do I know that aversion to death is not a lost youth who knows not his way home? Li Ji, the daughter of the border guard Ai, when first taken by the state of Jin, wept until her tears soaked her collar. Yet once she reached the king’s palace and shared his carved couch, feasting on fine meats, she came to regret her tears. How do I know that the dead do not regret their initial longing for life? One who dreams of drinking wine may wake and weep; one who dreams of weeping may wake and hunt. In the midst of a dream, one does not know it is a dream—even within the dream, one may divine its meaning. Only upon waking does one know it was a dream. And only with the great awakening does one realize that all this was a great dream. Yet fools believe themselves awake, priding themselves on their keen discernment: "Ah, the lord! Ah, the herdsman!" How rigid! Confucius, you and I are both dreaming. When I say you are dreaming, I too am dreaming. Such words are called "perverse consolation." Even ten thousand generations hence, should a great sage encounter them, it would be as if meeting in the space of a morning and evening.

The "weak loss" refers to one who departs from their homeland in youth. To linger long in a foreign land and forget one’s native country—those who delight in life and dread death are much the same. Lady Li was a consort of Duke Xian of Jin. Captured from the state of Lirong (Li being the name of the Rong lands), she was called "Li’s Consort." The *feng ren* (guardian of the borderlands) was an official charged with defending the frontiers. This serves as an analogy for life and death.

Between dream and waking, transformations unfold thus: while dreaming, one does not know it is a dream, and may even divine its meaning within the dream. Only upon waking does one realize that both the dream and its interpretation were but dreams. Such passages subtly capture the marvels of human nature. The herdsman and groom are lowly, yet the foolish man in the world, still dreaming, clings desperately to his sense of noble and base—is this not a profound delusion? That furtive, narrow vision—all I say to you now lies within the dream. Even my present words, calling you a dreamer, are but dream-speech. This idea suggests that the world is but an empty dream, though its patterns shift in wondrous, even eerie transformations.

My words here may seem utterly strange, yet within this strangeness lies the most subtle principle. Should a great sage arise ten thousand generations hence and grasp these insights of mine, it would be as if we met in the span of a single dawn and dusk. This is also what later ages mean when they say: "If there must be a Yang Xiong, he will understand me." Such is the mutual recognition of vision.

Now, suppose you and I debate: if you prevail over me, does that mean I am wrong and you are right? Or if I prevail over you, does that mean you are wrong and I am right? Or perhaps one of us is right, or one of us is wrong? Or perhaps both are right, or both are wrong? You and I cannot know for certain. Then all people are shrouded in obscurity—whom shall we ask to set things right?

If we seek one who agrees with you to arbitrate, since he already agrees with you, how can he set things right? If we seek one who agrees with me, since he already agrees with me, how can he set things aright? If we seek one who differs from both you and me, since he differs from us, how can he set things right? If we seek one who agrees with both you and me, since he agrees with us, how can he set things right? You are one, I am another, and this third person is yet another—three who cannot know one another. We must await another beyond us.

This "another" is the workings of creation, the "Heavenly Boundary."

The "Heavenly Boundary" is the earlier "Heavenly Equilibrium." What does it mean to harmonize with the Heavenly Boundary? It means: "Is it so? Is it not so? So or not so?" If something is truly so, then how does it differ from not being so? There would be no need for debate. If something is truly so, then how does it differ from not being so? Again, there would be no need for debate. The mutual dependence of transformative voices—if they do not oppose one another, they harmonize with the Heavenly Boundary, following it in boundless unfolding, thus exhausting the years. Forgetting the years, forgetting righteousness, one rouses oneself in the boundless—thus dwelling in the boundless. This is the boundary of distinction, the Heavenly Boundary. The reason it harmonizes is simply this: "is" and "is not," "so" and "not so"—both are preserved. This is the earlier "walking two paths." The moment one takes something to be so, the moment one takes it to be right, then "not so" and "not right" arise, giving rise to disputes over right and wrong. These are mere words—transformative voices, meaning the use of language to persuade and submit. "Mutual dependence" means opposition, contention. If, in the midst of disputes over right and wrong, one stubbornly pits language against itself to seek persuasion, how is this like following what is so without contention? Thus it is said: "if they do not oppose one another." These two characters, "do not oppose," are most extraordinary—"if they" is akin to saying "how is it like?" Without opposition yet in accord, this is harmonizing with the Heavenly Boundary. One may roam freely, exhausting the years—thus it is said: "following it in boundless unfolding, thus exhausting the years." "Following" means yielding; "boundless unfolding" means wandering freely. "Exhausting the years" is like Du Fu’s "carefree passage of days and months." If one can do this, then not only can one exhaust the years, but one may even forget them. Not only forget the years, but even forget principles and righteousness. Having forgotten years and righteousness, one stirs and dances in the realm of nothingness—this "stirs" is the meaning of "free and easy wandering." Wandering freely in the realm of nothingness, one’s entire life is then lodged in the realm of nothingness.

The shadow’s companion asked the shadow: "Earlier you were moving, now you are still; earlier you were sitting, now you are rising—why are you so without constancy?" The shadow replied: "Do I depend on something to be thus? Does what I depend on also depend on something to be thus? Do I depend on the scales of a snake or the wings of a cicada? How would I know why it is so? How would I know why it is not so?" This passage arises from the word "depend." The shadow’s companion is the faintest part of the shadow, without constancy—meaning it has no fixed measure. "Do I depend on something to be thus?" refers to the shadow’s movement, which depends on the form. Though I depend on the form, the form itself depends on something else—this is depending on the workings of creation. The form as form is no more than the scales of a snake or the wings of a cicada. Do I merely depend on them? The cicada and snake transform, yet their scales and wings remain—this is their molting. How can they move on their own? Since I depend on the form, and the form depends on something else, how can I know why it is so or not so? This is the metaphor for "not depending on that."

Once, Zhuang Zhou dreamed he was a butterfly, fluttering happily—a butterfly indeed. He took pleasure in it, unaware that he was Zhou.

Suddenly awake, he was Zhuang Zhou again—stiff and startled. Did Zhou dream he was a butterfly, or did the butterfly dream it was Zhou? Between Zhou and the butterfly, there must be a distinction. This is called the transformation of things.

This passage arises from the earlier dream sequence: the fluttering of the butterfly, the self-delight, the joy of following one’s will. In the dream, as the butterfly, he was so utterly content that he forgot his own self—hence "unaware that he was Zhou." *Qúqú* describes the rigidity of waking, the sensation of lying stiff upon the bed. Here, the brushstrokes of Zhuangzi’s prose depict Zhou’s realization: last night’s butterfly was but a dream, yet now he fears the butterfly, over there, might take this waking moment for its own dream. Thus he asks: Did Zhou dream of the butterfly, or did the butterfly dream of Zhou? Between dream and waking, there must be a boundary—hence "between Zhou and the butterfly, there must be a distinction." This line seems to conclude yet does not, leaving the matter unresolved, much like a Chan *huatou*, inviting the reader to investigate for themselves.

This is called the transformation of things—referring to the principle of the myriad things’ ceaseless change. The title of this chapter, "Discourse on Making All Things Equal," culminates in these two metaphors, their language extraordinary, their meaning profound. One who awakens to this truth sees that there is no ground for disputing right and wrong, no change in life and death, let alone the entanglements of gain and loss. The opening and closing resonate like a dammed river suddenly released, like linked rings that do not touch—an unbroken yet discontinuous flow, a single sweep of brushwork rising and falling. **Zhuangzi Kouyi, Scroll Two**
*Imperially Commissioned Complete Library of the Four Treasuries*

**Third Inner Chapter: "Nurturing the Life-Foundation"**
*"Master" here is akin to what Chan calls the "host within"; "nurturing the master" refers to what Daoists call the "elixir foundation" of this life.* First, the joy of roaming freely is spoken of; then, the state of being without right or wrong—this is the work of cultivating oneself. These three chapters seem to follow a sequence, yet what follows does not entirely adhere to it.

*"Our life has its limits, but knowledge is without bounds. To pursue the boundless with the bounded is perilous. And to be perilous in this pursuit—is this not danger enough?*
*Limits* (涯) means boundaries; human life has its boundaries, its finite limits. *Knowledge* (知) is thought, the endless workings of the mind. To follow boundless thought with a finite body—endlessly restless, when will it cease? *Perilous* (殆已) speaks of its dreadfulness; *已* is a particle. The following *已* echoes the previous one, as in the *"Equalizing Things"* chapter. Amidst this peril, one still employs thought and calculation, believing oneself to be wise and capable—yet I see only that it ends in peril. The repetition of *殆* (peril) further emphasizes this, deeply warning later generations. This *殆* is the same as the *"only peril"* in the *Book of Documents*. *已而为知者* is like saying, "clearly knowing, thus acting deliberately."

*"In doing good, avoid proximity to fame; in doing evil, avoid proximity to punishment. Follow the central path as your guiding principle—thus can you preserve your body, fulfill your life, nurture your kin, and live out your years."*
These lines precisely expound Zhuangzi’s teachings on nurturing life, his own way of self-cultivation. *"In doing good, avoid proximity to fame"* means that if one acts virtuously yet avoids deeds that attract renown; *"in doing evil, avoid proximity to punishment"* means that if one commits wrongs, one avoids acts that incur penalties—this aligns with the *"Webbed Toes"* chapter’s *"above, one dares not practice the conduct of benevolence and righteousness; below, one dares not engage in licentious and deviant acts."* *Supervisor* (督) means *urgency*—that is, responding only when pressed, acting only when unavoidable. Roaming the mind through this world, leaving no trace of good or evil, one simply follows the natural course of Heaven. Pressed, one responds; response arises without deliberation—this is the constant way. *Following* (缘) means compliance; *principle* (经) means constancy. Taking the meaning of *"responding only when pressed"* as one’s constant practice, one can preserve the body, fulfill the principle of life, filially nurture one’s parents, and live out one’s natural span—this is what Mencius meant by *"whether long or short-lived, one does not waver, but cultivates oneself and awaits [Heaven’s decree]."* Mencius speaks from the perspective of mind and nature, thus appearing solemn; this book speaks from the perspective of spontaneity, thus appearing carefree. Though their words differ, their intent in teaching people is the same.

Master Hui’an (Zhu Xi) glosses *督* as *"center"* but finds the phrasing of *"avoid proximity to fame"* and *"avoid proximity to punishment"* incomplete. He says: *"If one fears the entanglements of fame and dares not fully exert one’s efforts in learning, one inclines toward evil. 'In doing evil, avoid proximity to punishment' suggests choosing evils that do not lead to criminal penalties, secretly committing them, and cunningly avoiding the consequences of punishment—this would make Zhuangzi a man of unscrupulousness."* Yet if one examines Zhuangzi’s phrasing and cross-references it with the *"Webbed Toes"* chapter, this interpretation does not hold. Though *督* can be glossed as *"center,"* it is better rendered as *"urgency"*—this aligns more precisely with the evidence in the text itself.

*Cook Ding carved an ox for Lord Wenhui. Where his hand touched, where his shoulder leaned, where his foot stepped, where his knee pressed—all resounded with a crisp* 砉然 *and a smooth* 向然*. The blade sang* 騞然*, never failing to strike the right note, harmonizing with the dance of* Sanglin *and the rhythm of* Jingshou*.*
*"Ah!" exclaimed Lord Wenhui, "How excellent! How has your skill reached such heights?"*
*"Where his hand touched"* describes the movement of his hand; *"where his shoulder leaned"* refers to the tilt of his shoulder when applying force. *"Where his foot stepped"* describes the stance of his feet as he exerted himself, their placement naturally spaced. *"Where his knee pressed"* means his knees bent slightly as he leaned into the ox. These four lines depict the posture of a butcher at work. *砉然* (a crisp sound), *向然* (a smooth sound), and *騞然* (a ringing sound) all describe the sounds of his knife, with *"wielding the blade"* (奏刀) inserted in between—a matter of literary structure. This is like the *"Seventh Month"* poem: *"In the eighth month, in the wilds; in the ninth month, at the eaves; in the tenth month, the crickets are beneath my bed"*—where *"crickets"* is inserted in the middle. *奏刀* means advancing the blade; *"never failing to strike the right note"* means the sounds of *砉*, *向*, and *騞* all accorded with the musical modes. *Sanglin* and *Jingshou* are names of music; *dance* implies accompanying music, and *rhythm* (防) refers to the gathering of dancers. *"Harmonizing with Sanglin"* and *"striking the rhythm of Jingshou"* both describe how his movements matched the musical modes. *Lord Wenhui* is Lord Hui of Liang. *"Ah!"* is an exclamation of admiration.

The skill has reached such heights—these words describe its marvel. Butcher Ding laid down his knife and replied: "What your servant delights in is the Dao, which advances beyond mere skill. When I first began to dismember oxen, all I saw was nothing but oxen. After three years, I no longer saw whole oxen. To lay down the knife means to set it aside; that he spoke after setting it aside suggests his skill arose from learning the Dao, and thus his skill was no mere skill. After three years, he no longer saw whole oxen—this means that in the ox’s body, the places where it could be dismembered required no force and could be perceived at a glance.

Nowadays, I meet with it in spirit rather than seeing with my eyes; the senses’ knowing ceases, and the spirit’s desires proceed. I rely on the heavenly patterns, strike the great gaps, guide the blade through the great cavities, and follow what is inherently so. I have never touched the technical pathways or the binding joints—how much less the great bones! To meet with it in spirit rather than seeing with my eyes means the mind guards against it; *meeting* here means *guarding*. The senses are the ears, eyes, nose, and mouth. That the senses’ knowing ceases means that when one stands in concentration, the ears and eyes perceive nothing. The knowing of the ears and eyes all ceases and does not proceed, while the spirit moves of itself—this means naturally and spontaneously. The *heavenly patterns* are the ox’s body’s natural textures. *Relying* means following its natural textures to dismember it. The *great gaps* are where flesh and bone meet; *striking* means to strike. The *cavities* are the great empty spaces between the joints; *guiding* means to follow and dismember. Where flesh and bone meet, where the joints have empty spaces—all are inherently so, and I merely follow them to dismember. In my skill, when using the knife, I have never once touched the binding joints. *Binding joints* (綮) is pronounced *qing*; they are where flesh adheres to bone. If even the binding joints are untouched by the knife, how much less the great bones! *Great bones* (軱) is pronounced *gū*.

A good butcher changes his knife once a year—he cuts. An ordinary butcher changes his knife every month—he breaks it. Now my knife has been in use for nineteen years, having dismembered several thousand oxen, yet its edge is as if newly whetted. A *good butcher* is one skilled in butchery; an *ordinary butcher* is one among the common crowd, an inferior one. Inferior butchers change their knives every month because hacking at great bones damages or even breaks them. Good butchers change their knives once a year because their use of the knife still touches the binding joints, and cutting there may wear it down. But my knife has been in use for nineteen years, and though I have dismembered many oxen, its edge remains as if newly sharpened—this means it has suffered no damage. *Whetstone* (硎) is a grinding stone.

Where the joints have spaces and the knife’s edge has no thickness, to enter what has no thickness into what has spaces—how vast is the room for the blade to move! Thus, after nineteen years, the knife’s edge is as if newly whetted. *Where the joints have spaces* means the ox’s joints naturally have gaps; my knife is extremely thin. With such a thin knife, following the gaps to dismember, the blade can move freely within them. *How vast is the room* means there is no obstruction. This idea suggests that the difficulty or ease of worldly affairs all follows natural patterns. If I merely follow and proceed without clashing against them, my mind remains at peace, and thus nothing can harm my life—this is the method of nourishing life.

Yet whenever I come to where the sinews and bones are clustered, I see the difficulty and am startled into caution. My gaze lingers, my actions slow, and I move the knife with utmost care. Then, with a sudden *thwack*, it is dismembered, collapsing like earth to the ground. I raise the knife and stand, looking all around, then pause in satisfaction, wipe the knife clean, and put it away." Lord Wenhui said, "Excellent! From Butcher Ding’s words, I have learned how to nourish life."

This *yet* is a turn with profound meaning. It suggests that in navigating the world, one cannot always encounter smooth circumstances; there are also times when adversity arises. One must then adapt and proceed with flexibility. In favorable circumstances, it is easy to act, but when facing adversity, one often becomes flustered and loses composure—how can one’s mind remain undisturbed?

Thus, this turn is added: *clustered* (族) means where sinews and bones gather. Though I say I no longer see whole oxen with my eyes, and though I use the knife only at the great gaps and cavities, when I come to where sinews and bones are tangled, I still find it difficult, treating it as a challenge. *Startled* (怵然) means a change in demeanor; *caution* means heightened vigilance. *My gaze lingers* means that with my eyes, I cannot help but pause briefly before proceeding slowly. *My actions slow* means I proceed with great care. Once I have taken care, I move the knife with utmost subtlety—this means lightly, without daring to apply much force. *Thwack* (謋) is pronounced *tè*; *dismembered* (解) is pronounced *xiè*. *Thwack* suggests suddenness; *dismembered* means to come apart. Though I apply little force, the bones and flesh suddenly separate, collapsing like earth to the ground—this means it is abundant and easy. After dismembering the ox, I raise the knife and stand, looking all around in leisure. *Pausing* (踌躇) means composure; it also means self-satisfaction. *Satisfaction* (满志) means contentment.

It is not that his ambition is self-satisfied; rather, this means it fulfills my intent. Why is it as desired? Because I use no force in dismembering the ox, and though the ox is dismembered, the knife remains unharmed—this is why it is as desired. *"To care for the knife"* means to carefully put it away. This idea is a metaphor: when a person encounters adversity, they can respond with natural ease, keeping their mind undisturbed. Once the matter passes, they transform, and their body rests in non-action, as if nothing had ever occurred.

The following section, *"To do good without seeking fame,"* directly expounds the method of nurturing life. The passage about Pao Ding serves as its analogy, and here, at the end, it lightly concludes with *"thus attaining the nurturing of life"*—these four characters are where the momentum of the text is skillfully controlled, a point that must be examined closely.

Gongwen Xuan saw the Right Minister and was startled, saying: *"What sort of man is this? Why is he so singular?"* *"Was this given by Heaven, or by man?"* *"By Heaven, not by man."* *"Heaven’s creation made him thus, solitary; human appearance is shared, yet his is not. From this, we know it is Heaven’s doing, not man’s."*

Gongwen was his surname, Xuan his given name. The Right Minister was an official who had been punished by foot amputation. *"Singular"* (介) means alone; he retained only one foot. *"Given by Heaven or by man?"* means: was he born this way, or was he mutilated by man? Though the loss of a foot was clearly man’s doing, he said it was Heaven, not man. *"Heaven’s creation made him thus, solitary"* means that when Heaven created him, it intended for him to have only one foot. How do we know this? Because human appearance typically involves two feet walking side by side, yet his form stands apart from the multitude—this is Heaven’s design, not man’s. *"Shared"* (与) means paired. This idea suggests that in the world, excess and deficiency are all the work of creation; even what man does is ultimately the work of creation. Thus, when people encounter hardship, they should accept it with equanimity.

The marsh pheasant takes ten steps for a single peck, a hundred steps for a single drink. It does not wish to be kept in a cage; though its spirit may flourish, it is not content. The earlier discussion of accepting hardship with equanimity is like Pao Ding’s *"each time I encounter a joint, I see the difficulty"*—here, these lines borrow the marsh pheasant as a metaphor. They speak of human life in the world, where adversity is common, akin to treading on a tiger’s tail or walking within Yi’s drawn bow. The pheasant in the marsh takes ten steps for a single peck, a hundred steps for a single drink—this describes the difficulty of its sustenance. If kept in a cage, its food and drink would be abundant, yet the pheasant does not desire this. Thus, it is said: *"It does not wish to be kept in a cage."* Why does it not wish this? Though the caged pheasant’s food and drink are plentiful, and its spirit may seem to flourish, it is ultimately not at ease. *"Though its spirit may flourish, it is not content"*—*"flourish"* is pronounced *wang*; *"not content"* means not joyful. This idea suggests that one who truly cherishes their life will not drown in the mundane world but will instead preserve their own integrity.

When Lao Dan died, Qin Shi mourned him. After three cries, he departed. A disciple said: *"Was he not your master’s friend?"* *"He was."* *"Then is this manner of mourning acceptable?"*

chunks.original_text: 曰然始也 吾以为其人也 而今非也 向吾入而吊焉 有老者哭之如哭其子少者哭之如哭其母彼其所以防之必有不蕲言而言不蕲哭而哭者是遁天倍情忘其所受古者谓之遁天之刑庄子之学本于老子此处先把老子贬剥便是为贬剥尧舜夫子张本道我于老子亦无所私而况他人乎 三号而出言不用情也 弟子之问谓老子于秦失本朋友也 何其吊之如此不用情乎 夫子指秦失也 始者吾以为其人者言吾始以老子为非常之人也 今因吊之乃知其不为非常人也 何者老子之死其弟子之哭无老无少皆如此其悲哀此必老子未能去其形迹而有以感防门弟子之心故其言其哭哀且慕者有不期然而然也 天之所受本无物也 犹以有情相感则是忘其始者之所受而遁逃其天理背弃其情实如此皆得罪于天者故曰遁天之刑倍与背同 适来夫子时也适去夫子顺也安时而处顺哀乐不能入也古者谓是帝之悬解 上面既说了秦失一段就此却发明尽死生之理以结一篇盖欲人知其自然而然者于死生无所动其心而后可以养生也夫子有道者尊称之辞也言天地之间有道之士其来也亦适然而来其去也亦适然而去但当随其时而顺之既知其来去之适然则来亦不足为乐去亦不足为哀不能入者言不能动其心也悬者心有系着也帝者天也知天理之自然则天帝不能以死生系着我矣言虽天亦无奈我何也故曰帝之悬解 指穷于为薪火也不知其尽也 此死生之喻也谓如以薪炽火指其薪而观之则薪有穷尽之时而世间之火自古及今传而不绝未尝见其尽此三句奇文也死生之理固非可以言语尽且论其文前面讲理到此却把个譬喻结末岂非文字绝妙处 内篇人间世第四 前言养生此言人间世盖谓既有此身而处此世岂能尽绝人事但要人处得好耳看这般意思庄子何尝迂阔何尝不理防事便是外篇所谓物莫足为也而不可以不为一段意思 颜回见仲尼请行曰奚之曰将之卫曰奚为焉曰回闻卫君其年壮其行独轻用其国而不见其过轻用民死死者以国量乎泽若蕉民其无如矣 其年壮其行独者言少年自用不恤众议也轻用其国而不自知其过失轻民之生而戕贼之量其国中前后见杀者若泽中之蕉然谓轻民如草芥也荀子富国篇有曰以泽量与此意同本是若泽蕉却倒一字曰泽若蕉此是作文奇处云泽也梦亦泽也云梦昔皆为水今有土可耕不曰云梦土作乂而曰云土梦作又亦纤纩亦纤不曰纩纤而曰纤纩此文法也如往也民其无如者言其无所归也 回尝闻之夫子曰治国去之乱国就之医门多疾愿以所闻思其则庶几其国有瘳乎仲尼曰嘻若殆往而刑耳夫道不欲杂杂则多多则扰扰则忧忧而不救古之至人先存诸已而后存诸人所存于己者未定何暇至于暴人之所行且若亦知夫德之所荡而知之所为出乎哉德荡乎名知出乎争名也者相轧也知也者争之器也二者凶器非所以尽行也且德厚信矼未达人气名闻不争未达人心而强以仁义绳墨之言术暴人之前者是以人恶有其美也命之曰菑人菑人者人必反菑之若殆为人菑 有道则见无道则此圣贤之言也 庄子却反其说曰治国去之乱国就之谓如人能医必其门多疾之时方可行其术若是已治之国又何用我愿以所闻思其则言欲以所闻于夫子者而告之卫君使之思其法则而知改悔庶几其国可安也 若殆往而刑耳 若汝也

He replied: "Indeed. At first, I took him for a true man, but now I see he was not. When I entered to offer condolences, I saw elders weeping for him as if for their own sons, and the young weeping as if for their own mothers. The reason they restrained themselves to speak or weep only when compelled was to flee from Heaven and betray their true nature, forgetting what they had received. The ancients called this 'the punishment of fleeing from Heaven.' Zhuangzi’s teachings derive from Laozi, and here he first disparages Laozi—this is but the groundwork for disparaging Yao, Shun, and the Confucians. As for me, I hold no partiality toward Laozi, let alone others.

"Three cries and then departure—this was an expression of unfeeling conduct. The disciple’s question implied that Laozi and Qin Shi were friends, so why did he mourn so unfeelingly? My answer refers to Qin Shi. 'At first, I took him for a true man'—I initially believed Laozi to be an extraordinary person. But upon offering condolences, I realized he was not. Why? When Laozi died, his disciples, young and old alike, wept with such sorrow. This must mean Laozi had not shed his worldly traces, and something in him moved his disciples’ hearts, so that their words and tears of grief and longing arose unbidden. What Heaven bestows is originally formless, yet if one is moved by emotion, it is to forget one’s original endowment and flee from Heaven’s principle, betraying one’s true nature. Such a one offends against Heaven, hence the term 'the punishment of fleeing from Heaven'—*bei* means 'to betray.'

"To come when it is time and to depart when it is fitting—this is to dwell in accord with the times and follow their course, so that sorrow and joy cannot enter. The ancients called this 'the untying of Heaven’s bonds.' Having discussed Qin Shi’s conduct, I now clarify the principle of fully embracing life and death, concluding the chapter. The aim is for people to understand that what arises naturally should not disturb their hearts in matters of life and death, for only then can one nurture life. *Fuzi* is a term of respect for a man of the Dao. It means that among those with the Dao between Heaven and Earth, their coming is timely, and their going is fitting. One should simply follow the times and accord with them. Knowing that their coming and going are timely, one neither rejoices at arrival nor grieves at departure—this is what it means for sorrow and joy to 'not enter.' *Xuan* means the heart is bound; *Di* means Heaven. To know the naturalness of Heaven’s principle is to prevent Heaven from binding one with life and death. Though it be Heaven, it cannot constrain me—hence the term 'the untying of Heaven’s bonds.'

"A finger pointing to the firewood cannot exhaust the fire’s blaze—this is a metaphor for life and death. If you observe the firewood, it has a limit, but the fire in the world has been passed down from ancient times to the present without end. These three lines are a marvel of expression. The principle of life and death cannot be fully captured in words, yet in discussing the text, the preceding argument is concluded with this metaphor—is this not the most exquisite part of the writing?

*Inner Chapters, "The Human World," Chapter Four*
The previous section spoke of nurturing life; this one speaks of the human world. It means that once one has this body and dwells in this world, how can one completely sever human affairs? The key is to navigate them well. With such an understanding, how can Zhuangzi be called impractical? How can he be said to disregard human affairs? This aligns with the meaning of the Outer Chapters: 'Nothing is worth doing, yet nothing can be left undone.'

Yan Hui sought an audience with Confucius and asked to depart, saying: "Where are you going?" "I intend to go to Wei." "What will you do there?" "I have heard that the lord of Wei is young in years and acts alone. He governs his state lightly yet does not perceive his errors, and he treats the people’s lives as of little worth. The dead are measured by the state as if they were reeds in a marsh—how can the people endure this?" *His years are young, his conduct solitary*—this means he is young and self-willed, heedless of others’ counsel. *He governs his state lightly yet does not perceive his errors*—he misuses his state without recognizing his faults. *He treats the people’s lives as of little worth*—he harms and slaughters them. *The dead are measured by the state as if they were reeds in a marsh*—he treats the people as lightly as grass. Xunzi’s *Enriching the State* says: "measured by the marsh," which shares this meaning. Here, the phrase is inverted to "as if reeds in a marsh"—this is a marvel of composition. *Yun* means marsh, as in *Yunmeng*; in ancient times, it was all water, but now there is land to till. It is not called *Yunmeng soil* but *Yun soil, Meng land*—this is a literary technique. Similarly, *xuan* means fine silk, as does *kuang*; it is not called *xuankuang* but *xuan kuang*—another example of this technique. *How can the people endure this?*—it means they have nowhere to turn.

Hui had heard from the Master: "Where there is order, leave; where there is chaos, go—this is the teaching of the sages." But Zhuangzi reverses this, saying: "Where there is order, leave; where there is chaos, go." It is like a physician who can only practice when there are many illnesses. If a state is already well-governed, what need is there for me? *I wish to apply what I have heard and consider its principles*—this means he wishes to convey to the lord of Wei what he has heard from the Master, so that the lord might reflect on these principles and reform, perhaps bringing peace to his state.

Confucius said: "Alas! You will likely go and be punished. The Dao does not tolerate杂乱;杂乱 leads to excess, excess to disturbance, disturbance to anxiety, and anxiety to ruin. The utmost man first establishes himself before establishing others. If what is established in oneself is not secure, how can one attend to the conduct of violent men? Moreover, do you know what causes virtue to dissipate and knowledge to arise? Virtue dissipates for the sake of fame, and knowledge arises from contention. Fame is what people vie over, and knowledge is the tool of contention—both are inauspicious instruments, not the means to perfect conduct. Furthermore, if one’s virtue is profound and trust is firm, yet one’s *qi* does not reach others; if one’s fame is heard but not contended for, yet one forcibly imposes the language of benevolence, righteousness, rules, and techniques upon violent men, this is to make others resent what one considers beautiful. This is called 'bringing disaster upon others.' One who brings disaster upon others will have disaster reflected back upon them. You will likely bring disaster upon yourself.

*Where there is the Dao, appear; where there is no Dao, hide*—this is the teaching of the sages. But Zhuangzi reverses this, saying: "Where there is order, leave; where there is chaos, go." It means that if one can heal, one should do so only when there are many illnesses. If a state is already well-ordered, what use is there for me? *I wish to apply what I have heard and consider its principles*—he wishes to convey to the lord of Wei what he has heard from the Master, so that the lord might reflect on these principles and reform, perhaps bringing peace to his state."

You are perilously close to becoming one who will be executed—if you go there like this, you will only be put to death by them. It is better not to go.

The Dao does not desire杂: when this heart is unadulterated, it is pure, unified, empty, and luminous. If one harbors thoughts—considering how they are and how one might save them—this is already "harboring the heart," and within me, it is already杂. If I am not pure and unified, how can I save them?

杂 then 多: "many" refers to being scattered in many directions. 扰 means "chaos," and 忧 means "self-torment." You are tormenting yourself—how can you save others? The ancients first established what was within themselves before admonishing others. If what is within me is not settled, how can I attend to others? Though their conduct is violent and wicked, I am tormenting myself—how can I attend to others?

Virtue arises naturally. 知 is private cunning. The moment one harbors a desire for fame, one’s natural virtue is already lost. The moment one employs private cunning, contention arises. Thus it is said: virtue is lost through fame and cunning, and contention emerges from them.

争相轧 means "to overthrow one another." 争之器 refers to the tools of contention: if I use private cunning, they too will use private cunning, and the struggle will never cease. Fame and cunning are the most perilous affairs under heaven—if one insists on pursuing them, calamity is inevitable.

矼 means "thick," and 厚德 is "substantial virtue." 厚信 means "truly trustworthy conduct." Though I possess virtue and trustworthiness, if I do not understand their nature and qi, and though I may have a fine reputation and renown, if I do not comprehend their hearts—if I forcibly present the language of benevolence, righteousness, and legal standards before violent and wicked people—they will resent what you consider beautiful.

绳墨 refers to legal standards, and 术 is synonymous with 述. 菑人 means "one who brings disaster." They will surely call you a "disaster-bringer," and once this name is given, disaster will reflect back upon you. If you go now, you will likely bring disaster upon yourself—how can you transform the lord of Wei and save his state?

Moreover, if one merely delights in the worthy and despises the unworthy, what need is there to seek distinction? If you do not await the summons of kings and lords, they will surely take advantage of you, contend for victory, and your eyes will flicker in distress, your complexion will flatten in submission, your mouth will stammer in defense, your demeanor will reveal fear, and your heart will yield to compliance.

This is like using fire to fight fire, water to fight water—it is called "adding more." Following this path without end, if you persist in speaking earnestly to those who do not trust you, you will surely die before violent men.

If they truly knew the worthy and delighted in them, knew the unworthy and despised them, what need would there be for me to seek further distinction? It is precisely because they do not distinguish between worthy and unworthy that they act as they do. If they do not recognize worthiness, how will they know you are worthy and trust your words?

诏 means "summons." 若汝 refers to you. The lord of Wei has not summoned you, so if you go uninvited, he, as a lord, will surely take advantage of your words to contend for victory. When you are thus cornered, your eyes will flicker in distress, your complexion will flatten in submission, your mouth will stammer in defense, your demeanor will reveal fear, and your heart will yield to compliance.

Emperor Wu of Liang’s debate with He Chen perfectly illustrates this pattern—it speaks of contention that ends in defeat and self-submission. If the other party is violent and gains the upper hand, their momentum will only grow stronger, like using water to fight water or fire to fight fire—only adding more.

chunks.original_text: 益多者言増多其恶也 顺此而往则其为恶愈无穷极所为暴戾益甚矣 厚言者犹深言也 汝未有以信于人乃以不信之身而深言于暴人之前必为其所杀也 且昔者桀杀关龙逢纣杀王子比干是修其身以下伛拊人之民以下拂其上者也 故其君因其修以挤之是好名者也 昔者尧攻丛枝胥敖禹攻有扈国为虚厉身为刑戮其用兵不止其求实无已是皆求名实者也 而独不闻之乎 名实者圣人之所不能胜也 而况若乎 龙逢比干皆修其身以爱民为谏不知民自别人之民汝乃下而伛拊之伛拊爱养之意也 桀纣不爱民而汝乃爱桀纣之民是下拂其上也 所以见杀修善也 因其好善反以挤怒之谓此皆好名之过也 丛枝胥敖有扈皆是寓言国为邱墟死为厉厉无后无归之也 丛枝胥敖有扈之所以取祸至此者皆用兵不止以求名实也 实利也 不能胜言不能堪也 言求名自利之人虽尧禹且不能堪至于灭其国而况汝乎 胜音升尧禹无此事皆寓言也 虽然若必有以也尝以语我来颜回曰端而虚勉而一则可乎曰恶恶可夫以阳为充孔采色不定常人之所不违因案人之所感以求容与其心名之曰日渐之德不成而况大德乎将执而不化外合而内不訾其庸讵可乎 又设一转言汝之欲往也 必有所以以用也
chunks.translated_text:
The phrase "益多" refers to the multiplication of their evil. If you follow this path, their wickedness will grow boundless, and their violence and tyranny will only intensify. "厚言" means to speak deeply or excessively. If you have not yet earned others' trust and yet, with your untrustworthy self, speak at length before a violent man, you will surely be killed by him.

Consider the past: Jie killed Guan Longfeng, and Zhou killed Prince Bigan—both were men who cultivated themselves, humbled themselves to care for the people, and thus opposed their superiors. Their rulers, seizing upon their cultivation, cast them out—such are those who covet reputation. In ancient times, Yao attacked Congzhi and Xu'ao, and Yu attacked the state of Youhu. Their lands were laid waste, their bodies executed, their warfare unceasing, their pursuit of substance insatiable—all were seekers of fame and gain. Have you not heard of this? Fame and substance are things even the sages cannot overcome—how much less can one like you?

Guan Longfeng and Bigan cultivated themselves and admonished out of love for the people, not realizing that the people were not their own. You, however, lower yourself to care for them—"伛拊" means to cherish and nurture. Jie and Zhou did not love the people, yet you love the people of Jie and Zhou. This is opposing one's superior, and thus they were killed. Their cultivation of goodness was used against them, provoking anger—this is the fault of those who crave reputation.

Congzhi, Xu'ao, and Youhu are allegorical states, reduced to ruins, their dead becoming vengeful spirits—"厉" refers to those without descendants or refuge. The reason these states met such disaster was their unceasing warfare in pursuit of fame and substance. "实" means profit. "不能胜" means unable to endure. Those who seek fame and self-interest—even Yao and Yu could not endure it, leading to the destruction of their states—how much less can you?

"胜" is read as *shēng*. Yao and Yu did not actually do these things; they are allegories. Nevertheless, if you must have a method, I once spoke of this to Yan Hui: "Be upright yet empty, strive yet unified—would this suffice?" He replied, "How could it be so simple? To present yang as fullness, to display shifting colors—this is what ordinary people do not resist. They follow others' inclinations to seek favor, and their hearts are named 'the virtue of gradual encroachment.' If even this is not achieved, how much less can great virtue be? They cling rigidly without transformation, outwardly compliant yet inwardly unyielding—how can this be sufficient?"

This is another turn: if you insist on going, you must have a purpose for doing so.

chunks.original_text: 且试以语我尝试也 来助语也 端而虚者端正其身虚豁其心也 勉而一者黾勉而谨终如始也 能如此则可否恶恶可者言甚不可也 阳为充孔者言得志之人阳气方充满其貌甚扬扬自得孔甚也 采色不定者言其骄矜之色不常也 寻常之人每每不敢违而顺之畏之也 彼见人人皆畏已而汝欲以言语感动之彼将求欲案服汝心以快其意故曰求容与其心容与自快之意日渐小德也 言汝此等人名之曰小德且不能成况能成大德乎 执而不化者固执而不能回也 若如此则外将以端虚而求合于人内则守其勉而一者谓我在内无所訾病伎俩止于如此讵能自以为可乎 然则我内直而外曲成而上比内直者与天为徒与天为徒者知天子之与已皆天之所子而独以已言蕲乎而人善之蕲乎而人不善之邪若然者人谓之童子是之谓与天为徒外曲者与人之为徒也擎跽曲拳人臣之礼也人皆为之吾敢不为邪为人之所为者人亦无疵焉是之谓与人为徒成而上比者与古为徒其言虽教谪之实也古之有也非吾有也若然者虽直不为病是之谓与古为徒若是则可乎 然则而下又设为颜子之答分作三截内直者内以此理自守其真实也 此直字与真字相似自天子之贵下而与我皆天之所生则是皆出于自然者岂敢以已言自私欲人善其是者不善其非者若无此自私之心则其浑浑若童子然则与天合矣 故曰与天为徒外曲者外尽擎跽曲拳之礼人人皆为之则我亦为之人于我亦无疵病此因拜下礼也 虽违众吾从下处生此等议论以讥诮圣门如此则与人合故曰与人为徒成者自已之成说也 比合也 以自已之成说而上合于古人言引古人以为证也 虽借古人教诲之言乃是当面陈说是非而皆有谴谪之实盖谓我之所言非出于我古人已有之言也 若如此则虽讦直以暴其所行而人亦不以为罪故曰虽直而不病与古为徒者言其说与古人合也 若是则可者言如此可以说卫君否也 仲尼曰恶恶可太多政法而不谍虽固亦无罪虽然止是耳矣夫胡可以及化犹师心者也 政事也法方法也谓汝所言事目方法太多而终是不安谍谍音叠安也虽能如此三者固亦无罪然亦止于自免而已安可以化人故曰胡可以及化此其病在何处盖汝三者之说皆是师其有为之心便是容心便非无迹便非自然之道 颜回曰吾无以进矣敢问其方仲尼曰斋吾将语若有而为之其易邪易之者皞天不宜颜回曰回之家贫唯不饮酒不茹荤者数月矣若此则可以为斋乎曰是祭祀之斋非心斋也回曰敢问心斋仲尼曰若一志无听之以耳而听之以心无听之以心而听之以气听止于耳心止于符气也者虚而待物者也唯道集虚虚者心斋也 无以进者言更无向上着也有而为之其易邪言汝道汝有此伎俩要为之甚易邪才萌此轻易之心则皞天之意不相乐矣故曰易之者皞天不宜此两句最是人生受用切实处祭祀之斋在外心斋在内一志者一其心而不杂也听之以耳则听犹在外听之以心则听犹在我听之以气则无物矣听以耳则止于耳而不入于心听以心则外物必有与我相符合者便是物我对立也气者顺自然而待物以虚虚即为道矣虚者道之所在故曰唯道集虚即此虚字便是心斋 颜回曰回之未始得使实自回也得使之也未始有回也可谓虚乎夫子曰尽矣 得使言得教诲也此为颜子顿悟之言谓未得教诲之时犹自有我及既得教诲之后未始有我矣忘我则虚也尽矣者谓汝之所言尽其理矣
chunks.translated_text:
Moreover, let me put it to the test—this is but an attempt at discourse, an aid to conversation. "Be upright yet empty" means to rectify your person while keeping your mind open and vast. "Strive yet unified" means to exert yourself diligently, ever consistent from beginning to end. If you can do this, is it sufficient? "How could it be so simple?"—this is to say, it is far from sufficient.

"To present yang as fullness, to display shifting colors"—this describes those who, having attained success, are filled with yang qi, their demeanor swelling with self-satisfaction, their bearing exceedingly proud. "Shifting colors" refers to their haughty expressions, which never settle. Ordinary people dare not oppose them, instead yielding and deferring out of fear. Seeing that everyone fears them, if you seek to move them with words, they will only demand that you submit to their will to gratify their desires. Thus it is said: "to seek favor," for their hearts delight in such compliance. This is called "the virtue of gradual encroachment." If even this petty virtue cannot be achieved, how much less can great virtue?

"Clinging rigidly without transformation"—this means obstinately refusing to change. If you act thus, outwardly you may feign uprightness and emptiness to conform to others, but inwardly you cling to your "striving yet unified" resolve, believing yourself free of fault. How can this be deemed sufficient? If, however, you are inwardly straight and outwardly yielding, achieving harmony with what is above—then "inwardly straight" means guarding this principle within, preserving your true nature. This "straightness" resembles "truth." From the nobility of the Son of Heaven down to yourself, all are children of Heaven, all arising from the natural. How dare you, with your own words, seek to make others approve of what you deem right and disapprove of what you deem wrong? Without this self-serving heart, you remain as guileless as a child, thus merging with Heaven. This is called "being a companion to Heaven."

"Outwardly yielding" means fully observing the rites of bowing, kneeling, and prostrating—acts of ministerial deference. If everyone does this, why should I alone refuse? To do what others do is to avoid their censure. This is called "being a companion to man." "Achieving harmony with what is above" means aligning with the ancients, becoming their companion. Though your words may seem to instruct or rebuke, they are in truth the sayings of the ancients, not your own. If so, even blunt honesty will not be faulted. This is called "being a companion to the ancients." If you act thus, is it sufficient?

Yet if you descend further, consider Yan Hui’s reply, divided into three parts:

"Inwardly straight" means inwardly preserving this principle, guarding your true nature. From the exalted Son of Heaven to yourself, all are born of Heaven, all arise naturally. How dare you, with your own words, seek to make others approve of your rightness and disapprove of your wrongness? Without this self-serving heart, you remain as pure as a child, thus merging with Heaven. Hence, it is said: "being a companion to Heaven."

"Outwardly yielding" means fully performing the rites of bowing, kneeling, and prostrating—acts everyone observes. If I too observe them, others will find no fault in me. Though this may seem to follow the crowd, such compliance arises from humility. These discussions mock the sagely gate with such reasoning, yet they align with others. Hence, it is said: "being a companion to man."

"Achieving" refers to your own established doctrines. "Harmony with what is above" means aligning your doctrines with the ancients, citing them as evidence. Though you borrow the ancients' teachings, your words are direct rebukes, yet because they are not your own, even bluntness incurs no blame. This is called "being a companion to the ancients." If you act thus, is it sufficient?

Confucius said: "How could it be so simple? Too many policies and methods, yet no tranquility—though steadfast, you remain blameless, yet this is all it amounts to. How can it extend to transformation? You are still guided by your own mind." "Policies" refer to affairs of governance; "methods" to their implementation. Your words propose too many measures, yet they never settle into peace. Though you may achieve these three things and remain blameless, this only spares you from fault—how can it transform others? Thus it is said: "How can it extend to transformation?" Where lies the flaw? In your three doctrines, you are still guided by a mind of deliberate action, still harboring intentions, still leaving traces—far from the natural Dao.

Yan Hui said: "I have no further progress to make. May I ask the method?" Confucius replied: "Fast, and I will tell you. If you undertake this with preconceptions, will it be easy? To treat it as easy is to estrange Heaven—this is not fitting."

Yan Hui said: "My family is poor. For months, I have not drunk wine or eaten meat. Is this fasting?" Confucius said: "This is the fasting of sacrifice, not the fasting of the mind."

Yan Hui said: "May I ask about the fasting of the mind?" Confucius replied: "Unify your will. Do not listen with your ears, but listen with your mind. Do not listen with your mind, but listen with qi. Listening stops at the ears; the mind stops at signs. Qi is emptiness that awaits things. Only the Dao gathers in emptiness. Emptiness is the fasting of the mind."

"I have no further progress to make"—this means no higher attainment remains. "If you undertake this with preconceptions, will it be easy?" If you think your skills suffice to act with ease, the moment this frivolous thought arises, you estrange the vastness of Heaven. Hence, it is said: "To treat it as easy is to estrange Heaven—this is not fitting." These two lines are most vital for one’s life and practice.

The fasting of sacrifice is external; the fasting of the mind is internal. "Unify your will" means focusing the mind without distraction. Listening with the ears is still external; listening with the mind is still within oneself. Listening with qi is to be without thing. Listening with the ears stops at the ears and does not enter the mind; listening with the mind means external things must align with me, creating opposition between thing and self. Qi follows the natural and awaits things with emptiness. Emptiness is where the Dao resides. Hence, it is said: "Only the Dao gathers in emptiness." This "emptiness" is the fasting of the mind.

Yan Hui said: "Before I received your instruction, there was indeed a Yan Hui. Having received it, there is no longer a Yan Hui. Can this be called emptiness?" Confucius said: "It is complete."

"Received instruction" means having been taught. This is Yan Hui’s sudden awakening: before receiving instruction, there was still a self; after receiving it, there is no longer a self. Forgetting the self is emptiness. "It is complete" means your words exhaust the principle.

chunks.original_text: 吾语若若能入游其樊而无感其名入则鸣不入则止无门无毒一宅而寓于不得已则几矣 若汝也人世如在樊笼之中汝能入其中而游不为虚名所感动有迹则可名才至有迹则是动其心矣处世无心则无迹无迹则心无所动故曰游其樊而无感其名自此以下正是教人处世之法入则鸣是可与之言而与之言也不入则止是不可与之言而不与之言也意与论语同但文奇耳有方所则有门无方所则无门矣有臭味则有毒无臭味则无毒矣毒药味也此皆无心无迹之喻宅居也以混然之一为吾所居而寓此心于不得已之中则人间世之道尽矣几尽也 绝迹易无行地难 迹足迹也止而不行则绝无足迹此为易事然人岂能不行哉必行于地而无行地之迹则为难此意盖谓人若事事不为此却易事然谓之人生何者非事安得不为唯无为而无所不为则为难也 为人使易以伪为天使难以伪 为人使易以伪言为人欲所役则易至于欺伪唯防心而听造物之所使则无所容伪矣人使即人欲也天使即天理之日用者也难易二字有意易易流也难无所容其伪也 闻以有翼飞者矣未闻以无翼飞者也闻以有知知者矣未闻以无知知者也 闻以有翼飞者矣言鸟之飞必以翼也无翼而飞便是不疾而速不行而至此所谓神也此句乃喻下句盖以有知为知人之常也惟知其所不知则为无知之知此则造道之妙矣 瞻彼阕者虚室生白吉祥止止夫且不止是之谓坐驰瞻视也此以虚室喻心也谓视彼密室之中才有空缺处必有光入来是光自空中出也以彼之阕喻我之虚则见虚中自然生明生白即生明也不曰生明而曰生白此庄子之奇文也即此虚明之地便是万物之所由萃吉祥福也止于其所止下止字是虚处也唯止则虚唯虚则明便是戒生定定生慧之意若我才容心而不能自止则身虽坐于此而心驰于外又安能坐忘乎此以坐驰二字反说坐忘也 夫徇耳目内通而外于心知鬼神将来舍而况人乎是万物之化也禹舜之所纽也伏羲几蘧之所行终而况散焉者乎 耳

I speak to you: if you can enter and wander within its bounds without being moved by its reputation—entering, then you may respond; not entering, then cease—without gate, without poison, abiding in one dwelling and lodging in inevitability, then you are near. You, living in the world, are as if in a cage. If you can enter it and wander within without being stirred by hollow fame, then where there are traces, names may arise; but where traces arise, the mind is already moved. Moving through the world without intent leaves no trace; without trace, the mind remains unmoved. Thus it is said: "Wander within its bounds without being moved by its reputation." What follows is precisely the method for navigating the world: "Entering, then respond" means speaking when one may be spoken to; "not entering, then cease" means not speaking when one may not be spoken to. The meaning aligns with the *Analects*, though the phrasing is striking. Where there is a fixed place, there is a gate; where there is no fixed place, there is no gate. Where there is scent and flavor, there is poison; where there is no scent or flavor, there is no poison. Poison is the taste of medicine—all metaphors for being without intent or trace. A dwelling is where one resides; if you take this undifferentiated unity as your abode and lodge this mind in inevitability, then the Way of living in the human world is complete. *Ji* means "near completion."

"Erasing traces is easy; leaving no tracks while walking on the earth is difficult." Traces are footprints. To stop and not walk is to leave no footprints—this is easy. But how can one not walk? One must walk upon the earth, yet leaving no tracks while doing so is difficult. This means that if one refrains from all action, it is easy, but how can one live without acting? Since every aspect of life involves action, the challenge lies in acting without acting—this is difficult.

"Serving man is easy when feigning; serving Heaven is difficult when feigning." Serving man is easy when feigning, for one is driven by human desires and readily resorts to deception. But if one guards the mind and follows the workings of creation, there is no room for pretense. "Serving man" refers to human desires; "serving Heaven" refers to the daily application of Heavenly principle. The words "easy" and "difficult" carry meaning: the easy path leads to dissipation, while the difficult path leaves no room for pretense.

"I have heard of flying with wings, but never of flying without wings. I have heard of knowing with knowledge, but never of knowing without knowledge." "I have heard of flying with wings" means birds must fly with wings; flying without wings is to arrive swiftly without haste, to reach without walking—this is the marvel of the spirit. This phrase serves as a metaphor for the following line. Ordinarily, people know through knowledge, but knowing what one does not know is the knowledge of no-knowledge—this is the subtlety of attaining the Dao.

"Look at that empty chamber: when the room is vacant, brightness is born. Auspiciousness abides where it abides. But if one does not abide, this is called sitting in motion." *Zhan* means to gaze. This uses the empty chamber as a metaphor for the mind: when you observe that even in a sealed room, light enters through the smallest opening, the light emerges from emptiness. Comparing that emptiness to the mind’s vacancy, you see that from emptiness, clarity naturally arises—brightness is born. It does not say "brightness is born" but "whiteness is born," a striking turn of phrase by Zhuangzi. This state of empty clarity is where the myriad things gather, where auspiciousness dwells. "Abiding where it abides"—the second *zhi* refers to the empty place. Only by abiding can there be emptiness; only in emptiness can there be clarity, reflecting the principle that stillness gives rise to concentration, and concentration gives rise to wisdom. But if the mind is not restrained and cannot abide, though the body sits still, the mind races outward—how can one achieve sitting in forgetfulness? This is the meaning of "sitting in motion," the inverse of sitting in forgetfulness.

"When one follows the ears and eyes inward and is outwardly free from the mind’s knowledge, even spirits will come to dwell—how much more so men? This is the transformation of the myriad things, the pivot of Yu and Shun, the path nearly grasped by Fuxi and nearly trod by Qi. How much more so for those who are scattered and fragmented?"

The ears’ hearing and eyes’ seeing all inwardly connect to the heart—if I harbor no thoughts within, then I follow the hearing of the ears and seeing of the eyes. Though they inwardly connect, they are in truth external to the heart’s knowledge. What does it mean to be "external to the heart’s knowledge"? It means the heart remains unmoved, and external things cannot enter. Though one hears what is heard and sees what is seen, there is no heart engaged in hearing or seeing. In this way, the emptiness of this heart communes with spirits—how much more so with men? This is to say, only thus can one transform and influence others. "Spirits come to dwell" means that with utmost sincerity, this heart naturally harbors spirits and communes with the Creator. Thus, having expounded this, the text concludes with a single phrase: *This is the transformation of the myriad things.* This speaks of the principle of creation, the source from which all things arise. This was the great pivot seen by Shun and Yu, the path nearly trod by Fuxi and Qi to the end of their lives—how much more so for those beneath them? *Qi* may refer to an ancient sage-king, though no record confirms this; it is likely a figurative reference. *Scattered* refers to ordinary people. The text now shifts to further elucidate this, not adhering to the previous passage.

Ye Gong Zi Gao was about to be sent as an envoy to Qi. He asked Confucius, saying: "The king’s charge to Zhu Liang is of great weight. Qi’s treatment of envoys is reverent yet not urgent. Even a common man cannot be moved lightly—how much more so a feudal lord? I am deeply fearful. You once told Zhu Liang: ‘In all matters, great or small, few succeed without speaking harmoniously to bring them to fruition. If a matter fails, one will surely face the calamities of human law; if it succeeds, one will surely face the calamities of yin and yang. Only one of virtue can ensure no calamity follows, whether the matter succeeds or fails.’ I eat coarse food without discerning its coarseness, and my cooking stove remains cold from lack of use. Now, upon receiving my charge this morning, I drink ice by evening—have I not inwardly exhausted myself? I have not yet fully grasped the nature of the matter, yet I already face the calamities of yin and yang. If the matter fails, I will surely face the calamities of human law. These are twofold perils. As a minister, I am unworthy of this task. You must instruct me further."

*Zhu Liang* was Ye Gong’s name; *Zi Gao* was his courtesy name. "The charge to Zhu Liang is of great weight" means the mission to Qi is a grave responsibility. "Reverent yet not urgent" describes their treatment of envoys as courteous but slow in response. Even common men, when engaged, may not reciprocate—how much more so feudal lords? This is why he trembles with fear. *Zi* refers to the Master (Confucius). He once taught me: "In affairs, great or small, few succeed without speaking harmoniously to achieve their completion." *Few* means rare; *not speaking* means not communicating. In governing, if a matter fails, one will surely face punishment, hence "the calamities of human law." If one labors over calculations and schemes to succeed, excessive worry and stress will lead to illness, hence "the calamities of yin and yang." Only one of virtue can ensure no calamity follows, whether the matter succeeds or fails. All the above are Confucius’ words.

Now, since receiving the mission, I no longer taste my food—whether coarse or fine, I do not discern it. *Fine* means refined. Ordinarily, frequent meals keep the kitchen stove warm, but now, with little food due to worry, the stove remains cold. Moreover, upon receiving the charge this morning, my heart was already scorched, and by evening, I drank ice. *Nature* means reality. I have only just received the charge and not yet fully grasped the matter, yet I already suffer this affliction. If the matter fails, I will face punishment—thus, I suffer twofold calamities. As a minister, I am truly unequal to this task. *You must instruct me further* means, "What teaching can you offer me?" *Come* is an auxiliary word.
