**Outer Chapters: "Webbed Toes" (Chapter Eight)**

Webbed toes and extra fingers arise from nature, yet they exceed virtue; growths and tumors emerge from form, yet they exceed nature. To multiply methods of benevolence and righteousness and apply them is to array them in the five organs, yet this is not the true alignment of the Dao and virtue. Thus, webbed toes are but connected useless flesh, and extra fingers are but superfluous digits. To multiply methods and apply them to the passions of the five organs is to indulge in perverse acts of benevolence and righteousness, and to overuse one’s intelligence.

The big toe and the fingers are natural; *pian* (webbed) means joined, and *zhi* (extra) means branching. What is born with one is called *xing* (nature), and what all humans share is called *de* (virtue). Webbed toes and extra fingers are deformities, yet when compared to what all humans share, they become excessive. Here, the meanings of *xing* and *de* differ slightly from those of the sages. Growths and tumors are also deformities, but while webbed toes and extra fingers exist from birth, growths and tumors arise after form has taken shape—hence it is said they *"emerge from form yet exceed nature."* *Duo fang* (multiplying methods) means employing many approaches; *"applying them"* refers to their external use. *"Arrayed in the five organs"* means they do not arise from within. Since they are not the natural Dao, it is said they are *"not the true alignment of the Dao and virtue."* Gaozi spoke of righteousness as external; Zhuangzi goes further, treating even benevolence as external. He regards benevolence and righteousness as perverse indulgences and groups them with intelligence, all of which he sees as contrary to the learning of inward cultivation. Thus, he perceives them as meddlesome and excessive—*"multiplying methods"* is akin to *"meddling."*

Therefore, those whose vision is webbed are confounded by the five colors, indulging in ornate patterns—are not the dazzling blues and yellows, the embroidered *fu* and *fu* of court robes, the work of Li Zhu? Those whose hearing is multiplied are confounded by the five tones, indulging in the six pitches—are not the sounds of metal, stone, silk, and bamboo, the grand harmonies of *Huang Zhong* and *Da Lü*, the work of Shi Kuang? Those who branch into benevolence pluck at virtue to block their nature, seeking fame and causing the world to clamor like reeds in the wind, upholding laws that fall short—are these not the deeds of Zengzi and Shishi? Those whose eloquence is webbed pile up tiles and knot ropes, weaving phrases and wandering in the labyrinths of *"hard and white"* and *"same and different,"* exhausting themselves in empty praise and useless words—are these not the ways of Yangzi and Mozi? Thus, all these are the paths of excessive branching and webbed growths, not the ultimate correctness of the world.

The five colors and ornate patterns—blues, yellows, *fu*, and *fu*—were used in antiquity to nurture the eyes, yet Zhuangzi saw them as chaotic and indulgent. Thus, *"webbed vision"* echoes Laozi’s *"the five colors blind the eyes."* Li Zhu was a man of keen sight. If one doubts this, those who employ such vision will insist it is right.

Thus it is said: "Is this not so?"—yet Li Zhu is affirmed in this. The same applies to those who overreach in hearing and intention. For they treat ritual and music as external things. *"Tugging"* means to pull out, and *"blocking"* is like saying *"thatch-blocked."* Virtue and nature are fundamentally quiescent, yet forcing oneself to practice benevolence is to tug at virtue and block one’s nature. *"Laws"* are standards, and *"falling short"* refers to what people find difficult to attain. Compelling others to follow laws that are hard to follow—hence it is said: *"making the world pipe and drum to uphold laws that fall short."* *"Piping and drumming"* describes how words beguile and stir. To pile up tiles and knot ropes is to engage in futile affairs; the excessive speech of sophists drags on endlessly, layering without end and devoid of meaning—thus it is compared to piling tiles and knotting ropes. *"Refining"* means revising, as in revising one’s phrases to craft arguments—hence it is said: *"weaving phrases and wandering in the labyrinths of 'hard and white' and 'same and different.'"* *"Exhausting"* means laboring. *"Kui"* is pronounced like *"qi"*—to stand on tiptoe. Their words are all useless, yet they take pride in empty praise, toiling in vain—hence it is said: *"exhausting themselves in empty praise and useless words."* If one doubts this, then the followers of Yangzi and Mozi will insist it is right.

*"Excessive branching and webbed growths"* means superfluity. The Dao of nature is fundamentally without excess, yet all these are superfluous affairs, not the ultimate correctness. Ultimate correctness is the principle of what is inherently so. That which is ultimately correct does not lose the true condition of its nature and life—thus what is joined is not called *"webbed,"* what is branched is not called *"overreaching,"* what is long is not called *"excessive,"* and what is short is not called *"deficient."* Therefore, though the teal’s legs are short, lengthening them brings sorrow; though the crane’s legs are long, severing them brings grief. Thus, what is long by nature cannot be cut, and what is short by nature cannot be extended—there is no sorrow to be removed. Is benevolence and righteousness not contrary to human nature? Why do they bring so much sorrow?

Ultimate correctness means what is naturally so. What is naturally so does not lose the true principle of its nature and life—though joined, it is not *"webbed";* though branched, it is not *"overreaching";* though long, it is not *"excessive";* though short, it is not *"deficient."* These lines are deeply resonant, echoing the earlier saying: *"Nothing in the world is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, yet Mount Tai is small."* *"Overreaching"* means to rise on tiptoe—where there is overreaching, there is no levelness; without levelness, there is no ease. Observe how deliberately these words are chosen—how could they be careless? *"Long by nature"* and *"short by nature"* mean that length and shortness arise from one’s inherent nature. What is long or short by nature is at peace—there is no sorrow to remove. The analogy of the teal and crane is most apt. *"Yi"* here is a sigh. Speaking of these two extremes, benevolence and righteousness are excessive—are they not contrary to human nature? Thus, if benevolence and righteousness arose naturally, they would not bring such sorrow. *"Much sorrow"* refers to the toil of those who practice benevolence and righteousness.

In Zhuangzi’s words, from Confucius and Mencius back to Yao, Shun, Yu, and Tang, all fall within the scope of his mockery. Moreover, those with webbed toes weep when they are split, and those with extra fingers wail when they are bitten—whether in excess or deficiency, their sorrow is the same. Now, the benevolent of this world furrow their brows in worry over the world’s calamities, while the unbenevolent sever the true condition of their nature and life to greedily pursue wealth and honor. Is benevolence and righteousness not contrary to human nature? Since the Three Dynasties, why has the world been so clamorous?

Though webbed fingers and extra digits are both afflictions, they cannot be forcibly removed—removing them brings sorrow. *"Branched"* means an extra finger—hence it is said: *"in excess of the proper number."* *"Webbed"* means two fingers joined and inseparable—hence it is said: *"deficient in the proper number."* *"Furrowed brows"* means half-closed eyes; when one wishes to close them but cannot, the lashes bristle like reeds—hence it is said: *"furrowed brows."* *"Furrowed"* refers to the mugwort and wormwood. *"Furrowed brows"* conveys the sense of sitting alone in sorrow, a deliberate choice of words by Zhuangzi to describe the toil of the benevolent who worry over the world’s calamities. The unbenevolent, greedy for wealth and honor, destroy their nature and life. Both bring self-inflicted suffering—hence they are spoken of together. Again, he sighs: *"Is benevolence and righteousness not contrary to human nature?"*

—are these not the ways of Yangzi and Mozi? Thus, all these are the paths of excessive branching and webbed growths, not the ultimate correctness of the world.

The five colors and ornate patterns—blues, yellows, *fu*, and *fu*—were used in antiquity to nurture the eyes, yet Zhuangzi saw them as chaotic and indulgent. Thus, *"webbed vision"* echoes Laozi’s *"the five colors blind the eyes."* Li Zhu was a man of keen sight. If one doubts this, those who employ such vision will insist it is right.

Viewed in this light, benevolence, righteousness, and trustworthiness do not arise from what is inherently so. *"Clamorous"* means noisy and chaotic. Since the Three Dynasties and below, how boisterously this doctrine has prevailed! Moreover, those who rely on hooks, cords, compasses, and squares to set things right are carving away at their nature; those who depend on ropes, glue, and lacquer to make things firm are encroaching upon their virtue. To bend and twist with rites and music, to soothe and coax with benevolence and righteousness in order to comfort the hearts of the world—this is to lose what is constant and natural. Nature is what is spontaneous; virtue is what is self-attained from Heaven. Neither is the work of human effort. If one must await cultivation and refinement before things are set right, this is self-mutilation. Hooks, cords, ropes, glue, and lacquer are all metaphors for cultivation. To encroach, carve, mutilate, and destroy—this is to fix and solidify. To bend one’s body for rites and music, to coax with words for benevolence and righteousness, and thereby seek to comfort the hearts of the world—all this is to lose the principle of inherent nature. Hence it is said: *"to lose what is constant and natural."* *"To soothe and coax"* is like a mother’s gentle nurturing.

What is constant and natural in the world? That which is crooked is not made straight by hooks, that which is straight is not made so by cords, that which is round is not made so by compasses, that which is square is not made so by squares. That which is joined or separated does not rely on glue and lacquer, nor is it bound by ropes and cords. Thus, all things in the world grow enticingly of themselves, yet none know how they grow; all attain their due, yet none know how they attain it. From ancient times to the present, this principle has never varied—it cannot be diminished. Then why must benevolence and righteousness cling unceasingly like glue and lacquer, like ropes and cords, wandering between the Dao and virtue? This only serves to confuse the world.

The lines below *"what is constant and natural"* share the same meaning as *"that which joins does not form extra limbs, that which stands does not grow an extra toe."* Whether crooked or straight, round or square, joined or separated, or subjected to restraint—all should arise from spontaneity without reliance on human effort; only then is it the correct principle. *"Enticingly"* is like *"weeds"*—though weeds grow of themselves, who causes them to grow? What all things share—who bestows it? It is all spontaneous. Hence it is said: *"none know how they grow, none know how they attain it."* *"From ancient times to the present, never varied"* means one and the same, enduring through all ages without diminution. *"Unceasingly"* means without end. Glue and lacquer bind fast; ropes and cords constrain. To depart from one’s nature in pursuit of benevolence and righteousness, persisting without end, is to become bound and constrained—how then can one wander through the gate of the Dao and virtue? This only serves to confuse the world.

Zhuangzi and Mencius were contemporaries. Mencius spoke solely of benevolence and righteousness; Zhuangzi spoke solely of the Dao and virtue. Thus, his writings consistently suppress benevolence and righteousness while expounding spontaneity, which has its own lofty subtleties. Yet his words often exceed what is fitting. Generally speaking, Zhuangzi’s conception of benevolence and righteousness differs in meaning from Mencius’s. Readers should recognize and distinguish this for themselves.

Minor delusion confounds one’s direction; great delusion alters one’s nature. How do we know this is so? Since the time of Yu’s dynasty, when benevolence and righteousness were summoned to disturb the world, none have not rushed to answer the call of benevolence and righteousness. Is this not using benevolence and righteousness to alter one’s nature? Let us examine this: since the Three Dynasties and below, none in the world have not exchanged their nature for external things. The petty man sacrifices himself for profit; the scholar sacrifices himself for fame; the grandee sacrifices himself for his house; the sage sacrifices himself for the world. Though these several types differ in their undertakings and their reputations vary, in harming their nature and sacrificing themselves, they are one and the same. *"Delusion"* means confusion; *"direction"* refers to the four directions.

In minor delusion, east and west, south and north become transposed; in great delusion, one loses the nature of Heaven and Earth. The upper line illustrates the lower: "summoning" is like what people today call a signboard. Erecting the name of benevolence and righteousness to disturb and confuse the world, it causes all under Heaven to rush toward benevolence and righteousness, hastening at its beck and call. Knowing benevolence and righteousness but not knowing the virtue of the Dao—this is exchanging one’s nature for external things. The petty man is enslaved to profit; the gentleman, to fame; the minister, to his house; the ruler, to the world. *"Enslaved"* means to forget oneself in following it—this is called *"enslavement."* From Zhuangzi’s perspective, the world, the state, fame, and profit are all external things. To speak of the world and the state alongside fame and profit is to diminish the great with the small, to humble the high with the low—this is largely the method throughout the text.

These several types—referring to the sage, the minister, the scholar, and the petty man—though their undertakings and reputations differ, in forgetting themselves and harming their nature, they are one. All these are the errors of enslavement to things.

Zang and Gu were two men who herded sheep together and both lost their sheep. When asked what Zang was doing, he replied, "Holding a bamboo slip and reading." When asked what Gu was doing, he replied, "Gambling for sport." Though their pursuits differed, in losing their sheep, they were the same. Boyi died for fame beneath Shouyang Mountain, while Robber Zhi died for profit upon Dongling Heights. Though what they died for differed, in maiming their lives and harming their nature, they were the same. Why must Boyi be right and Robber Zhi wrong? All under Heaven are enslaved. Those who are enslaved to benevolence and righteousness are commonly called gentlemen; those enslaved to wealth and property are commonly called petty men. Yet in their enslavement, they are one—so where is the gentleman, and where is the petty man? If one considers the maiming of life and the harm to nature, then Robber Zhi is no different from Boyi. How then can one distinguish between gentleman and petty man?

Gambling and reading are two pursuits of differing worth, yet in losing the sheep, they are equal—this analogy is most apt. *"Holding a bamboo slip"* means holding a scroll. *"Gambling"* refers to casting dice; if one does not cast, it is called *"blocking."* The dice are like today’s dice, also called *"teeth"* or *"pips."* *"Blocking"* is the same as *"obstructing."* Boyi and Robber Zhi—did Zhuangzi not know their worth? He merely used them to make his point. All these are instances of excess. Though gentlemen and petty men differ, in maiming life and harming nature, they are one. His intent is to satirize the gentleman, so he borrows the petty man to illustrate—this is again the meaning of diminishing the great with the small, humbling the high with the low.

Moreover, can one truly bind one’s nature to benevolence and righteousness? Even those as upright as Zeng and Shi are not what I call *"preserved."*

Binding one’s nature to the five flavors—though one may be as discerning as Yu Er, this is not what I call *"preserved."* Binding one’s nature to the five tones—though one may be as skilled as Master Kuang, this is not what I call *"keen."* Binding one’s nature to the five colors—though one may be as sharp-sighted as Li Zhu, this is not what I call *"clear."*

What I call *"preserved"* is not the binding to benevolence and righteousness, but the preservation of one’s virtue alone. What I call *"preserved"* is not what is meant by benevolence and righteousness, but the following of one’s nature and the truth of life.

What I call *"keen"* is not hearing others, but hearing oneself. What I call *"clear"* is not seeing others, but seeing oneself. For one who does not see oneself but sees others, who does not attain for oneself but attains for others—this is attaining the attainment of others while failing to attain one’s own attainment. It is fitting oneself to the fitting of others rather than fitting oneself to one’s own fitting. Those who fit themselves to the fitting of others rather than their own fitting—whether Robber Zhi or Boyi—are equally given to excess and perversion.

I am ashamed of this. Therefore, above, I dare not cling to the conduct of benevolence and righteousness, and below, I dare not indulge in excess and perversion. *"Binding one’s nature"* means fixing one’s attention. Zeng refers to Master Zeng.

The name "Qiu" is likened to Yu Er, Shikuang, and Li Zhu, while comparing them to Zeng and Shi expresses the intent to humble the lofty. *"Zang"* denotes goodness, yet it is said: though this may be so, it is not what I deem good. To deem good its virtue and entrust to the natural endowment of one’s nature and fate—this is to follow the natural.

Within these few lines, such as *"What I call 'clear' is not hearing others, but hearing oneself"* and *"What I call 'bright' is not seeing others, but seeing oneself"*—the entire *Great Treasury of Sūtras* scarcely conveys this meaning. How could such words be uttered lightly? This *"others"* is no trifling matter; it is what Chan masters call *"a mad dog chasing a clod"* or *"an illusory flower yielding an illusory fruit."* *"Attaining one’s own attainment"* and *"fitting oneself to one’s own fitting"*—this is *"seeing oneself"* and *"awakening to oneself."* Generally, it is a matter of distinguishing the original mind from external things. To fail in grasping the original mind and instead gallop after externals—this is all excess and perversion.

*"Hearing oneself"* and *"seeing oneself"*—in my writings, this aligns with the *Analects’* *"silently recording it,"* the *Book of Changes’* *"silently accomplishing it, unspoken yet trusted,"* Mencius’ *"manifested in the four limbs, unspoken yet understood,"* and Master Cheng Yi’s *Preface to the Spring and Autumn Annals*: *"nurturing through deep immersion, silently recording, the mind penetrating"*—all express this meaning, though stated with greater plainness.

Master Zhu [Xi] reproved the learning of [Lu] Xiangshan, saying that the scholars of Jiangxi all raised their brows and darted their eyes, boasting of profound awakening, and so he vehemently refuted and vigorously rejected such claims. Thus, in his *Collected Explanations of the Analects*, he glosses *"recording"* (*zhi*) as *"remembering"* (*zhi*), saying *"silently remembering it."* For Mencius’ *"unspoken yet understood,"* he likewise says *"not awaiting others’ words to understand for oneself,"* refusing to speak of sudden awakening. This was due to his reproof, not the original purport of the *Analects* or *Mencius*. Yet if we consider Master Cheng Yi’s words *"silently recording, the mind penetrating,"* how could *"recording"* be read as *"remembering"*?

Nevertheless, those who study the Dao, when applying effort, often harbor a mind awaiting penetration and awakening—this is especially impermissible. As the saying goes: *"Clinging to delusion while awaiting awakening is as distant as Mount Sumeru."* Sudden and gradual awakening each have their own mechanism; one cannot say there is gradualness without suddenness, nor must everyone attain it through sudden awakening. Zhonggong’s *"maintaining reverence"* is gradual, while Yan Hui’s *"overcoming the self and returning to ritual"* is sudden. Otherwise, why would it be said: *"In one day, overcoming the self and returning to ritual, all under heaven will turn to benevolence"*? What is benevolence? To attain it in a single day—what is this if not sudden awakening?

Observe these lines: first, it raises the phrase *"overcoming the self and returning to ritual is benevolence,"* then says *"in one day, overcoming the self and returning to ritual, all under heaven will turn to benevolence,"* and further asks: *"Is benevolence to be pursued by oneself or by others?"*

chunks.original_text: 语势起伏便与禅家答话一同子细吟玩方见其味颜子既于言下领略乃曰请问其目此即禅家所谓如何保任之时四非四勿便是尽心知性知天之下继以存心养性事天修身俟命之事也 其曰为仁由已即禅家所谓此事别人着力不得也 先师尝曰佛书最好证吾书证则易晓也 上不敢为仁义之操是为善无近名也 下不敢为淫僻之行是为恶无近刑也 道德自然也 余恐有愧于道德虽不为近刑之事亦不为近名之事近名则非自然矣 故曰余愧乎 道德是以上不敢为仁义之操而下不敢为淫僻之行也 观庄子此语何尝不正心修身其戏侮尧舜夫子曾史伯夷初非实论特鼓舞其笔端而已塘东刘叔平向作庄骚同工异曲论曰庄周愤悱之雄也 乐轩先生甚取此语看来庄子亦是愤世疾邪而后着此书其见既高其笔又奇所以有过当处太史公谓其善属书离辞指事情用剽剥儒墨虽当世宿学不能自解免也 其言洸洋【上音汪下音羊】自恣以适已此数句真道着庄子 外篇马蹄第九 马蹄可以践霜雪毛可以御风寒龁草饮水翘足而陆此马之真性也虽有义【许宜反】台路寝无所用之及至伯乐曰我善治马烧之剔之刻之雒之连之以羁【丁邑丁立二反】编之以皂栈马之死者十二三矣饥之渴之驰之骤之整之齐之前有橛饰之患而后有鞭防之威而马之死者已过半矣 此段言外物能为身累之意翘足而陆者凡马立时其蹄必有跂起者也 此是下句处义台路寝即是王者之宫室也 义者养也 居移气养移体之地必当时有此二字烧剔治马蹄也 刻削也 亦削其蹄也

The cadence of these words rises and falls, much like the responses of Chan masters—only upon careful recitation and reflection does one taste their depth. Once Yanzi grasped the meaning at the words’ edge, he asked, *"May I inquire about its details?"* This is precisely what Chan calls *"how to preserve and uphold it"*—the *"four negations"* and *"four restraints"* are none other than the full realization of mind, the knowing of nature, and the knowing of Heaven, followed by the cultivation of mind, the nurturing of nature, the serving of Heaven, and the refining of the self to await destiny.

When it says *"to be benevolent depends on oneself,"* this is what Chan means by *"this matter cannot be forced by others."* Our late teacher once remarked: *"Buddhist texts best verify our own; once verified, they become easily understood."*

*"Above, one dares not practice benevolence and righteousness"*—this is *"doing good without seeking fame."*
*"Below, one dares not engage in licentious and deviant conduct"*—this is *"doing evil without incurring punishment."*
Virtue and the Dao are natural.

I fear I fall short of virtue and the Dao. Though I do not commit acts that bring punishment, neither do I pursue deeds that seek fame—for to seek fame is to depart from the natural. Thus, I say: *"I am ashamed before virtue and the Dao."* Therefore, *"above, one dares not practice benevolence and righteousness, and below, one dares not engage in licentious and deviant conduct."*

Observe Zhuangzi’s words—do they not also speak of rectifying the mind and cultivating the self? His mockery of Yao, Shun, Confucius, Zeng, and Bo Yi was never meant as serious critique; it was merely the flourish of his brush to rouse the reader. Liu Shuping of Tangdong once wrote a treatise comparing the *Zhuangzi* and the *Li Sao* as *"different tunes played with equal skill,"* saying: *"Zhuang Zhou was a master of pent-up indignation."* Master Lexuan greatly admired this remark. It seems Zhuangzi, too, wrote this book out of indignation toward a corrupt world. His vision was lofty, his brushwork extraordinary—hence his occasional excesses. Sima Qian said of him: *"He excelled in composition, diverging from conventional phrasing to depict events and express emotions. He borrowed from and critiqued the Confucians and Mohists, leaving even the most learned scholars of his time unable to defend themselves."* His words surge and swell, unbounded and self-indulgent, perfectly suiting his purpose—these few lines truly capture the essence of Zhuangzi.

**Outer Chapters, "Horse’s Hooves" (Chapter Nine):**
*"A horse’s hooves can tread upon frost and snow; its coat can ward off wind and cold. It grazes on grass, drinks water, lifts its legs, and gallops—this is the true nature of the horse. Though there be grand halls and towering pavilions, they are of no use to it. But when Bo Le says, ‘I am skilled at managing horses,’ he burns their hooves, brands their flesh, trims their manes, pierces their nostrils, and binds them with reins and halters. He tethers them to stable posts and black troughs—already, two or three out of ten horses die. He starves them, parches them, races them, spurs them, aligns them, and disciplines them. Before them lie the torments of bits and ornaments; behind them, the threats of whips and restraints—more than half the horses perish."*

This passage speaks to how external things can burden the body.
*"Lifts its legs and gallops"*—when any horse stands, its hooves naturally lift.
Here, *"grand halls and towering pavilions"* refer to the palaces of kings.
*"Nourishment"* (義) means *"to sustain."*
*"Dwelling transforms qi; nurturing transforms the body"*—this must have been the original meaning of these two characters.
*"Burning"* refers to cauterizing the hooves; *"trimming"* means cutting them.
*"Carving"* (刻) is also the trimming of hooves.

"Luo" means to bridle and harness; "ji" is the headstall that binds the head; "" are the fetters that hobble the feet—what we now call the front and rear tethers. "Lian" means to arrange them in rows. "Zao zhan" are the black troughs and racks where the horses are lined up together. "Zheng qi" means to align and arrange them in orderly ranks. "Jue" is the bit; "shi" are the ornamental reins beneath the jaw—hence the saying, "before them lie the torments of bits and ornaments." Horses are controlled by humans and cannot enjoy their natural joys, which is why so many die. This is the same meaning as Yuan Xian dragging his tail in the mud, though the phrasing here—with several "zhi" particles and the shift from "two or three out of ten" to "more than half"—is as richly woven as fine brocade. From this, countless brush techniques of past and present have sprouted. Some say this is a rough and erroneous passage from the Outer Chapters.

The potter says, "I excel at shaping clay: what is round fits the compass, what is square fits the carpenter’s square." The craftsman says, "I excel at working wood: what is curved fits the hook, what is straight aligns with the plumb line." Yet do clay and wood by nature desire to conform to compass, square, hook, and line? Still, generation after generation, people praise Bo Le for his skill in training horses and potters and carpenters for their skill in shaping clay and wood—this is also the error of those who govern the world.

The potter works clay; the craftsman works wood. Clay and wood are both fashioned by human hands into vessels, just as horses are scorched, trimmed, carved, bridled, raced, and drilled into alignment—do they not lose the natural qualities of earth and wood? People regard Bo Le and the artisans as capable, just as those from the time of Tai onward regard governing the world as a skill. This is the same idea as the earlier passage on benevolence and righteousness not being in accord with human nature. The meaning of these few lines is no more than this, though the wording is exquisite.

In my view, one who truly excels at governing the world does not act thus. The people have a constant nature: they weave to clothe themselves and till to feed themselves—this is called "shared virtue," unified and impartial, named "Heaven’s release." Thus, in the age of utmost virtue, their movements are unhurried, their gazes steady. At that time, mountains had no paths or tunnels, marshes no boats or bridges. The myriad things and all living beings dwelled together in their villages; birds and beasts formed flocks, grasses and trees grew freely. Thus, wild beasts could be led by tethers to roam, and the nests of birds and magpies could be climbed to peer into. In the age of utmost virtue, states dwelled among beasts, clans mingled with the myriad things—how could one distinguish between noble and base? Alike in ignorance, their virtue did not depart; alike in desirelessness, they were called "plain and uncarved." In plainness and uncarved simplicity, the people’s nature was preserved.

"Shared virtue" means what is received from Heaven is the same for all. Human life unfolds as each pursues their livelihood—some till, some weave—all following the natural workings of Heaven. Thus it is called "constant nature," which is what the earlier passage referred to as "constant thusness." "Dang" means partiality, leaning toward one side.

chunks.original_text: 纯一而无所偏倚放肆自乐于自然之中故曰一而不党命曰天放命曰犹言谓之也 齐物论之天行天钧天游与此天放皆是庄子做此名字以形容自然之乐至德之世言上古也 填填满足之貌颠颠直视之貌形容其人朴拙无心之意又就其卧徐徐其觉于于应帝王中翻出此语山无蹊隧路未通也 泽无舟梁水路未通也 人各随其乡而居自为连属一乡之中自有长幼上下相连属也 禽兽群居深山去人尚远无害之者草木各遂其生长未有斧斤之祸也 羁系禽兽而游攀引鹊巢而窥人与物相忘也 东坡杂说有少时所居书室鸟雀巢于低枝桐花四五日一至颇与此处相似见诗集二十八卷异巢诗注以此观之上古之时必是如此禽兽可与同居万物可与同聚又安有君子小人之分族聚也 并同也 无知不识不知也

Unblemished in singularity and free from partiality, they roamed unfettered and rejoiced in the spontaneity of nature—thus it is called "one and without faction," or what is termed *tianfang* ("Heavenly release"). *Ming yue* ("termed") means "to name it as such." The *tianxing* ("Heavenly workings"), *tianjun* ("Heavenly balance"), *tianyou* ("Heavenly wandering"), and *tianfang* ("Heavenly release") in the *Qiwulun* are all names coined by Zhuangzi to depict the joy of spontaneity in the age of utmost virtue, referring to antiquity.

*Tiantian* describes a state of fullness and contentment; *diandian*, a gaze of unwavering directness—both portraying the artless simplicity and absence of self-consciousness of those people. This passage is echoed in the *Yingdiwang* chapter. "Mountains without paths or tunnels" means roads were yet unopened; "marshlands without boats or bridges" means waterways were yet uncrossed. People dwelled according to their locales, forming natural bonds—within each village, elders and juniors, superiors and inferiors were organically connected. Birds and beasts lived in herds deep in the mountains, far from human harm; grasses and trees flourished unmarred by the axe’s calamity. Leading beasts by tethers to roam or climbing to peer into magpies’ nests—this was the mutual forgetting of humans and creatures.

Su Dongpo’s *Miscellaneous Sayings* records that in his youth, birds nested on the low branches of a paulownia outside his study, and a *huan* bird visited every four or five days—a scene reminiscent of this passage, as noted in the commentary to his *Yichao* poem in volume twenty-eight of his collected works. From this, we may infer that in high antiquity, humans must have dwelled alongside birds and beasts, gathered with the myriad things—how could there have been distinctions between noble and base, or divisions among clans? *Bing* means "alike" or "together"; *wu zhi* means "ignorant," "unaware," or "without knowledge."

chunks.translated_text:
When desire is absent, one is purely in accord with Heavenly Principle—this is the state of the whole world, hence it is called "the same." Free from desire, one does not depart from wholeness and simplicity, from unadorned purity. In that time, each attained the joy of its own nature, and so it is said: "Unadorned and simple, the people’s nature was fulfilled." "Its virtue does not depart" means it remains unadorned and simple. These two phrases follow one another, and the latter condenses the former into just "unadorned and simple"—such is the method of ancient prose. Modern writing no longer observes such discipline.

When the Sage stumbles and strains to enact benevolence, stretches and strains to enact righteousness, the world begins to doubt. When it sprawls and scatters to enact music, plucks and twists to enact ritual, the world begins to divide. Thus, if unhewn simplicity is not marred, what need is there for sacrificial goblets? If white jade is not shattered, what need is there for ritual scepters? If the Dao and virtue are not abandoned, what need is there for benevolence and righteousness? If nature and feeling are not estranged, what need is there for ritual and music? If the five colors are not disordered, what need is there for patterned ornament? If the five tones are not disordered, what need is there to respond to the six pitch-pipes?

To mar simplicity to make vessels is the fault of the craftsman. To shatter the Dao and virtue to make benevolence and righteousness is the error of the Sage. The preceding passage spoke of Bole; this passage speaks of the Sage—what follows echoes what came before. *Biexie* describes the manner of forced, halting movement; *diqi* describes the manner of uneasy standing and walking. *Chanman* is the same as *hanman*, meaning dissolute and unrestrained; *zhaipi* describes the use of hands and feet, with *pi* pronounced like *bo* (as in *pibo*). Here, ritual and music, benevolence and righteousness, are wrung from the midst of self-abasement—though the words may seem unorthodox, the phrasing is striking. "Begins to divide" means that hearts and traces begin to diverge; once divided, they are no longer pure and unified. Such instances of the word "divide" are all well-placed.

Goblets are carved from wood, so it is said: "If unhewn simplicity is not marred, what need is there for sacrificial goblets?" Jade must be cut to become a vessel, so it is said: "If white jade is not shattered, what need is there for ritual scepters?" The Dao and virtue are natural; Zhuangzi treats benevolence and righteousness as external, hence: "If the Dao and virtue are not abandoned, what need is there for benevolence and righteousness?" Nature and feeling are inherent; Zhuangzi treats ritual and music as forced upon the world, hence: "If nature and feeling are not estranged, what need is there for ritual and music?" Mencius spoke of "refining these two" and "delighting in these two"—such are the words of sages and worthies. In this text, however, the meanings of "ritual and music" and "benevolence and righteousness" differ, as they are all regarded as external things.

Patterned ornament disrupts the five colors; the six pitch-pipes disrupt the five tones—both are metaphors for the use of human effort rather than natural spontaneity. "The fault of the craftsman" and "the error of the Sage" are concluding phrases for the preceding passage.

Horses, when dwelling on land, eat grass and drink water; when pleased, they entwine necks and nuzzle; when angry, they turn their backs and kick. This is all the knowledge horses possess. But when yokes and crossbars are placed upon them, when forehead ornaments are fitted to them, horses learn to glare defiantly, to resist the bit, to rear fiercely, to feign submission, to seize the bit, and to steal the bridle. Thus, the knowledge horses possess that enables them to become thieves is the fault of Bole.

In the time of the Lord of Brightness, people dwelled without knowing what to do, walked without knowing where to go; they filled their cheeks with food and played, patted their bellies and wandered—this was all the ability people possessed. But when the Sage bent and twisted ritual and music to correct the world’s form, dangled and dangled benevolence and righteousness to console the world’s heart, the people then began to stand on tiptoe, to love cunning, to contend for profit, and this could not be stopped. This, too, is the error of the Sage.

This analogy again condenses the preceding discourse into a few lines, adding several phrases that make it all the more striking. When pleased, they entwine necks and nuzzle; when angry, they turn their backs and kick—this is clearly a painted image of horses. *Xiangmi* means to rub against one another. Observe how the phrases "entwine necks" and "turn their backs" are employed. *Henge* refers to the crossbar on a carriage; *e* is the yoke. *Yueti* is what is now called a forehead mirror. *Jieni* means to stand alone, to glare defiantly in anger. *Yine* means to curve the neck and resist the bit, refusing the bridle. *Zhi* means fierce; *man* means to charge. The manner of refusing restraint and butting against one another. *Gui* means to scheme; *qie* means to act stealthily. Scheming to take the bit, stealthily applying the bridle—all are the result of the horse’s fierce resistance to being tamed, making the use of bit and bridle so laborious.

If horses oppose humans, they are called thieves—their knowledge of this is due to Bole. Without the imposition of yokes, crossbars, bits, and bridles, horses would remain horses and humans would remain humans; how would one see their defiant, resistant postures?

"People’s ability was limited to this" means that this was the extent of human capacity. *Kuang* means to correct. Using ritual and music to correct people’s form, using benevolence and righteousness to console people’s hearts—these are all inventions of the Sage, absent in high antiquity. *Xianqi* means to raise and display; *diqi* means to be ill at ease. Loving cunning and contending for profit are like the horse’s scheming to seize the bit and stealthily apply the bridle.

The Inner and Outer Chapters resemble the *Zuozhuan* and *Guoyu*—all were composed by the same hand. The *Zuozhuan* was completed, and then the *Guoyu* was written, though its style differs from the *Zuozhuan*. This chapter of the *Zhuangzi* is similarly expansive and luxuriant, so some have doubted it was written by Zhuangzi, but this is not the case. *Zhuangzi Kouyi*, Scroll Three. <*Sibu*, Daoist School, *Zhuangzi Kouyi*>

The *Imperially Commissioned Complete Library of the Four Treasuries*
*Zhuangzi Kouyi*, Scroll Four
By Lin Xiang of the Song Dynasty

**Outer Chapters: "Opening the Satchel" (Chapter Ten)**

When one prepares to guard against thieves who would pry open satchels, rummage through sacks, or force open chests, one must bind cords tightly, fasten bolts securely, and lock clasps firmly—this is what the common world calls "wisdom." Yet when a great thief arrives, he hoists the chest, shoulders the satchel, and carries off the sack, hurrying away in fear only that the cords, bolts, and locks are not secure enough. Then does not what was once called "wisdom" become merely the amassing of goods for the great thief?

Let us examine this: Is there any so-called "wisdom" in the common world that does not amass for the great thief? Is there any so-called "sage" who does not guard for the great thief? How do we know this is so? In ancient times, the state of Qi had neighboring towns within sight of one another, where the sounds of chickens and dogs could be heard across the land. Nets and snares were spread wide, and plows and hoes pierced the earth—an expanse of over two thousand *li* square. Within its four borders, all that was established—ancestral temples and altars of soil and grain, the governance of cities, villages, districts, and hamlets—was it not all modeled after the sages’ laws? Yet Tian Chengzi, in a single day, murdered the ruler of Qi and stole the state. What he stole was not merely the state—he also stole the sages’ wisdom and laws along with it. Thus, Tian Chengzi bore the name of a thief and brigand yet dwelt in the security of Yao and Shun. Small states dared not condemn him; great states dared not punish him. For twelve generations, he held the state of Qi—was this not the theft of the state of Qi *together* with its sagely wisdom and laws, using them to guard his thieving self?

Reading this chapter, one perceives its fierce indignation and grandeur. The author crafts a striking metaphor, unique in its artistry.
*Qu* (胠) means to open; *tan* (探) means to reach in and take; *fa* (发) also means to open.

chunks.original_text: 鼠窃之盗却下此六字非妙文乎 缄縢绳结也 摄缠绕也 扃管钥也 鐍锁也 世俗之知本为鼠窃之备大盗至则并挈而去矣 田氏篡齐以私量贷公量入看左传所言便是借圣人之法以济其盗贼之谋战国之时大抵如此故庄子以此喻之 尝试论之世俗之所谓至知者有不为大盗积者乎所谓至圣者有不为大盗守者乎何以知其然邪昔者龙逄斩比干剖苌胣【勑纸反】子胥靡故四子之贤而身不免乎戮故跖之徒问于跖曰盗亦有道乎跖曰何适而无有道邪夫妄意室中之藏圣也入先勇也出后义也知可否知也分均仁也五者不备而能成大盗者天下未之有也由是观之善人不得圣人之道不立跖不得圣人之道不行天下之善人少而不善人多则圣人之利天下也少而害天下也多 胣裂也靡烂也皆得罪而丧其躯也四子虽贤而身皆得罪盗跖反以自免此言贤者不足自恃而窃圣道之名者或以自利为盗之圣勇义知仁此是庄子撰出这般名字以讥侮儒者其言虽怪而以世故观之实有此理说到不善人多善人少利天下少而害天下多处亦是精绝 故曰唇竭则齿寒鲁酒薄而邯郸围圣人生而大盗起掊击圣人纵舍盗贼而天下始治矣夫川竭而谷虚丘夷而渊实圣人已死则大盗不起天下平而无故矣圣人不死大盗不止虽重圣人而治天下则是重利盗跖也 楚方伐鲁以其酒薄也 而梁乃伐赵以鲁不得而援也 唇与齿似不相关唇竭而齿自寒川与谷不相干川竭而谷自虚丘与渊不相千丘夷而渊自实即今人所谓张公吃酒李公醉也 以喻圣人之法不为盗设而反为盗贼之资故曰圣人生而大盗起圣人不生而大盗不起掊击圣人纵舍盗贼言亦无圣人亦无盗贼而后天下治也 川水满则山谷之中皆有水川竭则谷自虚矣 川与谷虽不相通而春夏之盈秋冬之涸却同也 丘夷山頺而夷平也 犹曰山附于地剥也 山夷则土实之于渊是不相关而相因也 无故即无事也 重圣人而治言圣人复出也 圣人复出而制法愈密欺诈者得之益可以欺世故曰重利盗跖也 【鲁酒薄邯郸围又见淮南子其文稍异意亦同】 为之斗斛以量之则并与斗斛而窃之为之权衡以称之则并与权衡而窃之为之符玺以信之则并与符玺而窃之为之仁义以矫之则并与仁义而窃之何以知其然邪彼窃钩者诛窃国者为诸侯诸侯之门而仁义存焉则是非窃仁义圣知邪 斗斛权衡符玺仁义四者并言以下抑高之意窃钩小盗也钩腰带环也战国之诸侯篡夺而得皆大盗也小者诛而大者乃如此愤世之言也既为诸侯则其立国亦以爱民利物为事是不特窃国并窃圣人之仁义圣知也 故逐于大盗揭诸侯窃仁义并斗斛权衡符玺之利者虽有轩冕之赏弗能劝斧之威弗能禁此重利盗跖而使不可禁者是乃圣人之过也故曰鱼不可脱于渊国之利器不可以示人彼圣人者天下之利器也非所以明天下也 名为大盗者人皆欲逐之今之诸侯皆窃国者立于人上人谁不见故曰揭如此大盗昭昭于世并仁义斗斛权衡符玺以窃之而世未有立赏以求捕用刑以禁止者是皆愤世而为此言鱼不可脱于渊言不可离水也圣人之法只可自用不可使人人皆知之故曰非所以明天下也明者天下皆知之也 故绝圣弃知大盗乃止擿玉毁珠小盗不起焚符破玺而民朴鄙掊斗折衡而民不争殚残天下之圣法而民始可与论议 擿玉毁珠焚符破玺剖斗折衡皆是激说以结绝圣弃知之意非实论也殚残者毁削也尽去圣人之法民始纯一可与言道也故曰民始可与论议此皆愤世之辞故人每以剖斗折衡焚符破玺之事讥议之其实即老子不贵难得之货则民不为盗之意但说得过当耳东坡曰人生识字忧患始岂欲天下人全不识字耶
chunks.translated_text:
Are not the six characters "the theft of a rat’s pilfering" a stroke of literary brilliance? *Jian* (缄) and *teng* (縢) are knots and bindings; *she* (摄) is to coil and wrap; *jiong* (扃) are bolts and keys; *jue* (鐍) are locks. The wisdom of the common world exists only to guard against the pilfering of rats—yet when the great thief arrives, he carries it all away in one haul. Tian’s usurpation of Qi, lending with private measures and collecting with public ones—what the *Zuozhuan* describes is precisely the borrowing of the sages’ laws to advance his thieving schemes. Such was the way of things in the Warring States era, and thus Zhuangzi drew this analogy.

Let us examine it: Is there any so-called "utmost wisdom" that does not serve to amass for the great thief? Any so-called "utmost sageliness" that does not serve to guard for the great thief? How do we know this to be so? In ancient times, Long Feng was beheaded, Bi Gan was disemboweled, Chang Hong was torn limb from limb, and Wu Zixu’s corpse was left to rot—though these four were men of virtue, they could not escape execution. Yet when Zhi’s followers asked him, "Does theft also have its Dao?" Zhi replied, "Where is there anything that does not have its Dao? To divine the treasures hidden in a chamber—that is sageliness. To enter first—that is courage. To exit last—that is righteousness. To know what can and cannot be done—that is wisdom. To divide spoils equally—that is benevolence. Without these five, no one in the world has ever become a great thief." From this, we see that the good man cannot stand without the Dao of the sage, nor can Zhi act without the Dao of the sage. If the good men of the world are few and the ungood many, then the sage’s benefit to the world is slight, while his harm is great.

*Chi* (胣) means to tear apart; *mi* (靡) means to shred—both describe how they were condemned and their bodies destroyed. Though the four were virtuous, they all met with punishment, while the thief Zhi escaped unscathed. This shows that the virtuous cannot rely on themselves, and those who steal the name of the sagely Dao may use it for their own gain. The thief’s sageliness, courage, righteousness, wisdom, and benevolence—these are the names Zhuangzi fabricated to mock the Confucians. Though his words are strange, when viewed through the lens of worldly affairs, they hold truth. To say that the ungood are many and the good few, that the sage’s benefit to the world is slight while his harm is great—this is a most incisive observation.

Thus it is said: When the lips are gone, the teeth grow cold; when the Lu wine was weak, Handan was besieged. When the sage is born, the great thief arises. Only by smashing the sages and abandoning wisdom, releasing the thieves and brigands, does the world begin to be ordered. When the river runs dry, the valley empties; when the hills are leveled, the abyss fills. Once the sage is dead, the great thief no longer rises, and the world is at peace without incident. If the sage does not die, the great thief does not cease. Even if the sage is revered to govern the world, this is but to heap profit upon the thief Zhi.

When Chu attacked Lu because its wine was weak, Liang then attacked Zhao because Lu could not come to its aid. Lips and teeth seem unrelated, yet when the lips are gone, the teeth grow cold of themselves. Rivers and valleys seem unconnected, yet when the river runs dry, the valley empties of itself. Hills and abysses seem unrelated, yet when the hills are leveled, the abyss fills of itself—just as people today say, "Zhang drinks the wine, but Li grows drunk." This is to say that the sages’ laws are not made for thieves, yet they become the thieves’ resources. Thus it is said: When the sage is born, the great thief arises; when the sage does not exist, the great thief does not rise. Only by smashing the sages and releasing the thieves and brigands—only then, with neither sages nor thieves, does the world find order.

When the river is full, the mountain valleys are all filled with water; when the river runs dry, the valley empties of itself. Though rivers and valleys are not connected, their spring floods and autumn droughts are the same. *Qiu yi* (丘夷) means the hills are leveled and flattened—like saying the mountains are eroded and return to the earth. When the hills are leveled, their soil fills the abyss, showing how things unrelated are yet mutually dependent. *Wu gu* (无故) means without incident. *Chong shengren er zhi* (重圣人而治) means the sage reappears. When the sage reappears and his laws grow ever more intricate, deceivers find in them even greater means to deceive the world. Thus it is said: to heap profit upon the thief Zhi.

When measures like *dou* and *hu* are made to quantify, the thief steals them along with the grain. When scales and balances are made to weigh, the thief steals them along with the goods. When tallies and seals are made to authenticate, the thief steals them along with the authority. When benevolence and righteousness are made to rectify, the thief steals them along with the virtues. How do we know this to be so? Those who steal hooks are executed, while those who steal states become lords—yet at the gates of these lords, benevolence and righteousness reside. Is this not the theft of benevolence, righteousness, sageliness, and wisdom?

The *dou*, *hu*, scales, balances, tallies, seals, benevolence, and righteousness—these eight are spoken of together to humble the lofty. Stealing a hook is a petty theft, for a hook is but a belt ring. Yet the lords of the Warring States era, who gained power through usurpation, were all great thieves. The petty are executed, while the great attain such heights—this is the indignation of one who rails against the world. Once they become lords, their rule is built on loving the people and benefiting things, yet this is not merely the theft of the state—it is the theft of the sages’ benevolence, righteousness, sageliness, and wisdom.

Thus, when the great thief arises, he seizes the lords, stealing benevolence and righteousness along with the profits of *dou*, *hu*, scales, balances, tallies, and seals. Though rewards of high rank and emolument are offered, they cannot encourage; though the threat of the executioner’s axe looms, it cannot deter. That this heaping of profit upon the thief Zhi cannot be stopped is the fault of the sages. Thus it is said: The fish cannot leave the abyss; the state’s sharpest tools cannot be shown to others. The sage is the world’s sharpest tool—he is not meant to be displayed to the world.

Those called great thieves are pursued by all, yet today’s lords, all usurpers of states, stand above the people—who does not see this? Thus it is said: Such great thieves are manifest in the world, stealing benevolence, righteousness, *dou*, *hu*, scales, balances, tallies, and seals—yet the world offers no rewards to capture them, no punishments to forbid them. This is the indignation of one who rails against the world. "The fish cannot leave the abyss" means it cannot leave the water. The sages’ laws can only be used by oneself; they cannot be made known to all. Thus it is said: they are not meant to be displayed to the world. *Ming* (明) means to make known to all under heaven.

Thus, only by cutting off sageliness and discarding wisdom does the great thief cease. Smash the jades and shatter the pearls, and petty thieves will not rise. Burn the tallies and break the seals, and the people will return to simplicity. Break the *dou* and snap the scales, and the people will not contend. Only when the sages’ laws are utterly destroyed can the people begin to be spoken with.

Smashing jades, shattering pearls, burning tallies, breaking seals, splitting *dou*, and snapping scales—these are all extreme statements to conclude the argument for cutting off sageliness and discarding wisdom; they are not meant as practical discourse. *Dan can* (殚残) means to destroy and abolish. Only when the sages’ laws are entirely removed can the people become pure and unified, fit to be spoken with of the Dao. Thus it is said: the people can then begin to be spoken with. These are all the words of one who rails against the world, and so people often mock the splitting of *dou*, the snapping of scales, the burning of tallies, and the breaking of seals. Yet in truth, this is no different from Laozi’s idea that "not prizing rare goods will keep the people from stealing"—it is merely stated in an extreme manner. As Su Dongpo said, "When a man learns to read, his troubles begin"—yet who would wish the world’s people to remain entirely illiterate?

Disrupting the six pitch-pipes and melting away the *yu* and *se*, stopping up the ears of the blind Master Kuang—only then will the people of the world begin to preserve their natural hearing. Eradicating patterns and scattering the five colors, blinding the eyes of Li Zhu—only then will the people of the world begin to preserve their natural clarity. Destroying plumb lines and discarding compasses and squares, breaking the fingers of the craftsman Chui—only then will the people of the world begin to possess their innate skill. Thus it is said: "Great skill appears clumsy." Erasing the conduct of Zeng and Shi, silencing the mouths of Yang and Mo, casting aside benevolence and righteousness—only then will the virtue of the world begin to achieve primordial unity.

When people preserve their natural clarity, the world will not be dazzled; when they preserve their natural hearing, the world will not be burdened; when they preserve their innate knowledge, the world will not be deluded; when they preserve their inherent virtue, the world will not be perverse. Those like Zeng, Shi, Yang, Mo, Master Kuang, the craftsman Chui, and Li Zhu all externally establish their virtues and thereby confuse the world with their dazzling brilliance—such are those whom the Dao deems useless.

*Zhuo luan* means to pull out and disrupt. The six pitch-pipes have their ordered lengths; if one disrupts them, they become unusable. *Shuo jue* means to burn and discard. Only with the ears of one like Master Kuang can the affairs of pitch and music be accomplished; if one stops up his ears, then all hearing will accord with spontaneity, free from such artificial constructs.

chunks.original_text: 明巧两句其意亦同因巧字却举老子大巧若拙一语以证之亦是文法处曾史有忠孝之名杨墨有仁义之言攘除而弃掷之使仁义之说不行则天下之人同得此德始归于妙矣 不铄不消散也 不累无系累也 不惑不相诳惑也 不僻无偏陂也 以曾史杨墨与师旷工倕离朱并言亦以小抑大也 外立其德者重外物而失本心也 爚乱者言熏灼而挠乱之也 以正法言之此等人皆无所用言皆当去也 故曰法之所无用也 此一句结得极有力文字之好处 子独不知至德之世乎昔者容成氏大庭氏伯皇氏中央氏栗陆氏骊畜氏轩辕氏赫胥氏尊卢氏祝融氏伏羲氏神农氏 十二个氏只轩辕伏羲神农见于经自此以上吾书中无之或得于上古之传或出于庄子自撰亦未可知亦由佛言我于过去某劫也 虽若大言然以天地间观之自伏羲以来载籍所可考者三千余年岂有许大天地方有三千余年伏羲以前必有六籍所不传者但言之则近于怪妄然亦不可不知且如吾闽自无诸以来方见于汉至唐而后渐有文物无诸之前当犹草昧可也 近时囊山寺前耕于野者忽得一穴其间金玉之器鼎彝之属甚多人皆窃而去之最后既虚乡人皆相率而就观其砖无大小皆雕人物龙虎不胜精巧此前穴也 其后一壁以锄斧击之鞺鞺然有声但坚固不可动必是铜铁所灌意非有国者之坟不然书籍所载闽之上无闻焉 则必有之而不传者然则容成大庭之不可谓无之 当是时也
chunks.translated_text:
The two phrases on clarity and skill share the same meaning—hence, the character "skill" brings to mind Laozi’s saying, "Great skill appears clumsy," which serves as corroboration. This, too, is a matter of literary technique. Zeng and Shi bore names of loyalty and filial piety; Yang and Mo spoke of benevolence and righteousness. Cast them aside, discard them, and let the doctrines of benevolence and righteousness cease to circulate—then the people of the world will equally attain this virtue, and all will return to the profound and wondrous.

*Not to be dazzled* means not to dissipate; *not to be burdened* means to be free from entanglement; *not to be deluded* means not to deceive one another; *not to be perverse* means to be without bias or deviation. To speak of Zeng, Shi, Yang, and Mo alongside Master Kuang, the craftsman Chui, and Li Zhu is to diminish the great by means of the small. Those who *externally establish their virtue* value external things and lose their original mind. *To dazzle and disrupt* means to scorch and confound. From the perspective of the correct Dao, such people are of no use—indeed, they ought to be cast aside. Thus it is said, "such are those whom the Dao deems useless." This concluding phrase is rendered with great force, a fine example of literary excellence.

Yet you alone do not know of the age of utmost virtue? In ancient times, there were the clans of Rongcheng, Dating, Bohuang, Zhongyang, Lilu, Lixu, Xuanyuan, Hexu, Zunlu, Zhu Rong, Fuxi, and Shennong—twelve clans in all. Only Xuanyuan, Fuxi, and Shennong appear in the classics; those before them are absent from my books. Some may have been transmitted from antiquity, while others may have been fabricated by Zhuangzi himself—much like the Buddhist claim, "In a past kalpa, I..." Though it may seem boastful, when viewed within the scope of heaven and earth, the three thousand-odd years since Fuxi that can be verified in the records are but a fraction. How could there not have been vast ages before Fuxi, unrecorded in the Six Classics? To speak of them may verge on the fantastical, yet they cannot be entirely dismissed. Consider my own land of Min: only since Wuzhu has it been recorded in the Han, and only after the Tang did it gradually acquire culture and refinement. Before Wuzhu, it must have remained in a state of primitive simplicity. Recently, near Nangshan Temple, farmers plowing the fields suddenly uncovered a cavern filled with vessels of gold and jade, tripods, and ritual bronzes—so many that people secretly carried them away. When the cavern was finally emptied, the villagers all flocked to see it. The bricks, large and small, were carved with figures, dragons, and tigers of exquisite craftsmanship—this was the former cavern. Later, when they struck one wall with hoes and axes, it resounded with a *tang-tang* echo, yet it was too solid to dislodge, likely reinforced with bronze or iron. It must have been the tomb of a ruler, for otherwise, why would the records of Min’s past make no mention of it? Thus, there must have been such things, though they were not transmitted. By the same token, the clans of Rongcheng and Dating cannot be said never to have existed. In that age...

chunks.original_text: 民结绳而用之甘其食美其服乐其俗安其居邻国相望鸡狗之音相闻民至老死而不相徃来若此之时则至治已今遂至使民延颈举踵曰某所有贤者赢粮而趣之则内弃其亲而外去其主之事足迹接乎 诸侯之境车轨结乎 千里之外则是上好知之过也 上诚好知而无道则天下大乱矣 何以知其然邪甘食而下又是山无蹊隧处抽绎出来某所有贤者赢粮而趋之便是暗说孟子荀子推而上之孔子亦在其间矣 观齐稷下与苏张之徒便见庄子因当时之风俗故有此论好知则非自然之道矣 故曰好知而无道 夫弓弩毕弋机变之知多则鸟乱于上矣钩饵罔罟笱之知多则鱼乱于水矣削格罗落罝罘之知多则兽乱于泽矣知诈渐毒颉滑坚白解垢同异之变多则俗惑于辩矣故天下每每大乱罪在于好知 毕有柄之网也弋缴射也机变变诈也削格犹汉代曰储胥也犹今之木栅也捕兔鹿者亦有之罝罘亦网也知诈以智而相诈也渐毒相渐染而为毒乱也颉桀颉也滑汨乱也解垢隔角也坚白解垢异同皆当时辩者之名以取鱼取鸟取兽之事与辩者并言之亦是以曾史与斗斛权衡并讥之意每每常常也常常如此而至于大乱皆好智之罪也 故天下皆知求其所不知而莫知求其所已知者皆知非其所不善而莫知非其所已善者是以大乱 不知者务外求异者也已知者晓然而易见者也自然之理也不善在人者也已善在我者也即齐物所谓是其所是而非其所非言但知他人之非而不知己之所是者亦非也 故上悖日月之明下烁山川之精中堕四时之施喘耎之虫肖翘之物莫不失其性甚矣 夫好知之乱天下也 自三代以下者是已舍夫种种之民而悦夫役役之佞释夫恬淡无为而悦夫啍啍之意啍啍已乱天下矣 上而日月下而山川中而寒暑四时防而至于喘耎肖翘之物皆失其自然之理故曰莫不失其性甚矣 夫好知之乱天下也 此叹息一句而结之也 喘耎防息而动之物附地者也 蜗蜒之肖小也 翘轻也 飞物也
chunks.translated_text:
When the people knotted cords to use in place of writing, found their food sweet and their garments fine, delighted in their customs and dwelled in peace, when neighboring states lay within sight of one another and the sounds of their roosters and dogs carried between them, yet the people lived to old age and died without ever traveling beyond their lands—such was the age of perfect governance.

Now, however, the people crane their necks and stand on tiptoe, saying, “There is a worthy in such-and-such a place,” and they pack provisions to hasten toward him. Thus, they abandon their parents at home and forsake their lords’ service abroad, their footprints crisscrossing the borders of the feudal lords, their carriage tracks entangling lands a thousand *li* away. This is the fault of those above who prize knowledge.

If those above truly favor knowledge yet lack the Dao, the world will fall into great chaos. How do we know this is so? When food is sweet, yet the people below still hunger; when mountains lack paths and tunnels, yet they still carve them out—this is the same as when they hear of a worthy in some place and rush toward him with packed provisions. This is covertly criticizing Mencius and Xunzi, and if we trace it further, Confucius is included as well.

Observe the scholars of the Jixia Academy in Qi and the followers of Su Qin and Zhang Yi, and you will see why Zhuangzi, responding to the customs of his time, made such arguments. To favor knowledge is to depart from the Dao of nature.

Thus it is said: to favor knowledge yet lack the Dao—when the knowledge of bows, crossbows, fowling nets, and cunning schemes proliferates, birds are thrown into chaos above; when the knowledge of hooks, bait, dragnets, and fish traps multiplies, fish are thrown into chaos in the waters; when the knowledge of snares, fences, and hunting nets spreads, beasts are thrown into chaos in the marshes; when the transformations of cunning deceit, insidious poison, obstinate confusion, the “hard and white,” the “resolving of grime,” and the “same and different” abound, the common folk are bewildered by sophistry.

Thus, the world repeatedly falls into great chaos, and the blame lies in the love of knowledge. *Bi* refers to a handled net; *yi* and *zhuo* denote shooting with arrows; *jibian* means deceptive schemes; *xuege* are what the Han called *chuxu*—like today’s wooden palisades—also used to trap deer and rabbits; *jufu* is another kind of net. “Cunning deceit” means using intelligence to deceive one another; “insidious poison” means gradually corrupting and poisoning one another; *xiejie* means obstinate and unruly; *hua* means muddled and chaotic; *jiegou* means clashing horns. “Hard and white,” “resolving of grime,” and “same and different” were all names used by the disputers of the time. To speak of fishing, fowling, and hunting alongside the sophists is akin to Zhuangzi’s intent in satirizing Zengzi and Shishu alongside bushels and scales—repeatedly, time and again, such things lead to great chaos, all due to the fault of prizing knowledge.

Therefore, the world all knows to seek what it does not know yet does not know to seek what it already knows; all knows to condemn what it does not consider good yet does not know to condemn what it already considers good. This is why there is great chaos.

Not knowing is the pursuit of external and strange things; already knowing refers to what is clear and easily seen—these are the principles of nature. What is not good lies in others; what is already good lies within oneself. This is what *Qi Wu* means by “affirming what one affirms and negating what one negates.” To know only the faults of others while being blind to one’s own rightness is also wrong.

Thus, those above obstruct the brightness of the sun and moon, below they scorch the essence of mountains and rivers, and in between they disrupt the workings of the four seasons. Even the creatures that breathe and creep, the tiny and the winged, all lose their nature—how severe is the chaos wrought by the love of knowledge!

From the Three Dynasties onward, this has been the case: abandoning the people of simple diversity and delighting in the toiling flatterers, forsaking the tranquil and effortless and delighting in the clamorous and contentious. Clamor and contention have already thrown the world into chaos.

Above, the sun and moon; below, the mountains and rivers; in between, the cold and heat of the four seasons—even the creatures that breathe and creep, the tiny and the winged, all lose the principles of their nature. How severe indeed!

The chaos wrought by the love of knowledge—this sigh concludes the passage.

*Chuanruan* refers to creatures that breathe and move, clinging to the earth—like worms and snakes. *Xiaoqiao* means small and light, the flying creatures.

chunks.original_text: 蜂蝶之肖音萧种种殻实之貌役役务外作为之貌啍啍嗫嗫也 上句既结了却以三代实之谓三代以下便是如此故曰自三代以下是已啍啍役役两句对说下面只拈啍啍字结便与前篇素朴而民性得矣 处同逍遥游曰汤之问棘也 是已起语也 此曰三代以下是已结语也 起结虽异同一机轴也 外篇在有第十一 闻在宥天下不闻治天下也在之也者恐天下之淫其性也宥之也者恐天下之迁其德也天下不淫其性不迁其德有治天下者哉昔尧之治天下也使天下欣欣焉人乐其性是不恬也桀之治天下也使天下瘁瘁焉人苦其性是不愉也夫不恬不愉非德也非德也而可长久者天下无之 闻在宥天下不闻治天下也此篇又做一句破题又是一体在者优防自在之意淫乱也静定则不淫矣宥者宽容自得之意迁为外物所迁移也使天下之人性皆不乱德皆不移于外物又何用治之乎不恬不静也不愉不乐也以尧对桀言之曾史盗跖之也全书意势皆如此其理皆未正然笔力岂易及哉以不恬比不愉便无轻重矣 人大喜邪毗于阳大怒邪毗于阴阴阳并毗四时不至寒暑之和不成其反伤人之形乎使人喜怒失位居处无常思虑不自得中道不成章于是乎天下始乔诘卓鸷而后有盗跖曾史之行故举天下以赏其善者不足举天下以罚其恶者不给故天下之大不足以赏罚自三代以下者匈匈焉终以赏罚为事彼何暇安其性命之情哉 喜属阳怒属阴毗益也 医书所谓有余之病也 致中和则天地位失其中和则有四时不至寒暑不和之事气序既逆则人亦病矣 使人者言因尧桀在上致人如此也 喜怒失位居处无常谓妄为妄动也 憧憧徃来朋从尔思是思虑不自得也 成章有条理也 不成章则失中道矣
chunks.translated_text:
The swarms of bees and butterflies—*xiao* in sound like the rustling wind—embody the myriad forms of fruiting shells. *Ruyi* describes the ceaseless toil of outward striving, while *zhunzhun-nieznie* denotes the murmuring and whispering of contention. The preceding passage having concluded, it now grounds its claim in the Three Dynasties, declaring: "From the Three Dynasties onward, this has been the case." The paired phrases *zhunzhun* and *ruyi* are set in parallel, but only *zhunzhun* is singled out to close the argument, echoing the earlier passage: "When simplicity and plainness prevail, the people’s nature is preserved." The *Qiwulun* states: "Tang’s inquiry of Ji..."—this is an opening phrase. Here, it says: "From the Three Dynasties onward, this has been the case"—a closing phrase. Though their openings and closings differ, they turn on the same axis.

The Outer Chapters, in the eleventh section, *In You*, declare: "I have heard of letting the world be, but not of governing it." *In* means to fear the world’s indulgence in its nature; *you* means to fear the world’s deviation from its virtue. If the world neither indulges its nature nor deviates from its virtue, who would need to govern it? In ancient times, when Yao governed the world, he made its people joyful, each delighting in their nature—yet this was not tranquility. When Jie governed the world, he made its people weary, each suffering in their nature—yet this was not contentment. That which is neither tranquil nor content is not virtue; and that which is not virtue cannot endure long in the world. Thus: "I have heard of letting the world be, not of governing it." This passage again opens with a thematic statement, adopting yet another form.

*In* conveys the sense of ease and self-possession—indulgence is disorder. In stillness, there is no indulgence. *You* conveys the sense of magnanimity and self-contentment—deviation is being swayed by external things. If the nature of the world’s people is not disordered and their virtue is not swayed by externals, what need is there for governance? Neither tranquility nor stillness, neither contentment nor joy—Yao is contrasted with Jie, just as Zeng and Shi are contrasted with Robber Zhi. The momentum of the entire text follows this pattern, though its principles remain uncorrected. Yet who could match its literary force? To equate the lack of tranquility with the lack of contentment is to disregard their weight.

When one’s joy is excessive, it injures the yang; when one’s anger is excessive, it injures the yin. When yin and yang are both injured, the four seasons fail to arrive, the harmony of cold and heat is disrupted, and their inversion harms the human form. Thus, people’s joy and anger lose their proper place; their dwellings become unsettled; their thoughts grow restless and uncentered; the mean is no longer ordered. From this, the world first becomes haughty, perverse, and fierce—leading later to the conduct of Robber Zhi, Zeng, and Shi.

Therefore, even if the entire world were mobilized to reward the good, it would not suffice; even if the entire world were mobilized to punish the wicked, it would not be enough. The vastness of the world is inadequate for such rewards and punishments. From the Three Dynasties onward, the world has been in tumult, ever preoccupied with rewards and punishments. How could it have leisure to nurture the true essence of its nature and destiny?

Joy pertains to yang; anger, to yin. *Pi* means excess—the medical texts call this "the illness of surplus." When the mean and harmony are achieved, Heaven and Earth assume their proper positions. Without the mean and harmony, the four seasons fail to arrive, and the balance of cold and heat is lost. When the sequence of qi is inverted, people fall ill.

*Shi ren* refers to the way Yao and Jie, from their positions above, brought about such conditions in the people. Joy and anger lose their proper place; dwellings become unsettled—this is reckless action and movement. "Restless thoughts, coming and going, following friends and companions"—this is the mind uncentered. *Cheng zhang* means order and coherence. Without order, the mean is lost.

chunks.original_text: 乔好高而过当也 诘议论相诘责也 卓孤立也 鸷猛厉也 此四字皆形容不和之意盗跖曾史只是替换贤不肖字用心既不和则贤不肖皆非矣 为天下者于其贤者而赏之于其不肖者而罚之贤非真贤出于好伪举世皆然故欲赏而不足不给亦不足也 言世间此等人多矣 其意皆是讥贤者乃与为恶者对说所以重抑贤者也 人人皆慕赏避罚以伪相与则岂能安其性情自然之理哉 而且悦明邪是淫于色也悦聪邪是淫于声也悦仁邪是乱于德也悦义邪是悖于理也悦礼邪是相于技也悦乐邪是相于淫也悦圣邪是相于艺也悦知邪是相于疵也天下将安其性命之情之八者存可也亡可也天下将不安其性命之情之八者乃始脔卷伧囊而乱天下也而天下乃始尊之惜之甚矣天下之惑也岂直过也而去之邪乃齐戒以言之跪坐以进之鼓歌以舞之吾若是何哉 为明而好五色为聪而好五声皆乱其真矣 故曰淫德与理自然者仁与义有心以为之故以为乱于德而悖于理技能也 淫乐也 彼以礼乐为外物故曰相于技相于淫相助也 助益之而愈甚也 艺业也
chunks.translated_text:
Exaltation strives for loftiness yet overreaches; *jie* denotes arguments that interrogate and reproach. *Zhuo* means isolation; *zhi*, ferocity and severity. These four terms all describe the meaning of disharmony. Robber Zhi and Zeng Shen and Shi Yu merely substitute the words "worthy" and "unworthy"—when the mind is not in harmony, neither worthiness nor unworthiness is genuine.

Those who govern the world reward the so-called worthy and punish the so-called unworthy. Yet what passes for worthiness is not true worthiness, arising from a fondness for pretense—such is the way of the entire world. Thus, the desire to reward is never sufficient, nor is the capacity to do so. This speaks to the multitude of such people in the world. The intent here is to satirize the "worthy," contrasting them with evildoers, thereby heavily suppressing the truly worthy.

When all people admire rewards and shun punishments, engaging in pretense among themselves, how can they ever settle into the natural principles of their nature and destiny? Moreover, delighting in "clarity" is lewdness in form; delighting in "keenness" is lewdness in sound. Delighting in "benevolence" is disorder in virtue; delighting in "righteousness" is perversion of principle. Delighting in "ritual" is competition in technique; delighting in "music" is competition in excess. Delighting in "sagacity" is competition in artistry; delighting in "knowledge" is competition in fault-finding.

If these eight remain in the world, the true essence of nature and destiny may yet endure; if they vanish, it may yet endure. But when the world fails to preserve the true essence of nature and destiny, these eight begin to shred, coil, and entangle it, throwing the world into chaos. Yet the world then reveres and cherishes them—how profound is the world’s delusion! Is this merely a matter of excess to be discarded? Instead, they fast and purify themselves to speak of them, kneel and sit to present them, drum and sing to dance for them. What is to be done about this?

Pursuing "clarity" and favoring the five colors, or pursuing "keenness" and favoring the five sounds—both disrupt one’s true nature. Thus it is said: excess in virtue and departure from natural principle—benevolence and righteousness are contrived with intention, thereby causing disorder in virtue and perversion of principle. Skill and ability—excess in music—are external matters, hence "competition in technique" and "competition in excess," meaning they assist and amplify, making matters worse. Artistry and craft.

chunks.original_text: 疵病也 业能自劳病乃自苦以圣知之名而悦之则愈劳愈苦矣 故曰相于业相于疵此圣字止近似能字犹今言草圣之圣也 故于盗亦曰妄意室中之藏圣也 此皆字义不同处读者当自分别不可与语孟中字义相紊乱八者明聪仁义礼乐圣知也 安其自然则八者虽有亦不能为累故曰存可也 亡可也 不安其自然则八者能为害矣 脔卷局束之貌伧囊多事之貌岂直过也 而去之言不特猎涉一过随即休止齐戒以言谓郑重而夸说之跪坐以进谓致恭尽礼而相授鼓歌以舞之谓言之不足手舞足蹈也 此皆讥一时之学者吾若是何哉 言汝辈如此果何为哉
chunks.translated_text:
Illness and affliction—these are the consequences of one’s own toil and suffering. Delighting in the names of "sageliness" and "knowledge," one toils and suffers all the more. Thus it is said: "competition in craft" and "competition in affliction." This term *sheng* (sageliness) is merely akin to the *neng* (ability) in "grass-sage" (calligraphic mastery), as used today. Even in the case of thieves, it is said: "recklessly conjecturing the treasures within a house—this is *sheng* (cunning)." Here, the meaning of the character differs, and readers must distinguish for themselves, lest they confuse it with the sense of *sheng* in the *Mengzi*.

The eight—clarity, keenness, benevolence, righteousness, ritual, music, sageliness, and knowledge—if one rests in naturalness, though they exist, cannot become burdens. One who "dwells like a corpse" abides in stillness as a corpse does—this is what the *Classic of Rites* means by "sitting like a corpse." *Dragon* signifies pattern and brilliance. Dwelling like a corpse in non-action, one’s bearing naturally becomes a model, hence the phrase "dwelling like a corpse yet dragon manifest." *Abyss* denotes depth; *silence*, the absence of speech. *Thunderous voice* stirs others—though one does not speak, one’s virtue moves them, much as Chan masters say: though silent, their voice resounds like thunder. Thus, "abyssal silence yet thunderous voice." *Spirit* is the numinous; *Heaven*, the heavenly principle. In every movement and gesture, nothing departs from the heavenly principle, hence "spirit moves and Heaven follows." Can these three lines truly mark the *Zhuangzi* as a heretical text? Its principles are profound, its phrasing extraordinary—thus it surpasses all other masters.

*Steaming and piling* evokes the image of "wild horses and dust motes," where living things breathe upon one another in mutual animation. *Steaming* is movement; *piling*, the accumulation of fine, innumerable particles. In an empty chamber where sunlight enters like an egg, one may observe the dust in the beam—these two words are strikingly chosen: seeming to move yet not moving, seeming many yet without visible multitude. Thus, "steaming and piling." If I were to practice non-action above, the people below would rise at sunrise and rest at sunset, content and at ease, like the myriad things steaming and piling of their own accord. Why then should I trouble myself to govern them?

Cui Qu asked Lao Dan, "If one does not govern the world, how can the human heart be settled?" Lao Dan replied, "Take care not to disturb the human heart. The human heart presses downward when suppressed and surges upward when indulged; in its rising and falling, it is imprisoned and slain. Supple and yielding, it may soften the rigid; sharp and incisive, it may be carved and polished. Its heat scorches like fire, its cold congeals like ice, its swiftness darts like lightning. In the span of a single bow and rise, it may twice caress the ends of the earth. Abiding, it is abyssal and still; moving, it hangs suspended like Heaven. Proud and untetherable—is this not the human heart?"

This passage, when read alongside Mencius’ "entering and exiting without fixed time, direction unknown," reveals its extraordinary depth. *Undisturbed* means unagitated, free from disruption. *Pressing downward* describes the heart in low spirits, appearing ever more despondent; when favored, it ceaselessly seeks advancement. *Upward* denotes the heart’s aspiration; *downward*, its descent. Whether rising or falling, it is imprisoned and slain—self-ensnared and self-tormented. *Supple and graceful* describes beauty; the strong may be softened by it, as Xiang Yu wept before Lady Yu. *Sharp and incisive* refers to angularity; *carved and polished*, to refinement through grinding.

As the proverb says: "Entering as water caltrops, emerging as cockscombs"—this is precisely its meaning. Young men of early success retain some angularity, but once they encounter hardship and worldly affairs, all is worn smooth. Thus it is said: *sharp and incisive*, *carved and polished*—at times like scorching fire, at others like congealed ice. All describe the heart in moments of agitation, anger, sorrow, or fear. In a single breath, its movements surge and recede as though standing once more beyond the four seas—so swift is its haste.

*Thus it hangs suspended*—this is to *press downward*, as if passing by in an instant. *Abyssal and still*—this speaks of the heart’s unmoving state. *Moving, it hangs suspended like Heaven*—this describes the moment a thought arises, as though strung from the sky. *Proud and untetherable*—*proud* here shares its sense with *fèn* (indignant fury), evoking a defiant, ungovernable bearing. *Untetherable* means beyond restraint. The Buddhist sutras ask: "How to subdue the heart?" Observe the word *subdue*—it reveals the meaning of *proud and untetherable*. This passage portrays the human heart with extraordinary subtlety; even Zhuangzi’s brush could hardly surpass it.

Of old, the Yellow Emperor first used benevolence and righteousness to disrupt the human heart. Yao and Shun, in turn, wore the flesh from their thighs and the hair from their shins to nourish the bodies of the world, fretted over their five viscera to enact benevolence and righteousness, and strained their blood and qi to establish laws and standards—yet still they could not prevail. Yao then banished Huan Dou to Mount Chong, exiled the Three Miao to the Three Weirs, and cast Gong Gong into Youdu—this was his failure to master the world. By the time of the Three Kings, the world was thrown into great turmoil. Below arose Jie and Robber Zhi; above, Zeng and Shi; and the Confucians and Mohists all emerged. Joy and anger grew suspicious of one another, the foolish and wise deceived each other, good and evil reviled one another, and truth and falsehood mocked each other—thus the world declined. Great virtue diverged, and the threads of nature and destiny unraveled. The world prized cunning, and the common people exhausted themselves in pursuit.

The phrase "股无胈" signifies that the flesh of the thighs does not grow, while "胫无毛" speaks of wearing out one's legs. "矜" is pronounced *qin* and is the same as *qín*, meaning the shaft of a spear. The *Xiang Ji Zhuan* states, "hoes and spears with thornwood shafts"—this speaks of the rigidity of one's blood and qi. It is as if to say, one's inner vitality is exhausted. "规" means "to create." This describes how, in their efforts to establish benevolence, righteousness, and legal standards, they labored to such an extent. Yet despite this toil, there remained matters they could not overcome, hence the punishments of exile and banishment—this is what is meant by "not prevailing over the world." The "four crimes" brought the world into submission, which was originally an achievement of Shun, but Zhuangzi attributes it to Yao. Thus, though the wording may vary, the marvelous and strange are still evident. In the *Seeing the World* chapter, this is where the inconsistencies lie—it is as if the truth has been laid bare: even Yao and Shun were thus, and by the time it extended to the Three Kings, the terror only grew greater.

"施" means "to extend." Since the Three Kings were thus, below, the petty men followed the ways of Jie and Robber Zhi, while above, the gentlemen admired the reputations of Zeng and Shi, giving rise to the conflicts of the Confucians and Mohists. From this, each took joy in their own views and grew angry at others, each considered themselves wise and others foolish, each deemed themselves good and others evil, each believed themselves truthful and others deceitful. Both sides were the same, hence the mutual suspicion, deception, reproach, and mockery—this is the meaning of the *Equalizing Things* chapter: "That too has its right and wrong, this too has its right and wrong." The term "烂漫" is well-chosen: the principles of nature and destiny became utterly disordered. "求竭" means that there was nothing left to respond with.

Thus, axes and saws were fashioned, inked marking lines and executions were employed, and mallets and chisels were wielded—the world fell into great chaos. The fault lay in disturbing the human heart. Therefore, the worthy retreated to dwell beneath the towering cliffs of great mountains, while the lords of ten thousand chariots trembled with fear in their ancestral halls. In this age, those condemned to death lie heaped upon one another, those in cangues and stocks jostle in crowds, and those subjected to punishment and execution are seen everywhere. Yet the Confucians and Mohists still stretch forth their arms and raise their fists amidst the fetters and shackles. Alas! How extreme is their shamelessness and lack of remorse!

How do I know that the wisdom of the sages does not become the cangues and stocks of the world? That benevolence and righteousness do not become the fetters and chisels? How do I know that Zeng and Shi are not the first arrows of Jie and Robber Zhi? Therefore, it is said: "Abandon sageliness, discard wisdom, and the world will be greatly ordered."

This is a summary of the earlier point about not prevailing over the world, leading to the use of punishments. Axes, saws, inked marking lines, mallets, and chisels are all instruments of punishment. "绳" refers to binding restraints, while "墨" means tattooing or branding.
