The state of sudden surging forth—pushing, crowding, bursting out—is like oil flowing smoothly, alive and ripe. This is the extension of what departs and the contraction of what arrives, precisely what the *Yi* means by "exhausting the spirit and knowing transformation." Having transformed, it gives birth; having transformed again, it dies. Living beings mourn this; people grieve over it. They loosen their bow-cases and cast off their book-wrappers, entangled and confused. The soul and spirit are about to depart, and the body follows—this is the great return to the origin of things. Originally, birth arises from nothing into being; death transforms from being back into nothing. Though the principle is the same, humans and creatures take it as sorrow and delusion. *Taō* is the bow-case; *zhì* is the wrapper. The deluded still cling to something, remaining unclear. If one can awaken, they will untie the bow-case and discard the wrapper—casting it off, abandoning it. *Fēn* and *wǎn* describe transformation: the soul and spirit disperse, and the body follows. Thus, it is called the great return, meaning the return to one’s true dwelling.

The formless taking form and form returning to formlessness—this is universally known, not the concern of those who are about to reach the ultimate. This is the common discourse of the multitude. Those who reach it do not discuss it; those who discuss it do not reach it. The formless form is the unseen. Within form, there is an unseen form—this is what the Buddha calls the *Dharmakāya*, eternally abiding and indestructible. Yet though all know this, they cannot depart from form to seek it, and so they do not attain it. To make it one’s pursuit—this is learning, and to approach the ultimate, what one engages in does not end here. Thus, it is said: this is not the concern of those who are about to reach it. The multitude all speak of this, yet none have attained it. Hence, it is called the common discourse of the multitude. Expounding further: those who attain it do not discuss it; to have such discourse is to not have attained it. Thus, it is said: those who reach it do not discuss it; those who discuss it do not reach it. For the formless form is fundamentally easy to know and requires no explanation. To take this as a topic of discussion is to have not yet reached its most wondrous state—this is speaking at a yet higher level.

Clear insight finds no encounter; disputation is inferior to silence. The Dao cannot be heard; hearing is inferior to blocking it. This is called great attainment. To see and have an encounter is a seeing with traces. The Dao cannot be perceived through form or traces, hence there is no encounter. Thus, it is said: clear insight finds no encounter. Disputation is inferior to silence; to engage in disputation is already wrong. *Mò* means not speaking. The so-called Dao is not heard from others but heard by oneself. To call it "hearing" is already not the Dao. To have heard is not as good as not having heard; to block the ears and have no hearing is best. Thus, it is said: the Dao cannot be heard; hearing is inferior to blocking. *Dà dé* means profound attainment.

Dongguo Zi asked Zhuangzi, "Where does the so-called Dao reside?"
Zhuangzi said, "There is nowhere it does not reside."
Dongguo Zi said, "Specify a place, and then it can be so."
Zhuangzi said, "It is in the ants."
"How can it be so low?"
"It is in the weeds."
"How can it be even lower?"
"It is in the tiles and bricks."
"How can it be even more so?"
"It is in excrement and urine."
Dongguo Zi did not respond.
Zhuangzi said, "Your question fundamentally does not reach the essence. When Zheng Huo asked the market inspector about weighing a pig, the lower he went, the clearer it became." This is a well-crafted fabrication, though it may seem like an extreme statement. Yet in things, whether refined or coarse, the same principle emerges—this is one point of discourse. It aligns with the Buddhist idea of "the insentient preaching the Dharma"; even tiles and bricks blaze forth, constantly speaking. *Qī ér hòu kě* means specifying a place and then it can be so. *Zhì* is the root; your question does not reach the root, hence my answers grow ever lower. *Jiān shì* is like today’s meat market overseer. *Lǚ shǐ* means treading on a pig to know its weight. *Kuàng* means comparison; the lower the market’s base, the clearer the comparison. The official *Zhèng Huò* wanted to know the pig’s fatness or leanness. If he asked the most lowly, the comparison would be even clearer. Thus, it is said: the lower, the clearer. *Zhèng* is the market overseer; *Huò* is the person’s name. This is a metaphor for those who inquire about the Dao.

"You must not be fixed—nothing escapes the ultimate Dao." Such great words are likewise all-pervading and universal. These three—*zhōu*, *biàn*, *xián*—are different names for the same reality; their meaning is one. Have you ever wandered together in the Palace of No-What-Is? Joining in discussion, there is no end to its profundity. Have you ever been idle together—serene and still, vast and clear, harmonious and at ease? Empty and boundless, my will goes nowhere and does not know where it arrives; it departs and comes without knowing where it rests. I have gone and come without knowing its end, wandering in boundless vastness. Great knowledge enters and does not know its limit.

*Mò bì* means having no fixed certainty. If you have no fixed mind, then the principle of all things cannot escape, and how could you doubt my words? Thus, it is said: the ultimate Dao is like this; great words are likewise so. *Zhōu*, *biàn*, and *xián* all share the same meaning, hence it is said: different names, same reality. This sentence illustrates that in things, whether refined or coarse, the principle is one.

The Palace of No-What-Is has already been discussed, expressing the idea of no fixed certainty. *Tóng hé ér lùn* means that without refinement or coarseness, all join in the same discussion—how could there be an end to its profundity? *Diào xián* means harmonious ease. *Dàn*, still; *mò*, vast; *qīng*, clear; *diào xián*, all describe the wonder of non-action. *Liáo* means emptiness. *Yǐ* is the same as *yǐ* (already). To have investigated this to the emptiness of oneness is for my will to be fully content. Thus, it is said: empty and boundless, my will. These four words are concise yet powerful. If there is no going, how can there be an arrival? Though there is departure and coming, there is no place of rest. The two preceding sentences express the unknowability of going and coming. It concludes by saying: I have gone and come without knowing its end—merely seeing it wander in boundless vastness, entering great knowledge without knowing its limit. *Pánghuáng* means roaming; *féng hóng* means vast and open; *dà zhī* means the ultimate Dao.

That which is one with things has no boundary with things; that which things do not bound is called the boundary of things. The unbounded boundary is the boundary of the unbounded. They speak of fullness and emptiness, yet it is not fullness or emptiness; they speak of decline and decay, yet it is not decline or decay; they speak of beginning and end, yet it is not beginning or end; they speak of accumulation and dispersal, yet it is not accumulation or dispersal. To be one with things without boundary is to transform with things.

To transform with things is to be able to "thing" things—what is called "not-thinging" is precisely what enables one to "thing" things. If one does not transform with things, then boundaries arise. Once boundaries exist, one is confined by them; where there is confinement, there is limitation. Thus, what has boundaries is called the boundary of things. To push to the limit is to reach the limitless; to exhaust is to reach the inexhaustible. This is to be unbounded by the boundaries of things and to attain that which is unbounded—what is called the boundary of the unbounded.

It is like standing at the edge of a boundary and seeing that there is no boundary. The formless form, the form of the formless; the unbounded boundary, the boundary of the unbounded—such phrasing reveals the marvels of Zhuangzi’s prose. Decline and flourishing, decay and ascent: mention one, and the other is understood. Fullness and emptiness, rise and fall, beginning and end, gathering and dispersal—all appear to leave traces, yet in truth cannot be exhausted. This is the boundary of the unbounded.

Ē Hé Gān and Shénnóng studied together under Lǎolóng Jí. Shénnóng sat with the door shut, weaving by daylight. Ē Hé Gān pushed open the door at midday and entered, saying, "Lǎolóng is dead." Shénnóng leaned on his staff and rose, then cast it aside with a clatter and laughed, saying, "Heaven knew my stubbornness and arrogance, so it cast me aside and let him die. The Master died without ever drawing forth my wild words!" Yǎn Gāng, upon hearing this, said, "Those who embody the Dao are the ones upon whom the noble ones of the world depend. Yet even at the tip of an autumn hair, one ten-thousandth part of the Dao remains unattained—and still he knew to conceal his wild words before dying. How much more, then, should one who embodies the Dao do so?"

To see nothing when looking, to hear nothing when listening—such is the discourse of men when they speak of the Dao, yet this is merely a way of discussing the Dao, not the Dao itself. *Zhā* means to open; he pushed open the door and entered. *Bō rán* is the sound of casting aside the staff.

chunks.original_text: 天知予以天呼老龙吉也 夫子在则有启发予之大言今既死则无启发予之言盖谓老龙吉死而无言矣 弇姓也 缸名也 因吊老龙而闻神农之言体道者与道为一也 系归而宗之也 有体道之人则天下之君子皆归而宗之今神农于道未有所见而亦知老龙之死为藏其狂言况其体道与老龙同者乎 狂言即大言也 其意盖谓道在不言藏其言而死所以为道神农未造此境而亦为此言况高神农者乎 秋毫之端至小矣 于此而未有万分之一少之又少可知矣 佛经算数譬喻亦有此语势道本无声形不可视听若论说于人以冥冥而名其道是特强名而已实非道也 故曰所以论道而非道也 即言者不知之意形声有也 冥冥无也 知有之为无不若并与无无之盖谓神农之为此言亦未为知道也 于是泰清问乎 无穷曰子知道乎 无穷曰吾不知又问乎 无为无为曰吾知道曰子之知道亦有数乎 曰有曰其数若何无为曰吾知道之可以贵可以贱可以约可以散此吾所以知道之数也 泰清以之言也 问乎 无始曰若是则无穷之弗知与无为之知孰是而孰非乎 无始曰不知深矣 知之浅矣 弗知内矣 知之外矣 于是泰清中而叹曰弗知乃知乎 知乃不知乎 孰知不知之知无始曰道不可闻闻而非也 道不可见见而非也 道不可言言而非也 知形形之不形乎 道不当名无始曰有问道而应之者不知道也 虽问道者亦未闻道道无问问无应无问问之是问穷也 无应应之是无内也 以无内待问穷若是者外不观乎 宇宙内不知乎 大初是以不过乎 昆仑不游乎 大虚
chunks.translated_text:
"Heaven knew me"—here, "Heaven" is used to address the deceased Old Long Ji. While the Master lived, he could draw forth my grand words; now that he is dead, no one can. This means that with Old Long Ji’s death, my words have died with him.

Yǎn is the surname; Gāng, the given name. Upon offering condolences for Old Long Ji, he heard Shénnóng’s words. Those who embody the Dao become one with it. *Xì* means to depend upon and honor: if one embodies the Dao, all noble ones of the world will depend upon and honor them. Now, Shénnóng, who has not yet perceived the Dao, still understood that Old Long Ji’s death was a concealment of his wild words—how much more, then, should one who embodies the Dao in the same way as Old Long Ji do so? "Wild words" are the same as "grand words." His meaning was this: the Dao resides in non-speech. To conceal one’s words and die is to be in accord with the Dao. Shénnóng has not yet reached this realm, yet he still spoke thus—how much more should one surpassing Shénnóng do so?

The tip of an autumn hair is the smallest of things. To have not even one ten-thousandth part of the Dao within it is to have less than the least—this much is clear. Buddhist scriptures, in their calculations and analogies, also contain such expressions.

The Dao originally has no sound or form; it cannot be seen or heard. If one discusses it with others, naming it "obscure obscurity," this is merely a forced designation—it is not the Dao itself. Thus it is said, "This is a way of discussing the Dao, not the Dao." That is to say, the speaker does not truly know. Form and sound exist; obscurity does not. To know existence as non-existence is not as good as merging with non-existence entirely. This means that Shénnóng’s words, though spoken, do not yet constitute true knowledge of the Dao.

Thereupon Tài Qīng asked Wúqióng, "Do you know the Dao?"
Wúqióng said, "I do not know."
He asked again.
Wúwéi Wúwéi said, "I know the Dao."
Tài Qīng said, "Does your knowledge of the Dao have a pattern?"
Wúwéi said, "It does."
Tài Qīng said, "What is this pattern like?"
Wúwéi said, "I know that the Dao can be noble, can be base, can be constrained, can be dispersed—this is the pattern by which I know the Dao."

Tài Qīng then took these words and asked Wúshǐ, "If this is so, then is Wúqióng’s not-knowing correct, or is Wúwéi’s knowing correct? Which is right and which is wrong?"
Wúshǐ said, "Not-knowing runs deep; knowing is shallow. Not-knowing is internal; knowing is external."

Thereupon Tài Qīng sighed from within, saying, "Is not-knowing then knowing? Is knowing then not-knowing? Who knows the knowledge of not-knowing?"
Wúshǐ said, "The Dao cannot be heard—what is heard is not it. The Dao cannot be seen—what is seen is not it. The Dao cannot be spoken—what is spoken is not it. Do you know that the formless cannot be formed? The Dao should not be named."

Wúshǐ said, "If one asks about the Dao and another responds, neither knows the Dao. Even the one who asks about the Dao has not heard the Dao. The Dao has no questions; questions have no answers. To ask questions is to exhaust inquiry; to answer is to lack inwardness. Responding to exhaustion with emptiness—if this is so, then externally, one does not observe the cosmos; internally, one does not know what lies within the universe. Thus one does not transgress the Great Beginning, does not wander the Kunlun, and does not roam the Great Void."

ven at the tip of an autumn hair, one ten-thousandth part of the Dao remains unattained—and still he knew to conceal his wild words before dying. How much more, then, should one who embodies the Dao do so?"

To see nothing when looking, to hear nothing when listening—such is the discourse of men when they speak of the Dao, yet this is merely a way of discussing the Dao, not the Dao itself. *Zhā* means to open; he pushed open the door and entered. *Bō rán* is the sound of casting aside the staff.

chunks.original_text: 发语之端着于是两字即是佛经我闻一时之上着如是两字也 道之有数谓可历历而言也 贵贱合散皆道之可以历数者约合也 内自得也 外与道为二也 不知之知乃不可名言之妙也 形形之不形即不物乃能物物也 当对也 有道之名则名与道对立即离其本然之真矣 故曰道不当名道本无问问之而答我已离道彼之问者所闻亦非道矣 问穷者言其所见至于问而穷盖谓泥言语求知见之非也 无内者中心未得此道也 得此道则不应答之矣 宇宙可见者也 故曰外大初不可见者也 故曰内昆仑在于宇宙之外太虚又在昆仑之外昆仑且未过安得至太虚乎 光曜问乎无有曰夫子有乎其无有乎光曜不得问而孰视其状貌窅然空然终日视之而不见听之而不闻搏之而不得也光曜曰至矣其孰能至此乎予能有无矣而未能无无也及为无有矣何从至此哉 孰视其状数语只形容道之不可见也予能有无未能无无此言妙之又妙也未能无无则我犹在无字之内为无字所有矣何从至于窅然空然者乎圆觉曰说无觉者亦复如是觉而至于无觉可谓妙矣而犹以无觉为未尽即此未能无无为无所有之意前之知无为防清无始此之光曜无有似此等名字其寓意却甚明非其他王倪被衣等之比 大马之捶钩者年八十矣而不失毫芒大马曰子巧与有道与曰臣有守也臣之年二十而好捶钩于物无视也非钩无察也是用之者假不用者也以长得其用而况乎无不用者乎物孰不资焉 钩带也大马大司马也捶鍜也大司马之属有鍜钩者老而精绝至于无毫厘之差言其巧也非钩无察即前所谓唯蜩翼之知也用心专一于钩之外无所见也用者巧也不用者道之自然者也无不用者道之无为而无不为者也言我以不用自然之妙而用之于巧且长得其用而至于老况道之无为无不为者天下之物孰不资赖之乎 冉求问于仲尼曰未有天地可知邪仲尼曰可古犹今也 冉求失问而退明日复问曰昔者吾问未有天地可知乎
chunks.translated_text:
At the outset of speech, the two characters placed here correspond to the "Thus have I heard" at the beginning of Buddhist sutras. The numerability of the Dao means it can be enumerated and spoken of in detail. The convergence and dispersion of high and low are all aspects of the Dao that can be enumerated—this is the principle of convergence. Inwardly, one attains it; outwardly, one sets it apart from the Dao as a duality.

The knowing that transcends knowledge is the ineffable subtlety. That which is "formless among forms" is the non-thing that enables all things. To be in opposition is to have a name for the Dao, for then the name stands in opposition to the Dao, departing from its original truth. Thus it is said, "The Dao should not be named." The Dao itself has no questions; if one asks and another answers, I have already departed from the Dao, and the questioner’s hearing is also not the Dao.

"Exhausting inquiry" means that one’s views lead to a dead end in questioning, for it refers to clinging to words and seeking knowledge and perception where they do not exist. "Lacking inwardness" means the center has not attained this Dao. If one attains this Dao, one does not respond.

The cosmos is what can be seen, hence it is said, "externally, one does not observe the cosmos." The Great Beginning is what cannot be seen, hence it is said, "internally, one does not know what lies within." Kunlun lies beyond the cosmos, and the Great Void lies beyond Kunlun. If one has not even traversed Kunlun, how can one reach the Great Void?

Guangyao asked Wu You, "Does the Master possess it, or is he without it?" Guangyao, unable to ask further, gazed intently at his appearance—profoundly empty, utterly vacant. He looked at him all day without seeing, listened without hearing, and grasped without obtaining.

Guangyao said, "This is perfection! Who could attain such a state? I can attain being and non-being, but I have not yet attained non-being of non-being." When one becomes "without being," how can one reach this state?

The passage describing his gaze—"gazing intently at his appearance"—merely depicts the Dao’s invisibility. "I can attain being and non-being, but I have not yet attained non-being of non-being"—this saying is marvelous beyond marvels. If one has not attained non-being of non-being, then the self still resides within the realm of non-being, possessed by the concept of non-being. How can one reach the state of profound emptiness and utter vacancy?

The *Yuanjue Jing* says, "Those who speak of non-enlightenment are likewise so." To awaken to the point of non-enlightenment may be called marvelous, yet even this is not the ultimate, for it still regards non-enlightenment as incomplete. This is the meaning of "not yet attaining non-being of non-being." The earlier "knowing non-being" of Fang Qing and Wu Shi, and now Guangyao’s "without being," seem to use such names, yet their implied meaning is quite clear—unlike other figures such as Wang Ni or Bei Yi.

The smith of hooks under Da Ma was eighty years old yet never missed by a hair’s breadth. Da Ma said, "Are you skillful, or do you possess the Dao?"

He replied, "Your servant has his discipline. At twenty, I delighted in forging hooks. To other things, I paid no heed; apart from hooks, I observed nothing. This is the user borrowing from the non-user. By prolonging its use, one attains mastery—how much more so for that which is never unused? What thing does not rely on it?"

Hooks refer to belt hooks. Da Ma was the Grand Marshal. *Chui* means forging, and *qian* refers to the smith of hooks, an official under the Grand Marshal. Though old, his skill was so precise that not even a hair’s difference was missed—this speaks of his craftsmanship. "Apart from hooks, I observed nothing" echoes the earlier "knowing only the cicada’s wings." His focus was entirely on hooks, seeing nothing beyond. The "user" is skill, while the "non-user" is the Dao’s spontaneity. "Never unused" refers to the Dao’s non-action that accomplishes all. He says, "I borrow the marvel of non-use to apply to skill, and through long practice, I attain mastery even in old age. How much more so for the Dao, which is non-action yet accomplishes all? What in the world does not rely on it?"

Ran Qiu asked Confucius, "Before there was heaven and earth, could it be known?"

Confucius said, "It could. The past is like the present."

Ran Qiu, having asked amiss, withdrew. The next day, he asked again, "Formerly, I asked whether what existed before heaven and earth could be known..."

chunks.original_text: 夫子曰可古犹今也 昔日吾昭然今日吾昧然敢问何谓也 仲尼曰昔之昭然也 神者先受之今之昧然也 且又为不神者求邪无古无今无始无终未有子孙而有子孙可乎 冉求未对仲尼曰已矣 未应矣 不以生生死不以死死生死生有待邪皆有所一体有先天地生者物邪物物者非物物出不得先物也 犹其有物也 无已圣人之爱人也 终无已者亦乃取于是者也 太极之初阴阳判而为天地天地之运行阴阳之往来循环而无已古亦如是今亦如是也 以古犹今而答未有天地之问意盖如此昭昭见之甚明也 神者在我之知觉者也 不神者知觉之灵为气所昏也 昔日之昭昭虚灵知觉者在也 故能受之今之昧然者虚灵知觉者不在故又有所求而未知也 无今古无始终言太极之理一动一静无时不然也 造化之理生生不穷如人之有子孙不待其有而后知之也 有此人则有此子孙有此宇宙则有此阴阳无一息之可间断也 已矣 未应矣
chunks.translated_text:
Confucius said, "It could. The past is like the present."

"You said, 'The past is like the present.' Formerly, I was enlightened; today, I am benighted. May I ask what this means?"

Confucius said, "Formerly, you were enlightened because the spirit had first received it. Today, you are benighted because you now seek it through what is not spirit. Without past, without present, without beginning, without end—could there be descendants without ancestors?

Ran Qiu did not respond. Confucius said, "Enough. No answer is needed. One does not give life to life or death to death. Do life and death depend on something? All are of one body. There is that which existed before heaven and earth—is it a thing? That which gives rise to things is not itself a thing and cannot precede things. Yet it is as if there were a thing. Without end, the sage’s love for humanity also takes this as its model. At the inception of the Great Ultimate, yin and yang divided to form heaven and earth. The movement of heaven and earth, the alternation of yin and yang, cycles without end. The past was thus; the present is thus.

To answer the question of what existed before heaven and earth by saying the past is like the present—this is the meaning. The luminous is seen with utmost clarity. The spirit is the awareness within me; what is not spirit is the numinous clarity of awareness obscured by qi. Formerly, your luminous clarity was present, for the numinous awareness was there—thus you could receive it. Today, your benightedness arises because the numinous awareness is absent, and so you seek yet do not know.

Without past or present, without beginning or end—this speaks of the principle of the Great Ultimate. In every movement and stillness, it is ever thus. The principle of creation is inexhaustibly generative, like the descendants of a person—one does not wait for their existence to know of them. With this person, there are these descendants; with this cosmos, there are these yin and yang. Not a single breath’s interruption is possible.

Enough. No answer is needed."

chunks.original_text: 言汝到此不必更形于言矣 才有生字则有死字是因生而后生一死字也 才有死字则有生字是因死之名而后死其生者也 此即无生无死四字又如此变换言句死生之有待一体而已一体犹一本也 即一理也 即造化之自然也 物物者非物则有非物者必生于天地之先岂可以物名之故曰有先天地生者物邪言非物之物不可以物名也 既名为物则不得为在天地之先者矣 如此便是有物也 故曰物出不得先物也 犹其有物也 此是一句既曰有物则物之相物无穷已矣 故曰犹其有物也 无已如此等处皆其文字之妙者圣人之爱人则有迹可见矣 形迹之相求至于无时而已者盖其所取在于有物而不知物物者之非物也 颜渊问乎仲尼曰回尝闻诸夫子曰无有所将无有所迎回敢问其游仲尼曰古之人外化而内不化今之人内化而外不化与物化者一不化者也安化安不化安与之相靡必与之莫多狶韦氏之囿黄帝之圃有虞氏之宫汤武之室君子之人若儒墨者师故以是非相也而况今之人乎圣人处物不伤物不伤物者物亦不能伤也唯无所伤者为能与人相将迎 无将无迎即无心于物者也 应物而不累于物则为外化因感而应不动其心则为内不化故曰古之人外化而内不化与接为构日以心斗则为内化与物相劘相刃而见役于内则为外不化故曰今之人内化而外不化以我之内不化者而外应乎 物所过者化而无将迎则化亦不知不化亦不知故曰与物化者一不化者也 安化安不化一不化者无心之心也 安犹岂也 相靡言相磨也 靡与劘同安与岂与也 多求多也 求多相胜也 莫多则不求相胜也 必与之莫多言至道之人必与物不求多以相胜也 狶韦黄帝有虞汤武儒墨之师皆未能尽内不化之道故至于以是非相言其犹有是非之争也 五味相夺而后可以为故曰相以狶韦而下与儒墨对说是以小抑大之意囿圃宫室者谓其以此为窠臼也 不伤物即与物化也 既与物化则物亦不能伤谓其无所累也 惟其心无所累所以能与人相将迎前言无将迎此言与人相将迎即无为无不为不物乃物物之意 山林与皋壤与使我欣欣然而乐与乐未毕也哀又继之哀乐之来吾不能御其去弗能止悲夫世人直为物逆旅耳夫知遇而不知所不遇知能能而不能所不能无知无能者固人之所不免也夫务免乎人之所不免者岂不亦悲哉至言去言至为去为齐知之所知则浅矣 凡人游于山林皋壤之间其始也 必乐既乐则必有所感感则哀矣 兰亭记中正用此意因物而乐因物而哀去来于我皆不自由则我之此心是哀乐之旅舍也 此言自无主人公为物所动也 遇可见者也 不遇不可见者也 可见者人也 不可见者天也 能其所能人也 其所不能天也 举世之人皆有不自知不自能者既谓之人皆不免此故曰无知无能者固人所不免也 唯其知人而不知天故尝用心用智欲以免其所不可免者岂不可悲也 哉 至言则无言矣
chunks.translated_text:
Here your arrival at this point renders further words unnecessary. The moment "birth" arises, "death" follows—it is by birth that the word "death" comes to be. The moment "death" arises, "birth" follows—it is by the name of death that what is born is later called "life." This is what "no birth, no death" means, and how these phrases transform. Death and life depend upon one another; they are of one body—one body is like one root. It is one principle, the spontaneity of creation itself.

That which gives rise to things is not itself a thing; what is not a thing must have existed before heaven and earth—how could it be named as a thing? Hence it is said: "Is there something that existed before heaven and earth and yet is a thing?" To speak of the "not-thing" that is a thing is not to name it as a thing. Once named as a thing, it cannot be said to have existed before heaven and earth. Thus it is already a thing. Therefore it is said: "A thing cannot emerge before things." Yet where there is a thing, the appearances of things are endless. Hence it is said: "It is as if there were a thing." In such passages, the subtlety of the text shines—here the sage’s care for humanity leaves traces one can see.

The pursuit of appearances extends without cease, for what is sought lies in the existence of things, yet one does not know that what gives rise to things is not itself a thing. Yan Yuan asked Confucius, saying: "I once heard from you, Master, that one should not send off nor welcome anything. May I ask about the wandering you speak of?" Confucius replied: "The people of old transformed outwardly while inwardly remaining untransformed; the people of today transform inwardly while outwardly remaining untransformed. Those who transform with things are one with those who do not transform. How could one be at peace with transformation or non-transformation? How could one be at one with them without friction? One must be with them without seeking to surpass.

The parks of Xiwei, the gardens of the Yellow Emperor, the palaces of Youyu, the halls of Tang and Wu—these were the dwellings of the noble person, such as the followers of Confucianism and Mohism, who took them as teachers. Thus they contended with one another over right and wrong, and how much more so the people of today! The sage engages with things without harming them; one who does not harm things cannot be harmed by them. Only one who is without harm can send off and welcome others. To send off nothing and welcome nothing is to be without a mind for things. Responding to things without being burdened by them is outward transformation; being moved by stimuli without disturbing the heart is inward non-transformation.

Thus it is said: 'The people of old transformed outwardly while inwardly remaining untransformed.' To engage in daily contention with the heart is inward transformation; to grind and clash with things, being inwardly enslaved, is outward non-transformation. Thus it is said: 'The people of today transform inwardly while outwardly remaining untransformed.' With one’s inwardly untransformed self, one outwardly responds to things. What passes is transformed, yet without sending off or welcoming, one does not know transformation or non-transformation. Thus it is said: 'Those who transform with things are one with those who do not transform.'

'How could one be at peace with transformation or non-transformation?' 'How' here means 'how could it be?' 'To be at one' speaks of mutual friction. 'Friction' is the same as 'grinding.' 'How' is the same as 'how could it be?' 'Seeking to surpass' means seeking much; much seeking leads to competition. 'Without seeking to surpass' means not competing. 'One must be with them without seeking to surpass' means that one of the utmost Dao must be with things without seeking to surpass them.

Xiwei, the Yellow Emperor, Youyu, Tang, Wu, and the teachers of Confucianism and Mohism were all unable to fully embody the way of inward non-transformation, hence they came to contend over right and wrong. The struggle over right and wrong arises only after the five flavors contend, hence it is said 'contend.' To speak of Xiwei and below in contrast to Confucianism and Mohism is to express the idea of belittling the great.

Parks, gardens, palaces, and halls are called 'nests and burrows.' Not harming things is to transform with them; having transformed with things, they cannot harm you, for you are without burden. Only with a heart free of burden can one send off and welcome others. The earlier statement about 'sending off nothing and welcoming nothing' and this statement about 'sending off and welcoming others' are the same as 'non-action and yet nothing left undone,' expressing the meaning of 'not being a thing yet giving rise to things.'

Mountains and forests, marshlands and wilds—these make me joyful and glad. Yet before the joy is complete, sorrow follows. The coming of joy and sorrow I cannot resist; their going I cannot halt. Alas! The people of the world are but travelers in things. They know what they encounter but not what they do not; they know what they can do but not what they cannot. Ignorance and inability are what no person can avoid. Yet those who strive to avoid what no person can avoid—is this not also lamentable?

Profound words abandon words; profound action abandons action. To equalize knowledge with what is known is shallow indeed. When people wander among mountains, forests, marshlands, and wilds, they begin with joy. Once joyful, they are inevitably moved; once moved, sorrow follows. Among Lao Dan’s disciples was one named Gengsang Chu, who had partially grasped the Master’s Dao. He went north to dwell on Mount Weilü. Those among his retainers who were cunningly clever departed from him; those among his concubines who were ostentatiously benevolent kept their distance. Only the dull-witted and the idle remained to serve him. After three years, Weilü flourished. The people of Weilü said to one another: "When Master Gengsang first arrived, we regarded him with surprise. Now, when we reckon our days, we find them insufficient, but when we reckon our years, we find them abundant. He must be a sage! When Gengsang Chu heard this, he turned to the south with a troubled countenance. His disciples were perplexed. Gengsang Chu said: "Disciples, why are you perplexed by me? Chickens and chickens do not differ in their virtue, but in their capacity. Some can, some cannot—such is the inherent disparity in their endowment. Now my endowment is meager and insufficient to transform you. Why not journey south to see Laozi and entrust your learning to him? To 'entrust your learning' is to receive instruction. "All possess human form, and their hearts, ears, and eyes are the same—thus I say I do not know their difference. Each person has this heart, yet the mad cannot grasp it, just as the blind and deaf have nothing to see or hear. 'Separate' means 'open.' My form and another’s form are both open and unobstructed, yet I am now divided by desires. I seek the heart with the heart, yet it becomes ever more elusive. Thus it is said, 'desiring to seek one another, they cannot attain one another.' I strive to seek the heart but cannot grasp it, and now you tell me not to let my thoughts and cares flutter about. If I diligently apply myself to seek the Dao, might I yet attain understanding?"

Nanrong Chu spoke thus without resolution, and Master Gengsang, wishing to guide him further but having exhausted his words, directed him to see Laozi. Thus he said, "My words are exhausted"—a humble pretense, not truly at the end of his speech. The wild bee is a small bee; the bean caterpillar, a large worm in the bean. The Yue chicken is small, the Lu chicken large, and the swan goose a great bird. The small bee cannot enchant the large worm; the small chicken cannot brood the large egg—this illustrates that his power is too slight to transform you.

Thereupon, Nanrong Chu carried provisions and traveled seven days and seven nights until he reached Laozi’s abode. Laozi said, "Have you come from the land of Chu?"

Nanrong Chu replied, "Yes."

Laozi said, "Why have you come with so many others?"

Nanrong Chu, startled, looked behind him. Laozi said, "Do you not understand what I mean?"

Nanrong Chu bowed his head in shame, then looked up and sighed, saying, "Now I have forgotten my answer and lost my question."

Laozi said, "What do you mean?"

Nanrong Chu said, "If I am ignorant, people call me foolish; if I am wise, it only brings sorrow to my body. If I am unkind, I harm others; if I am kind, it only brings sorrow to myself. If I am unrighteous, I injure others; if I am righteous, it only brings sorrow to me. How can I escape this? These three concerns are what trouble me. I wish to ask you about them through my journey from Chu."

Laozi said, "A moment ago, I saw it in the space between your brows, and thus I understood you. Now you speak again, clinging to your words as if bound by rules, like a child clinging to its parents, or raising a pole to seek the sea. You are lost indeed—so bewildered!"

chunks.translated_text:
Here your cleansing has been thorough—how thorough! Yet where aversion lingers, the heart clings, and thus the inner vitality still brims. *Vernacular note*: *Vernacular* (韄) means binding an object with leather; *jian* (揵) is the bolt of a door. Both are metaphors for grasping and restraint. When one responds to external things and seeks to regulate oneself, the constraints multiply and cannot be grasped. With externals unsettled, one then turns inward, hence "will internally bolt." When the heart’s turmoil seeks self-regulation, it becomes entangled and cannot be grasped. With internals unsettled, one then turns outward again. This describes those who study the Dao yet fail to grasp its essence: whether attempting to control externally or internally, they find no foothold. In such a state, even the virtue one possesses cannot be held—how much less those who wander without the Dao?

"Wandering without the Dao" means following the principle of naturalness. Only the perfected person can follow naturalness.

Nanrong Chu said: "In my village, there is a sick man. When villagers ask about his illness, the sick man can describe his symptoms—yet his illness is still not severe. If I, having heard the great Dao, am like one who drinks medicine only to worsen his illness, then I wish only to hear the *Classic of Preserving Life*."

Laozi said: "The *Classic of Preserving Life*—can you embrace the One? Can you avoid losing it? Can you know fortune and misfortune without divination? Can you stop? Can you cease? Can you abandon others and seek within yourself? Can you be unburdened? Can you be guileless? Can you be like a child?

A child wails all day without hoarseness—such is the perfection of harmony. A child grasps all day without cramping—such is the fullness of its power. A child gazes all day without blinking—its focus is not external. It walks without knowing its destination, rests without knowing its purpose, flows with things and moves with the current. This is the *Classic of Preserving Life*."

When the sick man is still able to describe his symptoms, his illness is not yet severe. When illness becomes severe, he can no longer speak. Now, I wish to hear the great Dao yet do not know where I am afflicted—my confusion is profound. Though you offer teachings, they only deepen my bewilderment, like drinking medicine that worsens the illness. Thus, I dare not ask for instruction and wish only to learn the way of preserving life.

"Embrace the One" means preserving wholeness and purity. "Avoid losing" means safeguarding what is received from Heaven without loss. "Knowing fortune and misfortune without divination" means that the way of utmost sincerity can foresee all. "Can you stop?" means can you settle? "Can you cease?" is what the Buddhists call "great rest." "Abandon others and seek within" means focusing inward rather than outward. "Unburdened" describes being without encumbrance. "Guileless" describes being without knowledge. "Can you be like a child?" means not losing the heart of an infant. "Wailing" means crying.

"Summoning what you love" means seeking what is right; "casting off what you hate" means shunning what is wrong. Yet with love and aversion still present, your heart remains confused—hence ten days of sorrow. *Shú zāi* (how thoroughly!) is like *shú yǔ* (how long!), meaning your effort has been prolonged. *Yùyù hū* expresses the unsettled mind, not yet at peace.

chunks.original_text: 嗌喉也 嗄声干也 赤子嗥啼而声不干无容心而不伤其和也 掜屈不可伸也 人之手久握而不伸则伸时必有窒碍小儿则不然者其自然之性个个如此共同也 德性也 目视而不瞬虽视而无所视也 未知外物也 知有外物则为偏矣 瞬与瞬同行不知所之居不知所为即言无心也 委蛇随顺也 或行或居动而与物随顺波流也 同波即与物偕往之意如此则可以为卫生之常故曰是卫生之经已 南荣趎曰然则是至人之德已乎曰非也是乃所谓氷解冻释者夫至人者相与交食乎地而交乐乎天不以人物利害相撄不相与为怪不相与为谋不相与为事翛然而往侗然而来是谓卫生之经已曰然则是至乎曰未也吾固告汝曰能儿子乎儿子动不知所为行不知所之身若槁木之枝而心若死灰若是者祸亦不至福亦不来祸福无有恶有人灾也 趎问卫生之经求其次者也 及闻老子之言如此之妙故有至人之德之问此问自是而老子又曰非也 盖恐其住着于此又成窠臼即释氏所谓立处非真是也 氷解冻释即脱洒自悟之意相与交食于地与人同也 交乐于天自同乎 天也
chunks.translated_text:
The throat is the gullet. A hoarse voice is a dry throat. An infant wails and cries without its voice growing hoarse, for it has no deliberate intent and thus does not harm its harmony. "Clasping" means the inability to extend. When a person’s hand is clenched for too long and then stretched, there will inevitably be obstruction. An infant, however, is not like this—its nature is spontaneous, and all are alike in this. This is virtue.

The eyes gaze without blinking, though they see nothing; they are unaware of external things. To know of external things is to be partial. Blinking is the same as moving—one does not know where one dwells or what one does, which is to say, one is without intent. "Compliant and yielding" means following and adapting. Whether moving or at rest, one moves in accord with things, flowing like a wave. To be of the same wave is to go along with things in this way, and thus one may take this as the constant principle of preserving life. Therefore, it is called "the warp of preserving life."

Nan Rong Chu said, "Then is this the virtue of the perfected person?"

"No," was the reply. "This is what is called the melting of ice and the thawing of frost. As for the perfected person: they eat and associate with others on earth and take joy in the heavens. They do not entangle themselves with the gains and losses of people and things, nor do they conspire with others in strangeness, nor do they scheme together in affairs. They come and go with ease, guileless and unburdened. This is called 'the warp of preserving life.'"

"Then is this perfection?"

"Not yet. I have already told you: can you be like a child? A child moves without knowing what it does, walks without knowing where it goes. Its body is like the branch of a withered tree, and its heart is like dead ashes. In such a state, misfortune does not arrive, nor does fortune. Without misfortune or fortune, there is no aversion to the calamities of others."

Chu asked about the warp of preserving life, seeking what comes next. Upon hearing Laozi’s words, so wondrous, he then asked about the virtue of the perfected person. This question arose naturally, but Laozi again said, "No," for he feared Chu would cling to this and make it a fixed pattern—what the Buddhists call "taking the provisional as real." "The melting of ice and the thawing of frost" means liberation and spontaneous awakening. "Eating and associating with others on earth" means being the same as others; "taking joy in the heavens" means being in accord with the heavens.

chunks.original_text: 交俱也 同也 相撄相触也 为怪为异也 不为谋无计度之心也 不为事无事事之迹也 又曰是卫生之经已上言夫至人者此曰卫生则所言卫生之道即至人事矣 以此而观则前面非也 两字分明不是实话趎既闻此又曰然则是至乎 意谓此道即至道矣 而老子又曰未也 既曰未也 则当别有话头却又提起前头能儿子乎 之语则所谓未也 亦非实话祸福无有者言超出祸福之外也 人灾者世情之患害也 我既超出祸福之外则去世远矣 又何有世间之患害乎 曰非也 曰未也 盖不欲与之尽言使之自悟也 禅宗多用此一解
chunks.translated_text:
"To 'associate' means to be together, to be the same, to mingle and interact—this is to be strange, to be different. It is not to scheme, for there is no heart of calculation; it is not to act, for there are no traces of deliberate action. It is further said: this is the warp of preserving life. The above speaks of the perfected person, but here it speaks of preserving life—thus what is called the Way of preserving life is precisely the affair of the perfected person. Viewed in this light, the earlier 'No' was clearly not the whole truth. Chu, having heard this, then asked, 'Then is this perfection?'—meaning that this Way is the ultimate Way. Yet Laozi again said, 'Not yet.' Since he said 'Not yet,' there should have been another topic, but instead he returned to the earlier words, 'Can you be like a child?'—thus this 'Not yet' was also not the whole truth.

'Without misfortune or fortune' means to transcend beyond misfortune and fortune. 'The calamities of others' refers to the afflictions of worldly concerns. If I have already transcended beyond misfortune and fortune, then I have departed far from the world—how could I still have the afflictions of the worldly realm? To say 'No' and to say 'Not yet' is not to wish to speak exhaustively, but to allow him to awaken on his own. The Chan school often employs this method of explanation."

chunks.original_text: 宇泰定者发乎天光发乎天光者人见其人人有修者乃今有恒有恒者人舍之天助之人之所舍谓之天民天之所助谓之天子学者学其所不能学也行者行其所不能行也辩者辩其所不能辩也知止乎其所不能知至矣若有不即是者天钧败之 自此以下庄子泛言至理也 宇胸中也 泰然而定则天光发见即诚而明也 故曰宇防定者发乎 天光天光既发则人虽见其为人而已自同于天矣 人有修者修真之人也 修真之人至于天光既发则有恒矣 恒久也 便是至诚悠久也 至诚而至于悠久则天亦助之人亦归之舍止也 归也 天民天人也
chunks.translated_text:
The one whose cosmic vastness is settled emits celestial radiance—this emission of celestial radiance is seen by others as the person they perceive. Those who possess cultivation are now constant; those who are constant are abandoned by others yet assisted by Heaven. What others abandon is called the Heavenly People; what Heaven assists is called the Son of Heaven.

The scholar studies what they cannot study; the practitioner practices what they cannot practice; the debater debates what they cannot debate. To know the limit of what one cannot know is perfection. If there is any deviation from this, the celestial balance will disrupt it.

From this point onward, Zhuangzi broadly expounds the ultimate principle.

"Cosmic vastness" refers to the chest. When one is serene and settled, celestial radiance manifests—this is sincerity becoming illumination. Thus it is said, "The one whose cosmic vastness is settled emits celestial radiance." Once celestial radiance is emitted, though others see them as merely human, they have already merged with Heaven.

"Those who possess cultivation" refers to those who cultivate the real. When those who cultivate the real reach the point where celestial radiance is emitted, they become constant. Constancy means enduring permanence—this is the utmost sincerity extending into eternity. When utmost sincerity reaches eternity, Heaven assists them, and others gather to them—abandonment becomes dwelling, gathering becomes return. The Heavenly People are the people of Heaven.

chunks.original_text: 言非常人也 天子者天爱之如子也 学行辩皆有迹者也 所不能学所不能行所不能辩自然者也 人之所知至其所不能知而止则为所造之极故曰至矣 天钧即造化也 有不即是者不就是也 即就也 不就是反是也 反是则失造化自然之理矣 败失也 备物以将形藏不虞以生心敬中以达彼若是而万恶至者皆天也而非人也不足以滑成不可内于灵台灵台者有持而不知其所持而不可持者也 备物者备万物之理也 万物皆备于我也 将形者顺其生之自然也 不虞不计度不思虑也 退藏于不思虑之地而其心之应物随时而生即佛家所谓无所住而生其心也 存于中者敬则应于外者无不通即敬以直内义以方外也 达通也 彼在外者也 万恶者不如意之事也 吾之所造既至于是而犹有万恶至者则是天实为之非人事之失有以致之又何足以滑我胸中浑成之德故曰皆天也 而非人也 不足以滑成灵台心也 不纳于灵台外物不入其心也 外物不入其心所以不滑其成也 有持者言有所主也 不知其所持者虽有所主而不知其所主大而化也 不可持者言有所持守则未化矣 此一句三持字最说得精微不可草草看过 不见其诚已而发每发而不当业入而不舍每更为失为不善乎 显明之中者人得而诛之为不善乎 幽间之中者得而诛之明乎 人明乎 者然后能独行此数句又说不善之人未能成已而有所作为妄发也 妄发则每事皆不当业已入于其间虽知之而不能自舍此耻过作非者也 更换也 耻过而作非每有所更改转见差错故曰每更为失业不训事今人曰业已成行业已如此便是此业字如此之人所为既不善矣 非有人诛则有责言幽明之间有不可得而逃者人能知幽明之可畏则能谨独矣 故曰明乎 人明乎 然后能独行此即莫见乎 莫显乎 微是以君子慎其独也 独行即慎独也 似此数语入之经书亦得 劵内者行乎无名劵外者志乎期费行乎无名者唯庸有光志乎期费者唯贾人也人见其跂犹之魁然与物穷者物入焉与物且者其身之不能容焉能容人不能容人者无亲无亲者尽人 劵内者所求在我之分内也 即孟子所谓求则得之求在内者也 无名者人无得而名也 劵外求在外者也 务外之人志之所期不过为费用之资耳 言求以自利也 唯庸有光充实而有辉光也 庸常也 光常在也 舍己而求外志在得利商贾者之用心也 故曰唯贾人也 跂高而自立之貌人见其外或富或贵有过于人则以为魁然而可尊而不知其与物欲相为终始至于穷尽而后己是其一身皆没入于物欲之内矣 故曰与物穷物入焉 且苟也 逐逐于物苟且以求得有至于防身而不悔者故曰与物且者其身之不能容身且不能容于人何有以其不能容人之心及其甚者则亲戚骨肉皆疎弃矣 故曰不能容人者无亲人而无亲则人道绝矣 故曰无亲者尽人尽绝也 看此数句庄子如何不理会世法 兵莫于志镆铘为下冦莫大于阴阳无所逃于天地之间非阴阳贼之心则使之也 志者心有所着也心有所着皆能自伤人之自害莫于此志尤甚于兵之镆铘故曰兵莫于志镆铘为下阴阳之气皆能伤人犹冦也然此心若平和则阴阳岂能为害故曰非阴阳贼之心则使之即所谓其焦火其寒凝氷是也此两句极佳在心学工夫此语最切 道通其分也其成也毁也所恶乎分者其分也以备所以恶乎备者其有以备 成毁二事分而为二以道观之一而已矣故曰道通其分也人心既分彼我则于其私也必求备故曰其分也以备凡有皆归于无而私于求备者但求其有知道者恶之故曰所恶乎备者其有以备也
chunks.translated_text:
The speaker is no ordinary person. The Son of Heaven is one whom Heaven cherishes as its child. Learning, conduct, and eloquence all leave traces—these are what one can learn, what one can practice, what one can debate. What cannot be learned, cannot be practiced, cannot be debated is the natural. When one’s knowledge reaches its limit at what cannot be known and stops there, this is the ultimate of creation. Thus it is said, "It is the utmost."

Heaven’s balance refers to creation. "Not being this" means not being so. *Ji* (就) means to align. Not being so is the opposite. To be opposite is to lose the principle of creation’s spontaneity. *Bai* (败) means to lose. To prepare things to sustain form, to conceal the unexpected to nurture the mind, to revere the center to reach the external—if one is thus, then all the myriad evils that arrive are from Heaven, not from man, and are insufficient to disturb one’s completion. They cannot enter the numinous terrace.

The numinous terrace is that which holds yet does not know what it holds, and that which cannot be held. "Preparing things" means preparing the principles of the myriad things. The myriad things are all prepared within me. "Sustaining form" means following the spontaneity of one’s life. "Not anticipating" means not calculating, not deliberating. Retreating to conceal oneself in the place of non-deliberation, the mind’s response to things arises spontaneously—this is what the Buddhists call "not abiding yet giving rise to the mind." "Preserving within" means that reverence then responds externally without obstruction—this is the meaning of "reverence to straighten the internal, righteousness to square the external." *Da* (达) means to penetrate. *Bi* (彼) refers to what is external. "The myriad evils" are matters that do not go as one wishes. When one’s own creation has already reached this point, yet the myriad evils still arrive, this is truly Heaven’s doing, not a failure of human affairs sufficient to disturb the perfect virtue within my breast. Thus it is said, "All are from Heaven, not from man," and are insufficient to disturb the completion of the numinous heart. External things do not enter the mind, so they do not disturb its completion.

"Having hold" means having something to rely on. "Not knowing what it holds" means that though there is something to rely on, one does not know what it is—this is transformation through the great. "Cannot be held" means that if there is something to hold onto, one has not yet transformed. These three instances of *chi* (持) are most subtly expressed and must not be read carelessly.

If one does not see their sincerity yet acts, every action is inappropriate; if one enters into karma yet does not relinquish it, every change leads to loss, to wrongdoing. Is this not wrongdoing in the manifest? In the hidden, even spirits can condemn it as wrongdoing. Only when one is enlightened about spirits can one act alone. These several sentences further explain that those who do wrong have not yet perfected themselves yet act presumptuously. Presumptuous action means every affair is inappropriate; karma has already entered their midst, and though they know it, they cannot relinquish it—these are the shame of transgression and the commission of wrongs. *Geng* (更) means to change. Shame over transgression and the commission of wrongs lead to constant changes, each revealing greater error. Thus it is said, "Every change leads to loss." *Ye* (业) does not mean "affair"; today, people say *ye* (业) as in "already" or "karma," meaning it has already become one’s conduct. Such a person’s actions are not good. If no one condemns them, then spirits will censure them. This means that between the hidden and the manifest, there is nowhere to escape. If one knows that the hidden and the manifest are to be feared, then one can be cautious in solitude. Thus it is said, "Only when one is enlightened about man and enlightened about spirits can one act alone." This is the same as "Nothing is more concealed than the hidden, nothing more manifest than the subtle"—therefore the noble person is cautious in solitude. "Acting alone" is being cautious in solitude. These several phrases could be included in the classics.

Those within the contract act without seeking fame; those outside the contract aspire to extravagant expenditure. Acting without seeking fame is only the common that has radiance. Aspiring to extravagant expenditure is only the merchant’s way. People see them standing tall, like eminent figures, yet when they are exhausted by things, things enter them. Those who contend with things cannot even contain themselves—how can they contain others? Those who cannot contain others have no affection; those with no affection cut off all people.

Those within the contract seek what is within their allotted portion—this is what Mencius called "seeking and obtaining it, seeking within." "Without fame" means that no one can name it. Those outside the contract seek externally. Those who labor externally set their aspirations only on resources for expenditure—this is seeking for self-benefit. Only the common has radiance: *yong* (庸) means constant, *guang* (光) means constant radiance. Abandoning the self to seek externally, aspiring to profit—this is the mindset of merchants. Thus it is said, "Only the merchant’s way."

*Qi* (跂) is the appearance of standing tall. People see their external wealth or nobility surpassing others and think them eminent and worthy of respect, yet they do not know that they are bound to things, beginning and ending with desire, until they are exhausted and come to an end. Thus it is said, "When they are exhausted by things, things enter them." *Qie* (且) means "barely." Chasing after things, barely seeking to obtain, even to the point of endangering themselves without regret—thus it is said, "Those who contend with things cannot even contain themselves." How can they contain others with a heart that cannot contain others? In the extreme, even relatives and kin are estranged and abandoned. Thus it is said, "Those who cannot contain others have no affection; those with no affection cut off all people."

No weapon is sharper than the will. The *moye* sword is inferior to it. No greater bandit exists than yin and yang, from which there is no escape between Heaven and Earth. If not for the harm of yin and yang, then the mind causes it. The will is the mind’s attachment. All attachments can harm oneself, but none is sharper than the will—it is even more harmful than the *moye* sword. Thus it is said, "No weapon is sharper than the will; the *moye* sword is inferior to it." The qi of yin and yang can both harm people, like bandits. Yet if this mind is peaceful and harmonious, how can yin and yang cause harm? Thus it is said, "If not for the harm of yin and yang, then the mind causes it." This is what is meant by "Its heat scorches like fire, its cold congeals like ice." These two sentences are excellent for the work of the heart’s learning—this saying is most apt.

The Dao penetrates their allotment. Its completion is its destruction. What is detestable about allotment is its division; what is detestable about preparation is its having preparation. Completion and destruction are two matters, yet from the perspective of the Dao, they are one. Thus it is said, "The Dao penetrates their allotment." Once the human mind is divided into self and other, in its selfishness it must seek completeness. Thus it is said, "Its allotment is for preparation." All things return to nothingness, yet those who selfishly seek completeness only seek being. Those who know the Dao detest this. Thus it is said, "What is detestable about preparation is its having preparation."

Thus, to emerge without returning is to see its demonic aspect; to emerge and attain is called attaining death. That which responds to the external and can return to the internal becomes virtue; with virtue, one can be spirit-like and heaven-like. To pursue the external without knowing return is to sink into demonic realms. Thus it is said, "To emerge without returning is to see its demonic aspect." The Śākya tradition speaks of "demonic den calculations"—this is precisely it. Without right or wrong, this heart-mind remains ever alive; clinging to right and wrong without transformation, this heart-mind becomes dead. "To emerge and attain" refers to being enslaved by the external and attaining self-righteous views. *Equalizing Things* says, "A heart-mind near death cannot return to yang"—this is the meaning here.

Extinction yet possessing substance is one with the demonic. By means of the formed, one models the formless and thereby establishes it. "Substance" is the true principle within heaven and earth. Without the heart-mind, there is emptiness; emptiness is substance. If one extinguishes it with selfish intentions and takes the existent as substance, then that person is the same as the demonic. Thus it is said, "Extinction yet possessing substance is one with the demonic." Demonic realms and sinking into delusion all arise from the selfish heart-mind extinguishing principle, coveting and clinging to existence while unaware of true emptiness and real being. If one can regard the formed as if it were formless, then principle is established. "Model" means semblance. The Śākya tradition says, "One may empty all that exists, but must not reify what does not exist"—this is the meaning here.

Emerging without root, entering without aperture—substance exists yet without place.
Emergence is birth, the origin from which the myriad things arise. Though never without root, it cannot be known; thus it is called "without root." Entry is death, the end toward which the myriad things proceed. Though one knows where it ends, one does not see where it enters; thus it is called "without aperture." True principle, though existent, cannot be sought in any particular direction; thus it is called "without place."

Having duration yet without root or end—what has substance yet no place is space; what has duration yet no root or end is time. There is life, there is death, there is emergence, there is entry. In entry and emergence, no form is seen—this is called the Gate of Heaven.

The following explains the three sentences above:

chunks.original_text: 老子曰虚而不屈动而愈出虽出者不穷而不可屈其窍虚也 虚乃所以为实故曰有所出而无窍者有实出入一也 此解入字却曰所出可见其意宇四方上下也 道无定所四方上下皆是也 故曰宇即鸢飞于天鱼跃于渊言其上下察也 古往今来曰宙道之往来千万年而常如是者即宙也 生出也 死入也 生死出入皆有所自而无形可见此造化之妙也 天门即造化也 自然也 因言出入故下门字 天门者无有也万物出乎无有有不能以有为有必出乎无有而无有一无有圣人藏乎是 有不生于有而生于无故曰有不能以有为有必出于无有而此无有者又一无有也故曰无有一无有齐物曰有无也者有未始有无也者即是此意藏者退藏于密也圣人之心藏于无有故曰藏乎是 古之人其知有所至矣恶乎至有以为未始有物者至矣尽矣弗可以加矣其次以为有物矣将以生为防也以死为反也是以分已其次曰始无有既而有生生俄而死以无有为首以生为体以死为尻孰知有无死生之一守者吾与之为友是三者虽异公族也昭景也着戴也甲氏也着封也非一也 无物之始死生终始无分其次则有死生之名矣 防旅寓也 齐物言弱防而不知归以生为防即寓形宇内之意以死为反言归真也 以生为寄以死为乐才有生死之分便是有物故曰是以分已上焉 者无物太极之初也 次焉 者有物阴阳既分也 又其次者曰有生有生则有我矣 虽知有我犹以死生有无为一是知其分而又知其不分者也 三者虽有次第而皆未离于道譬如公族分而为三姓则同也 昭氏景氏以有职任而着也 甲氏以有封邑而着也 戴任也 任职也 昭景甲虽非一氏而皆楚国之公族也 上言三者虽异同乎 公族却于四也 字之下以非一也 结之就上生下绝而不绝之体此皆文字妙处 有生黬【户减反】也披然曰移是尝言移是非所言也虽然不可知者也 黬黡也釡底黑也亦疵病也喻气之凝聚也天地之气聚而为人元气之病也前言生者喑噫气也与此意同人之生也同是此气而强自分别故曰披然披者分也既有分别则各私其私既私其私则各是其是而所谓是者移矣移不定也彼亦一是非此亦一是非移也其意只与齐物论同而又撰出移是两字非所言者谓不当言也谓移是之说在人皆不当言言之皆为私也人虽各有一是而其所是者不定故曰虽然不可知者也 腊者之有膍【音毗】胲【古来反】可散而不可散也 腊祭也膍牛百叶也胲足指也牲之一体也方祭之时既杀此牲其四体与五脏皆散而置列爼之间谓之散则所祭之性本只是一物谓之不可散则五脏四体已分于鼎爼矣譬犹人之所谓是者移而无定也五脏只是百叶四体只举胲文法也 观室者周于寝庙又适其偃焉为是举移是 一室之中有寝有庙又有偃息之所在在不同谓之寝谓之庙谓之偃则同乎一室谓之室则又有寝庙偃之异名亦犹移是之不可定也此两句即移是之喻也举皆也以腊祭与室而观则其所为是者皆移 易而不可定之是也故曰为是举移是 请尝言移是是以生为本以知为师因以乘是非果有名实因以己为质使人以为己节因以死偿节若然者以用为知以不用为愚以彻为名以穷为辱移是今之人也是蜩与鸴鸠同于同也 上面既结一结又提起移是字再说是以生为本言既有是字则以生者为本以其所知之智为师因此而后以是非相乘孰为名乎 孰为实乎 故曰果有名实曰果有者言其非必有也 质本也 因吾一己之师以此为本而欲人皆听己之节度故曰因以为己质使人以为己节惟其因此自私是非之争虽以死偿之而亦甘心焉

Laozi said: "Empty yet not exhausted, in movement ever more emerges. Though what emerges is inexhaustible, its aperture cannot be exhausted—this is the emptiness of its aperture. Emptiness is precisely what makes it substantial; thus it is said, 'what has substance yet no aperture'—emergence and entry are one. This explains the character 'entry,' yet it speaks of 'emergence,' revealing its meaning: space encompasses the four directions, above and below. The Dao has no fixed place; all directions, above and below, are it. Thus it is called 'space'—as when the kite soars in the sky or the fish leaps in the abyss, illustrating the scrutiny of above and below. Past and present are called 'time'; the Dao’s coming and going through thousands and tens of thousands of years, ever thus, is time. Life is emergence; death is entry. In life and death, emergence and entry, all have their source, yet no form is visible—this is the marvel of creation. The Gate of Heaven is creation, spontaneity. Because it speaks of emergence and entry, it follows with the character 'gate.' The Gate of Heaven is Nonbeing. The myriad things emerge from Nonbeing. Being cannot make itself be; it must emerge from Nonbeing. Yet this Nonbeing is itself a Nonbeing. Thus it is said, 'Nonbeing, one Nonbeing.' *Qiwu* speaks of 'being and nonbeing,' and 'that which has never yet begun to be nonbeing'—this is the same meaning. 'Hiding' means retiring and concealing in secrecy. The sage’s heart conceals itself in Nonbeing; thus it is said, 'hiding therein.'

The knowledge of the ancients reached its utmost. How far did it reach? To the point of regarding things as never having begun to exist—this is the utmost, the limit, beyond which nothing can be added. Those next in order regarded things as existing, taking life as a defense and death as a return—thus they divided themselves. Those next said, 'At first there was Nonbeing; then there was life. Life suddenly becomes death. Taking Nonbeing as the head, life as the body, and death as the tail—who knows the unity of being and nonbeing, life and death? I would make friends with such a one.' These three, though different, belong to the same clan. The Zhaos and Jings became prominent through office; the Jias became prominent through enfeoffment. Though not one, they are all the noble clan of Chu. The above speaks of the three as different yet belonging to the same clan, but in the text below, it is said 'not one'—tying it together, this refers to the unbroken body of life and death above. These are the subtleties of the text.

Having life is *qian* (darkening). To assertively say 'this is it' is to have spoken of what should not be spoken. Yet it remains unknowable. *Qian* is a blemish, like the blackness at the bottom of a cauldron, or a defect—an analogy for the coagulation of qi. The qi of heaven and earth coagulates to form humans; this is the illness of primordial qi. Earlier it spoke of life as the muttering of qi—this is the same meaning. Human life arises from the same qi, yet people forcibly divide it. Thus it is said, 'assertively'—*pi* means division. Once there is division, each clings to their own; clinging to their own, each takes their own as right, and what is called 'right' shifts. Shifting means instability. This one calls it right, that one calls it right—this is shifting. The meaning is the same as in *Qiwulun*, yet it coins the term 'shifting right.' 'What should not be spoken' means it is not fitting to speak of it. To speak of 'shifting right' is, for people, always improper; all speech is self-serving. Though each person has their own 'right,' what they take as right is unstable. Thus it is said, 'though unknowable.'

The sacrificial victim at the *la* festival has its tripe and trotters—it can be dispersed yet cannot be dispersed. The *la* is the winter sacrifice. The tripe is the cow’s omasum; the trotters are the feet, parts of the sacrificial animal. When the sacrifice is made, the four limbs and five viscera are all dispersed and arranged on the cutting board. To call it 'dispersed' is to say the sacrificed nature is originally one thing; to call it 'indispersible' is to say the five viscera and four limbs are already separated in the cauldron and on the board. This is like what people call 'right'—shifting and unstable. The five viscera are represented by the tripe; the four limbs, by the trotters—this is the literary method.

Observing a house, one circles the bedchamber and ancestral temple, then proceeds to the resting place—this is to illustrate 'shifting right.' Within a single house, there is the bedchamber, the ancestral temple, and a place for repose; though their locations differ, to call them 'bedchamber,' 'temple,' or 'resting place' is to refer to the same house. Yet to call it a 'house' is to acknowledge the distinctions of bedchamber, temple, and resting place—just like the instability of 'shifting right.' These two sentences are analogies for 'shifting right.' 'Illustrate' means 'all.' Observing the *la* sacrifice and the house, what they take as right is all shifting, an unstable 'right.' Thus it is said, 'to illustrate shifting right.'

Let me speak of 'shifting right': taking life as the root, knowledge as the teacher, thereby riding upon right and wrong, indeed producing names and realities, thereby making oneself the standard, causing others to take one’s own restraint as their model, and even dying to repay that restraint. If so, then to act is to be wise, not to act is to be foolish; to penetrate is to be renowned, to be blocked is to be shamed—this is the 'shifting right' of people today. The cicada and the owl are the same in their sameness.

Above, it has already concluded one section, then raises the term 'shifting right' again, saying: 'taking life as the root.' Once there is the word 'right,' one takes life as the root, takes one’s own knowledge as the teacher, and thereafter rides upon right and wrong—who is truly named? Who is truly real? Thus it is said, 'indeed producing names and realities.' 'Indeed' means it is not necessarily so. 'Standard' is the root. Using one’s own teacher as the root, one desires others to follow one’s own restraint. Thus it is said, 'making oneself the standard, causing others to take one’s own restraint as their model.' Only because of this self-serving does the contention of right and wrong arise; though one may die to repay it, one willingly does so.

chunks.original_text: 故曰因以死偿节下节字因上节字而生也 唯其如此故于用舍穷通之际有知愚荣辱之分今世之人皆移是者也 故曰移是今之人也 彻通也 蜩与鸴鸠皆同讥大鹏亦犹移是之人不知至道之士而非笑之其见识与蜩鸠同矣 蜩与鸠同人又与蜩鸠同故曰同于同也 此鼓舞之文 蹍市人之足则辞以放骜兄则以妪大亲则已矣 故曰至礼有不人至义不物至知不谋至仁无亲至信辟金此数行又别一项说话与市人行而蹍其足则必以放傲自责而辞谢之恐其怒也 若兄蹍弟之足则妪诩之而已必无所辞谢盖其情亲不待谢也 大亲父母也 若父母而其子之足则并与妪诩亦无之矣 情亲之至自相孚也 至礼有不人谓礼之至者无人己之分忘其揖逊也 至义不物谓义之至者不待物物而度其宜也 至知不谋无容于谋度也 至仁无亲者言不见其相爱之迹也 至信辟金者言不待以金宝为质也 辟音屏除也 蹍足之喻为下面礼义五者设也 彻志之勃解心之谬去德之累达道之塞贵富显严名利六者勃志也容动色理气意六者谬心也恶欲喜怒哀乐六者累德也去就取与知能六者塞道也此四六者不荡胸中则正正则静静则明明则虚虚则无为而无不为也 彻与撤同解释也显华显也严威严也勃志言六者能悖乱其志也动举动也理辞理也谬心者言六者能绸缪牵系其心也累德者情胜则累其自得之真也知心知也能才能也塞道障道也荡荡乱也去此勃志谬心累德塞道四者之六害则胸中不为之荡乱此教人下工夫处也 道者德之钦也生者德之光也性者生之质也性之动谓之为为之伪谓之失知者接也知者谟也知者之所不知犹睨也动以不得已之谓德动无非我之谓治名相反而实相顺也 钦持守而恭敬也生德之发见者也发见则有光华矣性在我者也质本然也性之动而后有为有为而流于人伪则为性之失接应也谟谋也应接而至于有谋虑皆性中之知也此处字义与语孟不同以庄子读庄子可也不可自拘泥婴儿之视而无所视曰睨知者以其所不知而为知亦犹婴儿之睨也此即智者行其所无事之意凡所动用皆以不得已为之则谓之德即忘我也于忘我之中而又无非我此即形中之不形不形中之形也 羿工乎中防而拙乎使人无已誉圣人工乎天而拙乎人夫工乎天而俍乎人者唯全人能之惟虫能虫惟虫能天全人恶天恶人之天而况吾天乎人乎 防妙也射之中至于防妙故曰中防羿之不能使人无誉已亦犹圣人不能逃天下之名也工乎天者尽天道也俍乎人能自晦于人也俍音良善也能也全人者全德之人也 一雀适羿羿必得之威也以天下为之笼则雀无所逃是故汤以庖人笼伊尹秦穆公以五羊之皮笼百里奚是故非以其所好笼之而可得者无有也介者拸画外非誉也胥靡登高而不惧遗死生也 羿之射见雀必得雀亦畏之猿见养由基抱树而啼即此意也以天下为笼则雀皆在笼之中不待射之矣主意不在羿只引生下句而已 夫复謵不馈而忘人忘人因以为天人矣 复反复也犹易之反复道也謵习熟也不馈者不以遗予于人也 故敬之而不喜侮之而不怒者唯同乎天和者为然出怒不怒则怒出于不怒矣出为无为则为出于无为矣欲静则平气欲神则顺心有为也欲当则缘于不得已不得已之圣人之道 敬我亦不以为喜侮我亦不以为怒即所谓举世誉之而不加劝举世非之而不加沮也 天和造物之和气也 同乎
chunks.translated_text:
Thus it is said, "repaying with death for one’s restraint"—the term *restraint* below arises from the term *restraint* above. Precisely because of this, in the moments of acceptance or rejection, success or failure, distinctions of wisdom and folly, honor and disgrace emerge. The people of this age are all those who "shift right." Thus it is said, "those who shift right are the people of today." *Thorough* means penetrating. The cicada and the owl both mock the great Peng, just as those who "shift right" do not recognize the scholar of the utmost Dao and ridicule him—their vision and understanding are the same as the cicada and the owl. The cicada and the owl are alike, and people are likewise the same as the cicada and the owl; thus it is said, "the same in their sameness." This is stirring, exhortative prose.

If one treads on a stranger’s foot in the marketplace, one apologizes with humility; if an elder brother treads on his younger brother’s foot, one merely soothes him; if a parent treads on their child’s foot, not even soothing is needed. Thus it is said: "In the utmost ritual, there is no 'other'; in the utmost righteousness, there is no 'thing'; in the utmost wisdom, there is no scheming; in the utmost benevolence, there is no partiality; in the utmost trustworthiness, gold is set aside." These several lines form another distinct point. When one treads on a stranger’s foot in the marketplace, one must apologize with humility to avoid their anger. If an elder brother treads on his younger brother’s foot, one merely soothes him, without apology, for their bond is close and requires no thanks. *Great kinship* refers to parents. If parents tread on their child’s foot, even soothing is unnecessary—their intimacy is such that mutual trust is innate.

"In the utmost ritual, there is no 'other'" means that in the highest ritual, the distinction between self and other is forgotten, and formalities are abandoned. "In the utmost righteousness, there is no 'thing'" means that in the highest righteousness, one does not rely on external things to measure what is fitting. "In the utmost wisdom, there is no scheming" means that no deliberation is needed. "In the utmost benevolence, there is no partiality" means that no trace of preferential love is visible. "In the utmost trustworthiness, gold is set aside" means that no material pledge is required. *Set aside* is pronounced *bìng*, meaning to discard. The analogy of treading on feet is set forth for the five virtues of ritual, righteousness, wisdom, benevolence, and trustworthiness that follow.

Obstruction of the will, delusion of the mind, encumbrance of virtue, and blockage of the Dao—wealth, honor, prominence, fame, and profit are the six obstructions of the will; appearance, movement, countenance, principle, qi, and intent are the six delusions of the mind; aversion, desire, joy, anger, sorrow, and happiness are the six encumbrances of virtue; departure, approach, taking, giving, knowledge, and ability are the six blockages of the Dao. If these four sets of six are not stirred within the breast, then one is upright; if upright, then still; if still, then luminous; if luminous, then empty; if empty, then one acts without acting, yet nothing is left undone. *Thorough* is synonymous with *remove*. *Prominence* means splendor; *stern* means imposing. *Obstruction of the will* means these six can disorder one’s resolve. *Movement* refers to physical action; *principle* refers to verbal reasoning. *Delusion of the mind* means these six can entangle and bind the mind. *Encumbrance of virtue* means that when emotions prevail, they burden one’s innate truth. *Knowledge* refers to discernment; *ability* refers to talent. *Blockage of the Dao* means obstruction of the Dao. *Stirred* means disturbed. Removing these four sets of six harms—obstruction of the will, delusion of the mind, encumbrance of virtue, and blockage of the Dao—ensures that the breast is not disturbed. This is where one applies effort in cultivation.

The Dao is what virtue reveres; life is the radiance of virtue; nature is the essence of life. The movement of nature is called *action*; its deviation is called *loss*. Knowledge is encounter; wisdom is planning. What the wise do not know is like a sidelong glance. *Reveres* means to uphold and respect. *Life* is the manifestation of virtue; when manifested, it shines with brilliance. *Nature* is what resides within us; *essence* means its original state. When nature moves, action arises; when action flows into human artifice, it becomes a loss of nature. *Encounter* means response. *Planning* means strategy. Responding to encounters and engaging in planning are both expressions of the knowledge inherent in nature. The meaning of these terms differs from their usage in the *Analects* and *Mencius*; when reading Zhuangzi, one should read Zhuangzi and not be bound by rigid interpretations. The infant’s gaze, seeing yet seeing nothing, is called a *sidelong glance*. The wise, claiming knowledge of what they do not know, are like infants glancing sidelong—this embodies the idea of "the wise act without contrivance." All actions should arise from necessity, which is called *virtue*; this is forgetting the self. Within this forgetting of the self, there is yet nothing that is not the self—this is the unmanifest within form and the manifest within the unmanifest.

Yi was skilled at hitting the mark but clumsy at making others free of his praise; the sage is skilled at following Heaven but clumsy at dealing with people. Only the complete person can be skilled at following Heaven and adept at dealing with people. Only creatures can be creatures; only creatures can follow Heaven. How much more should the complete person despise the Heaven of others and despise the humanity of others—how much more should one despise one’s own Heaven and one’s own humanity?

*Mark* means subtlety; hitting the target with such subtlety is called *hitting the mark*. Yi’s inability to prevent others from praising him is like the sage’s inability to escape the world’s fame. *Skilled at following Heaven* means fully embodying the Dao of Heaven. *Adept at dealing with people* means concealing oneself among people. *Adept* is pronounced *liáng*, meaning good or capable. The *complete person* is one of complete virtue.

When a sparrow comes near Yi, he is certain to catch it—such is his power. If the world is made into a cage, then sparrows have nowhere to escape. Thus, Tang used a kitchen servant to enclose Yi Yin, and Duke Mu of Qin used five sheepskins to enclose Baili Xi. Therefore, if one does not use what they love to enclose them, there is nothing that can be obtained. The *obstinate* are those who cast off external praise and blame; the *cautious* are those who, even when climbing high, do not fear, and who disregard life and death.

Yi’s shooting ensures that when a sparrow appears, he will catch it—the sparrow also fears him. When the monkey sees Yang Youji, it clings to a tree and wails; the meaning is the same. If the world is made into a cage, then all sparrows are within it, and there is no need to shoot them. The main point does not lie with Yi but serves to introduce the following sentence.

To return and repeat without offering is to forget others; forgetting others is to thereby become one with Heaven. *Return* means to turn back, like the *Book of Changes*’ "turning back of the Dao." *Repeat* means familiarity. *Not offering* means not giving to others. Thus, one who is revered yet does not rejoice, or insulted yet does not anger, is only one who harmonizes with the harmony of Heaven. When anger arises from non-anger, then anger emerges from non-anger; when action arises from non-action, then action emerges from non-action. To desire stillness, one must calm the qi; to desire spirit, one must follow the mind. These are actions. To desire appropriateness, one must adhere to necessity; the path of the sage lies in this necessity. Revering me yet not rejoicing, insulting me yet not angering—this is what is meant by "though the whole world praises them, they are not encouraged; though the whole world blames them, they are not discouraged." *Harmony of Heaven* is the harmonious qi of creation.

The *Imperially Commissioned Siku Quanshu*: *Zhuangzi Kouyi*, Scroll Eight
By Lin Xi Yi of the Song Dynasty

**Miscellaneous Chapters: "Xu Wugui" (Chapter Twenty-Four)**

Xu Wugui, through Nü Shang, was granted an audience with Marquis Wu of Wei. The marquis greeted him, saying, "Master, you must be weary—enduring the toils of mountain and forest, yet still willing to meet with this lonely one."

Xu Wugui replied, "I am weary on your account. What weariness have you endured for me? If you indulge your desires and prolong your likes and dislikes, the true nature of your life and destiny will sicken. If you suppress your desires and restrain your likes and dislikes, your ears and eyes will suffer. I weary myself for you—what weariness have you endured for me?"

Marquis Wu, startled, made no reply. After a moment, Xu Wugui continued, "Let me tell you: I judge dogs. The lowest kind stops when full—this is the virtue of a wildcat. The middling kind gazes fixedly like the sun. The highest kind seems to have forgotten its singular nature. Indulging desires and prolonging likes and dislikes severs the principle of life and destiny; abandoning desires and likes and dislikes abruptly disrupts the constant function of ears and eyes—both are sickness. *Kan* (掔) is pronounced as *pan*, meaning to pull back. *Lide* (狸德) refers to a dog of the lowest grade, whose nature is like that of a wildcat. The phrase 'gazes fixedly like the sun' describes unwavering focus, eyes unblinking. 'Its singular nature' means its life is as if dead. Thus, it is said to have 'forgotten its singularity'—like a wooden chicken, motionless. This is the highest grade.

Yet judging dogs is not as good as judging horses. A straight horse meets the plumb line; a curved one, the hook; a square one, the carpenter’s square; a round one, the compass—these are the state’s horses. But they do not compare to the world’s horses. The world’s horses possess innate talent—like a plumb line, yet seeming lost; like having forgotten their singular nature. Such horses surpass all, leaving no trace, their destination unknown."

Marquis Wu was greatly pleased and laughed.

"When a horse meets the rules of plumb line, carpenter’s square, hook, and compass, it means every part of its body conforms to principle—these terms are borrowed from geometry and need not be taken literally. 'Innate talent' refers to natural endowment. 'Like a plumb line, yet seeming lost' describes a state of deep absorption. 'Forgotten its singularity' is the same as 'lost its singularity.' 'Destination unknown' means it moves without knowing where it halts. All these are metaphors. Marquis Wu grasped the meaning of effortless spontaneity and was thus greatly pleased, laughing."

When Xu Wugui departed, Nü Shang asked, "Master, how did you alone delight our lord?"

Xu Wugui said, "How I delight my lord: when admonishing him, I use the *Book of Poetry*, the *Book of Documents*, ritual, and music; when guiding him, I employ the *Golden Tablets* and the *Six Strategies*. Those who serve him and achieve great merit are too numerous to count, yet my lord has never once opened his mouth. How did you delight him so that he was pleased like this?"

Xu Wugui replied, "I simply told him how I judge dogs and horses."

Nü Shang said, "Is that all?"

Xu Wugui said, "Have you not heard of the exiles of Yue? After a few days away from their state, they rejoice upon seeing acquaintances. After a month, they rejoice upon seeing those they once knew in their homeland. After a year, they rejoice even upon seeing those who merely resemble their countrymen. Is it not true that the longer one is parted from others, the deeper the longing grows? Those who flee into the emptiness of the wilderness stumble over brambles and trip over stumps, following the paths of shrews and weasels. Yet when they hear the sound of human footsteps, they are overjoyed. How much more so when it is the voices of brothers and kin at their side?"

chunks.original_text: 久矣 夫莫以真人之言謦欬吾君之侧乎 金版六弢即太公兵法也 此书藏于朝廷故曰金版犹曰金匮石室之书也 从横反覆铺之意也 不可泥诗书为横六弢为从也 奉事从王事也 以诗书六弢之见之行事皆有效验故曰奉事而大有功启齿笑也 流人去国流落之人也 所知旧知识也 所尝见仅识面也 似人者似其乡人也 山间之蹊曰鼪鼬之迳柱塞也 踉音郎篇云欲行貌也 位居也 止也 言其困倦欲行而又止伏于谷中也 空谷也 闻足音而喜但是人则喜之矣 不必其知识乡人也 此意盖言武侯本然之真离失已久略闻此语如逃空谷而闻足音所以喜也 禅家所谓久客还家是也 謦欬喉中之声也 徐无见武侯武侯曰先生居山林食芧栗厌葱韭以宾寡人久矣 夫今老邪其欲干酒肉之味邪其寡人亦有社稷之福邪徐无曰无生于贫贱未尝敢饮食君之酒肉将来劳君也 君曰何哉 奚劳寡人曰劳君之神与形武侯曰何谓邪徐无曰天地之养也 一登高不可以为长居下不可以为短君独为万乘之主以苦一国之民以养耳 目鼻口夫神者不自许也 夫神者好和而恶奸夫奸病也 故劳之唯君所病之何也 武侯曰欲见先生久矣 吾欲爱民而为义偃兵其可乎 徐无曰不可爱民害民之始也 为义偃兵造兵之本也 君自此为之则殆不成凡成美恶器也 君虽为仁义几且伪哉 形固造形成固有伐变固外战君亦必无盛鹤列于丽谯之间无徒骥于锱坛之宫无藏逆于得无以巧胜人无以谋胜人无以战胜人夫杀人之士民兼人之土地以养吾私与吾神者其战不知孰善胜之恶乎 在君若勿已矣 修胸中之诚以应天地之情而勿撄夫民死已脱矣 君将恶乎 用夫偃兵哉
chunks.translated_text:
Long indeed has it been since the words of a true person echoed at our lord’s side!

The *Gold Tablets and Six Bow-Cases* refer to the *Military Methods of the Grand Duke*. This text is stored in the court, hence called "gold tablets," much like books kept in golden coffers or stone chambers. The terms "vertical" and "horizontal" describe its shifting, multifaceted strategies—they should not be rigidly equated with the *Book of Songs* or *Book of Documents*. "Serving in attendance" means serving the king’s affairs. Since the teachings of the *Book of Songs*, *Book of Documents*, and *Six Bow-Cases* have proven effective in practice, it is said that "serving in attendance has brought great merit." "Parting the lips" means to smile.

"Exiles" are those who have fled their state. "Acquaintances" are old friends. "Those once seen" are merely familiar faces. "Those who resemble people" are those who look like their countrymen. "Paths in the mountains" are called "the trails of shrews and weasels." "Obstructed" means blocked. *Liang* (踉) is pronounced *lang*; the *Sheng* chapter says it describes the appearance of wanting to move. *Wei* (位) means to dwell or stop, indicating exhaustion—wanting to move but stopping, crouching in the valley. "Empty valley" refers to a desolate ravine. Hearing the sound of footsteps brings joy, for it is the presence of a person, not necessarily an acquaintance or countryman. This suggests that Marquis Wu’s innate truth had been lost for so long that hearing such words was like one fleeing through an empty valley hearing footsteps—hence his joy. This is what Chan Buddhists call "a long journey returning home."

*Qingkai* (謦欬) refers to the sound from the throat.

When Xu Wugui met Marquis Wu, the marquis said, "Master, you dwell in the mountains and forests, eating acorns and chestnuts, spurning onions and leeks—yet you have long honored me with your presence. Are you now old and desiring the taste of wine and meat? Or is it that I, too, possess the good fortune of the altars of soil and grain?"

Xu Wugui replied, "Wugui was born in poverty and lowliness and has never dared to partake of your lordship’s wine and meat. I have come to trouble you."

The marquis asked, "How so? In what way do I trouble you?"

Xu Wugui said, "I trouble your lordship’s spirit and form."

The marquis asked, "What do you mean?"

Xu Wugui said, "The nurturing of Heaven and Earth is such that ascending high cannot be made permanent, nor can dwelling low be made brief. Yet you alone, as the lord of ten thousand chariots, exhaust the people of an entire state to nourish your ears, eyes, nose, and mouth. The spirit does not permit this. The spirit favors harmony and detests perversity, for perversity is sickness. Thus, I trouble you—what sickness afflicts you?"

The marquis said, "I have long wished to see you, Master. I wish to love the people and practice righteousness, to lay down arms—is this possible?"

Xu Wugui said, "No. Loving the people is the beginning of harming them. Practicing righteousness and laying down arms is the root of raising arms. If you proceed thus, you will likely fail. All achievements, whether good or bad, are instruments. Though you practice benevolence and righteousness, you will verge on hypocrisy. Form inevitably produces form; change inevitably arises from what is external. You must not array fine cranes between the ornate towers, nor keep swift steeds in the palace of carved eaves. Do not store rebellion in your gains. Do not seek to overcome others with skill, nor with schemes, nor with war. Those who kill people, those who seize others’ lands—do they nourish their private desires and spirits through war? Who can say which is better, victory or defeat? If you, my lord, cannot desist, then cultivate sincerity within your heart to respond to the feelings of Heaven and Earth, and do not disturb the people’s deaths—thus you will be freed. What need will you then have to lay down arms?"
