chunks.original_text: 所以之所以为两句只一意以珠弹雀人必不肯以物累身人则不知此臂喻甚明切此一段文似内篇 子列子穷容貌有饥色客有言之于郑子阳者曰列御防盖有道之士也居君之国而穷君无乃为不好士乎郑子阳即令官遗之粟子列子见使者再拜而辞使者去子列子入其妻望之而拊心曰妾闻为有道者之妻子皆得佚乐今有饥色君过而遗先生食先生不受岂不命邪子列子笑谓之曰君非自知我也以人之言而遗我粟至其罪我也又且以人之言此吾所以不受也其卒民果作难而杀子阳 郑国之相曰子阳列子郑人也以人言而遗粟言其非真知己既非真知己则誉者可信毁亦可信矣此亦甚切当此段与列子同 楚昭王失国屠羊走而从于昭王昭王反国将赏从者及屠羊屠羊曰大王失国失屠羊大王反国亦反屠羊臣之爵禄已复矣 又何赏之有王曰强之屠羊曰大王失国非臣之罪故不敢伏其诛大王反国非臣之功故不敢当其赏王曰见之屠羊曰楚国之法必有重赏大功而后得见今臣之知不足以存国而勇不足以死防吴军入郢畏难而避防非故随大王也 今大王欲废法毁约而见此非臣之所以闻于天下也 王谓司马子綦曰屠羊居处卑贱而陈义甚高子其为我延之以三旌之位屠羊曰夫三旌之位吾知其贵于屠羊之肆也 万钟之禄吾知其富于屠羊之利也 然岂可以贪爵禄而使吾君有妄施之名乎 不敢当愿复反吾屠羊之肆遂不受也 大王反国反屠羊言各得其本分事也三旌三公也三公之车服各有旌别故曰三旌此段亦佳 原宪居鲁环堵之室以生草蓬户不完桑以为枢而瓮牖二室褐以为塞上漏下湿匡坐而子贡乘大马中绀而表素轩车不容巷往见原宪原宪华冠縰履杖藜而应门子贡曰嘻先生何病原宪应之曰宪闻之无财谓之贫学而不能行谓之病今宪贫也 非病也 子贡逡巡而有愧色原宪笑曰夫希世而行比周而友学以为人教以为己仁义之慝舆马之饰宪不忍为也 茨者苫也 以草盖屋也
chunks.translated_text:
The phrase *suo yi zhi suo yi wei* ("that toward which one proceeds, that by which one proceeds") expresses but a single idea. To shoot a sparrow with a pearl—no one would willingly do so. To burden the body with external things—yet people fail to recognize this. The analogy of the arm is most clear and apt.

This passage resembles those in the "Inner Chapters." In *Liezi*, when Qiong’s appearance showed the signs of hunger, a guest spoke of it to Ziyang, the ruler of Zheng: "Lie Yukou is a man of the Dao. Living in your state, he suffers privation—does this not suggest you do not esteem men of worth?" Ziyang immediately ordered an official to send him grain. Liezi bowed twice to the messenger and declined. When the messenger left, Liezi entered his home, where his wife, striking her breast, said: "I have heard that the wife and children of a man of the Dao all enjoy ease and happiness. Now you show the signs of hunger. The ruler, recognizing his error, sent you food, yet you refused it—is this not fate?" Liezi laughed and replied: "The ruler does not know me himself. He sent me grain only because of another’s words. When he punishes me in the future, it will likewise be on the basis of another’s words. This is why I did not accept it." In the end, the people indeed rose in rebellion and killed Ziyang.

The minister of Zheng said: "Ziyang was Liezi’s ruler. He sent grain on the basis of another’s words, showing he did not truly know him. If one is not truly known, then praise may be believed, but so too may slander." This reasoning is also most apt.

This passage is similar to one in *Liezi*. When King Zhao of Chu lost his state, a butcher who slaughtered sheep fled with him. When the king returned to his state and was about to reward those who had followed him, the butcher came forward and said: "When the great king lost his state, I lost my butcher’s stall. Now that the great king has returned, I too have regained my butcher’s stall. My rank and emolument have been restored—what reward is there to give?" The king said: "Insist that he accept." The butcher replied: "The great king lost his state not through any fault of mine, so I dared not submit to punishment. The great king’s return is not through any merit of mine, so I dared not claim reward." The king said: "Let me see him." The butcher said: "According to the laws of Chu, only those who have rendered great service may be granted an audience. My wisdom was insufficient to preserve the state, and my courage was insufficient to die defending it. When the Wu army entered Ying, I fled in fear of danger—not because I deliberately followed the great king. Now, if the great king wishes to set aside the law and break precedent to see me, this is not what I have heard is right under heaven." The king said to Sima Ziqi: "The butcher’s station is lowly, yet his exposition of principle is lofty. You must secure him for me with the rank of the Three Standards." The butcher said: "I know the rank of the Three Standards is nobler than my butcher’s stall, and the emolument of ten thousand bushels is richer than my butcher’s profit. Yet how could I greedily accept rank and emolument and thereby cause my lord to gain a reputation for reckless bestowal? I dare not accept. I wish only to return to my butcher’s stall." He thus declined the offer.

When the great king returned to his state, the butcher regained his stall—each returned to his proper place. The Three Standards refer to the Three Dukes. The carriages and robes of the Three Dukes each have their own distinguishing banners, hence the term "Three Standards." This passage is also excellent.

Yuan Xian lived in Lu in a walled hut with a circumference of one *du*. The roof was thatched with cogon grass, the door was incomplete, and the hinge was made of mulberry wood. A jar served as the window for two rooms. Coarse cloth stopped the gaps above, while below, dampness seeped through. Yet he sat upright and sang. Zigong arrived in a grand carriage, his inner robe dark blue and his outer robe white, the canopy too wide to pass through the alley. He went to see Yuan Xian. Yuan Xian, wearing a cap of rushes, shoes of hemp, and leaning on a staff of bramble, came to the gate. Zigong said: "Alas! Master, what ails you?" Yuan Xian replied: "I have heard that to lack wealth is called poverty, and to study yet be unable to practice is called affliction. Now, I am poor—not afflicted." Zigong stepped back, his face showing shame. Yuan Xian laughed and said: "To act in pursuit of worldly favor, to befriend for mutual advantage, to study for others, to teach for oneself, to use benevolence and righteousness as a pretext, and to adorn oneself with carriages and horses—these are things I cannot bear to do."

*Ci* means thatch; to cover a house with grass.

chunks.original_text: 夫妻二室皆以瓮为牖故曰瓮牖二室壁中凿而取明者曰牖以旧衣而塞其牖抵风雨也 故曰褐以为塞拊琴瑟也 匡坐正坐也 绀深青赤色也 表素者以白色为外衣也 轩车不容巷言巷小而车大也 华冠华皮为冠也 縰履曳其履也 希世而行言其所以行媚世也 比周而友所交非人也 学不为己而为人教人非为道而为利假仁义以文奸故曰仁义之慝 曾子居卫缊袍无表颜色肿哙手足胼胝三日不举火十年不制衣正冠而缨绝捉衿而肘见纳履而踵决曳縰而歌商颂声满天地若出金石天子不得臣诸侯不得友故养志者忘形养形者忘利致道者忘心矣 缊袍今之絮衣也 无表者外破而露其絮也 肿哙虚浮也 正冠而缨绝方欲正其冠而缨又绝缨所以维其冠也 肘见衿之袖已破也 踵决履之后已破也 曳縰扶曳而行也 商颂所歌之曲也 若出金石有节奏也 养志者忘形不以养身者累其心也 养形者忘利不逐外物以劳其身也 致道者忘心无心则近道也 孔子谓颜回曰回来家贫居卑胡不仕乎颜回对曰不愿仕回有郭外之田五十亩足以给饘粥郭内之田十亩足以为丝麻鼓琴足以自娱所学夫子之道者足以自乐也回不愿仕孔子愀然变容曰善哉回之意丘闻之知足者不以利自累也审自得者失之而不惧行修于内者无位而不怍丘诵之久矣今于回而后见之是丘之得也 郭外田也郭内园也颜子未必有此庄子之言亦未必可信所学夫子之道足以自乐乐者何物也故二程毎教人求颜子乐处此不可草草看过也知足者不以利自累言足乎已者无待于外也审信也在我者真有以自得则外物之失不足喜惧也无位而不怍不以人不知为愧也诵之久矣于今见之谓昔闻其语今见其人也某之得者言真得友也 中山公子牟谓瞻子曰身在江海之上心居乎魏阙之下奈何瞻子曰重生重生则利轻中山公子牟曰虽知之未能自胜也瞻子曰不能自胜则从神无恶乎不能自胜而强不从者此之谓重伤重伤之人无寿矣魏牟万乘之公子也其岩宂也难为于布衣之士虽未至乎道可谓有其意矣 心居魏阙者未能忘富贵也 重生则轻利知本心之可贵则外物轻也 虽知之未能自胜者理未能胜欲也 不能自胜则从者谓此心未能自己则且听而顺之此言在江海之间而时起此念不必强为抑遏也 若强为抑遏则能内伤其神亦或至于致病故曰不得自胜则从从顺之也 顺之则于神无伤故曰神无恶乎 不能自胜一伤也 此念动时也 若于念起之时强抑遏而不顺之则苦于自制是二伤也 故曰重伤此非自寿之道无寿者不入寿者之也 魏牟以公子而为者故其自胜愈难虽所学未至于道亦有向道之意矣 此语即中庸勉而行者之事 孔子穷于陈蔡之间七日不火食藜羹不糁颜色甚惫而歌于室颜回择菜子路子贡相与言曰夫子再逐于鲁削迹于卫伐树于宋穷于商周围于陈蔡杀夫子者无罪借夫子者无禁歌鼔琴未尝绝音君子之无耻也 若此乎 颜回无以应入告孔子孔子推琴喟然而叹曰由与赐细人也 召而来吾语之子贡子路入子路曰如此者可谓穷矣 孔子曰是何言也 君子通于道之谓通穷于道之谓穷今丘抱仁义之道以遭乱世之患其何穷之为故自省而不穷于道临难而不失其德天寒既至霜雪既降吾是以知松栢之茂也 陈蔡之隘于丘其幸乎 孔子削然反琴而歌子路扢然执干而舞子贡曰吾不知天之高也 地之下也 古之得道者穷亦乐通亦乐所乐非穷通也
chunks.translated_text:
The two chambers of their dwelling both used jars as windows—hence "two chambers with jar-windows." Walls were hollowed out to admit light, called *you*; old clothes were used to seal these windows against wind and rain—hence "coarse cloth to block them." *Kuang* means to sit upright. *Gan* is a deep blue-red color. *Biao su* refers to wearing white as an outer robe. "The canopy too wide to pass through the alley" describes the narrowness of the lane compared to the carriage. *Hua guan* means a cap made of birch bark. *Xi lv* describes dragging one’s hemp shoes. "To act in pursuit of worldly favor" means conducting oneself to curry favor with the age. "To befriend for mutual advantage" means associating with unworthy people. "To study for others, to teach for oneself" means learning not for one’s own sake but for others, and teaching not for the Dao but for profit. To "use benevolence and righteousness as a pretext" is to employ them to gloss over wickedness—hence "the wickedness of benevolence and righteousness."

When Master Zeng resided in Wei, his quilted robe had no outer layer, his complexion was swollen, his hands and feet calloused. For three days he did not kindle a fire, and for ten years he did not make new clothes. When he straightened his cap, its strings snapped; when he grasped his lapel, his elbow showed; when he put on his shoes, the heels split. Yet as he dragged his hemp shoes, he sang the *Odes of Shang*, his voice filling heaven and earth as if issuing from metal or stone. The Son of Heaven could not make him a minister, nor could the feudal lords befriend him. Thus, those who cultivate the will forget the body; those who cultivate the body forget profit; those who attain the Dao forget the mind.

A *yun* robe is today’s padded garment. "No outer layer" means the outer fabric was worn through, exposing the padding. *Zhong kuai* describes a swollen, puffy appearance. "Straightening his cap, the strings snapped" means that as he adjusted his cap, its ties broke—the ties being what secure the cap. "Elbow showing" means the sleeves of his lapel were torn. "Heels split" means the backs of his shoes were broken. *Ye xi* means to drag oneself along. *Shang song* refers to the songs he sang. "As if issuing from metal or stone" describes the rhythmic quality. "Those who cultivate the will forget the body" means they do not burden their minds with nurturing the body. "Those who cultivate the body forget profit" means they do not exhaust themselves chasing external things. "Those who attain the Dao forget the mind" means that without a mind, one draws near the Dao.

Confucius said to Yan Hui, "Hui, your family is poor and your station low—why do you not take office?" Yan Hui replied, "I do not wish to. Outside the city walls, I have fifty *mu* of fields, enough to provide gruel and porridge; within the city walls, ten *mu* of fields, enough for silk and hemp. Playing the zither is enough for my amusement, and what I have learned of the Master’s Dao is enough for my joy. I do not wish to take office." Confucius’s expression changed as he sighed, "How excellent is Hui’s intent! I have heard that those who know contentment do not burden themselves with profit, that those who are truly self-possessed do not fear loss, and that those who cultivate virtue within are not ashamed without rank. I have recited this for a long time, but only now do I see it in you—this is my gain."

"Fields outside the city walls" refers to farmland; "within the city walls," to gardens. Yan Hui may not have actually possessed these—Zhuangzi’s words may not be entirely trustworthy. "What I have learned of the Master’s Dao is enough for my joy"—but what is this joy? Thus, the Cheng brothers often instructed others to seek Yan Hui’s joy, a matter not to be dismissed lightly. "Those who know contentment do not burden themselves with profit" means that those content with themselves have no need of external things. "Truly self-possessed" means that if what is within is genuinely sufficient, the loss of external things brings neither joy nor fear. "Not ashamed without rank" means not feeling shame at being unknown. "Recited this for a long time, but only now do I see it" means having heard these words before but only now witnessing them in a person. "This is my gain" means truly having gained a friend.

Prince Mou of Zhongshan said to Zhanzi, "Though my body dwells by rivers and seas, my heart remains in the palace halls of Wei—what is to be done?" Zhanzi replied, "Value life, and profit will become light." Prince Mou said, "Though I know this, I cannot overcome myself." Zhanzi said, "If you cannot overcome yourself, then follow your spirit—why resent it? If one cannot overcome oneself yet forcibly resists, this is called double injury. Those doubly injured do not enter the ranks of the long-lived."

"Heart remains in the palace halls" means being unable to forget wealth and rank. "Value life, then profit becomes light" means that if one recognizes the preciousness of the original mind, external things grow light. "Though I know this, I cannot overcome myself" means that principle has not yet triumphed over desire. "If you cannot overcome yourself, then follow" means that if the mind cannot yet master itself, one should listen and comply for the time being. This refers to dwelling by rivers and seas while such thoughts occasionally arise—there is no need to forcibly suppress them. If one forcibly suppresses them, it may internally harm the spirit and even lead to illness. Hence, "If you cannot overcome yourself, then follow"—following causes no harm to the spirit, so "why resent it?" "Cannot overcome oneself" is one injury. This refers to the moment when such thoughts arise. If, when these thoughts arise, one forcibly suppresses them instead of complying, the struggle with self-control is a second injury. Hence, "double injury"—this is not the way to longevity. "Do not enter the ranks of the long-lived" means not joining the category of those who live long.

Prince Mou of Wei was the son of a ruler of ten thousand chariots, yet he retired to cliffs and caves—something difficult for a commoner. Though he had not yet reached the Dao, he could be said to have the intent. These words align with the *Doctrine of the Mean*’s encouragement to practice.

When Confucius was besieged between Chen and Cai, for seven days he ate no cooked food, subsisting on unsalted vegetable broth. His complexion was deeply fatigued, yet he sang in his chamber while playing the zither. Yan Hui was picking vegetables, while Zilu and Zigong discussed, saying, "The Master was twice expelled from Lu, his traces erased in Wei, his tree felled in Song, and now he is trapped between Chen and Cai. Those who would kill him bear no guilt; those who would lend him aid face no prohibition. Yet he sings and plays the zither without ceasing—can a gentleman be so shameless?"

Yan Hui had no reply. He entered and told Confucius, who pushed aside the zither and sighed deeply, "You and Ci are petty men! Summon them, and I will speak with them." When Zilu and Zigong entered, Zilu said, "In such circumstances, one could truly be called destitute." Confucius said, "What words are these? When a gentleman is in accord with the Dao, that is called accord; when he is cut off from the Dao, that is called destitution. Now, I embrace the Dao of benevolence and righteousness yet encounter the calamities of a disordered age—how can this be called destitution? Thus, when I examine myself, I am not cut off from the Dao; when facing adversity, I do not lose my virtue. When the cold arrives and frost and snow descend, I thereby know the flourishing of the pine and cypress. The straits of Chen and Cai may be my good fortune!"

Confucius then composed himself, returned to the zither, and sang. Zilu, emboldened, took up a shield and danced. Zigong said, "I did not know the height of heaven or the depth of the earth!"

Those of old who attained the Dao found joy in poverty and joy in prosperity—their joy did not depend on poverty or prosperity.

When the Dao and virtue are present in this way, then destitution and success become as orderly as the sequence of cold and heat, wind and rain. Thus, Xu You found joy in Yingyang, and Gong Bo found contentment in Qiushou. "A broth of greens without a grain of rice"—this speaks of having vegetables but no rice, yet borrowing from others to press upon them is not forbidden, nor is it deemed a fault. When the cold arrives, one knows the flourishing of the pine and cypress—this is what is meant by "only when the year grows cold do we know the pine and cypress." Through the straits of Chen and Cai, the Way of the sage in enduring destitution can manifest itself and serve as a model for later generations. Thus it is said, "How fortunate for me in this!"

*Xiaoran* suggests a carefree and unconstrained manner; *fan qin* means to take up the zither again and play. *Guran* describes a leaping or exultant movement—Zilu, upon hearing these words, rejoiced. The following lines from Zigong indicate his enlightenment through this. Qiushou is the name of a mountain; the so-called Gong Bo may not necessarily refer to the Gonghe Regency—most of these are likely allegorical and difficult to verify in fact. The intent is that Zigong, overjoyed, spoke thus, praising the likes of Xu You who could remain joyful in destitution by delighting in their Way. Xu You and Gong Bo are both invoked through Zigong’s words. Shang and Zhou refer to the Zhou capital, which included the former lands and people of Shang.

Shun wished to yield the world to his friend, Beiren Wuze. Beiren Wuze said, "How strange is the ruler of later times! Dwelling in the fields and furrows, yet wandering at Yao’s gate—this alone would not suffice. Now he further wishes to smear me with his disgraceful conduct. I am ashamed to see him!" Thereupon he cast himself into the Qingling Abyss.

*"This alone would not suffice"* means that Shun’s actions were already improper; your own failings are yours alone to bear—why further defile me? Thus he drowned himself. This account appears nowhere else in the classics and is likely allegorical. *"Disgraceful conduct"* refers to base virtue.

When Tang was about to attack Jie, he consulted Bian Sui, who said, "This is not my affair." Tang asked, "Who would be suitable?" Bian Sui replied, "I do not know." Tang then consulted Wu Guang, who said, "This is not my affair." Tang asked, "Who would be suitable?" Wu Guang replied, "I do not know." Tang said, "What of Yi Yin?" Wu Guang said, "He is strong and enduring of filth—I know nothing else of him." Tang then conspired with Yi Yin to attack Jie, defeated him, and offered the throne to Bian Sui. Bian Sui declined, saying, "When the ruler attacked Jie, he consulted me—had I plotted with him, he would have taken me for a traitor. Having defeated Jie, he now offers me the throne—he would take me for a greedy man. I was born in a disordered age, and this man of no Dao has twice defiled me with his disgraceful conduct. I cannot bear to hear of it again!" Thereupon he cast himself into the Zhou River and died.

Tang then offered the throne to Wu Guang, saying, "The wise plan it, the martial accomplish it, and the benevolent occupy it—this is the Way of antiquity. Why do you not take your place?" Wu Guang declined, saying, "To depose a ruler is not righteous; to kill the people is not benevolent; for others to face peril while I enjoy the benefits is not upright. I have heard that one who does not act righteously does not accept its emoluments, and in an age without the Dao, one does not tread its soil—how much less accept its honors? I cannot bear to witness this any longer!" Thereupon he carried a stone and drowned himself in the Lu River.

*"Strong and enduring of filth"* suggests the capacity for action and the patience to endure worldly disgrace. *"The martial accomplish it"* refers to those who succeed in warfare. *"The benevolent occupy it"* refers to Wu Guang as the benevolent one.

Bian Sui and Wu Guang were both recluses of old, though their acts of drowning themselves cannot be verified—these, too, may be allegorical.

In the rise of the Zhou, there were two knights dwelling in Guzhu named Boyi and Shuqi. The two said to each other, "We have heard there is one in the west who seems to possess the Dao—let us go and observe." When they reached Qiyang, King Wu heard of them and sent the Duke of Zhou to meet them and make a covenant, saying, "You shall be raised two ranks in wealth and appointed to the first rank of office." He then sacrificed an animal, buried its blood, and swore the oath. The two looked at each other and laughed, saying, "Alas! How strange! This is not what we call the Dao. In ancient times, when Shennong possessed the world..."

At that time, sacrifices were performed with utmost reverence yet without prayers for blessings. In their dealings with others, they were loyal and trustworthy, governing with diligence yet seeking nothing in return. They delighted in governance when governing, and delighted in order when order prevailed—not seeking self-perfection through others’ corruption, nor elevating themselves through others’ baseness, nor profiting from the times. Now, the Zhou, seeing the disorder of the Yin, hastily seized power, scheming above while bribing below, relying on military force to maintain authority, slaughtering animals to swear oaths as a pledge of trust, flaunting their conduct to please the masses, and resorting to warfare to secure gain. This is but replacing one chaos with another, one tyranny with another. We have heard that the knights of old, when encountering an age of order, did not shirk their duty, and when facing an age of chaos, did not cling to mere survival. Today, the world is benighted, the virtue of the Zhou has declined—it is but a mire in which to sully ourselves. Better to avoid it and keep our conduct pure.

The two brothers then journeyed north to Mount Shouyang, where they starved to death. As for Boyi and Shuqi, when it came to wealth and rank, if they could be done without, they would never rely on them. With lofty integrity and unyielding conduct, they rejoiced in their own resolve, refusing to serve the world. Such was the steadfastness of these two knights.

*Shu* in *Shu Dan* is a term for younger brother. *Adding two ranks of wealth* means doubling their emolument. *Appointed to the first rank of office* refers to the highest grade of official position. *Slaughtering an animal and burying its blood* describes the ritual of swearing an oath with sacrificial blood before interring it. Their reference to Shennong alludes to the ancient age, which was not like this.

Sacrifices were performed in their proper seasons with reverence, yet without supplication for blessings. *Governing with diligence yet seeking nothing* means having no desire for fame. *Delighting in governance when governing, and in order when order prevailed* suggests acting without self-serving intent. *Hastily seizing power* describes their eager pursuit of virtuous governance. *Bribing below* refers to using ranks and emoluments to entice the world’s knights. *Relying on military force* means resorting to perilous means. *Maintaining authority* means establishing martial power.

Yáng xíng—"to display one’s conduct"—means to make one’s name known. *Replacing tyranny with chaos* suggests being no better than Zhòu in evil. *Their alignment with Zhōu*—does this mean I am the same as Zhōu? *This world is but filth and disgrace to my person*—as if wearing court robes and cap while sitting in mud and ashes. *Not relying on it* means not taking it as a resource. Hòu Shān notes that in one’s parents’ years, one still relies on salary—hence the use of this "rely." *Defiant conduct* is excessive. *To be obstinate* means to be excessive and nothing more—this is precisely defiant conduct. It is said that Bóyí and Shūqí did not seek lofty integrity through defiant conduct; had there been even the slightest principle permitting acceptance of wealth and rank, they would have accepted it. They would not have gone to such extreme lengths. Only because there was no justifiable reason to accept did they act thus.

*The world is benighted, the Shāng in chaos*—this refers to Zhōu, which, though newly risen, already acted in such a manner. Hating that it seized the world through cunning schemes, the text calls this "the decline of virtue." This piece is incomplete and resembles the style of *Zhuāngzǐ*, yet passages like *shooting sparrows with a pearl* and *the weight of the world on one’s arms* or *the butcher of sheep* are still fine, though ultimately not equal to his other works. As for *Robber Zhí*, *Sword*, and *Fisherman*, they are even worse.

*Zhuāngzǐ* Miscellaneous Chapters, "Robber Zhí," Chapter Twenty-Nine:
Confucius was a friend of Liǔxià Jì. Liǔxià Jì’s younger brother was named Robber Zhí. Robber Zhí led a band of nine thousand men, rampaging across the world, invading and plundering the feudal lords, breaking into houses, driving off people’s cattle and horses, seizing their wives and daughters, greedy for gain and forgetting kinship, disregarding parents and brothers, and not sacrificing to ancestors. Wherever he passed, the people of great states guarded their cities, while those of small states took refuge in their strongholds—all the world suffered under him.

Confucius said to Liǔxià Jì, "As a father, one must be able to instruct one’s son; as an elder brother, one must be able to teach one’s younger brother. If a father cannot instruct his son, or an elder brother cannot teach his younger brother, then the intimacy between father and son, elder and younger brother, is worthless. Now, sir, you are a man of talent in this age, yet your younger brother is Robber Zhí, a scourge to the world, and you cannot teach him. I secretly feel shame for you. I beg to go and admonish him on your behalf."

Liǔxià Jì said, "Sir, you say that as a father, one must be able to instruct one’s son, and as an elder brother, one must be able to teach one’s younger brother. But if a son does not heed his father’s instruction, or a younger brother does not accept his elder brother’s teaching, even with your eloquence today, what can you do? Moreover, Zhí’s nature is such that his mind is like a gushing spring, his will like a whirlwind. He is strong enough to resist enemies, eloquent enough to gloss over wrongs. When things go his way, he is pleased; when they do not, he is enraged. He is quick to insult others with words. You must not go."

Confucius did not listen. With Yán Huí driving and Zǐgòng on his right, he went to see Robber Zhí. Robber Zhí was just then resting with his troops on the southern slope of Mount Tài, mincing human livers for his meal. Confucius alighted from his carriage and approached, saying to the herald, "I, Kǒng Qiū of Lǔ, have heard of the general’s lofty virtue and respectfully bow twice in greeting." The herald went in to announce him.

When Robber Zhí heard this, he flew into a great rage, his eyes blazing like stars, his hair bristling beneath his cap. "Is this not that crafty, deceitful man Kǒng Qiū of Lǔ? Tell him for me: you fabricate words, concoct phrases, falsely invoke the names of Wén and Wǔ, wear a cap like a tree branch, gird yourself with the ribs of a dead ox, prattle endlessly with your glib tongue, create right and wrong at will to delude the lords of the world, and lead the scholars of the world astray from their roots. You recklessly preach filial piety and brotherly love, hoping to gain enfeoffment and riches by luck. Your crimes are great and heavy—flee quickly, or I will add your liver to my midday meal!"

Confucius again sent word, saying, "I am fortunate to be acquainted with Jì and wish to gaze upon the hem of your robe." The herald went in again to announce him. Robber Zhí said, "Bring him forward." Confucius hurried forward, avoided the mat, stepped back, and bowed twice.

Robber Zhí, greatly enraged, stretched out his legs, grasped his sword, glared with bulging eyes, and roared like a tiger. "Qiū, come forward! If your words please me, you will live; if they displease me, you will die."

Confucius said, "I have heard that there are three virtues in the world. To be born tall and large, handsome and peerless, so that young and old, noble and base all delight in seeing you—this is the highest virtue. To comprehend the workings of Heaven and Earth and distinguish all things—this is the middle virtue. To be brave, resolute, and daring, gathering multitudes and leading armies—this is the lowest virtue."

chunks.original_text: 天下矣 尧舜有天下子孙无置锥之地汤武立为天子而后世绝灭非以其利大故邪且吾闻之古者禽兽多而人民少于是民皆巢居以避之昼拾橡栗暮栖木上故命之曰有巢氏之民古者民不知衣服夏多积薪冬则炀之故命之曰知生之民神农之世卧则居居起则于于民知其母不知其父与麋鹿共处耕而食织而衣无有相害之心此至德之隆也 然而黄帝不能致德与尤战于涿鹿之野流血百里尧舜作立群臣汤放其主武王杀纣自是之后以强凌弱以众暴寡汤武以来皆乱人之徒也 今子修文武之道掌天下之辩以教后世缝衣浅带矫言伪行以迷惑天下之主而欲求富贵焉 盗莫大于子天下何故不谓子为盗丘而乃谓我为盗跖子以甘辞子路而使从之使子路去其危冠解其长剑而受教于子天下皆曰孔丘能止暴禁非其卒之也 子路欲杀卫君而事不成菹于卫东门之上是子教之不至也 子自谓才士圣人邪则再逐于鲁削迹于卫穷于齐围于陈蔡不容身于天下子教子路菹此患上无以为身下无以为人子之道岂足贵邪世之所高莫若黄帝黄帝尚不能全德而战涿鹿之野流血百里尧不慈舜不孝禹偏枮汤放其主武王伐纣文王拘羑里此六子者世之所高也 孰论之皆以利惑其真而强反其情性其行乃甚可羞也 世之所谓贤士伯夷叔齐伯夷叔齐辞孤竹之君而饿死于首阳之山骨肉不葬鲍焦饰行非世抱木而死申徒狄谏而不听负石自投于河为鱼鳖所食介子推至忠也 自割其股以食文公文公后背之子推怒而去抱木而燔死尾生与女子期于梁下女子不来水至不去抱梁柱而死此四子者无异于磔犬流豕操瓢而乞者皆离名轻死不念本养寿命者也 世之所谓忠臣者莫若王子比干伍子胥子胥沈江比干剖心此二子者世谓忠臣也 然卒为天下笑自上观之至于子胥比干皆不足贵也 丘之所以我者若告我以事则我不能知也 若告我以人事者不过此矣 皆吾所闻知也 今吾告子以人之情目欲视色耳
chunks.translated_text:
"The world is vast indeed! Yao and Shun possessed all under Heaven, yet their descendants had not even a speck of land to stand a cone. Tang and Wu established themselves as the Sons of Heaven, yet their posterity was cut off and extinguished. Was this not because the profit they sought was too great?

Moreover, I have heard that in ancient times, beasts were many and people few. Thus, the people all dwelt in nests to avoid them, gathering acorns by day and roosting in trees by night—hence they were called the people of the Nest-Builder. In ancient times, the people knew not how to make clothing. In summer, they piled up firewood, and in winter, they warmed themselves by it—hence they were called the people who knew how to live. In the age of Shennong, they lay at ease and rose in peace. The people knew their mothers but not their fathers, and lived among the elk and deer. They tilled the soil to eat and wove cloth to wear, with no thought of harming one another. This was the height of perfect virtue.

Yet the Yellow Emperor could not preserve such virtue. He fought with Chiyou at the wilds of Zhuolu, and blood flowed for a hundred *li*. Yao and Shun arose and appointed ministers. Tang exiled his lord, and King Wu killed Zhou. From that time onward, the strong oppressed the weak, and the many bullied the few. From Tang and Wu onward, all have been the followers of disorder.

Now, you cultivate the Way of Wen and Wu, grasp the world’s debates, and teach later generations. You wear fine robes and narrow sashes, speak with artful words and false conduct to delude the lords of the world, all to seek wealth and honor. There is no greater thief than you! Why does the world not call you Robber Qiu, but instead calls me Robber Zhi?

You used sweet words to deceive Zilu and make him follow you. You made Zilu remove his towering cap and lay aside his long sword to receive your teachings. The world all says, ‘Kong Qiu can stop violence and prohibit wrongdoing.’ Yet in the end, Zilu sought to kill the lord of Wei, and when the affair failed, he was minced to pieces at the eastern gate of Wei. This was because your teaching was insufficient.

You call yourself a man of talent and a sage? Then why were you twice driven from Lu, your traces erased in Wei, impoverished in Qi, besieged in Chen and Cai, and left with no place in the world to dwell? You taught Zilu to meet such a fate—above, you brought no benefit to yourself; below, you brought no benefit to others. Is your Way worth esteeming?

Of those the world exalts, none surpasses the Yellow Emperor. Yet even he could not preserve his virtue in full. He fought at the wilds of Zhuolu, and blood flowed for a hundred *li*. Yao was unkind, Shun was undutiful, Yu was crippled by toil, Tang exiled his lord, King Wu attacked Zhou, and King Wen was imprisoned at Youli. These six men are those the world exalts. Yet upon examination, all were deluded by profit, forcing themselves to act contrary to their true nature. Their conduct is truly shameful.

As for the so-called worthy men of the world—Bo Yi and Shu Qi—Bo Yi and Shu Qi renounced the lordship of Gubuzhu and starved to death on Mount Shouyang, their bones and flesh left unburied. Bao Jiao adorned his conduct to condemn the world and died clinging to a tree. Shentu Di remonstrated but was not heeded; he carried a stone and threw himself into the river, where he was eaten by fish and turtles. Jie Zitui was most loyal: he cut flesh from his own thigh to feed Duke Wen. Later, Duke Wen betrayed him, and Zitui, enraged, left and burned to death clinging to a tree. Weisheng made a tryst with a woman beneath a bridge. When the woman did not come and the waters rose, he did not leave but held fast to the bridge pillar and drowned. These four men were no different from dismembered dogs or drifting pigs. They clutched their begging bowls, all seeking fame and scorning death, heedless of preserving their lives and nurturing their destiny.

Of the so-called loyal ministers of the world, none surpass Prince Bigan and Wu Zixu. Zixu was drowned in the river, and Bigan had his heart cut out. These two men are called loyal ministers, yet in the end, they were laughed at by all under Heaven. From a higher perspective, even Zixu and Bigan are not worth esteeming.

As for what you, Qiu, have used to deceive me—if you speak to me of spirits and ghosts, I cannot know it. But if you speak to me of human affairs, it is no more than this, all of which I have heard and understood.

Now, let me tell you of human nature: the eyes desire to see beauty, the ears desire to hear..."

chunks.original_text: 欲听声口欲察味志气欲盈人上寿百岁中寿八十下寿六十除病瘦丧死忧患其中开口而笑者一月之中不过四五日而已矣 天与地无穷人死者有时操有时之具而托于无穷之间忽然无异骐骥之驰过隙也 不能悦其志意养其寿命者皆非通道者也 丘之所言皆吾之所弃也 亟去走归无复言之子之道狂狂伋伋诈巧虚伪事也 非可以全真也 奚足论哉 孔子再拜趋走出门上车执辔三失目芒然无见色若死灰据轼低头不能出气归到鲁东门外适遇栁下季栁下季曰今者阙然数日不见车马有行色得微往见跖邪孔子仰天而叹曰然栁下季曰跖得无逆汝意若前乎 孔子曰然丘所谓无病而自灸也 疾走料虎头编虎须几不免虎口哉 入保者闭门自守也 心如涌泉言其气方旺也 意如飘风虚骄轻飏之意也 妄称文武言妄称文王武王之道以自名枝木削木枝之皮以为冠牛胁牛皮也 得幸于季言与下季得相亲也 望履幙下言一见于幙下而望其履也 此再通谒之辞知维天地知可以包罗天地天地不能出其知之外也 能辩诸物才能可以辩名诸物也 谓其无不知也 其卒之也
chunks.translated_text:
The eyes desire to see beauty, the ears desire to hear sound, the mouth desires to savor flavor, and the will and qi desire fulfillment. The long-lived reach a hundred years, the moderately long-lived eighty, and the short-lived sixty. Yet within this span, one must subtract days lost to illness, emaciation, mourning, death, and sorrow—so that in a month, one may open one’s mouth to laugh no more than four or five days at most.

Heaven and Earth are without end, but human death comes at its appointed time. Clutching the tools of our fleeting span, we entrust ourselves to the boundless, vanishing in an instant like a swift steed galloping past a crack in the wall. Those who cannot delight their will and nurture their lifespan are not masters of the Dao.

All that you, Qiu, have spoken are things I reject. Leave at once, return home, and speak no more of it. Your Way is wild and reckless, full of deceit, cunning, and falsehood—it cannot preserve the true. What is there to discuss?

Confucius bowed twice, hurried out the door, mounted his carriage, and grasped the reins—three times he fumbled them. His eyes were dazed, seeing nothing; his complexion was ashen, like dead embers. He leaned against the crossbar, head bowed, unable to catch his breath. Upon returning to Lu, just outside the eastern gate, he encountered Li Xiashu under a willow tree.

Li Xiashu said, “For days now, you have been absent—your carriage and horses bore signs of travel. Might you have gone to see Zhi?”

Confucius looked up to the heavens and sighed. “Yes.”

Li Xiashu said, “Did Zhi perhaps offend you as he did before?”

Confucius said, “Indeed. What I did was like needlessly cauterizing myself when I had no illness—running wildly to measure a tiger’s head, braiding its whiskers, nearly escaping the tiger’s jaws by sheer luck. Entering a fortress, one bolts the gates and guards oneself. My heart surged like a gushing spring, my qi still vigorous; my intent soared like the wind, empty and arrogant, light and reckless. I falsely invoked the ways of Wen and Wu, like stripping bark from a branch to make a cap or flaying an ox’s flank for leather. I was fortunate to gain favor with Xiashu and glimpse his presence beneath the curtain—this was my second audience. Yet he spoke of knowing Heaven and Earth, as if his knowledge could encompass them, as if Heaven and Earth could not escape its bounds. He claimed to discern all things, to possess knowledge without limit. And in the end, this is how it concluded.”

chunks.original_text: 要其终也 禹偏枯言其胼胝也 孰论之详论之也 磔犬流豕言其身之自杀如杀犬豕也 操瓢而乞有求于人也 离丽也 泥着于名也 故曰离名不念本不知其本真之性伋伋即汲汲也 执辔三失言辔屡落也 车马有行色言其似有所往而方归也 微无也 得无徃见跖乎 若前乎 者若我前日之所言也 子张问于满苟得曰盍不为行无行则不信不信则不任不任则不利故观之名计之利而义真是也 若弃名利反之于心则夫士之为行不可一日不为乎 满苟得曰无耻者富多信者显夫名利之大者几在无耻而信故观之名计之利而信真是也 若弃名利反之于心则夫士之为行抱其天乎 子张曰昔者桀纣贵为天子富有天下今谓臧聚曰汝行如桀纣则有怍色有不服之心者小人所贱也 仲尼墨翟穷为匹夫今谓宰相曰子行如仲尼墨翟则变容易色称不足者士诚贵也 故势为天子未必贵也 穷为匹夫未必贱也 贵贱之分在行之美恶满苟得曰小盗者拘大盗者为诸侯诸侯之门义士存焉 昔者桓公小白杀兄入嫂而管仲为臣田成子常杀君窃国而孔子受币论则贱之行则下之则是言行之情悖战于胸中也 不亦拂乎 故书曰孰恶孰美成者为首不成者为尾子张曰子不为行即将防戚无伦贵贱无义长幼无序五纪六位将何以为别乎 满苟得曰尧杀长子舜流母弟防戚有伦乎 汤伐桀武王杀纣贵贱有义乎 王季为适周公杀兄长幼有序乎 儒者伪辞墨者兼爱五纪六位将有别乎 且子正为名我正为利名利之实不顺于理不监于道吾日与子讼于无约曰小人殉财君子殉名其所以变其情易其性则异矣 乃至于弃其所为而殉其所不为则一也 故曰无为小人反殉而天无为君子从天之理若枉若直相而天极面观四方与时消息若是若非执而圆机独成而意与道徘徊无转而行无成而义将失而所为无赴而富无殉而成将弃而天比干剖心子胥抉眼忠之祸也 直躬证父尾生溺死信之患也 鲍子立干申子不自理廉之害也 孔子不见母匡子不见父义之失也 此上世之所传下世之所语以为士者正其言必其行故服其殃离其患也 盍不为行者言何不修其德行也观之名计之义而义真是者言欲求名利惟修义为是也人若弃名利则反逆其心无以自乐必欲求之非行义不可此学干禄之意也 多信者显言多为可信之言以求荣显此言假信之多以自利者子张言以义求利满苟得则曰今之求名利者诈而已矣若谓弃名利而反逆其心必欲得之则纵吾心之所欲以为苟得自满之计犹为天真而无矫揉故曰抱其天也 小盗者拘大盗者为诸侯即前胠箧篇之论言行之情悖战于胸中谓其行不顾言言不顾行也成者为首不成者为尾即前所谓得其时者为义之徒失其时为夫此意盖以仁义之行皆为诈伪而非天真也五纪五常也六位三纲也君臣父子夫妇也子正为名者谓汝以仁义之名求得我则但为利而已不假矫伪之名也为名为利皆非真实道理故曰名利之实不顺于理不监于道无约无拘束而听其自然也曰满苟得曰无约此又寓意于其名者如前篇知无为之也 弃其所为者舍其所当为而不为谓不能存生保性也 殉其所不为者谓为利为名乃其所不当为者也 殉天理自然则无君子小人之名矣 故曰无为小人反殉而天无为君子从天之理言亦不为君子亦不为小人则可以殉从汝天理之自然矣 而汝也 无曲无直相而视之皆自然至极之理故曰若枉若直相而天极东西南北各有其方而春夏秋冬属焉
chunks.translated_text:
To grasp its end: Yu became half-paralyzed, his hands and feet calloused. Who could discuss this in detail? His body was torn apart like a dismembered dog, his blood flowed like a slaughtered pig—this was self-destruction. He held a gourd to beg, seeking from others. To be *li* (detached) is to be mired in fame, clinging to names. Thus it is said: to be detached from fame is not to contemplate the root, not to know one’s true nature. *Jiji* (restless) means *jiji* (urgent). Holding the reins, he lost them thrice—this speaks of the reins slipping repeatedly. The carriage and horses bore the marks of travel, as if they had somewhere to go yet were returning. Is it not so subtle as to be absent? Could it be that you have gone to see Robber Zhi?

As for what came before—those were my former words.

Zizhang asked Mang Goude, “Why not act? Without action, there is no trust; without trust, there is no task; without task, there is no profit.” Thus, one observes fame and calculates profit, and righteousness is truly therein. If you abandon fame and profit and return them to the heart, then the scholar’s conduct cannot be absent for a single day.

Mang Goude said, “The shameless grow rich; the trusted become prominent. The greatest fame and profit lie in shamelessness and trust.” Thus, one observes fame and calculates profit, and trust is truly therein. If you abandon fame and profit and return them to the heart, then the scholar’s conduct embraces their Heaven.

Zizhang said, “In the past, Jie and Zhou were noble as Sons of Heaven, rich with all under Heaven. Now, if you tell a hoarder, ‘Your conduct is like Jie and Zhou,’ they will flush with shame and harbor resentment—this is what petty men despise. Confucius and Mo Di were poor as commoners. Now, if you tell a prime minister, ‘Your conduct is like Confucius and Mo Di,’ they will change their expression and deem it insufficient—this is the true nobility of scholars. Thus, to be powerful as a Son of Heaven is not necessarily noble; to be poor as a commoner is not necessarily base. The distinction between noble and base lies in the beauty or ugliness of conduct.”

Mang Goude said, “Petty thieves are imprisoned; great thieves become lords. At the gates of lords, righteous scholars reside. In the past, Duke Huan of Qi, Xiaobai, killed his brother and took his sister-in-law, yet Guan Zhong served as his minister. Tian Chengzi murdered his lord and usurped the state, yet Confucius accepted his gifts. To condemn their conduct is to lower them; to discuss their words is to elevate them—this is the contradiction of speech and action warring in the breast. Is it not perverse?

Thus, the *Book* says: ‘Who is ugly? Who is beautiful? The successful are heads; the failed are tails.’ Zizhang said, ‘If you do not act, then you will guard against sorrow without order, noble and base without righteousness, elder and younger without sequence. How will the Five Constants and Six Positions be distinguished?’

Mang Goude said, “Yao killed his eldest son; Shun exiled his younger brother—was there order in guarding against sorrow? Tang punished Jie; King Wu killed Zhou—was there righteousness in noble and base? King Ji was the rightful heir; the Duke of Zhou killed his elder brother—was there sequence in elder and younger? The Confucians speak false words; the Mohists preach universal love—how will the Five Constants and Six Positions be distinguished?

Moreover, you rectify for fame; I rectify for profit. The reality of fame and profit does not accord with principle, does not reflect the Dao. Daily, I dispute with you before Wu Yue, saying: ‘Petty men die for wealth; gentlemen die for fame.’ Their motives differ, their natures change, yet in the end, they abandon what they should do and die for what they should not—this is the same. Thus it is said: ‘Do not act as a petty man, and turn to die for Heaven. Do not act as a gentleman, and follow Heaven’s principle.’

Whether crooked or straight, observe them equally—this is the ultimate principle of Heaven. Facing the four directions, ebb and flow with the seasons. Whether right or wrong, grasp the round mechanism, and intent will wander with the Dao. Without turning, there is no conduct; without completion, there is no righteousness. To lose what you pursue, to gain without seeking, to abandon and follow Heaven—Bi Gan had his heart carved out; Wu Zixu had his eyes gouged out—these were the calamities of loyalty. Zhi Gong testified against his father; Weisheng drowned—these were the disasters of trust. Baozi stood by a pole; Shenzi did not defend himself—these were the harms of integrity. Confucius did not see his mother; Kuangzi did not see his father—these were the failures of righteousness.

These are what the past transmitted and the present discusses, taking them as the standard for scholars: rectify your words, verify your conduct. Thus, they suffer their misfortunes and encounter their disasters.

Why not act? This means: why not cultivate virtue? To observe fame and calculate righteousness, and righteousness is truly therein—this means that to seek fame and profit, only cultivating righteousness is correct. If one abandons fame and profit, they turn against their heart and have no joy; they must seek them, and nothing but righteous conduct suffices—this is the intent of studying for official salary.

‘Many trustworthy words bring prominence’—this means using many trustworthy words to seek glory, speaking of feigning trust to benefit oneself. Zizhang spoke of seeking profit through righteousness; Mang Goude said, ‘Those who seek fame and profit today do so through deceit.’

If you say to abandon fame and profit yet turn against the heart, you must seek them—then follow your heart’s desires, indulging in self-satisfaction as a scheme for mere gain, still preserving Heaven’s truth without affectation. Thus it is said: embrace your Heaven.

Petty thieves are imprisoned; great thieves become lords—this is the argument from the *Opening Trunks* chapter. ‘The contradiction of speech and action warring in the breast’ means their conduct disregards their words, their words disregard their conduct. ‘The successful are heads; the failed are tails’—this is what was previously called: those who seize the moment are followers of righteousness; those who lose it are *kuang* men.

This intent suggests that acts of benevolence and righteousness are all deceit and not Heaven’s truth. The Five Constants are the five virtues; the Six Positions are the three bonds: ruler and minister, father and son, husband and wife.

‘You rectify for fame’ means: if you seek to obtain me through the name of benevolence and righteousness, it is merely for profit, not feigning false names. Fame and profit are not true principles, so it is said: ‘The reality of fame and profit does not accord with principle, does not reflect the Dao.’

Wu Yue means ‘unrestrained,’ listening to nature. Mang Goude said, ‘Wu Yue’—this is another allusion in his name, as in the previous chapter’s ‘Knowing Non-Action.’

‘Abandoning what they should do’ means forsaking what they ought to do, not preserving life or protecting nature. ‘Dying for what they should not do’ means acting for profit and fame, which they ought not to do.

To die for Heaven’s principle and nature is without the names of gentleman or petty man. Thus it is said: ‘Do not act as a petty man, and turn to die for Heaven. Do not act as a gentleman, and follow Heaven’s principle’—this means neither acting as a gentleman nor a petty man, so one can die for the natural principle of your Heaven.

And you—whether crooked or straight, observe them equally, for all are the ultimate principle of nature. Thus it is said: ‘Whether crooked or straight, observe them equally as Heaven’s ultimate.’ East, west, south, north each have their direction, and spring, summer, autumn, winter belong to them.”

chunks.original_text: 消息往来皆一气也 故曰面观四方与时消息执圆机则无是非故曰若是若非执而圆机信意而行独得于我则从容体道矣 故曰独成而意与道徘徊转背也 背道而行自名以义以求成功则失其所谓本真者矣 故曰无转而行无成而义将失而所为而汝也 趋赴于富而求殉其成功则将失其自然之天矣 故曰无赴而富无殉而成将弃而天凡曰无者言莫如此也 禁止之意也 正其言谓以忠信廉义之言为实也 必其行者谓必为忠信廉义之行也 服被也 离丽也 言必遭其殃害也 子张欲行义以求富贵因干禄之语而借其名也 满苟得则以苟得而满其欲为自然之道故设为问答之辞意谓矫饰以求利达不如直情之为愈盖矫孟子天爵人爵之也 无足问于知和曰人卒未有不兴名就利者彼富则人归之归则下之下则贵之夫见下贵者所以长生安体乐意之道也 今子独无意焉 知不足邪意知而力不能行邪故推正不忘邪知和曰今夫此人以为与己同时而生同乡而处者以为夫绝俗过世之士焉 是专无主正所以览古今之时是非之分也 与俗化世去至重弃至尊以为其所为也 此其所以论长生安体乐意之道不亦远乎 惨怛之疾恬愉之安不监于体怵惕之恐欣欢之喜不监于心知为为而不知所以为是以贵为天子富有天下而不免于患也 推正不忘者言汝之无意于富贵岂其智不足邪意度也 度汝亦知此而力有不及邪故推正理以遏求富贵之心而不能忘邪此人富贵之人也 言此等富贵之人皆与我同生斯世同处此乡岂是绝俗过世之士言其非有甚高而不可及也 其意盖谓此亦眼前人耳 我岂不知之此人其心全无所主全失其性命之正但知趋时以求已分之益而为流俗所化言其所为皆俗人也 是非之分者言以他人为非以已为是自求其身之益也 古今久近也 前一时如何今一时如何览察其时之向背以自求利也 至重至尊者天理之自然也 皆弃而去之独为其所谓求富贵之事此岂长生安身养心之道也 求富贵之人其身其心或安或否或悲或喜迷而不觉不能自见故曰不监于体不监于心为为者为其所为乃人为也 所以为者天理也 知有人为而不知有天理虽为天子犹不免于损身之患害况其下者乎 无足曰夫富之于人无所不利穷美究势至人之所不得逮贤人之所不能及侠人之勇力而以为威强秉人之知谋以为明察因人之德以为贤良非享国而严若君父且夫声色滋味权势之于人心不待学而乐之体不待象而安之夫欲恶避就固不待师此人之性也 天下虽非我孰能辞之知和曰知者之为故动以百姓不违其度是以足而不争无以为故不求不足故求之争四处而不自以为贪有余故辞之弃天下而不自以为廉廉贪之实非以迫外也 反监之度势为天子而不以贵骄人富有天下而不以财戏人计其患虑其反以为害于性故辞而不受也 非以要名誉也 尧舜为帝而雍非仁天下也 不以美害生也 善卷许由得帝而不受非虚辞让也 不以事害己也 此皆就其利辞其害而天下称贤焉 则可以有之彼非以兴名誉也 此又不言贵只言富穷美者可以尽求其所好也 究势者可以尽权势之事也 虽至人贤人亦有不及焉 言其力量之可以自用也 使人因人秉人皆言其富可以使人也 即十万通神之意欲欲富也 恶恶贫也 避贫而就富不待教而后能故曰不待师此出于天性之自然也 天下之人虽皆以为非而我安能辞避之此设为贪者之言无足贪而不知足也 故名以无足满苟得之也
chunks.translated_text:
All ebb and flow, all coming and going, are but a single qi. Thus it is said: "Face the four directions and observe the ebb and flow of the seasons. Grasp the round mechanism, and there will be no right or wrong." Thus it is said: "Whether right or wrong, grasp the round mechanism, act with sincere intent, and attain it uniquely for yourself—then you may move with ease and embody the Dao." Thus it is said: "Attain it uniquely, and your intent will wander with the Dao, turning away from it."

To act in opposition to the Dao, to seek success by self-styled righteousness, is to lose what is called one’s original truth. Thus it is said: "Do not turn and act, do not achieve and claim righteousness—lest you lose what you ought to do, and you yourself." To hasten toward wealth and seek to die for one’s achievements is to lose one’s natural Heaven. Thus it is said: "Do not hasten toward wealth, do not die for achievement—lest you abandon your Heaven." The word "do not" here means "must not do this"—it is a prohibition.

To rectify one’s words means to take loyalty, trustworthiness, integrity, and righteousness as true. To ensure one’s conduct means to act with loyalty, trustworthiness, integrity, and righteousness. "Clothed" means to be covered; "detached" means to be separated. It is said that one will inevitably suffer harm. Zizhang sought to practice righteousness to attain wealth and honor, borrowing the language of seeking office to lend it a name.

"Filled by mere acquisition" means to satisfy one’s desires through mere acquisition, taking it as the natural Dao. Thus, the question and answer are posed: "Is it not better to follow one’s true nature than to feign virtue for profit and advancement?" This echoes Mencius’s distinction between the Heavenly nobility and the human nobility.

Wu Zu asked Zhi He: "Among people, there has never been one who did not pursue fame and seek profit. Those who are wealthy are followed by others; those who are followed become lowly; those who are lowly are honored. To see the lowly and honor them is the way to long life, bodily ease, and joyful contentment. Yet you alone have no such intent—is it that you lack the wisdom, or that you know but lack the strength to act?"

Zhi He replied: "Now, these people—those who live in the same era and dwell in the same village as oneself—take themselves for those who transcend the common and surpass the world. They lack any true principle, yet they survey the times of past and present, distinguishing right from wrong. They abandon what is most weighty and cast aside what is most honorable to pursue what they do. How can their discourse on the way to long life, bodily ease, and joyful contentment not be far from the mark?

The pain of sorrow and the comfort of serenity are not reflected in their bodies; the fear of alarm and the joy of delight are not reflected in their hearts. They know how to act but not why they act. Thus, even those who are honored as Son of Heaven and possess all under Heaven cannot escape suffering. To 'rectify and not forget' means: Is your lack of desire for wealth and honor due to insufficient wisdom, or do you understand this yet lack the strength to act? Thus, I press the true principle to restrain the heart that seeks wealth and honor, yet you cannot forget it.

These wealthy and honorable people are those who live in the same era and dwell in the same village as oneself—are they those who transcend the common and surpass the world? They are not so lofty as to be unattainable. Their intent is merely to say: 'These are but ordinary people before my eyes—how could I not know them?' Yet their hearts lack any guiding principle, wholly losing the rectitude of their nature and destiny. They only know how to follow the times to seek their own advantage, being transformed by the common customs. What they do is no different from what ordinary people do.

The distinction of right and wrong means taking others as wrong and oneself as right, seeking one’s own benefit. 'Past and present' refers to the near and the far—how things were in a previous time, how they are now. They observe the trends of the times to seek their own advantage. What is most weighty and most honorable is the natural principle of Heaven, yet they abandon it all to pursue what they call the quest for wealth and honor. How can this be the way to long life, bodily ease, and nurturing the heart?

Those who seek wealth and honor—whether their bodies are at ease or not, whether their hearts are joyful or sorrowful—they are deluded and unaware, unable to see themselves. Thus it is said: 'Not reflected in the body, not reflected in the heart.' To 'act' is to do what one does—this is human effort. The 'why' of acting is the principle of Heaven. To know human effort but not the principle of Heaven—even if one is Son of Heaven, one cannot escape harm to the body, let alone those below."

Wu Zu said: "Wealth, for people, is without disadvantage—it exhausts beauty and exhausts power, reaching what even the utmost person cannot attain, what the worthy cannot match, and what the brave and strong cannot rival. It wields the wisdom and plans of others as its own discernment, and adopts the virtue of others as its own excellence. Without even possessing a state, it commands awe like a lord and father. As for the allure of sounds and sights, flavors and pleasures, power and influence—people delight in them without needing to learn, and their bodies find ease without needing to imitate. Desires and aversions, avoidance and pursuit—these are not taught by a teacher; they are the nature of people. Though all under Heaven may oppose me, who can refuse it?"

Zhi He said: "The actions of the wise are purposeful, moving with the people without violating their measure. Thus, they are content and do not contend. Without purpose, they do not seek; without insufficiency, they do not contend. They are everywhere yet do not consider themselves greedy; they have surplus yet decline it. They abandon all under Heaven yet do not consider themselves incorrupt. The reality of incorruptibility and greed is not imposed from without—it is reflected in the measure within.

In power as Son of Heaven, they do not use their nobility to lord over others; possessing all under Heaven, they do not use their wealth to toy with others. They calculate the harm and consider the consequences, seeing it as detrimental to their nature—thus they decline and do not accept. It is not to seek fame and reputation. Yao and Shun ruled as emperors, yet their harmony was not benevolence toward all under Heaven—it was not to harm life with beauty. Shan Juan and Xu You declined the throne, and it was not empty modesty—it was not to harm themselves with affairs. These were all cases of pursuing benefit and declining harm, and all under Heaven calls them worthy. Yet they did not do so to seek fame and reputation.

Here, it does not speak of honor but only of wealth. 'Exhausting beauty' means one can pursue all one desires; 'exhausting power' means one can exercise all authority. Even the utmost person and the worthy cannot match this—it speaks of the power to act for oneself. To 'make others act' and 'wield others' means that wealth can command people—this is the meaning of 'ten thousand spirits in communion.' To desire wealth and hate poverty, to avoid poverty and seek wealth, does not require teaching—it is said: 'It does not await a teacher.' This arises from the natural nature of Heaven. Though all under Heaven may deem it wrong, how can I avoid it?" This is the speech of the greedy, who are insatiable—thus they are named Wu Zu, the "Insufficient One," and belong to the category of "filled by mere acquisition."

chunks.original_text: 动以百姓者言智者之所为每以百姓之同得于天者为主故不敢自违于法度百姓所同得有物有则者也 度即则也 足而不争德足于己而无所争也 无以为故不求为不在人而在天人力无所与故曰无以为知人力之无所与则不求矣 使其在我有所不足则穷极四方而争求之亦不以为贪此求德也 求在内者也 德足而有余则身外之物皆辞之虽辞天下亦不为廉此贪廉二者之实非以为人也 非务外也 而皆反求诸天理之法度而监之故曰反监之度以财戏人鼔舞天下也 虑其反反身而虑之也 雍黎民于变时雍也 不以美害生者言其无为而为不以美名而害其身有天下而不与也 可以有之言天下之贤名可以自有而无愧也 其为道为德出于中心之诚非求以兴名誉也 此又把尧舜与许由皆作好 无足曰必持其名苦体绝甘约养以持生则亦久病长阨而不死者也 知和曰平为福有余为害者物莫不然而财其甚者也 今富人耳 营钟鼔管钥之声口嗛于刍豢醪醴之味以感其意遗忘其业可谓乱矣 侅溺于冯气若负重行而上也 可谓苦矣 贪财而取慰贪权而取竭静居则溺体泽则冯可谓疾矣 为欲富就利故满若堵耳 而不知避且冯而不舍可谓辱矣 财积而无用服膺而不舍满心戚醮求益而不止可谓忧矣 内则疑劫请之贼外则畏防盗之害内周楼防外不敢独行可谓畏矣 此六者天下之至害也 皆遗忘而不知察及其患至求尽性竭财单以反一日之无故而不可得也 故观之名则不见求之利则不得缭意绝体而争此不亦惑乎 必持其名者言必欲求名而不求富贵之利则徒然自苦其身虽存如大病然绝甘去美味也 约养俭以自奉也 久病长阨而不死即易所谓贞疾常不死也 平为福有余为害物莫不然财其甚此篇文字枝叶太粗比之让王渔父又不及但如此四句亦好语也 岂可泯没嗛塞满其口也 猿猴之颔曰嗛感其意者动其意也 言役其心也 遗忘其业失其所当为也
chunks.translated_text:
Those who move with the common people speak of how the wise in their actions always take as their foundation what the people jointly receive from Heaven—thus they dare not violate the standards and measures. What the people jointly receive consists of things and principles. Measures are principles. To be content and not contend is to have virtue sufficient within oneself and nothing to strive for. With nothing to rely upon, one does not seek to act; what lies not in others but in Heaven, where human effort has no part—this is called "nothing to rely upon." Knowing that human effort has no part, one ceases to seek. If within oneself there is insufficiency, one exhausts the four directions in striving and seeking, yet does not deem it greed—this is seeking virtue, seeking what lies within. When virtue is sufficient and overflowing, one rejects even external things; though one may reject the world, this is not for the sake of frugality. In both greed and frugality, the reality lies not in acting for others, not in striving outwardly, but in returning to seek within the standards of Heavenly principle and examining them. Thus it is said: "Returning to examine the measure, using wealth to amuse people and drumming up the world." To consider it repeatedly is to turn back to oneself and reflect. To bring harmony to the people in times of change is to harmonize. Not allowing beauty to harm life means acting without acting, not allowing the fame of beauty to harm one’s person. To possess the world yet not be involved with it—this is to say that the worthy name of the world can be possessed without shame. Their practice of the Way and virtue arises from sincerity of the center, not from seeking to raise fame and reputation. Here again, Yao and Shun are placed alongside Xu You as those who love fame.

The insatiable say: "One must hold to one’s name, torment the body, reject sweetness, and restrain nourishment to preserve life—this is to suffer long illness and endless distress without dying." To know harmony is to be level; excess brings harm. There is nothing that does not follow this, but wealth is its extreme. Now, the rich man’s ears are filled with the sounds of bells, drums, pipes, and flutes; his mouth savors the taste of fine meats and rich wines, stirring his mind and causing him to neglect his proper work—this may be called disorder. Indulging in excess and drowning in surging qi, like bearing a heavy burden while climbing—this may be called suffering. Coveting wealth brings exhaustion; coveting power brings depletion. Dwelling in stillness, one drowns the body; dwelling in ease, one surges—this may be called sickness. Pursuing wealth and chasing profit, one’s ears are filled as if by a wall, yet one does not know to avoid it, surging forward without cease—this may be called disgrace. Wealth accumulates without use; one clings to it without release. The heart is filled with sorrow and vexation, seeking more without end—this may be called worry. Within, one fears the threat of robbery and extortion; without, one dreads the harm of thieves. One surrounds oneself with towers and defenses, dares not walk alone—this may be called fear. These six are the greatest harms under Heaven. All are neglected and unexamined, yet when calamity arrives, one exhausts one’s nature and depletes one’s wealth, seeking in vain to return to a single day of former ease. Thus, if one looks for fame, it cannot be seen; if one seeks profit, it cannot be obtained. Yet one wearies the mind and wears the body, contending for these—is this not delusion?

Those who "must hold to their name" speak of those who insist on seeking fame and not the profit of wealth and honor, thus pointlessly tormenting themselves. Though they live, it is as if gravely ill—rejecting sweetness, forsaking fine flavors, restraining nourishment, and practicing frugality in self-care. "Long illness and endless distress without dying" is what the *Yi* calls "steadfast illness, ever undying." Levelness brings fortune; excess brings harm. There is nothing that does not follow this, but wealth is its extreme. Though the wording of this passage is rough and its branches and leaves too coarse—falling short of the *Rang Wang* and *Yu Fu*—even these four lines are fine words. How can they be erased? "The monkey’s cheek" is called *qian*; "stirring the mind" means moving the intent, speaking of enslaving the heart. "Neglecting one’s work" is losing what one ought to do.

chunks.original_text: 冯气怒其气而不得通也 侅溺不自在也 若人行负重物而登高然取慰取足也 取竭用尽也 今谚云有势莫尽用是也 静居则溺言不耐闲而自没溺于嗜欲也 体泽则冯者其身充肥悦泽则冯满有骄涨之意也 满若堵者言积财而高于堵所谓阿堵物是也 不知避不知足趋求而未已也 冯恃也 恃此以为夸而不能舍服膺念念不忘也 念念不忘但见憔憔戚戚之意满于胸中故曰满心戚醮不自得如此犹求益而不止也 劫请劫取也藏于屋内者恐有劫盗故为楼防周环其室运而出外恐有大盗必盛其徒旅而不敢独行防窗也楼墙上之楼也六者曰乱曰苦曰疾曰辱曰忧曰畏是也遗忘而不察者言皆失检而不自觉也单独也但也故事也反复也及其病患已成虽欲求全其生去其财但求一日复如贫居无事之初而不可得也尽性全生也竭去也反愿去富而就贫也及至于此则名亦何在利亦何在缭意绝体缠缚其身心也争利之时徒缠缚其身心反以成此祸患非愚乎 东坡谓让王以下四篇非庄子所作此见极高四篇之中盗跖尤甚而太史公庄子传但谓作渔父盗跖胠箧以诋讥孔子之徒略不疑其文字精粗异同何也岂子长之意且以其非议夫子为言不暇及其文字乎不然则此书此篇在汉而后或因散轶为人所窜易亦犹今列子也 杂篇说剑第三十 昔赵文王喜剑剑士夹门而客三千余人日夜相击于前死伤者岁百余人好之不厌如是三年国衰诸侯谋之太子悝患之募左右曰孰能悦王之意止剑士者赐之千金左右曰庄子当能太子乃使人以千金奉庄子庄子弗受与使者俱往见太子曰太子何以教周赐周千金太子曰闻夫子明圣谨奉千金以币从者夫子弗受悝尚何敢言庄子曰闻太子所欲用周者欲绝王之喜好也 使臣上大王而逆王意下不当太子则身刑而死周尚安所事金乎 使臣上大王下当太子赵国何求而不得也 太子曰然吾王所见唯剑士也 庄子曰诺周善为剑太子曰然吾王所见剑士皆蓬头突垂冠曼胡之缨短后之衣瞠目而语难王乃悦之今夫子必儒服而见王事必大逆庄子曰请治剑服治剑服三日乃见太子太子乃与见王王脱白刃待之庄子入殿门不趋见王不拜王曰子欲何以教寡人使太子先曰臣闻大王喜剑故以剑见王王曰子之剑何能禁制曰臣之剑十步一人千里不留行王大悦曰天下无敌矣 庄子曰夫为剑者示之以虚开之以利后之以发先之以至愿得试之王曰夫子休就舍待命令设戏请夫子王乃校剑士七日死伤者六十余人得五六人使奉剑于殿下乃召庄子王曰今日试使士敦剑庄子曰望之久矣 王曰夫子所御杖长短何如曰臣之所奉皆可然臣有三剑唯王所用请先言而后试王曰愿闻三剑曰有天子剑有诸侯剑有庶人剑王曰天子之剑何如曰天子之剑以燕溪石城为锋齐岱为锷晋魏为脊周宋为镡韩魏为铗包以四夷裹以四时绕以渤海带以常山制以五行论以刑德开以阴阳持以春夏行以秋冬此剑直之无前举之无上案之无下运之无旁上决浮云下绝地纪此剑一用匡诸侯天下服矣 此天子之剑也 文王芒然自失曰诸侯之剑何如曰诸侯之剑以知勇士为锋以清廉士为锷以贤良士为脊以忠圣士为镡以豪杰士为铗此剑直之亦无前举之亦无上案之亦无下运之亦无旁上法圆天以顺三光下法方地以顺四时中知民意以安四乡此剑一用如雷霆之震也 四封之内无不宾服而听从君命者矣 此诸侯之剑也 王曰庶人之剑何如曰庶人之剑蓬头突垂冠曼胡之缨短后之衣瞠目而语难相击于前上斩颈领下决肝肺此庶人之剑无异于斗鸡一旦命已绝矣
chunks.translated_text:
Fuming with qi, his qi obstructed and unable to flow freely—this is *hai*, drowning in discomfort. It is like a man carrying a heavy burden while climbing a height, seeking comfort, seeking sufficiency. "Taking to the extreme" means exhausting all use. As the common saying goes: "When you have power, do not use it all." Living in stillness, he drowns—unable to endure idleness, he submerges himself in desires. When the body is sleek and glossy, the one who fumes is full and plump, radiant with health, swelling with arrogance and distension. "Full as a wall" speaks of amassing wealth until it towers like a wall—this is what is called the "thing at the wall." Unaware of avoidance, insatiable, he pursues without end. *Feng* means reliance; relying on this, he boasts and cannot let go, clinging to it in his breast, thought after thought unceasing. With thought after thought unceasing, only the look of weariness and sorrow fills his chest—thus it is said, "a heart full of sorrow, a face of distress," never at ease. Even so, he seeks more without cease.

"Forced taking" means seizing by force. Those who hoard within their houses fear thieves and robbers, so they build towers and fortify their chambers, encircling their rooms. When venturing out, they fear great bandits, so they muster their retinue and dare not travel alone—guarding their windows. The towers are the structures atop the walls. These six are called: disorder, suffering, illness, disgrace, worry, and fear. "Neglecting and failing to examine" means losing restraint and being unaware of it. *Dan* means "only"; *gu* means "matter"; *fanfu* means "repeatedly." By the time illness and affliction have taken form, even if one wishes to preserve life and relinquish wealth—seeking only to return to the carefree days of poverty—it cannot be attained. "Exhausting one’s nature to preserve life" means "depleting" and "removing." One wishes to cast off wealth and return to poverty. By this point, where is one’s name? Where is one’s profit? Entangled in thought, the body bound—when contending for profit, one merely binds body and mind, only to bring about this disaster. Is this not foolish?

Su Dongpo said that the four chapters following *Rang Wang* were not written by Zhuangzi. This judgment is exceedingly astute. Among these four, *Dao Zhi* is the most egregious. Yet Sima Qian’s *Biography of Zhuangzi* merely states that *Yu Fu*, *Dao Zhi*, and *Qu Qie* were written to criticize Confucius and his followers, without the slightest doubt as to the refinement or coarseness of the text, or its differences. Why is this? Could it be that Sima Qian’s intent was merely to address the disparagement of the Master, leaving no room to consider the quality of the writing? Otherwise, this book and this chapter, appearing after the Han, may have been altered by later hands due to scattered and lost texts—much like the *Liezi* of today.

**Miscellaneous Chapters: "Discourse on Swords" (Chapter 30)**

Long ago, King Wen of Zhao was fond of swords. Over three thousand swordsmen gathered at his gates as guests, clashing before him day and night. Each year, over a hundred died or were wounded, yet the king’s delight never waned. After three years of this, the state declined, and the feudal lords plotted against it. The crown prince, Kui, grew anxious and summoned his attendants, saying, "Whoever can please the king and put an end to these swordsmen will be rewarded with a thousand gold pieces." His attendants replied, "Zhuangzi is the one who can do this."

The crown prince then sent men bearing a thousand gold pieces to offer to Zhuangzi, but Zhuangzi refused to accept them. He went with the messengers to see the crown prince and said, "What instruction does the crown prince have for me, that he would grant me a thousand gold pieces?" The crown prince replied, "I have heard that you are enlightened and sagely. I humbly present these thousand gold pieces as gifts for your attendants. Since you have refused them, how dare I speak further?" Zhuangzi said, "I have heard that the crown prince wishes to employ me to end the king’s fondness for swords. If I were to advise the king and oppose his will, and below, fail to meet the crown prince’s expectations, I would face execution and death. How then could I make use of the gold? If I were to advise the king above and meet the crown prince’s expectations below, what in the state of Zhao could I not obtain?"

The crown prince said, "Indeed. But my father, the king, only sees swordsmen." Zhuangzi replied, "Very well. I am skilled in the way of the sword." The crown prince said, "But the swordsmen my father sees all have disheveled hair, bristling whiskers, slouching caps with long tassels, short robes, glaring eyes, and speak with difficulty. The king delights in them. Now, if you were to appear before him in Confucian garb, the matter would surely go awry." Zhuangzi said, "I request to prepare the attire of a swordsman." After three days of preparing his sword attire, he met with the crown prince, who then presented him to the king. The king drew his naked blade and awaited him.

Zhuangzi entered the palace hall without haste and did not bow to the king. The king said, "What do you wish to teach me, that you have had the crown prince announce you?" Zhuangzi replied, "I have heard that Your Majesty is fond of swords, and so I have come to present my swordsmanship." The king said, "What can your sword do to withstand and control others?" Zhuangzi replied, "My sword can cut down one man every ten paces and travel a thousand *li* without hindrance." The king was overjoyed and said, "You would be invincible in the world!"

Zhuangzi said, "One who wields the sword shows emptiness, offers advantage, follows with action, and strikes first. I wish to demonstrate this." The king said, "Sir, rest and return to your lodging. I will arrange a contest and summon you." The king then had the swordsmen spar for seven days, during which over sixty were killed or wounded. He selected five or six men to present their swords at the foot of the hall and then summoned Zhuangzi, saying, "Today, I wish to see you spar with these men and test their swords." Zhuangzi replied, "I have long awaited this."

The king said, "Sir, what kind of weapon do you wield—long or short?" Zhuangzi replied, "I am prepared to wield any length. However, I possess three swords, and Your Majesty may choose which to use. Allow me to explain them before demonstrating." The king said, "I wish to hear about the three swords." Zhuangzi replied, "There is the sword of the Son of Heaven, the sword of the feudal lords, and the sword of the common people."

The king said, "What is the sword of the Son of Heaven like?" Zhuangzi replied, "The sword of the Son of Heaven has its blade forged from Yanxi and Shicheng, its edge from Mount Tai of Qi, its spine from Jin and Wei, its grip from Zhou and Song, and its guard from Han and Wei. It is wrapped with the four barbarians, bound with the four seasons, encircled by the Bohai Sea, and girded by Mount Chang. It is governed by the five phases, judged by punishments and virtue, opened by yin and yang, held in spring and summer, and wielded in autumn and winter. When thrust forward, nothing stands before it; when raised, nothing is above it; when pressed down, nothing is beneath it; when swung, nothing lies beside it. Above, it cleaves the floating clouds; below, it severs the roots of the earth. When this sword is once employed, it rectifies the feudal lords, and the world submits. This is the sword of the Son of Heaven."

King Wen appeared lost in thought and said, "What is the sword of the feudal lords like?" Zhuangzi replied, "The sword of the feudal lords has its blade forged from men of wisdom and courage, its edge from men of integrity and incorruptibility, its spine from men of worth and goodness, its grip from men of loyalty and sagacity, and its guard from men of valor and heroism. When thrust forward, nothing stands before it; when raised, nothing is above it; when pressed down, nothing is beneath it; when swung, nothing lies beside it. Above, it models the round heaven, following the three luminaries; below, it models the square earth, following the four seasons; within, it understands the people’s will, bringing peace to the four directions. When this sword is once employed, it is like the shock of thunder. Within the four borders, none do not submit and obey the ruler’s command. This is the sword of the feudal lords."

The king said, "What is the sword of the common people like?" Zhuangzi replied, "The sword of the common people is wielded by men with disheveled hair, bristling whiskers, slouching caps with long tassels, short robes, glaring eyes, and harsh speech. They clash before one another, striking above at necks and throats, and below at livers and lungs. This is the sword of the common people—no different from fighting cocks. A single morning’s life may be cut short. None of these are of use to the state. Now, Your Majesty occupies the throne of the Son of Heaven yet delights in the sword of the common people. I humbly submit that this is unworthy of you."

Over three thousand men, skilled in swordsmanship, served as retainers at the king’s gate, their followers sustained by stipends—what today would be called "rewarding retainers." "Disheveled hair, bristling whiskers" refers to their exposed hair and whiskers. "Slouching caps" means their caps were not worn high, like today’s wrapped headcloths, with tassels dangling beneath the chin. "Harsh speech" describes their contentious exchanges when seeking to fight, feigning openings to provoke an attack. "Striking later yet arriving first" mimics the hawk’s concealed strike before it pounces. "Setting the game" refers to staging swordplay. "Dun-sword" means decisive cutting, clashing blades in combat. "Imperial staff" denotes the sword’s use by the ruler, a staff held in hand. "Point" is the sword’s tip; "edge," its blade. "Guard" is the sword’s mouth; "hilt," its handle. "Enveloped by the four seasons" signifies its use in accord with the times. "Governed by the five phases" means it follows the principles of the five phases. The sun embodies virtue; the moon, punishment—sun and moon, yin and yang, spring and summer, autumn and winter all align with the natural workings of creation. "Thrusting, lifting, pressing, wielding, cleaving above, severing below" all describe the vastness of its application. "Dazed and self-lost" means that upon hearing these grand words, one realizes the shallowness of their former pursuits and thus feels adrift. "Above modeling Heaven, below modeling Earth, harmonizing with the people’s will" corresponds to the harmony of heaven’s timing, earth’s advantage, and human accord. **Miscellaneous Chapters: "The Fisherman" (Chapter Thirty-One)**

Confucius wandered in the woods of the Black Curtain and rested, sitting upon the Apricot Platform. His disciples read books while Confucius strummed a zither and sang. Before the song was half-finished, a fisherman came ashore. His beard and brows were snowy white, his hair hung loose, and his sleeves swayed as he walked. Ascending from the marsh to the shore, he stopped, leaning his left hand on his knee and resting his right hand on his chin to listen. When the song ended, he beckoned to Zilu and Zigong, who both faced the guest. Pointing at Confucius, the guest asked, "Who is that?"

Zilu replied, "A gentleman of Lu."

The guest inquired about his clan, and Zilu answered, "The Kong clan."

The guest asked, "What does the Kong clan govern?"

Zilu did not respond, but Zigong answered, "The Kong clan cultivates loyalty and trust in their nature, practices benevolence and righteousness in their conduct, refines ritual and music, and selects proper human relationships. Above, they are loyal to the ruler of the age; below, they transform the common people, all to benefit the world. This is what the Kong clan governs."

The guest asked again, "Is he a lord with lands?"

Zigong said, "No."

"Is he an advisor to kings and marquises?"

Zigong said, "No."

The guest laughed and turned to leave, saying, "He may be benevolent, but I fear he will not escape harm. He wearies his mind and exhausts his body, endangering his true nature. Alas, how far he has strayed from the Dao!"

Zigong returned and reported to Confucius. Confucius pushed aside the zither and rose, saying, "Is he a sage?" He then descended to seek him by the marsh’s edge, where the fisherman was about to pole his boat away. Turning and seeing Confucius, he stood facing his village. Confucius retreated, bowed twice, and approached.

The guest said, "What do you seek?"

Confucius replied, "Just now, sir, you left with words unfinished. I, unworthy as I am, do not understand their meaning. I have waited humbly in your presence, hoping to hear even the sound of your cough or spittle to complete my instruction."

The guest said, "Ah! How earnest is your love of learning!"

Confucius bowed twice and rose, saying, "From my youth, I have cultivated learning, and now, at sixty-nine, I have yet to hear the ultimate teaching. How dare I not empty my heart?"

The guest said, "Like seeks like, and sounds resonate with their kind—this is the principle of Heaven. Let me explain what I possess and expound upon what concerns you. What concerns you is human affairs: the Son of Heaven, feudal lords, great officers, and common people—these four ranks, when properly ordered, bring the finest governance. If these four abandon their positions, no greater disorder arises. When officials manage their duties and people attend to their tasks, none overstep their bounds. Thus, fields lie fallow, homes stand exposed, clothing and food are insufficient, taxes are unpaid, wives and concubines quarrel, and elders and juniors lack order—these are the worries of the common people. Inability to fulfill duties, mismanagement of office, impure conduct, neglect of subordinates, failure to achieve merit, and loss of rank and salary—these are the worries of great officers. The court lacks loyal ministers, the state is in chaos, craftsmen lack skill, tribute is unrefined, the seasons and ranks are disordered—these are the worries of the Son of Heaven and feudal lords. Yin and yang fall out of harmony, cold and heat arrive untimely, harming the myriad things; feudal lords act violently, seizing and attacking one another, ravaging the people; ritual and music lack restraint, resources are exhausted, human relationships are unordered, and the common people are licentious—these are the worries of the Son of Heaven’s ministers.

Now, you possess neither the authority of a lord or minister above nor the office of a great officer below, yet you presume to refine ritual and music, select proper human relationships, and transform the common people. Is this not excessive meddling?

Moreover, people have eight flaws, and affairs have four perils—these cannot go unexamined.

To meddle in affairs not one’s own is called *zong* (officiousness).
To advance without regard is called *ning* (obsequiousness).
To speak to curry favor is called *tao* (flattery).
To speak without discerning right or wrong is called *fang* (recklessness).
To delight in speaking of others’ faults is called *chan* (slander).
To sever close relationships is called *zei* (treachery).
To praise falsely to harm others is called *te* (malice).
To accommodate both good and bad with a pleasing countenance, seeking to gain what one desires, is called *xian* (deviousness).

These eight flaws externally confuse others and internally harm oneself. The noble person does not befriend such people, and the enlightened ruler does not employ them.

The four perils are:
To love undertaking great affairs, altering constants to seek merit and fame, is called *tao* (presumptuousness).
To monopolize knowledge, arrogate affairs, encroach upon others, and act self-righteously is called *tan* (greed).
To see one’s faults yet not change, and to hear remonstrance yet grow more obstinate, is called *hen* (stubbornness).
To approve of those who agree with oneself and disapprove of those who disagree, even if they are good, is called *jin* (arrogance).

Only by eliminating the eight flaws and avoiding the four perils can one begin to be taught."

The Black Curtain was the name of the woods.
